entries: The character must decipher the ramblings of their fool and discover what must be done to ascend beyond mortality and be reborn into a powerful supernatural entity.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the otherworldly nature of the desired ascension. Does the character wish to become a lord of the heavens, the hells, the Fey lands, or the deathly realms? Did they seek this type of ascension before encountering their fool or was it instigated by the spirit? Why does the character pursue such a transformational rebirth?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The character is present during or even accidentally causes the beheading of a fool, whose bodiless spirit haunts them. They soon realize there is truth and prescience woven through the specter's often incoherent ramblings, and a single strange rhyme of fools, monarchs, rebirth, and ascension points to a particular gloomy time and place where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Reveler|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Deliverance
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Deliverance seeks an inherited family heirloom of great importance and power that was broken apart and lost during a previous trip they took aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}. They follow a soul-powered compass that they hope will lead to the artifact's pieces and the truth behind its fateful purpose once made whole.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must find all three of the pieces of the fractured artifact and restore it to discover its origin, true power, and how to harness it for themselves.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine what type of item the family heirloom is and why it's special to the character. Who was the family member they inherited it from, and what was their relationship like? Which Druskenvald province was it retrieved from and how did they first find it?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: After the character retrieved the inherited heirloom from Druskenvald, their return trip aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express} was interrupted by a hooded, lantern-bearing figure that stole the artifact, split it into three pieces, and ejected the character from the train into the Shroud. The character miraculously survived and emerged somewhere in the mortal realms with a strange, broken compass in their possession. Time has since passed, but one night, the compass glows with ghastly energy, its needle pointing toward wherever the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Ghostlight Passenger|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Duality
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Duality has a soul that they severed in two in the hopes of expunging their mortal sins, vices, and flaws. A near-exact duplicate born of sin itself commits increasingly wicked acts under the guise of the character, working toward a nefarious goal that only the character can stop as they communicate with their doppelganger through mirrors and other reflections.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must track down their sinful duplicate, uncover the nature of the copy's wicked plot, and find a way to mend their severed soul to bring an end to their counterpart's vile and catastrophic machinations.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine how the duplicate both mirrors and differs from the character in appearance and behavior. What sin most defines the doppelganger, what is their greatest moral flaw, and why did the character so drastically act to purge them? What did the soul severing process require? How does the character now behave differently?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The character receives news of or discovers heinous acts allegedly committed by them. Following the trail of sin, they eventually see a reflection of themselves, but something is off, and the eyes are full of menace. The doppelganger speaks to the character with taunts and threats, mentioning catching a train and leaving clues that point toward where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Reflected Wanderer|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Evolution
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Evolution believes themself to be the next stage of evolution for mortal species, having undergone a transformational experiment to become closer to "perfection." However, they are still not satisfied and follow the notes of a renowned researcher to transcend the limitations of natural biology.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must unlock the potential of the experiments conducted on them, discover how to blend science and magic to achieve the final stage of evolution, and become the ultimate lifeform.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the experiments conducted on the character. Did they experiment on themselves, or did an external figure do it? What sort of physical limitations were they seeking to transcend? Who is the researcher they idolize, and what were they seeking?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The character has hit a dead end in unlocking the next stage of their personal evolution and has sought out the researcher who inspired their pursuit. When they finally discover the laboratory or place of study, it is mostly destroyed. Piecing together a fragmented collection of notes that still remain, the character determines that the researcher sought out the location where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Experiment|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Immortality
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Immortality seeks a remedy for an incurable, magical disease through the lost arts of blood, vital energy, and the soul-stuff of anima. Aided by an enigmatic, alchemical being in a flask, they seek the truth, and with each new discovery of strange alchemy, they come closer to perfecting a grand elixir and unlocking the secrets of immortality, eternal youth, and invulnerability.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must master the alchemical arts of life essence, discover the recipe for a grand remedy of immense power, concoct a cure for their magical malady, and unlock the secrets of immortality.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the incurable disease. What are its symptoms and how was it caused? Does the character have the affliction themselves or does one of their loved ones? Does the researched remedy take the form of a potion, a stone, or something else entirely? What is the appearance and personality of the oddity in the flask?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The effects of the magical disease that the character contends with continue to worsen, and all attempts at remedying it have failed. Their study of alchemical practices leads them to the ruins of an ancient city said to have once conquered death. There, they uncover a strange entity in a flask that claims to know the truth of immortality. The being is not openly forthcoming with many details but speaks of the time and place where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Crimson Aspirant|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Kindred
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Kindred searches for a family member who went missing in Druskenvald after experiencing a series of worsening nightmares. Following clues in a dream journal left behind by their loved one, the character knows that a terrible, crooked fate awaits their kin and only they can bring salvation.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must track down their loved one's location, uncover the malign forces they've been mixed up with, and rescue them before they suffer a terrible fate.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine which family member the character seeks. Are they from one of the thirteen primary provinces of Druskenvald or from the mortal realms? How was the relationship between them, and how did the worsening nightmares affect their bond?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The character's family member had confided in them about terrifying nightmares of a man with a crooked grin that continued to get worse, causing loss of sleep and fraying sanity. One night, the character arrives at their loved one's home and finds them gone. There are clear signs of a struggle. Left behind is a dream journal, which paints a terrifying picture of the nightmares and clearly depicts where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Druskenvald Dweller|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Liberation
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Liberation has made a deal with a powerful entity that now owns their soul, and what awaits them in death is not pretty. Their only hope to escape their fate seems to be in the hands of their shadow, which seemingly has a mind of its own but can be persuaded to help through games of chance.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must seek help in outwitting the entity they made a deal with, find a way to break the supernatural chains that bind them, and reclaim the mastery of their own fate once more.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the entity that has claimed the character's soul. Are they fiendish, fey, deathly, or something else? What is their personality, and what relationship do they have with the character? How does their influence affect the appearance and behavior of the character's shadow? What deal was made, and what did the character receive in exchange for their soul?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The character's luck is running out as the deal they've made with the entity has gone bad, and they've been reminded of the terrible fate that awaits them. Seeking a way to get out of the bargain, they return to the place where the deal was made, and the character's shadow suddenly springs to life and wordlessly challenges them to a game of chance. The character is victorious, and the shadow guides them to where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Crossroads Gambler|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Malediction
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Malediction is truly cursed, as is their entire family line. The curse that hangs over their bloodline spells doom and a fate worse than death for all whom they hold dear. Only through delving into ancient secrets and forbidden, profane knowledge of strange origin can they hope to break the curse that afflicts them.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must seek the forgotten secrets that whisper of their curse, obtain the occult knowledge of how to break it, and take the necessary steps to free themselves from the malediction that afflicts them and their line.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the curse that afflicts the character. Were they cursed themselves, or was it inherited from an ancestor? What sort of otherworldly force originated the curse, whether it be fiendish, cosmic, fey, or other eldritch forces? To which fate is the character and their line doomed by this curse?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: The looming threat of the curse has driven the character to constant research, seeking any knowledge that might lead toward a solution. After numerous dead ends, the character discovers a secret society with access to an esoteric library. After gaining access, the character steals a mysterious page before escaping and follows it to wherever the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Scholar of the Forbidden|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Pilgrimage
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Pilgrimage holds a strong, mystical connection to the spirits of the dead and can feel their emotions innately. Guided by augury, which grants divination, the character is drawn to places of great spiritual unrest, where they erect sacred monuments to bring a final peace to the tormented dead.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must make a pilgrimage to locations of great spiritual significance, erect cleansing monuments at each one, and complete the sacred formation to soothe and put to rest the countless tortured spirits of the realm.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the character's duty to the spirits. Is it motivated by religious, primal, occult, or other ends? What is the character's relationship with the dead, and how has the emotional connection shaped them? How does the character practice augury, whether it be through stone, bone, antler, or other methods? What do their sacred monuments look like?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: While performing sacred rites to honor the dead, the character is overwhelmed by the tortured agony of countless souls somewhere beyond the mortal realms. Believing that such a profane affront to the departed cannot stand, they perform their spiritual augury, which points to the time and place where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Rest Warden|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Rapture
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Rapture zealously serves a deity or other greater power as their chosen prophet. They hear the voice of their god, who wishes to gain a foothold in a godless realm by enacting a great feat of divine intervention in the hopes of leaving their mark upon the land and its people, who must be converted into the fold.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must spread the word of their deity throughout the land, convert a following of devotees, break the barriers to the divine's influence, and bring about an act of their godly intervention.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the character's deity. What is their godly domain, and what are their tenets? What do they demand of their followers, and how does the character showcase their commitment to them? What divine intervention do they seek to enact in Druskenvald and why?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: While the character is spreading the word of their god, they have a near-death experience but are brought back from the brink by their deity. The character hears their god speak directly to them, telling them of the holy quest they must undertake to gather the faithful in the land of death and establish a foothold for their divine will. The deity guides the character to where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Cultist|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Rejuvenation
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Rejuvenation upholds the sanctity of the natural world and the cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Through communion with the green world and following the wisdom of the trees, they seek to purge the land of rot and corruption to usher in a new age of flourishing.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must find the areas of the natural world that are suffering, discover the extent of the corruption that afflicts the land, learn how to bring about the necessary healing, and fully purge the corruption to initiate a great regrowth.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine the nature of the character's guardianship of the wilds. How did they first favor the natural world over civilization? What relationship do they have with the trees and the green places? Do they serve the cycle individually or as part of a group? Which season do they favor and uphold as their ultimate charge?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: While walking through the woods during their favored season, the character stumbles upon an ancient hollow, and the trees of the deepest wood communicate with them. They learn of a landscape corrupted, rotten, and crooked in a realm devoid of the cycle of the seasons, pleading for the salvation of these wilds. After the character accepts the mantle of warden, they hear the wisdom of the trees and are guided to where the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Wicker Weaver|CrookedMoon24}

reward.name: Thread of Slaughter
entries: A character bound by the Thread of Slaughter is a consummate hunter and holds a reverence for the art of killing. Called forward by the appearances of a great spiritual beast, they leave the hunting grounds of the mortal realms to seek the deadliest prey, seeking to become the ultimate predator.

entries.name: Goal
entries: The character must hunt and kill the foulest creatures of the eternal night, discover what it means to be an apex predator, and undergo the transformation to become the most feared beast that stalks the dark wood.

entries.name: Personalization
entries: Determine which great beast the character embodies and follows. Are they a predator of land, sky, or water, and how does its spiritual form appear to the character? What about this beast does the character find kinship with, and which of its traits do they strive for? What set the character on their path of bloodshed?

entries.name: Call to Adventure
entries: Following the success of the greatest hunt the character had experienced, they are still left unsatisfied by the kill. In that moment, the spectral form of the spiritual beast they have kinship with appears before them, and with a look, the character understands that they must seek deadlier hunting grounds. The character instinctively knows where and when the adventure begins.

entries.name: Associated Background
entries: {@background Night Stalker|CrookedMoon24}

table.name: Chaotic Curses
rows: The Fool (Upright). You become a clown and are foolish and silly.
The Fool (Reverse). You cannot stop laughing. You have the most extreme case of gallows humor; the more macabre something is, the funnier it becomes to you.
The Magician (Upright). You consider being headless the ideal state of being. You believe you can remove your head and endeavor to remove the heads of your allies.
The Magician (Reverse). Everyone around you appears to have had their eyes replaced by small round black buttons.
The High Priestess (Upright). You cannot stop coughing up blood.
The High Priestess (Reverse). Every time you drink something, you feel as if you are drowning.
The Empress (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of wrath.
The Empress (Reverse). Everything you touch begins to rot.
The Emperor (Upright). You see false visions of a past where you did horrible things. They are so realistic and convincing that you begin to doubt your own reality.
The Emperor (Reverse). You believe your soul belongs to a dark entity that can come to claim it at any moment.
The Hierophant (Upright). You have an insatiable hunger for bones.
The Hierophant (Reverse). You are so incredibly sleepy, it's hard to keep your eyes open. Every time you start to fall asleep, you jolt awake as if from a nightmare.
The Lovers (Upright). You lose all sense of direction. No matter what you do or what anyone says, you believe you are lost and will never find your way.
The Lovers (Reverse). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of pride.
The Chariot (Upright). You have an overwhelming fear of death and are afraid that everything can kill you, even the most mundane things.
The Chariot (Reverse). Your third eye opens—literally. It gives you no additional powers, but you now have a third eye in the middle of your forehead.
Strength (Upright). You believe yourself to be the ferryman of the dead, and all souls must be judged by you.
Strength (Reverse). When you move, you emit the sound of leprosy bells, even though you have neither bells nor leprosy.
The Hermit (Upright). You feel your personality split in two. A dark and evil version of yourself wrestles for control over your mind.
The Hermit (Reverse). You turn into a talking black cat. You know who you are, but the people around you have no reason to believe you.
Wheel of Fortune (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of greed.
Wheel of Fortune (Reverse). You believe you are immortal—you are not.
Justice (Upright). A pox appears all over your body.
Justice (Reverse). You are incredibly unlucky. You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on every roll.
The Hanged Man (Upright). Every time you must make a d20 roll, you instead roll with a d12.
The Hanged Man (Reverse). A creepy mask affixes to your face, and nothing you do can remove it.
Death (Upright). Your face disappears and is replaced by smooth, featureless skin.
Death (Reverse). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of gluttony.
Temperance (Upright). Your eyes disappear from your face and appear in the palms of your hands.
Temperance (Reverse). You can only move by crawling around on all fours, and the crawling is always creepy and unsettling.
The Devil (Upright). Your head is replaced by the head of a black goat.
The Devil (Reverse). Every time you eat something, you find 1d8 human teeth inside.
The Tower (Upright). You fall madly in love with the next person you see.
The Tower (Reverse). You become incredibly gullible, and you believe everything you are told.
The Star (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of lust.
The Star (Reverse). You believe you are invisible—you are not.
The Moon (Upright). You feel like you are covered in cobwebs, yet nothing you do can stop the feeling. If you don't shake them off soon, you believe you will be cocooned.
The Moon (Reverse). You believe you are turning into a were-creature—you are not.
The Sun (Upright). Your skin shrivels and hardens, taking on a bark-like texture and appearance.
The Sun (Reverse). You believe your body has begun to rot and decay—it hasn't.
Judgement (Upright). You have an insatiable thirst for blood.
Judgement (Reverse). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of sloth.
The World (Upright). You have a mounting desire to consume brains.
The World (Reverse). You grow a pair of fangs, making it incredibly difficult to talk.

Ace of Wands (Upright). Everyone around you sounds like they are speaking unintelligible gibberish, and nothing allows you to comprehend what they are saying—not even magic that would normally allow you to understand any language.
Ace of Wands (Reverse). You believe you can talk to the dead—you cannot.
Two of Wands (Upright). You hear the voice of a dead clown antagonizing you in your mind.
Two of Wands (Reverse). You believe you are the reincarnated soul of a witch unjustly burned at the stake.
Three of Wands (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of envy.
Three of Wands (Reverse). You hallucinate that you and all your allies have turned into the undead.
Four of Wands (Upright). You believe your shadow is out to get you.
Four of Wands (Reverse). You are unable to tell a lie.
Five of Wands (Upright). A mushroom cap appears on your head like a hat, but you cannot remove it.
Five of Wands (Reverse). You are unable to tell the truth.
Six of Wands (Upright). Blood begins to pour from your eyes.
Six of Wands (Reverse). Your head is replaced by a jack-o'-lantern.
Seven of Wands (Upright). You feel like pollen clouds the air, and you cannot stop sneezing.
Seven of Wands (Reverse). You believe your body is being held together by straw, and you need to keep stuffing your clothing with it or you will collapse.
Eight of Wands (Upright). A swarm of carrion birds continually circles overhead. You believe this to be an omen of your impending death.
Eight of Wands (Reverse). You believe you are a walking, talking skeleton—you are not.
Nine of Wands (Upright). You smell the intense scent of pumpkin spice. Nothing you do makes the aroma dissipate, and it's beginning to give you a horrible headache.
Nine of Wands (Reverse). You cannot shake the feeling that you are being followed.
Ten of Wands (Upright). You see someone watching you out of the corner of your eye. When you turn to check, there is no one there.
Ten of Wands (Reverse). When you move, you hear footsteps following behind you. When you stop moving, the sound stops as well. No one else can hear this.
Page of Wands (Upright). Your legs turn into bird legs. If you happen to have bird legs, your legs turn into human legs.
Page of Wands (Reverse). All food appears and smells rotten. Rotten food instead looks delicious.
Knight of Wands (Upright). You believe the sky is filled with thousands of vicious and aggressive swarms of birds.
Knight of Wands (Reverse). You become incredibly clumsy, and you trip and fall over everything—even your own feet.
Queen of Wands (Upright). You are horribly afraid of the dark.
Queen of Wands (Reverse). You believe you are a vampire—you are not.
King of Wands (Upright). Your bones become incredibly fragile, and you can't stop breaking them.
King of Wands (Reverse). There is a worm in your brain trying to convince you to do unspeakable things.
Ace of Cups (Upright). Everyone around you appears to have an eerie, unnatural smile on their face. No matter what their true emotions, the smile never fades.
Ace of Cups (Reverse). You hear children laughing all around you. When you turn to find the source, the laughter stops, but it returns when you look away again.
Two of Cups (Upright). You believe you are dead and that no one can see or hear you, even if they say otherwise.
Two of Cups (Reverse). You believe you are being followed by a large black dog that is an omen of your impending doom.
Three of Cups (Upright). You believe you can tell the future, and you make wild claims for what is to come.
Three of Cups (Reverse). Your teeth become rotten and fall out, just to painfully regrow minutes later and then fall out again. The cycle keeps repeating itself.
Four of Cups (Upright). There is honey all over your legs, and nothing you do can remove it. Everything sticks to you.
Four of Cups (Reverse). You believe that scarabs are eating your body from the inside out.
Five of Cups (Upright). You believe that everyone around you is dead and that you are speaking to ghosts that don't realize they have died.
Five of Cups (Reverse). You become incredibly superstitious, going so far as to make up your own superstitions to justify your fear.
Six of Cups (Upright). You believe that everyone around you is a sinner and needs to be redeemed.
Six of Cups (Reverse). You randomly cough up feathers. This seems normal to you.
Seven of Cups (Upright). You believe you can communicate great distances via howl.
Seven of Cups (Reverse). You sprout a pair of membranous bat wings from your back. If you previously had wings, they are replaced by these wings. You cannot fly, though you believe you can.
Eight of Cups (Upright). You believe you can communicate via echolocation—you cannot.
Eight of Cups (Reverse). Hundreds of eyes—ever blinking, ever watching—sprout up all over your body.
Nine of Cups (Upright). You feel as if you are suffocating, almost as if you are being buried alive.
Nine of Cups (Reverse). Randomly, when you attempt to speak, grave dirt pours out of your mouth.
Ten of Cups (Upright). Worms wriggle beneath your skin, exiting your body from your mouth, eyes, and ears.

Ten of Cups (Reverse). The disembodied hand of a long-dead wizard has pledged itself to your service. This hand functions as a physical Mage Hand and can perform simple tasks for you. This seems normal to you, but everyone else that witnesses this hand is horrified by it.
Page of Cups (Upright). Every time you're injured, bugs, insects, spiders, and maggots spill out of your wounds instead of blood.
Page of Cups (Reverse). You turn into a creepy doll.
Knight of Cups (Upright). You believe spiders are crawling all over your body, and nothing you do removes them all.
Knight of Cups (Reverse). You have a horribly uncomfortable hangnail, and when you pull on it, your flesh unzips from your body.
Queen of Cups (Upright). You believe you can turn people to stone by makingeye contact with them—you cannot.
Queen of Cups (Reverse). You are overwhelmed by the smell of burning hair and flesh.
King of Cups (Upright). The first person you see appears to you as a biblically accurate angel. Every time you close your eyes, they get closer to you. Don't blink.

King of Cups (Reverse). You believe a monster lurks behind every door, and you must check twice to be safe. Roll a d20. On a 1, you see 1d100 harmless skeletons lurking behind the door. You are the only one who can see these skeletons.
Ace of Swords (Upright). Your body is covered in frost, and you freeze in place. You are unable to move.
Ace of Swords (Reverse). Your skin feels like it is melting off, and nothing you do provides relief.
Two of Swords (Upright). You believe you can send long-distance messages via the mycelium network—you cannot.
Two of Swords (Reverse). You randomly see the visions of another's demise. The only way to get the visions to stop is to tell the person what you've seen in excruciating detail.
Three of Swords (Upright). You become deathly afraid of fire—even the tiniest of flames.
Three of Swords (Reverse). Hair begins to grow all over your body. If you are already covered with hair, it all falls out.
Four of Swords (Upright). Your feet and hands swap places.
Four of Swords (Reverse). Tiny fruit flies buzz all around you. Nothing you do can rid yourself of them.
Five of Swords (Upright). You are unable to control your facial expressions. No matter how capable you are of lying, your facial expressions are over exaggerated and give away your true feelings.
Five of Swords (Reverse). It's both too hot and too cold at the same time. When you put on more layers, you feel like you're burning up. When you remove your layers, you feel like you are freezing.
Six of Swords (Upright). You believe everyone around you is whispering about you, but every time you focus on what they are saying, the whispering stops.
Six of Swords (Reverse). You are overwhelmed with an intense paranoia of the coming winter, and you feel the need to hoard random objects like a magpie—rocks, sticks, clumps of weeds, or trinkets.

Seven of Swords (Upright). You believe you are turning into a scarecrow; you are convinced that you must stand like a scarecrow with your arms out or you and your allies will be horribly devoured by swarms of birds.
Seven of Swords (Reverse). You believe the next person to speakto you is secretly planning to kill you—they are not
Eight of Swords (Upright). You feel like you have not eaten for an entire winter season. Your hunger cannot be sated, and you'd eat practically anything.
Eight of Swords (Reverse). You feel like you have eaten too much and are on the verge of being sick. Nothing provides relief.
Nine of Swords (Upright). You have an unshakeable head cold. Your nose is runny, your throat is sore, and your muscles ache. It's inconvenient and even magic can't cure it.
Nine of Swords (Reverse). You can only speak in song, rhyme, poetry, prose, rap, or other artistic outlets.
Ten of Swords (Upright). You feel the need to dance, and you cannot stop.
Ten of Swords (Reverse). You feel the need to express yourself through interpretive dance and must do so whenever you speak.
Page of Swords (Upright). Flowers begin to sprout up all around your body. You are nearly swallowed up by them and are unable to move.
Page of Swords (Reverse). You can no longer see in color. Everything is in shades of black and white.
Knight of Swords (Upright). You randomly slip bird noises into your speech. You do not realize you are doing this.
Knight of Swords (Reverse). You begin to grow feathers all over your body. If you are already covered in feathers, they all fall out.
Queen of Swords (Upright). A raven circles overhead, mocking you by mimicking your allies' voices.
Queen of Swords (Reverse). You hear the wailing death throes of those that have died at your hand. Not even the Silence spell can quiet their voices.
King of Swords (Upright). You begin to age rapidly. This does not kill you, but you suffer all other effects of an aging body.
King of Swords (Reverse). The first person you see appears to you as a clown, and you are deathly afraid of clowns.
Ace of Coins (Upright). Your skin is incredibly itchy, and nothing you do provides relief. You are beginning to believe that the only solution is to remove your skin piece by piece.
Ace of Coins (Reverse). You feel the need to juggle whatever you are holding. You believe that if you stop juggling, you will die.
Two of Coins (Upright). You turn into a marionette, and you believe you are being controlled by a puppet master that manipulates your movement using your puppet strings.
Two of Coins (Reverse). You can only speak in a whisper.
Three of Coins (Upright). All your words come out as screams no matter how hard you try to control your volume.
Three of Coins (Reverse). You are overcome by theatrics. Everything you do is overdramatic. You randomly burst into song or monologue, or you wax philosophical.
Four of Coins (Upright). Your memory is hazy; you keep forgetting things. When you forget something important, you replace it with false details, and it is clear you're doing so.
Four of Coins (Reverse). You believe everyone you meet is flirting with you—they are not.
Five of Coins (Upright). When you speak, bees pour out of your mouth and swarm those around you.
Five of Coins (Reverse). Your jaw transforms into mandibles.
Six of Coins (Upright). You believe you have preternatural strength, but you have actually become incredibly weak.
Six of Coins (Reverse). You are a mime, unable to speak, and can only communicate through pantomime.
Seven of Coins (Upright). Your body becomes covered in moss and lichen.
Seven of Coins (Reverse). You are filled with overwhelming sorrow and cannot shake it.
Eight of Coins (Upright). You feel incredibly lonely no matter how many people you are around.
Eight of Coins (Reverse). You believe you are being stalked by a witch's familiar.

Nine of Coins (Upright). You believe you have been called upon by an ancient evil to enact their dark machinations. You are their herald of doom, and you must convert those around you to this darkness.
Nine of Coins (Reverse). You believe the trees are trying to tell you the ancient secrets of the land, but the only way to truly hear their words is to bury yourself within the roots of a tree.
Ten of Coins (Upright). You believe you are a witch in need of a familiar, and the first creature you see will do.
Ten of Coins (Reverse). You think you are a bridge troll, and anyone that tries to move past you must pay a toll.
Page of Coins (Upright). You believe you are betrothed to a creature of the deep, and you must prepare to leave the surface world behind.
Page of Coins (Reverse). Whenever you open your mouth, a dense, dark fog billows out. It doesn't inhibit your speech, but it's very spooky.
Knight of Coins (Upright). You are a fool, and everyone around you perceives you as such.
Knight of Coins (Reverse). You are like a moth to the flame; you are incredibly drawn to any source of light.
Queen of Coins (Upright). Every creature you see appears to have humanoid teeth.
Queen of Coins (Reverse). The bones in your arms disappear.
King of Coins (Upright). You are haunted by the ghost of a very depressing clown.
King of Coins (Reverse). Your hair turns into wriggling venomous snakes that are friendly to you but aggressive to everyone else.

feat.name: Altered
entries: You have been changed through magic, science, or a volatile blend of the two. You have a blatant physical augmentation of your choice from the options below. The augmentation is obvious—such as with stitches, grafts of other creature's body parts, or implants—unless disguised.

entries.name: Aquatic Adaptation
entries: You have gills or mucus membranes that allow you to breathe water, and you have webbed extremities that grant you a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have scales, plates, or thick hide that grants you an AC of 13 + your Dexterity or Constitution modifier (choose the ability when you select this feat).

entries.name: Natural Weapons
entries: You have claws, fangs, horns, or some other natural weapon that you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes} that deal {@damage 1d8} damage on a hit. The damage is Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing as appropriate to the form.

entries.name: Night Vision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, its range increases by 30 feet.

feat.name: Charm Twister
entries: You know hedge remedies and hexes passed down through Old Ways teachings, and you can impart them into small wicker charms you weave. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Old Blessing
entries: You can cast the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell once using this benefit, targeting only creatures carrying a wicker charm you've woven, and you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have. Your spellcasting ability for casting the spell in this way is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose the ability when you select this feat).

entries.name: Twisted Hex
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can weave spite into a wicker charm you touch. Choose an ability. When another creature is carrying the charm, or while this charm is within an area that the creature considers home, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and attack rolls using the chosen ability. When the creature fails one of these rolls, it can make a Charisma saving throw, destroying the charm on a success (DC = 8 plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} and the ability modifier you chose for Old Blessing). You can only have one Twisted Hex charm at a time. If you make a new one, the previous one loses its magic.

feat.name: Crimson Ritualist
entries: Your study of blood magic and life force has borne fruit, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Blood Lash
entries: You learn the {@spell Blood Bolt|CrookedMoon24} cantrip. Your spellcasting ability for it is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose the ability when you select this feat).

entries.name: Bottled Life
entries: When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can perform a 1-minute ritual to transfer some of your life essence into a vessel for later use. Expend a number of {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} up to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and bleed into a vial of water or other liquid. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, a creature can drink the vial to roll the {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} you expended. The creature regains a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the total rolled plus its Constitution modifier. The vial remains potent until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Cult Initiate
entries: Your cult instructs you in eldritch rites, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Two Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the Warlock spell list. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this feat's spells (choose the ability when you select this feat).

entries.name: Level 1 Spell
entries: Choose a level 1 spell from the Warlock spell list. You always have that spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

entries.name: Spell Change
entries: Whenever you gain a new level, you can replace one of the spells you chose for this feat with a different spell of the same level from the Warlock spell list.

feat.name: Dread Speech
entries: You have articulated a few words of forbidden truth that resonate with—and fray—the fabric of creation, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Eldritch Word
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can speak a magical word aloud to force a creature within 60 feet of yourself to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC = 8 plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} and Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma modifier; choose the ability when you select this feat). On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the start of your next turn. You can use this benefit safely once, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can use it again before resting, but you take {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage, which can't be reduced or prevented in any way.

entries.name: Shred Fate
entries: Your dread secrets can unravel the destiny of your foes. You always have the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell prepared, and your spellcasting ability for it is the ability you chose for Eldritch Word. You can cast it once without Material components or a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

feat.name: Fate Gambler
entries: Coming out ahead, whether in games of chance or in life-or-death contention, fills you with resolve and vigor. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Bet Big
entries: If you don't already have it, you gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} whenever you succeed on an ability check made against another creature, when you reduce a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or when a creature fails a saving throw you forced it to make. If, in any of these cases, the creature has a CR of 0 or lacks a CR (such as another player character), you don't gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Win Big
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can expend your {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} to gain a number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your level.

feat.name: Ghostlight Medium
entries: You formed a mystical connection to the Ghostlight Express that affords you insight into the nature of spirits, granting the following benefits.

entries.name: Ghostly Touch
entries: When you damage a creature with the Incorporeal Movement trait, you can ignore the creature's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, if any.

entries.name: Spirit Sense
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can sense any Undead within 60 feet of you, or any creatures in the Ethereal Plane that overlaps that area. You learn the distance and direction to any creatures you detect (or an Ethereal creature's equivalent position on your plane). Once you detect a creature with this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Grave Keeper
entries: Studying funeral rites and tending the dead's rest has made you a conduit between the worlds of the living and the dead. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Divine Channel
entries: You gain one use of the Channel Divinity feature from the Cleric class, and you can create the Turn Undead effect with it. If you already have Channel Divinity, you add this use to the feature from one class of your choice. Your save DC for this benefit is 8 plus your Wisdom modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

entries.name: Last Rites
entries: You can enact a 10-minute ritual to prepare the corpse of a Medium or smaller creature, expending at least 10 GP worth of incense, oils, linen wraps, or similar trappings. The prepared corpse can't become Undead.

feat.name: Hunter of Hunters
entries: You are adept at hunting monstrous prey, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Dead Aim
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can scrutinize a creature to spot its vulnerable points. The next time you deal damage to the creature before the start of your next turn, you ignore the creature's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, if any.

entries.name: Studied Quarry
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on ability checks made to recall information about a creature.

feat.name: Memory Starved
entries: Your mind ravenously gathers details and desperately clings to its memories and faculties, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Desperate Detail
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Iron Mind
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws made to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition and to avoid having your memories read or altered.

feat.name: Reveling Fool
entries: You joined a troupe of madcap revelers and learned to take on the guise of a fool, channeling otherworldly laughter and joviality. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Fool's Mask
entries: By donning a jovial mask and a fool's, jester's, or clown's costume, you take on a new identity that hides your own. In the guise of the fool, you can get away with minor transgressions against people in positions of authority or station.

entries.name: Jester's Repartee
entries: You always have the {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB|Hideous Laughter} spell prepared, and your spellcasting ability for it is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose the ability when you select this feat). You can cast it once without Material components or a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

feat.name: Unreflected
entries: Your image is separated from you, making you unable to cast a reflection or a shadow, but you're able to easily slip notice. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Inscrutable
entries: Creatures have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) checks made against you.

entries.name: Unremarkable
entries: The loss of some part of yourself leaves you able to fade into the background. While you are within a group of at least two other creatures of your type and that there are no more than one size larger or smaller than you, you can take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action from creatures outside that group by making a Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check instead of Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}), with no need for being behind cover or {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB}. If you are ever more than 5 feet from at least two other such creatures while hiding this way, you are revealed.

feat.name: Death Defier
entries: When the hand of death reaches for your soul, you have found a way to reject its call. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Cling to Life
entries: You add your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1) to {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB|Death Saving Throws}.

entries.name: Enduring Vitality
entries: If an effect would kill you outright without {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB|Death Saving Throws} or would reduce you directly to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} without dealing damage, you are instead reduced to a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your level. You can't use this benefit again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Swift Witchcraft
entries: You have honed your skills in the rituals of witchcraft and can quickly weave your magic in times of need. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Swift Invocation
entries: You can use an action to cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 minute. Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

trait.name: Aversion to Faith
entries: The alpengrendel has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls while in a consecrated area or on attack rolls against a creature holding or wearing a {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The alpengrendel regains 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of each of its turns. If the alpengrendel takes Acid or Lightning damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn. The alpengrendel dies only if it starts its turn with 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The alpengrendel makes one Claws attack and one Tusks attack.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) Slashing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Cold damage.

action.name: Tusks
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) Piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Cold damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Frost Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 15}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 21 ({@damage 6d6}) Cold damage. Until the start of the alpengrendel's next turn, the target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved, and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

monster.name: Bat Hound
languages: understands Common plus one other language but can't speak

trait.name: Barred by Water
entries: The bat hound can't willingly move into running water or to a space up to 20 feet above running water. If it starts its turn in running water, it takes 10 Acid damage and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Glide
entries: If it doesn't have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition and isn't wearing heavy armor, the bat hound can extend its membranous wings to move up to 5 feet horizontally for every 1 foot it descends in the air.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The bat hound can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) Piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) Necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, the bat hound regains a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the Necrotic damage taken, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 13}).

bonus.name: Outmaneuver
entries: The bat hound takes the {@action Dash|XPHB} and {@action Disengage|XPHB} actions, and until the end of the turn, needn't spend extra movement to move a creature it is grappling.

reaction.name: Safe Descent
entries: {@actTrigger} The bat hound takes damage from a fall and isn't wearing heavy armor. {@actResponse} The bat hound extends its wings and reduces the fall's damage to 0.

trait.name: Spirits Susceptibility
entries: The elemental takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) Force damage for every bottle of alcohol splashed onto it, and its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two Hexed Slam attacks.

action.name: Hexed Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 10 ft. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be cursed until the start of the elemental's next turn. While cursed, the creature subtracts {@dice 1d4} from its attack rolls and saving throws.

action.name: Swamp Grasp {@recharge 5}
entries: Swamp water and plants roil around the elemental. {@actSave str} {@dc 16}, each creature on the ground in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the elemental. {@actSaveFail} 11 ({@damage 2d10}) Poison damage, and the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition for 1 minute, until the elemental has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition, or until the elemental dies. The target or a creature within 5 feet of it can take an action to make a {@dc 16} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check, ending the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition on the target on a success.

monster.name: Boneflayer
languages: Sylvan; understands Common but can't speak it

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The boneflayer doesn't provoke an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Thunderous Ward
entries: When the boneflayer hears a drum or gong, or takes Thunder damage, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The boneflayer makes one Beak attack and one Talons attack.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) Slashing damage, and the target has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) Piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 14}) from both talons. While {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

bonus.name: Swoop {@recharge 5}
entries: If the boneflayer has a creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, the boneflayer flies up to half its {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks} and drops that creature.

monster.name: Boogleswarm
languages: understands Common but can only speak if the swarm has gathered at least one Humanoid tooth

trait.name: Mimicry (Only if the Swarm Can Speak)
entries: The swarm can speak in the voice of a creature whose tooth it has implanted (see the Bite action). Listeners must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check to discern the mimicry.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny {@creature weasel|XMM}. The swarm can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

trait.name: Sweet Tooth
entries: If the swarm can see or smell sugar at the start of its turn, it must use all its movement to move closer to the sugar. If it reaches the sugar, the swarm has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition until the start of its next turn as it consumes the sugar, and this trait doesn't function again until the swarm finishes a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes two Bite attacks that must have different targets.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) Piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) Piercing damage if the swarm is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}. If the target is a creature that has teeth, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or lose one of its teeth. The swarm immediately implants the tooth into one of its mouths. A creature that has already lost a tooth to this attack automatically succeeds on the saving throw.

spellcasting.name: Coven Magic
headerEntries: While within 30 feet of at least two hag allies, the hag can cast one of the following spells, requiring no Material components, using the spell's normal casting time, and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability: {@spell Augury|XPHB}, {@spell Find Familiar|XPHB}, {@spell Identify|XPHB}, {@spell Locate Object|XPHB}, {@spell Lucky Charm|CrookedMoon24} (lasts until the hag casts it again, or chooses to end it with no action required), or {@spell Unseen Servant|XPHB}. The hag must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} before using this trait to cast that spell again.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hag casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}):

trait.name: Scoured Filth
entries: The hag is burned by soapy water. Treat a bucket or flask of it splashed on the hag as a vial of Acid. If the hag is fully immersed in soapy water at the start of its turn, it takes 20 Acid damage.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The hag can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hag makes two Bite attacks or uses Spellcasting to cast {@spell Contagion|XPHB}. It can also use Warping Caress.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, reach 5 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) Necrotic damage, and the target has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the start of the hag's next turn.

action.name: Warping Caress
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 17}, one creature within 5 feet. {@actSaveFail} 19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) Necrotic damage, and the target gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. Until the target's {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level is reduced to 0, its body is warped and twisted, and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and saving throws that use Strength or Dexterity. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only. {@actSaveSuccessOrFail} If a Humanoid dies from this action, the hag can spend 2 days of work to shape its corpse into a {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24}, or it can combine it with the corpse of a horse to create a {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24}.

trait.name: Ashen Forbiddance
entries: The corvodaemon can't cross a line of ashes created by burning feathers sprinkled with Holy Water.

trait.name: Demonic Restoration
entries: If the corvodaemon dies outside the Abyss, its body dissolves into ichor, and it gains a new body instantly, reviving with all its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} somewhere in the Abyss.

trait.name: Devour Anima
entries: A creature the corvodaemon reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} is cursed until it regains any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. When the cursed creature fails a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB} at the start of its turn, it dies regardless of how many failures it has.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The corvodaemon can mimic the voice of any creature it has heard, or of a creature known to one of the creatures within range of its telepathy. A hearer can discern the voices are imitations with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The corvodaemon can use Feeding Frenzy if available. It then makes one Beak attack and one Claws attack.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) Piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Psychic damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) Slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Feeding Frenzy {@recharge 5}
entries: The corvodaemon enters a voracious feeding frenzy, driven by its insatiable hunger for souls. Until the start of its next turn, the corvodaemon's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} doubles, and when it damages a creature, it gains {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half the damage taken.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The clergy casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

spellcasting.name: Crimson Blessing (1/Day)
headerEntries: The clergy casts {@spell Bless|XPHB} using the same spellcasting ability as Spellcasting.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The clergy can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Vampire Weakness
entries: The clergy has the following weaknesses:

items.name: Self-Loathing
entries: The clergy has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} if it can see its reflection.

items.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The clergy takes 20 Radiant damage if it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Consume
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) Necrotic damage. The target's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum decreases by an amount equal to the damage taken, and the clergy regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to that amount.

trait.name: Crooked Thorns
entries: At the start of each of its turns, the effigy deals 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Psychic damage to any creature it is grappling or any creature grappling it.

trait.name: Old Bindings
entries: The effigy takes an extra 10 Force damage if it's hit by an attack roll using {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB} or {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} (treat as a {@item Club|XPHB} or {@item Light Hammer|XPHB}).

action.name: Impale
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) Piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 13}) from one of two branch arms. Until the grapple ends, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

spellcasting.name: Confusion (1/Day)
headerEntries: The crooked man casts {@spell Confusion|XPHB}, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}).

trait.name: Aversion to Self-Sacrifice
entries: The crooked man takes 20 Necrotic damage if he can see a creature willingly take damage or gain a condition in place of someone else, or to someone else's benefit.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The crooked man has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The crooked man makes two Crooked Claw attacks, and he can replace one attack with a use of Snap Limb. He can also use {@spell Confusion|XPHB} if available.

action.name: Crooked Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 11}, reach 5 ft. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) Slashing damage plus 21 ({@damage 6d6}) Psychic damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 16}) from one of two claws. Until the grapple ends, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Snap Limb
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 19}, one creature the crooked man is grappling, and that has limbs that can break. {@actSaveFail} 35 ({@damage 10d6}) Force damage, and the bones (or equivalent) in one of the target's limbs (crooked man's choice) breaks, causing an appropriate effect below. A broken limb heals in 40 days, or when the creature regains any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} from magic or Regeneration. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

action.name: Broken Arm
entries: {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls. Can't hold anything or manipulate objects with the limb.

action.name: Broken Leg
entries: {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} halved. If the creature takes the Dash action, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Broken Wing
entries: {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} reduced to 0.

bonus.name: Blinking Teleport
entries: The crooked man has the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition for 1 minute and teleports to an unoccupied space he can see within 60 feet. The condition ends immediately after the crooked man deals any damage.

trait.name: False Crows
entries: The swarm can't enter a space with a drawn or painted image or crafted effigy of a crow. A creature holding such an icon has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws the swarm forces it to make.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny crow. The swarm can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

trait.name: Wing Bind
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, any creature (other than a Fiend) with a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} that starts its turn in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the swarm. {@actSaveFail} The target's {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} is 0 until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Peck
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) Piercing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) Piercing damage if the swarm is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}. If the target is a creature, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls until the start of the swarm's next turn.

action.name: Cacophony {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the swarm. {@actSaveFail} 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Psychic damage, and the target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the start of the swarm's next turn. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

trait.name: Explosive Death
entries: The deepdreck explodes when it dies. {@actSave dex} {@dc 14}, each creature in a 15-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the deepdreck. {@actSaveFail} 13 ({@damage 3d8}) Poison damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

trait.name: Fragrance Aversion
entries: The deepdreck has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and saving throws while within 10 feet of burning incense or a creature wearing Perfume.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The deepdreck can burrow through solid rock at half its {@variantrule Burrow Speed|XPHB} and leaves a 5-foot-diameter tunnel in its wake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deepdreck makes two attacks, using Claw or Putrid Emission in any combination.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Poison damage.

action.name: Putrid Emission
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6}, range 60 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) Poison damage, and the target has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the start of the deepdreck's next turn.

trait.name: Irresistible Payment
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a creature that offers the drakkenhob alcohol or any amount of gold and succeeds on a {@dc 16} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check forces the drakkenhob to accept the offer and immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} to get away from the creature by the safest route possible.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drakkenhob makes two Rend attacks.

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, reach 5 ft. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) Piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) Psychic damage.

action.name: Terrifying Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 15}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Psychic damage, and the target drops whatever it is holding and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition. A {@condition Frightened|XPHB} target takes the Dash action and moves away from the drakkenhob by the safest route on each of its turns unless there's nowhere to move. It repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

bonus.name: Call the Hounds
entries: The drakkenhob lets out a wolf-like howl and magically summons three hunting hounds (use the Wolf stat block) that appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of it. The hounds take their turn immediately after the drakkenhob on the same {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count, and they obey the drakkenhob's mental commands. The hounds vanish when they or the drakkenhob drop to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or when the drakkenhob uses this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} again.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The dream eater doesn't provoke an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Moth Ward
entries: A creature holding a moth's wing automatically succeeds on saving throws against the dream eater's Hypnotic Wings.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The dream eater can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dream eater makes two Talons attacks and can use Devour Dreams.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) Slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 14}) from one of two talons, and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends.

action.name: Devour Dreams
entries: The dream eater unfurls its tongue and devours the dreams from a creature's mind. {@actSave cha} {@dc 16}, a creature the dream eater is grappling, or a creature within 5 feet of it that has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition ({@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} creatures fail automatically). {@actSaveFail} 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Psychic damage, and the creature's Charisma score decreases by {@dice 1d6}. A creature reduced to 0 Charisma by this effect doesn't recover lost Charisma when it finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, and it has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition until its mind is restored with a {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Heal|XPHB}, or {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

bonus.name: Hypnotic Wings
entries: The dream eater's wings shine with dazzling rainbow colors until the start of its next turn, emitting {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the dream eater and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 30 feet. {@actSave wis} {@dc 16}, each creature in the dream eater's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}. {@actSaveFail} Until the start of the dream eater's next turn, the target has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition, and its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0.

trait.name: Coffin Boat
entries: The ferryman rides an open coffin on a swell of swamp water, allowing it to travel with a {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} of 40 feet over any surface, including liquids, ignoring {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. The coffin can hold two other Medium creatures. Two Small creatures or four Tiny creatures count as one Medium creature.

While riding the coffin, the ferryman has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition, and the coffin moves with the ferryman unless the ferryman has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. The coffin has AC 15; HP 25; {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage.
If the coffin is destroyed, the ferryman can magically create a new one using a 10-minute ritual.

trait.name: Payment
entries: The ferryman must peacefully offer a ride in its boat to a creature that takes the {@action Influence|XPHB} action to offer it 3 CP. If that creature is cursed by the ferryman, the curse ends. If the boat is full, the ferryman must return to offer the creature a ride once its current passengers leave the boat. If the creature or its allies damage the ferryman or force it to make a saving throw, this effect ends and the creature can't use that ferryman's Payment trait again.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The ferryman regains 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of each of its turns if it has at least 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ferryman makes two Lantern Pole attacks and uses Hexed Lantern if available.

action.name: Lantern Pole
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 10 ft. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Necrotic damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Hexed Lantern (1/Day)
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, each creature of the ferryman's choice in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} The creature is cursed for 1 minute and must subtract {@dice 1d4} from {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}.

monster.name: Festerhulk
languages: understands Common and Giant but can't speak

trait.name: Fungal Step
entries: The festerhulk ignores {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} caused by plants or fungi.

trait.name: Spore Cloud
entries: At the end of each of the festerhulk's turns, each creature in a 5-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the festerhulk takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Necrotic damage and has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. A Giant or Humanoid killed by this damage rises as a new creature 24 hours later: Festerhulk (if a Giant), {@creature Zombie|XMM} (if a Humanoid).

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The festerhulk takes 10 Radiant damage if it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The festerhulk makes two Fetid Slam attacks and uses Slime Mold if available.

action.name: Fetid Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 11}, reach 10 ft. Hit:20 ({@damage 2d12 + 7}) Bludgeoning damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Slime Mold (1/Day)
entries: The festerhulk disgorges a mass of ravenous slime mold into an unoccupied space within 20 feet. This mass uses the Black Pudding stat block except it is a Plant, and its size is Medium. The mass acts on the festerhulk's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}. It, and any masses it Split into, dries up and dies in 1 hour.

trait.name: Bridle Binding
entries: If a creature puts a bridle on the fleshdobbin (treat as securing {@item Manacles|XPHB}), the fleshdobbin has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition while it wears the bridle, and it can't take the bridle off on its own.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The fleshdobbin can't shape-shift.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fleshdobbin makes one Claw attack and one Wailing Halberd attack.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 10 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) Piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Wailing Halberd
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 15 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) Slashing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Psychic damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 15}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 28 ({@damage 8d6}) Psychic damage. In addition, the target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition and repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: {@actTrigger} A creature the fleshdobbin can see hits it with a melee attack roll while the fleshdobbin is wielding a Melee weapon. {@actResponse} The fleshdobbin adds 3 to its AC against that attack, possibly causing it to miss.

trait.name: Blighted Aura
entries: The ground in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the gloomwood is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} from mushrooms and fungus that grow in the area. A creature that ends its turn in the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Necrotic damage.

trait.name: Carved Past
entries: As an action, a creature can use a Dagger or Woodcarver's Tools to carve the name in Sylvan of the ancient home of the gloomwoods into the gloomwood's trunk. Until the gloomwood finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, it can't use its Fungal Fling or Spore Stomp actions.

trait.name: Fungal Step
entries: The gloomwood ignores {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} caused by plants or fungi.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gloomwood makes two attacks, using Slam or Fungal Fling in any combination.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, reach 10 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Necrotic damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 16}) from one of two branches. Until the grapple ends, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Fungal Fling
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 10}, range 60/180 ft. {@h}23 ({@damage 5d6 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Spore Stomp {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, reach 5 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage. {@hom}Each creature within a 20-foot {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on the target must make the following saving throw. {@actSave con} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} 36 ({@damage 8d8}) Poison damage, and the target has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The gobblegeist doesn't provoke an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Repelled by Stars
entries: The gobblegeist can't willingly move to a space within 10 feet of a seven-pointed star drawn on a surface or woven from wicker.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gobblegeist makes two Beak attacks. It can replace one attack with a Talons attack.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) Piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Necrotic damage. The target's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the Necrotic damage taken, and the gobblegeist regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to that amount.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 15}) from both talons, and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends.

action.name: Eye Beam
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 14}, each creature in a 120-foot-long, 5-foot-wide line. {@actSaveFail} 6 ({@damage 1d12}) Psychic damage, and the target has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the start of the gobblegeist's next turn.

trait.name: Endless Footwork
entries: When the herald's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0, attack rolls made against it have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}, and if its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0 at the start of its turn, it takes 20 Necrotic damage.

trait.name: Perfect Grace
entries: The herald doesn't provoke an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} when it leaves an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The herald makes three Banner Pole attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Lethal Jape.

action.name: Banner Pole
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10} (with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if the target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0), reach 10 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 6}) Slashing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) Thunder damage, and if the target is a Large or smaller creature, the herald can move it to any other unoccupied space within the Banner Pole's reach.

action.name: Lethal Jape
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 15}, a creature the herald can see within 60 feet. {@actSaveFail} 24 ({@damage 7d6}) Psychic damage, and the target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0 until the end of its next turn. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.
