entries: You hurl a twisting bolt of blood at a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage, and you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
The spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d6}), 11th level ({@dice 3d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d6}).

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach levels 5 ({@dice 2d6}), 11 ({@dice 3d6}), and 17 ({@dice 4d6}).

spell.name: Blood Sacrifice

components.m: a drop of your own blood

entries: You sacrifice a portion of your life force to enhance your magical power. When you cast this spell, you take {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage, which can't be reduced or prevented in any way. For the duration, when you cast a spell that deals damage, one target of the spell (your choice) takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the same type as the spell's normal damage type (your choice if there are multiple).

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage you take and the extra damage your spells deal both increase by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Buried Alive
entries: You send your enemies to their graves even if they aren't dead yet. A creature that you can see within range that is standing on the ground must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the ground opens and swallows the target, burying it up to 10 feet deep. While buried, the target has {@quickref Cover||3||total cover}, has the {@condition restrained} and {@condition blinded} conditions, and can't breathe. On a successful save, the target is knocked {@condition prone}, and its speed is reduced to 0 until the end of its next turn. A buried creature can dig out of the grave by using its action to make a DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. On a success, it digs 5 feet closer to the surface. If it succeeds by 5 or more, it reaches the surface. When the creature reaches the surface, it exits the ground {@condition prone}.
The target automatically succeeds on its saving throw if it's standing on any thickness of stone or metal, or at least 2 inches of wood.

spell.name: Call of the Wild

components.m: a bit of animal fur or hide

entries: You unleash a primal howl that calls lesser creatures to your command. Each Beast in a 100-foot sphere centered on you when you cast the spell must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition charmed} by you, it can understand your commands, and it follows them on its next turn to the best of its ability. On your subsequent turns, you can take an action to issue a new command. On a successful save, a target is {@condition charmed} by you until the start of your next turn, but you have no additional ability to command it. The howl is audible within 300 feet.

spell.name: Captivate Undead
entries: You usurp the negative energy animating an Undead creature that you can see within range, attempting to take control of it. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, for the duration, the target is {@condition charmed} by you (ignoring any immunity to that condition), and it is friendly toward you. On a successful save, the target has disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes against you before the start of your next turn. If you or any of your allies damage the target or force it to make a saving throw, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Chorus of the Lost
entries: You summon the eerie song and wailing of lost souls from a point you can see within range. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered there must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} psychic damage, and it is {@condition frightened} for the duration. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage, and it is {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. A {@condition frightened} target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Chain of Conviction
entries: You hurl a spectral, barbed chain at a creature that you can see within range. The target makes a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} force damage, is pulled up to 30 feet toward you, and is bound by the chain. While bound by the chain, the creature is tethered to you and can't move or teleport to a space more than 30 feet away from you, and you have advantage on attack rolls made against the creature.

On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage only. The bound target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success. If you are ever more than 30 feet away from the target, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Consuming Pyre
entries: You cause a creature that you can see within range to burst into consuming, relentless flames. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d8} fire damage and {@damage 2d8} necrotic or radiant damage (choose when you cast the spell), and the radiant flames linger. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only.

While the flames linger, the creature takes the damage again at the start of each of its turns. The target, or another creature within reach of the target, can take an action to allow the target to repeat the saving throw, ending the spell on a success.
A creature killed by the damage from this spell is reduced to ash, along with any nonmagical equipment it is wearing or carrying.

spell.name: Creeping Rot
entries: You send tendrils of black and gray rot toward a target that you can see within range. Three tendrils then leap from that target to as many as three other targets of your choice, each of which must be within 30 feet of the first target. A target can be a creature or a nonmagical plant that isn't a creature, such as a tree or shrub. In either case, each can be targeted by only one of the tendrils.

A target that is a creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 3d8} necrotic damage and is {@condition poisoned} for the duration. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only. A creature {@condition poisoned} in this way takes {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns. A {@condition poisoned} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.
A Plant creature automatically fails the initial save, and a nonmagical plant that isn't a creature simply withers and dies.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, one additional tendril leaps from the first target to another target for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Crimson Harvest
entries: A wave of blood sweeps out from you. Each creature of your choice within 15 feet of you that isn't behind {@quickref Cover||3||total cover} must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d10} necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
If you damage at least one Small or larger creature, one creature of your choice that you can see within the area regains a number of hit points equal to half the damage roll.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Crooked Ward
entries: You touch an immobile surface and mark a symbol that causes agony in twisted creatures. An {@condition invisible}, 30-foot- radius sphere springs out from the point you touch. Each Aberration, Fey, Fiend, Monstrosity, or Undead in the sphere has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls. When an affected creature enters the sphere for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the start of its next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: You can maintain {@status concentration} on this spell for longer if you cast it using a spell slot of 4th level (up to 1 hour) or 5th level (up to 8 hours). If you use a 6th level spell slot or higher, the spell doesn't require {@status concentration}, and the duration becomes 24 hours.

spell.name: Culling Sickle
entries: You create a ghostly sickle that lasts for the duration and can strike out at your foes. The sickle appears hovering in your space and moves with you. When you cast this spell and as a bonus action on each of your turns, you can direct it to fly at and strike a creature within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d8} necrotic damage, and you gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage dealt. After the sickle hits or misses, it returns to hover in your space.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Cursed Cacophany
entries: You focus on a creature that you are familiar with that is on the same plane of existence as you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be cursed for the duration. Once a target fails its saving throw against this spell, you can't target it with a ritual casting of the spell for 24 hours.

While cursed, the target hears haunting, discordant music and has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. The first time the target fails one of those rolls during a turn, it repeats the save against this spell with neither advantage nor disadvantage, ending the spell early on a success.

spell.name: Devil's Due

time.condition: which you take when another creature within range takes damage

entries: You absorb a measure of a creature's suffering and escaping vital essence. Expend and roll one Hit Die. You regain a number of hit points equal to the number rolled plus your spellcasting ability modifier.
If the creature took damage from a critical hit, double the number of hit points you regain.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can expend one additional Hit Die for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Dissolution
entries: You touch a creature or nonmagical object and break the target's substance down into its most fundamental components. Make a melee spell attack. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} force damage, and its AC is reduced by 1 against the next attack roll made against it before the end of your next turn.
The spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach 5th-level ({@dice 2d8}), 11th-level ({@dice 3d8}), and 17th-level ({@dice 4d8}).

spell.name: Eye Burn

time.condition: which you take when a creature you can see within range targets you with an attack

entries: You sting the eyes of a creature attacking you. The target must make a Constitution saving throw (a creature with {@sense blindsight} or immunity to the {@condition blinded} condition succeeds automatically). On a failed save, the target is {@condition blinded} until the end of the turn. On a successful save, it must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the triggering attack roll. The target automatically succeeds on its saves against your subsequent casting of this spell for 24 hours.

spell.name: Field of Reaping

components.m: a dried corn husk or wheat hull

entries: You create a shadowy field that reaps escaping life force in a 30-foot cube originating from a point within range. A creature hostile to you in the field when it appears, or when it enters the field for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, is cursed until the end of its next turn. While cursed, the first time the creature takes damage during a turn, it takes an extra {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage, and a creature of your choice within the field that isn't cursed by it regains a number of hit points equal to the necrotic damage taken.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Ghastly Charge
entries: You call forth the spirits of long-dead knights, which charge forward from you in a 90-foot long, 20-foot wide line, and then vanish. Each creature of your choice in the line must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 5d12} necrotic damage, is {@condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn, and must immediately use its reaction, if available, to move as far as its speed allows away from you, using the safest route. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d12} for each slot level above 6th.

spell.name: Harvest Moonglow
entries: You call upon the light of the harvest moon to illuminate a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point within range. The area is bathed in silvery {@quickref Vision and Light||2||dim light}. {@condition Invisible|XPHB} creatures and objects in the light become visible as translucent, shimmering images. When one of your allies is within the light, it can use a bonus action to absorb some of the light and gain {@dice 2d6} temporary hit points.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the temporary hit points increase by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Harrowing Ballad
entries: You inflict a mind-eroding song on a creature that you can see within range. If the creature has an Intelligence score of 4 or higher, it must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by you for the duration.

While {@condition charmed} in this way, the target is struck with a rapidly repeating ballad that only it can hear; it takes {@damage 1d6} psychic damage at the start of each of its turns, and it has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on Constitution saving throws made to maintain its {@status concentration}. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Hungering Blade
entries: You imbue a weapon you are holding, or your unarmed strikes, with ravenous negative energy. For the duration, when you hit a creature with an attack using the empowered weapon or unarmed strike for the first time on a turn, the target takes necrotic damage equal to your spellcasting ability modifier, and you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

spell.name: Intrusive Despair
entries: You curse a creature within range, filling its mind with creeping paranoia and despair. When the target uses its action to attack or cast a spell, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or waste its action. Once the target succeeds on three saving throws against this spell, the spell ends.

spell.name: Isolation
entries: One creature that you can see within range must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have its mind shrouded in the dread of total isolation. For the duration, all other creatures are {@condition invisible} toward the target, which the target can't see through—even with {@sense blindsight}, {@sense truesight}, or magic such as the See Invisibility spell—and the target can't perceive other creatures with any of its other senses. The target moves around other creatures, or otherwise rationalizes not moving through spaces occupied by them (such as perceiving a door as closed or as a wall if another creature is standing in the way). The target still feels pain but can't identify the source of any injury caused by another creature. The target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.

spell.name: Lucky Charm

components.m: a four-leaf clover and a shard of broken mirror

entries: You touch a Tiny, nonmagical object, infusing it with a portion of your own luck for the duration. While another creature carries the object, that creature has advantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws, and you have disadvantage on them.

spell.name: Martyr

m.text: a Dagger worth at least 1 CP

entries: You touch a dead creature that died within the last minute and transfer your life essence into it. The target returns to life with hit points equal to your current hit point total. You immediately drop to 0 hit points (which nothing can prevent) with two failed death saving throws, and you must immediately make a death save. You can't regain hit points or become stable until after you make this save.

spell.name: Mirrored Agony

time.condition: which you take when a creature you can see within 60 feet of you damages your ally

entries: The triggering creature makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it takes an amount of psychic damage equal to the damage it dealt to your ally. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

spell.name: Mist of Mourning
entries: You summon a thin mist that saps joy and vigor in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point within range. Each creature in the mist when it appears, or when it moves into the mist for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be filled with deep melancholy until the end of its next turn. An affected creature's speed is halved, it has disadvantage on attack rolls, and it subtracts {@dice 1d8} from all its damage rolls.

spell.name: Murder of Crows
entries: You summon and unleash a murder of deadly crows. Each creature of your choice in a 30-foot cone originating from you makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 5d6} force damage and is {@condition blinded}. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only. A {@condition blinded} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. The effect also ends if the creature regains any hit points. The crows disperse and vanish after they strike.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Mysterious Presence
entries: You touch a willing creature and shroud its presence. Until the spell ends, other creatures must subtract {@dice 1d4} from any Wisdom ({@skill Insight} or {@skill Perception}) checks made against the target.

spell.name: Puppet Master
entries: One creature that you can see within range must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by you for the duration.

Magical marionette strings attach to the {@condition charmed} creature's limbs or body, and it must use its action on its turn to make a melee attack against a creature other than itself that you mentally choose, moving to reach the target if necessary. The target can act normally on its turn if you don't choose another creature, or if the creature isn't within the target's reach after it moves. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.
On your later turns, you must take a bonus action to maintain control of the target, or the spell ends.

spell.name: Sacrificial Siphon
entries: You touch another creature and lay a curse that drains the target's vitality and transfers it to you. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the target is cursed for the duration. While cursed, the target must subtract {@dice 1d4} from its attack rolls and ability checks, and when the target takes damage, you can use your reaction to gain 10 temporary hit points. On a successful save, you gain 5 temporary hit points, and the target must subtract {@dice 1d4} from its ability checks until the start of your next turn.

spell.name: Sanctum of the Shepherd

m.text: adamantine or diamond powder worth 200+ GP, which the spell consumes

entries: You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of faint, shimmering light centered on a point within range. You and a number of creatures of your choice up to your spellcasting ability modifier (minimum of 1 other creature) can absorb protective magic from the sphere. When any of the chosen creatures finish a long rest in the area, the sphere vanishes, and those creatures gain a +1 bonus to AC for the remainder of the duration. Chosen creatures who don't finish a long rest in the sphere gain no benefit.

spell.name: Sanctum of the Flock

m.text: powdered silver worth 25+ GP, which the spell consumes

entries: You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of faint, shimmering light centered on a point within range. You and a number of creatures of your choice up to your spellcasting ability modifier (minimum of 1 other creature) can absorb empowering magic from the sphere. When any of the chosen creatures finish a long rest in the area, the sphere vanishes, and those creatures gain {@dice 2d10} temporary hit points, and for the remainder of the duration, they have advantage on Charisma checks that use one of their skill proficiencies. Chosen creatures who don't finish a long rest in the sphere gain no benefit.

spell.name: Sanguine Secrets

m.text: a drop of blood, which the spell consumes

entries: You draw knowledge through the power of blood about a creature you can see within range. You learn the target's species and creature type, its current hit points, and any conditions affecting it. You also learn if it has any of the following, and, if so, what they are: vulnerability, resistance, or immunity to damage or conditions.
Additionally, the next ability check or attack roll you make against the target before the end of your next turn has advantage.

spell.name: Scarlet Dawn
entries: Crimson light shines down in a 20-foot-radius, 60-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within range. Each creature in that area that isn't a Construct or Undead must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 4d10} necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Constructs and Undead in the area regain {@dice 4d10} hit points.
If any of this spell's area overlaps with an area of darkness created by a spell of 3rd level or lower, that other spell is dispelled.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d10} and the level of spell that can be dispelled increases by 1 for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Shadow Drain
entries: For the duration, you siphon away the vitality and sense of self through the shadows of creatures within 15 feet of you that aren't behind {@quickref Cover||3||total cover}.

When you cast this spell, you can designate creatures to be unaffected by it. Whenever any other creature enters the area or starts its turn there, or when the area enters a creature's space, the creature must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d6} necrotic damage and has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only. A creature makes this save only once per turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Summer Winds
entries: You unleash a blast of light and wind in a 15-foot cone. Your allies in the cone regain {@dice 2d6} hit points. Undead within the cone that are hostile to you must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage and healing increase by {@dice 2d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Unraveling Whisper
entries: Choose a creature you can see within range and whisper a frightful phrase that only the target can hear. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} psychic damage and is {@condition frightened} until the start of your next turn. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage only.
While {@condition frightened} in this way, the creature has vulnerability to your choice of bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Veil of the Reaper

components.m: a dried corn husk or wheat straw

entries: You wrap yourself in shadows that veil you between strikes. At the end of any turn in which you hit a creature with an attack roll, you become {@condition invisible} until the start of your next turn.

entries: Below are all 22 Major Arcana cards that can be pulled in the Fated Tarot Reading, along with Adela Druskenvald's interpretation of the cards, who always pulls the cards in the upright position. You'll also find the Fabled Heirloom or boon that each card corresponds to, as well as where it can be found in The Crooked Moon adventure. For all Fabled Heirlooms, see appendix B.

deck.name: Encounters
entries: The {@variantrule Encounter|XPHB} cards in this deck are designed to provide unexpected and engaging scenarios the characters might stumble upon during overland travel in The Crooked Moon. Before using this deck, take a moment to familiarize yourself with the potential encounters-you'll need to fill in the details based on your campaign's tone and player preferences.

entries.name: Draw an Encounter
entries: When the party is traveling, resting, or exploring you can shuffle all 22 encounter cards and draw a card to introduce a unique event.

entries.name: Set the Scene
entries: Establish the mood and present the initial scenario after reviewing the encounter.

entries.name: Present the Choice
entries: Players may respond however they wish-engaging directly or avoiding entirely. Use the Development to evolve the encounter as choices are made.

entries.name: Resolve the Outcome
entries: Use the suggested guidance to determine the results of the player's choices-consequences or rewards, often based on their success or failure in the encounter. Some encounters may resolve quickly, while others can have lingering influence on the campaign that can last much longer.

Not all of these encounters lead to combat. They should be used to add interest to your adventure. Use your judgment when introducing one of these encounters-some are trivial in challenge, while others are potentially very deadly. You may opt to choose an encounter instead of drawing one randomly, at your discretion.

card.name: Bathed in Moonlight
entries: Following the sound of massive wings flapping nearby reveals a shallow pond in which a {@creature Dream Eater|CrookedMoon24} bathes.

entries.name: Development
entries: If disturbed, the dream eater fights for 1 Round (Level 1+) or 2 Rounds (Level 6+) before fleeing, or until destroyed (Level 12+).

entries.name: Outcome
entries: The iridescent surface of the pool can be collected, producing a {@item Nightwatcher Potion|CrookedMoon24} for each character.

card.name: Borrowed Faces
entries: Six wooden masks hang from a dead tree or perch, rotating slowly as if surveying the area.

entries.name: Development
entries: For each mask that is plucked from its hanging place, a creature will grow in its place in {@dice 1d4} hours, which takes the shape of the character who removed the mask and menaces the area until destroyed. These imitations use the stat block of {@creature Violet Fungus|XMM} (Level 1+) or {@creature Awakened Tree|XMM} (Level 6+) or {@creature Woodwarped|CrookedMoon24} (Level 12+).

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Each hostile plant possesses a {@item Nectar of the Green Man|CrookedMoon24} which can be collected after they are destroyed.

card.name: Buried Offering
entries: A stone and wicker statue, overgrown with vines, stands at a crossroads, its gaping mouth stuffed with herbs and dirt.

entries.name: Development
entries: Small clumps of dirt around the statue indicate that holes were dug and then backfilled, but unearthing them reveals nothing within.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: A character who buries something related to living things in the soil (a fresh sprig, lock of hair, or even blood) finds a {@item Nectar of the Green Man|CrookedMoon24} under the mound of dirt they unearthed as they backfill the offering. The offering is consumed.

card.name: By Candlelight
entries: The characters spy figures chanting near a flickering light in the distance, a {@item Black Candle|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: Development
entries: Left uninterrupted, the cultists manifest a {@creature Crooked Effigy|CrookedMoon24} (hostile to all creatures) after 1 minute, which consumes the black candle and attacks until destroyed.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Interrupting the ritual causes the cultists to become hostile toward the characters, who benefit from the candle's Witchlight feature within its dim light.

card.name: Circle of Hunger
entries: A frantic {@creature Commoner|CrookedMoon24} stands in a clearing, surrounded by snarling wolves. They cry out for help.

entries.name: Development
entries: There are 3 {@creature Wolf|XMM|Wolves} (Level 1+) or 3 {@creature Winter Wolf|XMM|Winter Wolves} (Level 6+) which can be destroyed or driven off by the characters. If the characters are Level 12+, the wolves and the commoner are an illusion produced by a nearby {@creature Hypnovulfen|CrookedMoon24} which attacks if the characters intervene.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If real, saving the commoner earns their gratitude. They offer each character a meal and a {@item Harvest Brew|CrookedMoon24}. If the commoner was an illusion, a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check reveals a flask of {@item Sight of Sin|CrookedMoon24} in the nearby undergrowth.

card.name: Hell at Its Heels
entries: A riderless {@creature Riding Horse|XMM}, bleeding and wild-eyed, stumbles into the characters' path. A torn saddlebag dangles from its side.

entries.name: Development
entries: The moment the characters approach, a number of hostile {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds} equal to the characters' level (averaged, rounded down) catch up and attack both the horse and the characters.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: If the bat hounds are destroyed and the horse calmed (DC 13 {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}), a {@creature Hemonculus|CrookedMoon24} can be found within the saddlebag. Failure: If the horse escapes or is destroyed, the saddlebag contains one {@item Draught of the Red Hunger|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: Laughing Stones
entries: A circle of mossy stones is spotted. No sound passes through or within the circle, as though affected by a {@spell Silence|XPHB} spell.

entries.name: Development
entries: When a stone is removed, laughter fills the area and a trapped {@creature Kackle|CrookedMoon24} appears, hostile to all creatures. Returning the stone banishes the kackle.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If the kackle is defeated, its lantern tumbles to the floor, which has the properties of a {@item Cape of the Mountebank|XDMG}, and the magic of the stone circle is ended.

card.name: Left to Boil
entries: One {@creature Dingpot|CrookedMoon24} sits unattended, filled with bubbling brew, attempting to speak with 1d4 frogs ({@creature Commoners|XPHB}).

entries.name: Development
entries: 2 {@creature Giant Owl|XMM|Giant Owls} swoop in to capture one frog and attempt to escape with a meal.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: The frogs are defended, reverting to commoners after {@dice 1d4} hours. Failure: If any frogs perish, the dingpot loses its Brew feature.

card.name: Magpie's Choice
entries: A {@creature Magpie of Omens|CrookedMoon24} perches nearby, holding a glinting trinket in its beak.

entries.name: Development
entries: If a character accepts a trinket, roll {@dice 1d2}: on a 1, they have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on their next d20 roll; on a 2, {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}. The magpie returns two more times over the next two days.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: The magpie bonds with a character if all three gifts are accepted politely. Failure: If rude, the magpie never again approaches.

card.name: The One Who Waited
entries: A dead {@creature Commoner|XMM} perched atop a tree is spotted, clutching a large horn.

entries.name: Development
entries: If sound above a whisper is produced within 60 ft of the tree, a {@creature Wellwyrm|CrookedMoon24} emerges from below. It retreats for 1 minute whenever a horn or similar {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} is sounded.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: The wellwyrm can be guided away toward a nearby waterway where it departs in peace.

card.name: Pass It On
entries: A wooden signpost reads: 'Pass it on.' Underneath, two bottles of {@item Jinxed Rum|CrookedMoon24} and a single {@item Jinxed Poker Chip|CrookedMoon24} can be found.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Removing the items without replacing them with something of equal or greater value curses the takers: until the curse is removed, they enter the Crooked Fortune dark bargain.

card.name: Plucked from the Path
entries: A {@item Bloody Fiddle|CrookedMoon24} lies in the dirt on the path.

entries.name: Development
entries: The first character to play it attunes instantly. 1d4 days later, a {@creature Bearded Devil|XMM} (Level 1+), {@creature Bone Devil|XMM} (Level 6+), or {@creature Rakshasa|XMM} (Level 12+) appears, demanding its return.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If returned peacefully, the creature vanishes, leaving behind a {@item Devilbone Button|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: A Price for the Herd
entries: {@dice 2d6} {@creature Goat|XMM|Goats} graze nervously while a {@creature Goatstealer|CrookedMoon24} watches from the trees.

entries.name: Development
entries: The goatstealer does not attack—it waits. If offered a goat, it devours and lingers.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If fed: The goatstealer bonds to the character who granted permission. If destroyed: The goats are saved.

card.name: Rock-a-Bye Baby
entries: A rocking cradle is found alone—no infant rests within, yet it gently rocks itself back and forth.

entries.name: Development
entries: Upon closer inspection, a pair of silver stork scissors rests on the pillow. The cradle is actually a {@creature Mimic|XMM} which attacks if disturbed.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: The pair of {@item Midwife Shears|CrookedMoon24} remain if the mimic is defeated.

card.name: Second Bite of the Cherry
entries: A strange fruit-bearing tree thrives where nothing else grows. There, a ghostly orchard worker ({@creature Wayward Haint|CrookedMoon24}) tends to the tree, unable to grasp and pick the shining produce.

entries.name: Development
entries: The worker is very protective of the tree and hostile to any who approach unless they are convinced someone can help them with their final harvest.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: Aiding the haint frees them of their tether to the world, and it offers each character one fruit as thanks (acts as a potion of {@item Reaper's Revenge|CrookedMoon24}) before fading away.
Failure: The haint loses itself to rage and despair, and the fruits wither to nothing.

card.name: Stench of Greed
entries: The stench of a small nearby cave is so foul it can be sensed within a half mile.

entries.name: Development
entries: Disturbing the entrance awakens 1d4 {@creature Dretch|XMM} (Level 1+), 1d6 {@creature Ghoul|XMM} (Level 6+), or 1d4 {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|Deepdrecks} (Level 12+), who dwell in the cave and attack intruders.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If the monsters are destroyed, a cache of silver bars ({@dice 2d6}, worth 25 gp each) is found among rotting bones and broken tools.

card.name: Thicker Than Water
entries: Just off the path, a dirty wine bottle filled with four uses of {@item Draught of the Red Hunger|CrookedMoon24} is spotted. Its label reads Briar Public House.

entries.name: Development
entries: Uncorking the bottle within 60 feet of where it was found draws the attention of two {@creature Skeleton|XMM|Skeletons} (Level 1+), two {@creature Vampire Spawn|XMM} (Level 6+), and one {@creature Vampire|XMM} (Level 12+).

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Defeating the undead heightens the wine's potency as per the Heightened Brewing rules.

card.name: A Thirst for Stories
entries: One {@creature Moonshine|CrookedMoon24} sips a bottle of {@item Haint Hooch|CrookedMoon24} and tells bombastic stories to the shadows, asking the characters to join it for a tall tale.

entries.name: Development
entries: Failing to join the moonshine attracts {@creature Shadow|XMM|Shadows} (Level 1+), {@creature Wight|XMM|Wights} (Level 6+), or {@creature Wraith|XMM|Wraiths} (Level 12+) equal to the number of characters.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: If the characters join, the moonshine shares a {@item Haint Hooch|CrookedMoon24} with each and bonds with the best storyteller.
Failure: When the undead are defeated, the moonshine fades with a melancholic whistle.

card.name: The Threadbare Guide
entries: A hunched traveler ({@creature Knight|XMM}) wrapped in rags leans on a gnarled staff. He claims to know this area well but refuses to reveal his name or past.

entries.name: Development
entries: The traveler offers each character an {@item Elixir of Fogwalking|CrookedMoon24} and promises safe passage for their next journey in exchange for a future cost.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Accept: After their next long rest, characters' {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} are halved (rounded down). Their next overland journey is shrouded in mist, taking 1 hour regardless of distance.
Refuse: The traveler thanks them and continues on his way.

card.name: Thread of Affection
entries: One {@creature Witchwoven|CrookedMoon24} sits at a makeshift dinner table, waiting nervously.

entries.name: Development
entries: The witchwoven awaits a {@creature Corn Dolly|CrookedMoon24} for a romantic date. Without help, they will fail to charm their beloved.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: With the right advice, the corn dolly agrees to continue their courtship. The witchwoven grants the effects of {@spell Heroism|XPHB} (+4 spellcasting modifier) for 24 hours.
Failure: Rejected, the witchwoven produces a {@item Tincture of Mourning|CrookedMoon24} before unraveling.

card.name: Under the Bridge
entries: A dilapidated stone bridge spans a dry riverbed. Below, a {@creature Salmon of Knowledge|CrookedMoon24} flops on the parched ground, having lost its orb of water.

entries.name: Development
entries: The salmon suffocates in {@dice 1d4+1} minutes, dissolving into foam without its orb. Attempts to rehydrate it only delay its demise.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Success: The orb of water is nearby and can be returned, bonding the salmon with its savior.
Failure: The salmon dissolves into the riverbed, never to return.

card.name: Well Wishes
entries: A dry stone well stands alone. From its depths, a faint voice calls for aid.

entries.name: Development
entries: The voice belongs to a lingering spirit trapped within the well, asking for an item of sentimental value to be dropped inside.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: Accept: A {@creature Ghost Crawler|CrookedMoon24} emerges and bonds with the giver.
Refuse: The spirit turns bitter, and a {@creature Will-o'-Wisp|XMM} attacks until destroyed.

card.name: The Fool

entries: "Ooooo! The Fool! I love this card! New adventures, new beginnings, new opportunities; who could say no to that? It's almost like it's telling you that a new journey awaits you the moment you step off this train, don't you think?"
If {@i The Fool} is pulled, the {@item Whistle of the Vagrant|CrookedMoon24} is left in the grass after the defeat of {@creature The Ghostlight Locomotive|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Magician

entries: "The Magician is a powerful card! You already have everything you need to succeed. All you gotta do is harness your own power, and you can create the future of your dreams. You're no marionette letting someone else pull your strings. It's your turn to be the puppet master!"
If {@i The Magician} is pulled, the {@item Marotte of the Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24} is held by a lifeless marionette after the defeat of {@creature The Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The High Priestess

entries: "The High Priestess! Well, ain't that swell! You gotta listen to your heart and use your intuition. Look into that place where your memories rest, and you'll find you've got all the experience you need to make the tough choices ahead."
If {@i The High Priestess} is pulled, the {@item Mask of Lethica Nightborne|CrookedMoon24} is found among the mementos on the shrine in {@area Lethica's Quarters|4a4|x} in Memory's Rest Sanatorium.

card.name: The Empress

entries: "When times get tough, there is nothin' quite like a mother's love! And that's really the Empress in a nutshell. This card appears when you need it the most. I see a house on a hill and a mama tucking you in tight after a terrible nightmare. That's the Empress."

If {@i The Empress} is pulled, the {@item Cauldron of the Vermintoll Coven|CrookedMoon24} remains in {@area the ruins of the Crooked House|22a|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Vermintoll Abomination|CrookedMoon24}

card.name: The Emperor

entries: "You ever wanted complete control over your life? You're in luck! The Emperor promises that in spades! Sure, you gotta do a bit of work first—break some habits, change a belief or two—but if you do that, you'll be the one dealing the cards, not losing the game!"

If {@i The Emperor} is pulled, the {@item Blunderbuss of the Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} is clutched in {@area Mister Crossroads's dead hands|3cd|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Hierophant

entries: "Learnin' is next to godliness. I'm pretty sure that's how the saying goes! Anyway, the Hierophant is telling you just that. There is someone in your future that can lead you down the right path. You just gotta seek em' out and be practically bloodthirsty in your quest for knowledge."

If {@i The Hierophant} is pulled, the {@item Sword of the Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24} is embedded in {@area the altar of the Sanguine Cathedral|342|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Lovers

entries: "Awww, the Lovers! There sure ain't nothin' better than love. Someone has recently come into your life who's gonna flip your world on its axis. Don't get me wrong, I'd love for you to have your own Phil, but this person could be anyone! Even if they're the cat's pajamas, don't let love overtake logic."
If {@i The Lovers} is pulled, the {@item Planchette of Adela Druskenvald|CrookedMoon24} is found on the charred corpse of Adela Druskenvald in the {@area Green Queen Inn|747|x}.

card.name: The Chariot

entries: "The Chariot is all about freedom and breaking free from the cage of self-doubt. I know it can be hard, but don't let the wicked voices inside your head tell ya that you can't escape. Banish your inner demons, trust in yourself, and let the chariot guide you."
If {@i The Chariot} is pulled, the {@item Scythe of the Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24} remains in the {@area Fields of the Crow|2b9|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24}

card.name: Strength

entries: "Strength is one of my favorites! A girl like me ain't got a lotta muscle, but I do gotta lotta heart, and that's really what this card is all about. Don't bury yourself beneath the weight of your past. Find your inner strength and you can face whatever challenges await!"
If {@i Strength} is pulled, the {@item Shovel of Yorgrim|CrookedMoon24} is found in the chamber of rest in {@area Shadestone Sanctuary|60f|x} in Maidenmist Cemetery.

card.name: The Hermit

entries: "The Hermit isn't as lonely as it seems. You don't need to run off into the forest or anything. You just need to break up your routine a little. It's time to walk a new path. While it's easy to rely on a guide, you gotta start relying on yourself!"
If {@i The Hermit} is pulled, the {@item Staff of Farryn of the Greenwood|CrookedMoon24} is found embedded in the ground beside the {@area Befouled Wellspring|57b|x} in Hartsblight Forest.

card.name: Wheel of Fortune

entries: "Everything is about to change! Fate can be a bit scary when you have no control, but don't fret. What is to come is the direct result of choices you've already made. Since the Wheel of Fortune never stops spinnin', you can always make new choices to correct the path."
If {@i Wheel of Fortune} is pulled, the {@item Cutlass of Briggsy Kratch|CrookedMoon24} is found in the swamp water of {@area the Drowned Crossroads|388|x}.

card.name: Justice

entries: "Oh, Justice! You may find yourself in a position to cast judgment, but don't let that kind of power go to your head! Everything isn't always what it seems, so always consider both sides to any story. You might have the power now, but eventually karma will rebalance the scales."
If {@i Justice} is pulled, the {@item Shield of Marius Renathyr|CrookedMoon24} is found hanging in the stables of {@area the Crimson Monastery|2f4|x}.

card.name: The Hanged Man

entries: "Oh honey! You might be feelin' like the world has been flipped upside down. Heck, you might even be feelin' powerless or trapped. But the Hanged Man encourages you to live in the moment, have a little patience, and let the solution come to you!"
If {@i The Hanged Man} is pulled, the {@item Banjo of Ol' Jericho Sticks|CrookedMoon24} is found in the basement of the windmill in {@area Foxwillow|276|x}.

card.name: Death

entries: "DEATH!! How spooky! Oh, don't worry! It ain't as scary as all that! Look around ya. You're on a train traveling through death itself and it's still a party. This card simply means that one chapter of your life is ending so that a new one can begin."
If {@i Death} is pulled, the {@item Idol of the Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} is found hanging in {@area Gorthos's den|594|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: Temperance

entries: "Temperance is about change and endurance. Life, and even death, can be chaos. But even in turmoil, you can find harmony. Simply look for the good in the bad, and temper yourself so you can embrace the change that is to come."
If {@i Temperance} is pulled, the {@item Veil of the Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24} remains {@area over Matron Lethica's face|4e2|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Devil

entries: "Oh Gosh! I don't want to spook ya, but it looks like you might be easily manipulated! Whatever you do, don't give into temptation. The Devil whispers of dark entities that would use your desires to corrupt you for their nefarious ends. Beware!"
If {@i The Devil} is pulled, the {@item Cane of Phillip Druskenvald|CrookedMoon24} can be found {@area in Kehlenn's barrow|781|x} before the battle with {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Tower

entries: "The Tower crumbles all around you. Truths are laid bare, and something in your life is soon to be destroyed. That may sound scary, and that's because it is! But remember, if the forest burns, from the ashes another forest will grow anew."
If {@i The Tower} is pulled, the {@item Visage of the Old Ways|CrookedMoon24} is found {@area on a slain cultist|733|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The Star

entries: "Aren't you the lucky one getting the Star card?! When all around you is nothing but darkness, the star is a shining beacon of hope within it. Use the light inside yourself to take control of your destiny."

If {@i The Star} is pulled, the character this card was pulled for gains a feat of their choice for which {@area they qualify after defeating|419|x} {@creature Stonoga Blackstinger|CrookedMoon24} in Skitterdeep Mine.

card.name: The Moon

entries: "You wouldn't think the Moon was eerie by the name alone, but I'm tellin' ya, it is! You are surrounded by illusions and trickery, and nothing is what it seems to be. You must seek truth amidst the madness, even when you aren't sure if you can trust yourself."

If {@i The Moon} is pulled, the character this card was pulled for receives three Twists of Fate that last until they are expended after defeating {@creature Vessla Browntooth|CrookedMoon24} in {@area the Crooked House|22a|x}. Once per turn, when a creature the character can see makes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, the character can expend one Twist of Fate to replace the {@dice d20} roll with a 1 or a 20.

card.name: The Sun

entries: "Nothin' is quite as fun as the Sun! This card is positutely positive! The Sun illuminates the shadows and chases away the darkness. Good things lie ahead! Just don't forget that for every ray of light that is cast, there is always a shadow along with it."

If {@i The Sun} is pulled, the character this card was pulled for increases one ability score of their choice by 2 after defeating {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24} in the {@area Roving Rookery|674|x}. This increase can't raise a score above 24.

card.name: Judgement

entries: "Oh no! It looks like your past has come back to haunt you! It's time for you to confront your past and atone for anything that needs atoning! Judgement comes for everyone!"

If {@i Judgement} is pulled, the {@item Lantern of the Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} remains on the floor of the {@area Tomb of the Shrouded|633|x} after the defeat of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}.

card.name: The World

entries: "Now this card is just the berries! The World is ever changing and constantly throwing obstacles in your way, but pulling this card is a sign that you are about to overcome something monumental. Everything you must sacrifice will be worth it! Victory awaits!"

If {@i The World} is pulled, the character this card was pulled for is granted the ability to cast the {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell one time {@area after defeating|7a7|x} {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}.

book.name: The Crooked Moon Part One: Player Options & Campaign Setting
book.author: Avantris Entertainment

contents.name: Druskenvald
headers: The Land Between Life and Death

data.name: Introduction: A Dreadful Folktale
entries: {@i Somewhere, lost in the shrouded realms of death, lies a land of endless night where long-forgotten horrors are revealed to those who travel through the mist.}
{@i There, in a crooked house lives a Crooked Man with a crooked grin. He raises crooked arms to a Crooked Tree at the edge of midnight and hears the whispers of the Old Ones}.
{@i They speak of a beast that stalks the darkest woods and darkest hearts, a crown of horns upon its head. If you lose your way and feel a warm breath that chills you to the bone, run.}

{@i Follow the songs of harvest time, and before long, you'll find revelry in the dancing shadows of blazing wicker. No matter your story, these lonesome, misty rails will deliver you to where the hallowed cannot save you.}
{@i Now is the time to brave the dark wood, beware the witching hour, and weave your own dreadful folktale underneath the Crooked Moon}.

You are about to embark upon a journey into the unknown, where uncanny folk with strange superstitions revere the Old Ways, and creatures of folklore lurk on the isolated fringes of civilization. {@i The Crooked Moon} is a tome intended to equip you with all the tools you'll need to bring Folk Horror to 5E and turn your game into a terrifying tale told among friends.

entries.name: Using This Book
entries: Within these pages, you'll find a plethora of options, rules, mechanics, and inspiration to craft characters and campaigns rooted in Folk Horror. Whether you are taking up the mantle of the Game Master (GM) or facing the terrors that await you as a Player, this book offers the guidance to make your tabletop roleplaying game (TTRPG) experience an unforgettably dreadful folktale. {@i The Crooked Moon} on D&D Beyond consists of two parts:

entries.name: {@book Part 1|CrookedMoon}
entries: Features an overview of the setting of Druskenvald, including its thirteen major provinces, and they provide the player options needed to create thematic and compelling characters either hailing from or destined to this realm of eternal night.

entries.name: {@adventure Part 2|CrookedMoon}
entries: Contains a robust and thrilling Folk Horror adventure campaign in which a group of wayward souls becomes stranded in the isolated valley of Wickermoor Hollow and must contend with the malign machinations and minions of the Crooked Queen, taking the characters from level 1 to 14 (and optionally all the way to level 20).

entries.name: Appendices
entries: Provide additional options for GMs to enhance the horror in their games with folkloric monsters, eerie magic items, and a table of Chaotic Curses.

entries.name: What Is Folk Horror?
entries: Despite being so deeply rooted in tradition and old superstition, the term "Folk Horror" is a surprisingly new articulation to describe a nebulously defined genre with a wide variety of media under its umbrella. {@i The Crooked Moon} looks to the work of writer and filmmaker Adam Scovell to help define Folk Horror and guide its influence throughout the book.

A work of Folk Horror might be one that utilizes folklore to instill a sense of uncanny dread (such as the 2015 film {@i The Witch}), presents the clash between the archaic and the modern (such as the 1973 film {@i The Wicker Man}), or creates its own folklore by weaving various elements of a culture's collective consciousness (such as the 2014 series {@i Over the Garden Wall}). However, Scovell's framework of the "Folk Horror Chain" unifies these archetypes and more into a broad but consistent definition.

entries.name: The Folk Horror Chain
entries: To determine what constitutes a Folk Horror story, Adam Scovell denotes four key narrative, thematic, or aesthetic aspects of a work that form a cause-and-effect series of "links" in a chain:

entries.name: Landscape
entries: The first link is the prominence of the landscape or environment, often becoming a living, breathing character of its own. These stories most often take place in rural locations and commonly focus on nature or agriculture. Most importantly, these remote landscapes isolate the characters and communities within them.

entries.name: Isolation
entries: The people in these remote environments are cut off from the prevailing society and standard trappings of civilization. Whether a group of several characters or a small community, the folk of these stories find themselves separated from society physically, and most importantly, outside of its dominant ideologies and beliefs. The main action of many Folk Horror stories is initiated by outsiders, often representing modernity or urbanity, interloping into these communities.

entries.name: Skewed Morality
entries: In these stories, the isolated communities and groups develop skewed belief systems, often manifesting in an adherence to ancient superstitions, the practice of the occult, or a hostile rejection of the morals of society at large. This strange and warped morality inevitably leads to a horrific action and the final link in the chain.

entries.name: The Happening
entries: Generally, at the climax of these stories, the skewed morality of the isolated groups living in remote landscapes manifests a supernatural or violent happening. This dreadful event might take the form of the summoning of an otherworldly entity, a ritual sacrifice, a demonic or ghostly possession, a bloody murder, or some other act of killing or occultism.

entries.name: The Chain in Practice
entries: When defined in this way, Folk Horror is a broad but thematically consistent genre that can include works from any narrative medium, time period, or global culture. The chain encompasses archetypal Folk Horror stories such as the 2019 film {@i Midsommar}, as well as unexpected examples like the 1974 film {@i The Texas Chainsaw Massacre} and even genre-bending works like the 2007 film {@i Hot Fuzz}.

While {@i The Crooked Moon} leans heavily upon the aesthetics, tropes, archetypes, and plot threads found in quintessential examples of Folk Horror, this book also draws inspiration from the wide umbrella of works encompassed by the Folk Horror Chain, as well as elements of other horror subgenres such as Gothic Horror, Body Horror, Cosmic Horror, and more. You are encouraged to weave your own inspirations into your campaigns and characters to achieve a cooperative horror story best suited for your table.

entries.name: Folk Horror in Your Game
entries: Horror as a genre has a notorious reputation for being difficult to execute in a game of heroic fantasy. The goal of this book is to provide as many tools as possible for you to strike the appropriate level of dread in your game, but there are many additional factors to be mindful of when setting off to weave a dreadful folktale with your friends.

entries.name: Aligning on Goals
entries: One of the biggest sources of friction between people at a table is a misalignment of what everyone is hoping to achieve in the game. This is especially true when it comes to horror. Some players may want a deeply serious Folk Horror story where the tone and tension are maintained by all at the table. Others may be interested in a more goofy, spooky flavor of horror with plenty of jokes. Certain gamers may prefer to focus on engaging with mechanics and striving for tactically and strategically optimal play.

These styles of play—and many others—are all valid, but if there is a misunderstanding between players and clashing goals, this can lead to interpersonal conflict and soured sessions. Before you begin a campaign that draws from The Crooked Moon, your group should meet for a "Session Zero" to discuss each player's goals for the game and strive to seek full alignment before the first session so that the game runs smoothly and is as fun as possible for all involved.

entries.name: Creating Compelling Characters
entries: The quality of a Folk Horror story is inextricably tied to the "folk" who feature in it. A story driven by compelling, multi-dimensional, and thematic characters can elevate a fun game of roleplaying into a deeply moving experience you and your friends will remember for the rest of your lives. The adventure campaign included in this book provides a large cast of memorable NPCs, but the most important characters of the story are the protagonists piloted by the players. Below is guidance to create and roleplay unforgettable Player Characters:

entries.name: Collaborate
entries: The character creation process should be a collaborative experience between the players and the GM. Through working together, bouncing ideas back and forth, and iterating on initial concepts, the Player Characters who emerge from the process will be compelling and well-balanced, both thematically and mechanically, and the GM will be well-equipped to incorporate character-specific elements into the adventure.

entries.name: Prioritize Theme
entries: The key to an exceptional character is a foundation based on theme first and foremost. Instead of starting with the mechanics of the character sheet, consider what theme you want to exhibit in a Folk Horror story, both aesthetically and narratively. Don't be afraid to leverage classic archetypes and tropes in fiction and borrow heavily from your favorite characters from various media. This will equip you with plenty of inspiration and ammunition to play a thematically rich and consistent character.

entries.name: Inhabit Your Character
entries: Creating a compelling backstory for your character is useful, but far more important is knowing who they are. Remember that your character is a real person in an imaginary world and not just a collection of statistics, traits, and abilities. If you strive to understand who they are, you will be better equipped to roleplay a wholly realized and multi-faceted character and will know how they would react to any scenario. To help discover who your character is, answer the following questions:

items: What are your character's defining personality traits?
What ideals drive your character forward?
What are your character's flaws?
What does your character fear and desire most?
Which archetype best applies to your character?
How has your character's past shaped them?
How would you describe your character without mentioning what they do, what they have, or what they look like?
Are there any aspects of your character that are superfluous to the answers to the above questions or are thematically unfitting for a Folk Horror adventure?

entries.name: Onward to Druskenvald
entries: You are now prepared to venture through the Shroud aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express} and face the terrors that await you in Druskenvald. Nothing in this book is meant to be prescriptive, and you are encouraged to use its contents in whatever way works best for you and your table. With {@i The Crooked Moon} as your guide, you are well-equipped to craft an unforgettable and haunting Folk Horror story with your friends.

entries.name: Comfort and Safety
entries: Many of the themes and topics core to Folk Horror can be deeply distressing for some. While the most disturbing elements of the genre have been greatly diminished, much of the content within The Crooked Moon deals with serious and potentially unsettling themes that should be considered with care and caution to ensure the comfort and safety of everyone at the table. To achieve this, be sure to approach the following topics during your group's Session Zero:

entries.name: Content Warnings
entries: The Crooked Moon contains elements of graphic and gory violence, depictions of mental health issues, cultural and religious conflict, endangerment of children and animals, grotesque body horror, family trauma, allusions to suicide, and more. Ensure that all players are aware of what awaits them so you can gauge everyone's comfort levels.

entries.name: Establishing Boundaries
entries: Solicit the themes and topics that each player does not wish to engage with in the game. Once established, these boundaries should always be honored and considered hard lines that are never crossed.

entries.name: Safety Tools
entries: Utilize safety tools that are understood by everyone at the table, empowering players to safely flag when they're uncomfortable without judgment and enabling the GM to change topic, pause the scene, fade to black, or otherwise steer the game away from the source of discomfort.

entries.name: Regular Check-Ins
entries: Make sure that all players check in regularly to gauge ongoing comfort levels and establish open and active communication to ensure that everyone feels heard.

entries.name: Here are the old fears
entries: Surrounded by looming walls of shrieking fog and forever trapped between dusk and the Witching Hour, Druskenvald is a realm made from the stuff of nightmares. Equal parts dreamland and afterlife, it beckons forth departed souls to be reborn into strange new folk that call this sinister place home. Lurking within the shadows of the night that never stops are ancient and terrible things that even the lord of the land forgot. Whether living or dead, heroic or humble, none are safe from the beasts that stalk the deepest woods and darkest hearts beneath the Crooked Moon.

It is this ever-present crescent with the face of a grinning witch that makes Druskenvald a bit eerie, uncanny, and crooked. It is a vestige of the forgotten, primordial origins of the realm, casting a wickedly gleeful look upon the land as if weaving a plot that only it knows with an inevitably dire outcome. However, to nearly all who live throughout the domain's provinces, it has simply always loomed high overhead and provided much-needed light in an endless night so filled with terrors.

entries.name: The Land Between Life and Death
entries: Druskenvald {@i (DRUSK-in-vahld)} is a realm that exists outside the lands of the mortal and material. Enveloped in a seemingly endless expanse of eldritch gloom, it exists in a paradoxical state of limbo between the warring furies of life and death. Beyond the misty borders of this domain may lie countless worlds and afterlives, but Druskenvald stands apart—a self-contained demiplane where the living, dead, and everything in between can coexist.

Within these confines is a landmass hewn into the shape of a crescent moon and a dark and roiling sea that stretches from its eastern coastline until it disappears into the haze. Looming mountain peaks to the north and south flank the lands between, forming an enormous continent-sized valley that nonsensically spans numerous environments in a relatively short distance and never experiences the turn of a season. The laws of nature and logic have no dominion over a place that is just as much nightmare and folktale as it is a land to explore.

The mystifying nature of Druskenvald is made most apparent by the thirteen major provinces that comprise it. As if pulled from a child's storybook featuring a broad collection of varying tales, each of these territories has a wholly distinct biome, topography, and climate. From forest to moor, desert to tundra, swamp to farmland, they all exist side by side like a collection of bizarre patches stitched together upon a grandmother's quilt. Despite the uniqueness of each Druskenvaldian patch, travel between provinces is not especially difficult, and borders can be crossed with a simple step.

entries.name: Night of the Crooked Moon
entries: In Druskenvald, the sun never rises. Instead, the land is bathed in an orange glow from the horizon for a few brief hours at the height of dusk, only to be swallowed by the encroaching darkness that dominates the rest of the night.

The Crooked Moon, an eternal crescent with the visage of a leering hag, hangs eternally overhead. Its light waxes and wanes with the cycle of each night as it moves through the sky with no discernible pattern, casting long, creeping shadows. At times, it looms large in the sky, its baleful eye glowering over the land with malicious intent. At other times, it shrinks to a small sliver nearly lost in the night sky, leaving the land blanketed in total darkness.

The people of Druskenvald have adapted to their peculiar 24-hour "day" cycle from the Twilight Hour through the Witching Hour, dividing their time according to the shifting light in their own ways. Some rise as soon as the golden glow of the hidden sun shows itself above the horizon and settle in before the most treacherous hours of night. Others only wake during true darkness. While they may not agree on how to honor Druskenvald's time, all peoples and provinces have aligned on the same naming conventions for the phases of each passing night.

entries.name: Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen
entries: Before Druskenvald became the harrowing realm it is today, it was a place of vibrant life and rebirth, ruled by Kehlenn {@i (KEH-linn)}, the Green Queen. This afterlife demiplane was an enormous forest, teeming with "green magic" that facilitated the natural cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Mortal souls would journey here to be reincarnated as plants, animals, and other natural beings, contributing to the eternal cycle.

Kehlenn was a Fey queen, neither benevolent nor malevolent, but a guardian of this natural order. She believed in the sanctity of the cycle, where each death brought forth new life, and the essence of the departed merged with the vibrant flora and fauna of the realm. Her dominion was one of serene balance, where the natural world thrived in an endless loop of renewal, untouched by the corrupting influences of sentient ambition and desire.

Kehlenn's vision of peace reigned until Phillip Druskenvald arrived. Where he came from and how he discovered this realm of rebirth is forgotten to all including Phillip himself, but his appearance initiated a cataclysmic conflict that left Kehlenn a hollow shell of her former self. The once lush forest became the fog-shrouded landscape of Druskenvald. Kehlenn, now the Crooked Queen, retreated to the deepest and darkest wood within Wickermoor Hollow, a minor province and the only one not under the dominion of Phillip and his Crescent Court.

In this weakened state, she lingers nearly dormant as she waits to reclaim her domain. Her bitterness festers, and she whispers the words of the Old Ways to those who will listen. Many of the monsters and creatures not shaped by the nature of their provinces have been made bent and crooked by the hateful spite of the Crooked Queen.

entries.name: Phillip and Adela Druskenvald
entries: Since coming to power, Phillip Druskenvald has attempted to shape the realm he named after himself into a reflection of his own ideals. A master of unchained ambitions, he envisions a realm where civilization crushes the wild pulse of nature, where order reigns supreme over the primal chaos of the afterlife. In his mind, he has crafted a sanctuary—a place where souls are reborn into lives filled with the pleasures and comforts they once knew, no longer bound by the harsh cycles of nature.

In Phillip's eyes, he is a benevolent ruler who has given the inhabitants of Druskenvald a second chance at life, which he believes to be the ultimate desire of every mortal. However, as the years have gone on, he has become out of touch with the people for whom he is responsible. Often aloof and completely unaware of the realities of living in Druskenvald, he presumes that the inhabitants of Druskenvald are having as good and easy a time as he is.

At Phillip's side stands his beloved wife Adela {@i (uh-DELL-uh)}, the most precious soul in existence to him. Adela was once a mortal woman living in the material world, but one born with immense powers of divination and prophecy. Her unbound curiosity, enthusiasm, and drive, along with an obsession with the spiritual world, drew her to seek out the {@book Ghostlight Express|CrookedMoon|1|The Vagrant and the Ghostlight Express}. It is there she met Phillip, and the two fell deeply in love and were promptly married. She now assists her husband and is invaluable in the governance of Druskenvald.

entries.name: The Crescent Court
entries: The Druskenvalds do not rule the domain alone. There are thirteen major provinces, each with a lord or lady who governs and embodies the essence of their territory. Some of these nobles are members of the origin species of their province, while others, though different in form, still represent the province's spirit. These diverse leaders form the Crescent Court, a council that governs all of Druskenvald.

The nobles of the Crescent Court enjoy a significant degree of autonomy in the governance of their provinces with little direct oversight from Phillip. As long as each province maintains order and does not disrupt the affairs of neighboring provinces or the Druskenvalds themselves, the lords and ladies are free to rule as they see fit.

Several times a year, the Crescent Court gathers at Chateau Clair de Lune {@i (sha-TOH KLAIR-duh-LOON)}, the Druskenvalds' sprawling manor. The home was built by Phillip to Adela's exacting design, and it serves as an ideal place of residence and headquarters for the domain's leadership. When court is called, there is pageantry and celebration, but important matters are discussed and crucial decisions are made regarding the governance of Druskenvald.

Oftentimes, the primary focus of the meetings is on the malefic machinations of the Coven of the Midnight Moon. This coven of thirteen witches is led by a powerful crone known as Mother Midnight. She and her daughters work in the shadows, terrorizing the thirteen major provinces of Druskenvald to some incomprehensible end.

entries.name: The Shroud
entries: No matter the power of the beings that dwell in Druskenvald, virtually none can pierce the wall of fog that encircles it. The phantom gloom, known among the inhabitants of Druskenvald as the Shroud, appears as a dense gray mist that wails in a chorus of agonized voices. The Shroud is, in reality, the condensed essence of the primordial element of death itself given form. It lingers just beyond the fringes of the mortal realms and serves as the veil that separates the lands of the living and the dead.

All souls not offered salvation by the hallowed or delivered damnation by the hells must pass through the Shroud on their way to the afterlife to which they are destined. They must first be led through the mist by the Strangers—timeless beings with the power to safely guide the dead to the other side. While these entities use many methods and take many forms, such as shepherds, ferrymen, reapers, or angels of death, all are bound to their solemn duty for eternity. Without the protective shield of a Stranger, the phantom mist annihilates wayward souls and devours their anima, the quintessential soul-stuff that provides all beings spiritual identity and sentience.

entries.name: The Vagrant and the Ghostlight Express
entries: The Vagrant {@i (VAY-grint)} is the enigmatic Stranger who ferries souls to Druskenvald, possessing the unique ability to come and go from the domain as he pleases. All others must be guided by him aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}, a spectral locomotive powered by the Shroud itself. The old black ghost train traverses the boundaries between life and death, unbound to any track as it courses through the mists. This mysterious mechanical ferry is the only means of passage in and out of Druskenvald for all, living or dead.

None know the Vagrant's origin, how he came to cooperate with Phillip, or his ultimate aims. Whether or not it is his true form, the visage he favors is that of an amiable frogman dressed in ragged clothing. The sole conductor of the {@i Ghostlight Express}, he is known by all passengers for his charming demeanor and love of stories and fiddle tunes.

In the mortal realms, the Vagrant's mirthful fiddle and haunting whistles herald the arrival of the ghost train, which emerges seemingly out of nowhere, rolling in on a bank of dense fog. It is said that only the dead may see this arrival, but there are a few fortunate, or perhaps unfortunate, living souls who have discovered how to gain passage while still alive.

entries.name: The People of Druskenvald
entries: Souls that arrive in Druskenvald are reborn into a wide variety of species, including those which inhabit the world of the living. However, the realm's predominant populace is comprised of thirteen distinct species, each having originated from one of the thirteen shrouded provinces.

The origins of these species are as varied as the land itself, some rising from the landscape, others being crafted by the provincial lords, and still more arriving from magical phenomena, emerging into Druskenvald as fully formed adults, infants, or any age in between. In just as many instances, the rebirth is initiated by two parents seeking a child through biological, magical, or technological means.

No matter the species, most inhabitants of Druskenvald emerge anew, their memories of a past life erased, allowing them to live their next life with a clean slate. A few cling to fragments of their former selves, their memories either shrouded in mist or vivid and unyielding. Even rarer are those with a fully clear picture of their past life, even remembering their moment of death. While many of these beings remain in their province of origin, others choose to roam across Druskenvald and settle in other communities.

Besides the thirteen species native to Druskenvald, humans are the most populous species found in the realm compared to other folk such as dwarves, elves, or halflings. This is due to the deep connection that Phillip and Adela Druskenvald have to the domain they rule. Despite having become deathless, immortal beings long ago, their once-human hearts have left a clear imprint upon the land.

entries.name: Death in Druskenvald
entries: There is no guarantee of the fate that befalls those who die again while in the confines of this realm of rebirth. For many, the cycle starts once more, and the soul of the recently deceased is reborn as one of the species of Druskenvald. Sometimes, they return as the same species they had been in life, but just as often, they awaken as an entirely different one.

Some experience a "Final Death," where the soul simply fades into oblivion and ceases to exist. For those who were particularly wicked in their second chance at life, the Shroud claims it. The soul's anima is devoured, and the spirit is transformed into a shrieking abomination doomed to wander the eldritch fog forever.

Rarely, the souls of the dead are reincarnated by the original nature of Kehlenn's domain and are turned into plants or animals by whatever lingering remnants of green magic still pervade the realm. These souls, marked by the Crooked Queen herself, are warped into the crooked monsters that lurk in the old places and stalk along the fringes of civilization.

entries.name: Provinces of Druskenvald
entries: As with any folktale, and especially within the genre of Folk Horror, the heart of the story can be found in the land itself, with the setting becoming a major character in its own right. In this section, you will discover the thirteen primary provinces of Druskenvald, the people who call them home, and how the unique aspects of each region affect the nightly life of the locals. In addition to major features and pieces of folklore of each province, you'll gain a deeper understanding of its ruler, the witch of the Midnight Moon that terrorizes its people, and notable locations rife with opportunities for haunting adventures.

The forthcoming province overviews are intended to serve as inspiration and guidance for crafting your own adventures in Druskenvald that range across a wide variety of environments, challenges, and themes. The minor province of Wickermoor Hollow, unrecognized by the ruling authority of the Crescent Court, is featured and heavily detailed in this book's adventure campaign, {@i The Crooked Moon} (see chapters 8–26).

entries.name: Ardengloom
