entries: This rough-built wood and stone building houses the masonry workshop and business of Solomon Roderick. The space is strewn with stone-working tools and pieces of granite, marble, and other stone.

entries.name: Solomon Roderick, the Stonemason
entries: Solomon Roderick (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Guard|XMM}) is a heavyset, heavily scarred man of 40 years. His skin is as hairless and rough as the stone he works with, and his brown eyes are equally cold when dealing with strangers or customers.

Roderick lives above his workshop with his eight-year-old daughter, Sofia. Her mother left the village not long after she was born, leaving Solomon to raise the girl alone. She assists him in the shop when she's not attending Finneas Trout's lessons.

The most skilled mason in the hollow, Solomon understands his craft and the leverage that gives him. He works with subordinates who spend their time overseeing the removal of stone from the area's quarries, leaving Solomon to manage the building and maintenance of stone structures throughout Wickermoor Village.

While he comes across as cold, calculating, and strict, Solomon is as soft-hearted as they come while in private with the people he cares for. He dotes on his daughter, whose happiness and wellness are his chief goal. Solomon is a recent convert to the Brightsinger, and his newfound faith is strong, making large donations to the church and those in need.

entries.name: V13: Carpentry Workshop
entries: Beatrice Wells performs her carpentry here, building or repairing structures throughout Wickermoor Village as needed. She also takes on smaller projects, such as furniture, cabinets, and farming implements. Lumber, boards, and other building supplies are carefully maintained within the workshop, while more is stored outside the building, leaning against the sides of the structure.

entries.name: Beatrice Wells, the Carpenter
entries: Beatrice Wells (Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) is a master carpenter and invaluable asset to Wickermoor Village. From wagons to furniture to structures, Beatrice is an expert with wood, known equally for her artistry and the sturdiness of her creations. She has a visionary quality that allows for unique and breathtaking work. She is fascinated beyond reason by the twisted architecture of the Crooked House (see {@adventure The Crooked House|CrookedMoon|5}).

Beatrice, along with her husband Branden (Chaotic Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) and their four young children, Robin, Lark, Jay, and Wren (Neutral Good, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}), live in their second-floor living quarters.

The Wells family dutifully follow the teachings of the Brightsinger (see {@area The Brightsingers|03b|x}). As she finds free time, Beatrice started building a chapel for Weston Murdoch on the Abandoned Church site ({@area area V19|17e|x}). The Wells family dresses in bright clothes and sing songs to each other, even as they work.

entries.name: V14: Bread by Holly
entries: The inviting scent of baking bread—as well as various sweet treats—wafts from this building from early in the Twilight Hour until the start of the Nightfall Hour. A small shop at the east end of the building displays a variety of baked goods for sale.

The rear of the shop is dominated by tables, shelves, and four wood-burning ovens that are in constant use. Holly's two daughters, Violet and Lavender, help their mother at the shop when they are not at school. No one (apart from Holly) knows who the fathers were, and the rumor mill has given up on finding out. The building contains no living quarters, as Holly and her children live with the butcher Siv Harga, with whom the baker has a relationship.

entries.name: Holly Aster, the Baker
entries: Holly Aster (Neutral Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) spends most of her time in the kitchen, either preparing the ingredients for the night's baking or fussing by the ovens. Her ruddy complexion is exacerbated by the heat of the ovens, and her straight pale hair is held back with pins while she works.

Holly comes from a long line of bakers living in Wickermoor Hollow, with her mother and her grandmother both filling the role of the bread-maker for the town. Both her mother and her grandmother died on their 35th birthdays of unknown causes, and Holly is just weeks away from hitting that milestone.

Holly is a dedicated Follower of the Old Ways, and she shares a curse with her mother and grandmother: she and her progeny are doomed to die on their 35th birthdays until the Crooked Queen returns. Holly knows this, and she has a terrible dilemma: join the cult of the Crooked Queen and help usher in the return of Kehlenn or die. How she chooses to act on that is left up to you.

entries.name: V15: Harga's Meats
entries: The butchery here is run by Siv Harga, a strapping woman who has become an expert in selecting and preparing meats of many kinds. The ground floor of her shop is divided evenly between the work area and the display area. Behind the shop are pens where animals that Siv has purchased from farmers for slaughter await their fate.

Siv employs a strange woman called Mrs. Oakum to help her in all aspects of the work. Mrs. Oakum leaves town each Evening and returns to town at Twilight the next night, but no one knows where she goes or what she does at night for food and shelter. The truth is Mrs. Oakum is a Chaotic Good {@creature Werewolf|XMM}. She struggles against her curse and keeps the bloodlust in check by skimming scraps from the butcher shop and spending her nights far away from innocent people.

entries.name: Siv Harga, the Butcher
entries: Siv Harga (Chaotic Good, human {@creature Scout|XMM}) is a tall, solidly built woman with blonde hair that she keeps braided. Growing up, her family moved around Wickermoor Hollow as animal herders. Siv finally settled down in Wickermoor Village as an apprentice to the town's butcher. When he passed, she took over the business and proved to be more than adequate. Siv shares a nearby house with her partner Holly Aster, Holly's two daughters, and her younger brother Ulf (Neutral Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}), who assists her at the shop while not in school.

Her knowledge of animals is a boon not just to her profession, but to the local farmers as well. Some think her connection with the animals she butchers is supernatural, and Siv does nothing to dissuade that attitude.

Her bond with the natural world led Siv to join the Fold of the Patient Lady. She believes that nature provides if believers are respectful and thoughtful about how to give back to nature in return. Even as she slaughters animals for her customers, she says a prayer of thanks to the Patient Lady and never allows cruelty to the animals in her care.

entries.name: V16: The Smithy
entries: Jean Myriel runs the smithy, where he works with a variety of metals to meet the needs of the village and the surrounding population as best he can. He is equally adept at making horseshoes, farming implements, and Simple weapons as he is working delicate gold jewelry and silver candlesticks. The second floor of the smithy contains storage and living quarters for Jean.

entries.name: Jean Myriel, the Smith
entries: Jean Myriel (Lawful Good, human {@creature Berserker|XMM}) emigrated to Wickermoor Village from Dawn's Gate several years ago. The unique methods with metalwork and strange designs he developed in his apprenticeship were seen as too bizarre and unorthodox for the conservative community. Stealing away in the dead of night and heading east, he found a home in Wickermoor Village.
While he once kept his beard wild and untamed, he's recently made the decision to trim his facial hair to make himself more "presentable." His shorter frame belies a mass of muscles beneath.

He is sure of himself and his skills, but he also knows when to accept the advice of others. After leaving the faith of the Crimson Rose behind in Dawn's Gate (see {@adventure The Crimson Monastery|CrookedMoon|7}), he has remained non-religious and upholds the ideals of the Newcomers.

entries.name: V17: The Wickery
entries: This chandlery is run by Oswick Frey. The building acts as a workshop, storage area, and living quarters. Its proximity to the butcher shop makes access to the fat used in candle-making quite convenient.

The two-story building is designed with ramps rather than stairs to accommodate Wick's wheeled chair. A rooftop lookout gives one of the best vantages of the village and surrounding area, except for the clock tower ({@area area V25|189|x}).

entries.name: Oswick Frey, the Chandler
entries: Most of the candles in town are made by Oswick (Chaotic Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}), a young man who loves his job. Having lost the use of his legs as a child, Oswick moves with the aid of a special chair designed and perfected by himself and other tradespeople of the town. Wick's bright red hair and pale complexion helped earn him his nickname as much as his job.

Oswick is madly in love with Finneas Trout (see {@area area V8|16a|x}), the schoolteacher, but he has kept the feelings to himself. Oswick's gregarious personality and fondness for sharing stories turns into awkward stammering in Finneas's presence.
Oswick is a member of the Followers of the Old Ways and provides free candles to the faithful around town so they may use them to conduct numerous rituals in honor of the Green Queen.

entries.name: V18: A Stitch in Time
entries: A large window display shows colorful and imaginative pieces of apparel, denoting that this shop houses a clothier and tailor. The sign hanging outside the shop, reading "A Stitch in Time," confirms this.

The owner and proprietor, Thomasin Ardor, designs fanciful and beautiful outfits. Unfortunately, the clientele available to her are generally only interested in plain and functional clothing. Thomasin also dabbles in shoe repair.
The shop's main floor is a showroom and work area. Upstairs are living quarters and a storage area, the latter containing bolts of cloth among other tailoring supplies.

entries.name: Thomasin Ardor, the Tailor
entries: Thomasin Ardor (Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) is the village's most proficient tailor. As a child, she fell through a large pane of glass, but her life was saved with a critical medical procedure. This trauma, in conjunction with her quiet and cool disposition, leaves her the brunt of unfounded rumors and gossip.
She often keeps folks at a distance, and the only person in town she is close with is Randall Graham (see {@area area V7|168|x}), who stitched her up following her childhood accident.

While Thomasin is a benevolent member of the Followers of the Old Ways and reveres the Green Queen, Randall Graham is attempting to leverage their relationship to subtly guide her into joining the cult of the Crooked Queen. Whether she falls to wickedness or discovers Randall's plot and rebuffs him is up to you.

entries.name: V19: Abandoned Church
entries: This area contains the foundation and partial walls of a church originally built from marble and granite. The building is still somewhat intact, but all the furnishings are gone, the wooden windows and doors are newly refitted, and cloth tarps cover holes where there were once glass windows. New wooden construction shows that the place is in the first stages of reclamation.

Watching over the altar is an 8-foot-tall statue of a praying knight with a sour grimace on his face. The villagers call him the Man in Marble and describe him as a mythical protector of Wickermoor Village from a better age, attributing the sneer on his face to his distaste for how times have changed.

No one in town knows to what or whom the church was originally dedicated, but recently a pilgrim named Weston Murdoch came to town with his wife, Joan, and his children, Peter and Charlotte. Following his arrival, he repurposed the Abandoned Church as a place of worship to the Brightsinger after attributing the presence of songbirds roosting in the ruined rafters as a sign of his deity's blessing.

entries.name: Weston Murdoch, the Pilgrim
entries: Weston Murdoch (Lawful Good, human {@creature Priest|XMM}) had his eyes opened to the power of goodness and forgiveness as a young child. His parents were both criminals who died for their crimes, and Weston was taken in by a loving family who taught him the path of light. He now strives to bring that same hope and redemption to others.

He is a charismatic man in his late twenties with sandy hair, blue eyes, and a personality that lights up a room the moment he enters. His wife and children, equally beaming and exuberant, make a powerful team of missionaries.

Weston is the leader of the Brightsingers in Wickermoor Village. The flocks of beautiful songbirds that congregate around his home are constantly at odds with the pigeons who occupy the Dovecote ({@area area V21|182|x}).

entries.name: V20: Post Office
entries: The Post Office is maintained by Theodora Mayville, who uses a bevy of carefully trained carrier pigeons to maintain a message service between Wickermoor Village and other towns in the valley, as well as larger towns from other regions.

The Post Office contains a mess of letters, messages, tiny scrolls, and small packages. Some of the parcels and packages are delivered via wagon, but many of the messages and missives are small enough to send via pigeon. Her assistant, Geneva Fairchild, handles these deliveries and is rarely seen within Wickermoor Village. When Theodora is not present, Geneva handles the business whenever she isn't traveling.
Theodora maintains a separate residence on the outskirts of town, and she spends much of her free time in the company of the pigeons in the Dovecote ({@area area V21|182|x}).

entries.name: Theodora Mayville, the Postmaster
entries: Theodora Mayville is a woman in her early 30s with a tall, slender build. She has white-blonde hair that's always set in a single ponytail, but it often falls into disarray under a brown leather hat. Her violet eyes are sharp and kind. She wears plain brown clothes and gold earrings in the shape of pigeons. She cherishes her beloved carrier pigeons as her children, and one of her birds is often roosting on her shoulder.

Theodora is really Golub Graygullet, the {@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24} and leader of the {@area Vermintoll Coven|024|x}. She alters or doctors every single letter that comes and goes from Wickermoor Village, ensuring the information in the town is controlled as much as its people's minds. When the characters discover her true identity, it triggers the events in {@adventure The Roving Rookery|CrookedMoon|13}. She won't hesitate to discreetly aid the characters in seeking out and killing her sisters Vessla (see {@adventure The Crooked House|CrookedMoon|5}) and Stonoga (see {@adventure Skitterdeep Mine|CrookedMoon|9}) in the name of furthering the Crooked Queen's machinations.

entries.name: V21: Dovecote
entries: This surprisingly large Dovecote is a haven for the pigeons used to deliver messages for the post. The cooing and fluttering isn't as loud as one might expect. In addition to the coops and cages that hold the birds, additional storage space for the Post Office ({@area area V20|180|x}) is found here.

The peaceful visage of the Dovecote is a mere illusion; it is actually the horrific lair of Golub Graygullet, the pigeon hag of the Vermintoll Coven. The Dovecote is bewitched to sprout enormous pigeon legs that allow it to rise from the ground and walk across Wickermoor Hollow. This only occurs in {@adventure The Roving Rookery|CrookedMoon|13} after Theodora Mayville's true identity is revealed.

entries.name: Peeping Albert, the Pigeon Familiar
entries: {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}) is a grotesque pigeon with human-like ears and human hands for talons serving as the familiar of the hag Golub Graygullet. Albert acts as the hag's eyes and ears both in town and over the length and breadth of Wickermoor Hollow. The presence of the songbirds, which arrived shortly after Weston Murdoch and the rest of the Brightsinger worshipers, has made Peeping Albert particularly cross.

entries.name: V22: Shade Funeral Home
entries: One of the most striking buildings in Wickermoor Village, this black marble structure is home to the undertaker Mori Shade. The basement of the building contains the workshop used to prepare bodies for their final rest in {@adventure Maidenmist Cemetery|CrookedMoon|12} to the southeast of town, as well as a chilled vault for storing the recently deceased. The main floor contains meeting areas and places for ceremonies to be held. The second floor contains storage areas for equipment and coffins, as well as Mori's living quarters.

entries.name: Mori Shade, the Undertaker
entries: Mori Shade (Neutral, human {@creature Scout|XMM}) deals in death. Rather than making her an outcast in the town, she's earned the respect of the people. They trust her to handle their remains with dignity and respect. She takes an interest in the various beliefs of the people, making her a good source of folklore.
A slight woman of indeterminate age, Mori has a stately, if grim, bearing. Her striking white hair is contrasted by an all-black wardrobe.

Mori does not follow the faiths of Wickermoor Hollow. Instead, she adheres to the spiritual beliefs of the Strangers (see {@book Druskenvald|CrookedMoon|1} chapter of {@book The Crooked Moon Part One|CrookedMoon}) who serve as ferrymen of the dead. She learned much of these beliefs from Yorgrim, the gravedigger (see {@adventure Maidenmist Cemetery|CrookedMoon|12}), with whom she works closely in giving the dead their proper burial.

entries.name: V23: Antique Bookstore
entries: The main areas of this building contain {@item Book|XPHB|Books} of all shapes, subjects, genres, and varieties. The shop also sells {@item Paper|XPHB}, {@item Parchment|XPHB}, {@item Ink|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB|Ink Pens}, and other supplies used in writing.
The second story contains the tools for bookbinding, ink-making, and the creation of paper and parchment. It also contains the living quarters for its owner, Eleanor Heyling.

entries.name: Eleanor Heyling, the Antiquarian
entries: Eleanor Heyling's (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Noble|XMM}) love of rare books is readily apparent to anyone who enters her shop and spots her nose-deep in her newest acquisition. She will not sell a book until she's read it. Some claim that she has been cursed by her reading, while others claim she's gained magical powers from the pursuit of rigorous study.

Although she is only in her early 40s, Eleanor has the look of an older woman. A life of little sleep and eye strain has left her far-sighted and sickly. She adopted her younger sister's three children: Margery, Algernon, and Sheridan (Neutral Good, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}). They go to school on most nights but are otherwise left to their own devices by their eccentric aunt. In fact, they often end up caring for her more than she cares for them.

Although Eleanor has lived in Wickermoor Village all her life, she is staunchly in the camp of the Newcomers. She values all knowledge and the wisdom her collection has imparted upon her, remaining skeptical of the strange rituals and beliefs of the other factions in town.

entries.name: V24: Druskenvald Estate
entries: Resting on a hill overlooking Wickermoor Village, the recently named Druskenvald Estate sits like an overgrown weed waiting to be plucked. The highlight of the grounds is the manor itself, which is called "the Crooked House" by the townsfolk due to its strangely askew construction.

Once called the Lockwood Estate, the manor had been long abandoned until recently. Mayor Somerton decided to gift the estate to Phillip Druskenvald in the unlikely hope that the lord of the land might finally visit his humble village. He even used public funds to keep it maintained and tasked the Jenkin family to move in and be ready to serve as the Druskenvalds' servants. More about the Crooked House and the Jenkins can be found in {@adventure The Crooked House|CrookedMoon|5}.

entries.name: V25: Haunted Clocktower
entries: The tall tower attached to the mayor's home and office contains the town's clock. It has always kept perfect time, but its bell occasionally strikes at random times, which always brings strange happenings.

If you wish to randomly determine when the clock will experience a haunted strike, roll a {@dice d12} when the characters finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. That night, from the Evening Hour through the Witching Hour, the random strike will occur during the hour that was rolled. As soon as the strike occurs, a restless spirit will make itself known to the characters, whether through strange noises, moving objects, appearing before them, or fully manifesting and attacking as a {@creature Ghost|XMM}.

entries.name: V26: The Old Pyethymer Place
entries: In the oldest part of the residential rows of Wickermoor Village is a narrow lane with many abandoned houses. At the end of this lane stands the Old Pyethymer {@i (PYE-tye-mur)} Place, which is the most decrepit of the bunch.

The town's children proclaim that it's haunted by the ghost of its former inhabitant and sometimes dare each other to explore it for themselves. These children never return, as the Old Pyethymer Place is not a real house at all, but is a {@creature House of Horror|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: V27: Homes
entries: A smattering of personal homes fills out the remainder of Wickermoor Village. Some of these homes are occupied by workers in the environs of the village: farmhands, herding folk, miners, quarry workers, hunters, artisans, or tradesmen.

entries.name: V28: Pavilion
entries: This open-air Pavilion offers a place for villagers to sit for a spell, have an outdoor meal, hold meetings, sell goods, or otherwise perform public works.

entries.name: Other NPCs
entries: These NPCs are not connected to any single location in Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Sister Rain, the Preacher
entries: Sister Rain (Neutral Good, human {@creature Priest|XMM}) travels throughout the hollow espousing the bountiful blessings of the Patient Lady. She has no official residence in the village and instead lives in the natural environments outside of town. She also sometimes stays with her congregants and preaches in the Founder's Round ({@area area V9|16c|x}). Sister Rain's moods and demeanor are as fickle as the weather and nature that she reveres, often living a nomadic lifestyle travelling between the various communes dedicated to the Patient Lady that dot Wickermoor Hollow.

Sister Rain is a slight woman in her mid-thirties. She wears a green floral print dress that sets off her long, flowing, flaming-red hair. Her green eyes are bright with the fervor of her faith, and her features can flash between joy and anger in a moment. She wears a plain silver necklace with a pendant in the shape of a blossoming sunflower.

Sister Rain is the leader of the Fold of the Patient Lady, and she espouses the need to accept and protect the bounties of nature. Her presence is anathema to the most zealous and evil followers of the Crooked Queen.

entries.name: Jeremiah Stover, the Farmer Spokesman
entries: The farmers living around Wickermoor Village work long hours and perform hard labor to keep the population fed. They have established a rudimentary union to ensure that they receive fair compensation for their work. The representative they've chosen is Jeremiah Stover (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Tough|XMM}), a tuber farmer whose dedication to the Old Ways, the land, and its workers makes him the perfect candidate. He works equally hard in his fields as he does in advocating for his peers.

entries.name: Gaston Doray, the Artist
entries: Gaston Doray (Neutral Evil, human {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM}) is a painter whose works all contain an ethereal quality. He came into town on a fog-shrouded night a few years ago, and no one has been able to determine his history. He's quite young, with just the beginnings of a beard sprouting on his chin and cheeks.

Adela Druskenvald becomes quite taken with Gaston and his dream-like paintings, becoming his patron. He has a particular candor with friends and strangers alike that some find refreshing, while others find uncomfortable. In all pursuits, he is deeply philosophical and sometimes even nonsensical to the simple folk of Wickermoor Village.

Gaston is a conduit through which Kehlenn expresses visions, which have driven him to very recently begin the initiation into the cult of the Crooked Queen. As the adventure progresses, Gaston's paintings become more and more bizarre and unsettling. By the end of the adventure, Gaston is completely unhinged and does the bidding of the worst of the Crooked Queen's followers.

entries.name: Hilda Brom, the Huntress
entries: While farms throughout the hollow feed the people, hunting for wild game is invaluable—and profitable—for times when crops fail. Hilda Brom (Neutral Good, human {@creature Scout|XMM}) is renowned as one of the most skilled hunters and trappers. She seems wild and unsocial to people she first meets, but her personality shines for those she knows and trusts. If a criminal escapes justice, the mayor and constable call upon her to hunt a different caliber of prey.

Hilda is a Follower of the Old Ways, finding special kinship with and reverence for the Green Queen. She has seen too much in the grim and sometimes haunted wilds to ignore the grasp of the spirit world on the land. If the characters ever get into trouble elsewhere in Wickermoor Hollow, Hilda might show up to lend a hand.

entries.name: Creating Your Own Adventures
entries: The overarching narrative of {@i The Crooked Moon} campaign focuses on the secret plot of the {@area minions of the Crooked Queen|02c|x} to release {@area Kehlenn|021|x} from the {@adventure Crooked Tree|CrookedMoon|17} and give flesh to {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}, ushering in an age of disintegration, annihilation, and crooked rebirth. This plot is woven throughout the chapters of this adventure, with each new foe defeated bringing their plan closer to fruition. Refer to the "Back in Wickermoor Village" section of subsequent chapters to see how the town will be affected by the story's development.

However, the information earlier in this chapter includes just a handful of the people, places, and plots that are possible in Wickermoor Village. This town should provide the framework to create your own adventures that you can interweave throughout the events of {@i The Crooked Moon}. Use the details below as inspiration for fleshing out the adventure and making it truly your own.

entries.name: Subplots
entries: If you wish to give the characters some downtime from the main plot and steer them toward some lower stakes side quests, you can use the subplots below. You will need to create hooks to draw the characters' attention to these plots and decide on the details to fit them best in your story. They can be used in between any adventure chapters when the characters return to Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: The Return of Gory Gus
entries: A year ago, the cold, calculating killer Gus Strong—called "Gory Gus" by the population—was tried and then beheaded before the Oak of Many Faces ({@area area V10|16e|x}) as punishment for his crimes. On the anniversary of his beheading, one of the townsfolk is murdered in the same way that Gus killed his victims. Evidence points to one of the characters being the killer. Clues can be found and followed to exonerate the character, showing that Gory Gus's apprentice has picked up her master's gory trade.

entries.name: A Bad Seed
entries: Villagers begin falling ill under mysterious circumstances during a special picnic celebrating a recent rich bounty of fruit, honey, and dairy. Clues at the picnic point to cursed apples being the culprit. The characters can investigate the apple orchard, where one of the townsfolk has entered a pact with {@creature Horned Devil|XMM|Fiends} in return for riches and power. The {@creature Fiend Cultist|XMM|diabolist} and the Fiends must be killed to break the withering curse that is affecting the picnic attendees.

entries.name: The Bloody Cup
entries: The village hosts an annual sporting and gaming event where teams from different parts of Wickermoor Hollow come together to compete. This year, the events of the competition turn bloody—or bloodier than normal—as "accidents" begin to plague the competition. The characters can compete on behalf of Wickermoor Village or watch, but without their intervention, the competition turns into a bloodbath.

entries.name: The Play's the Deadly Thing
entries: Hickock and Company, a traveling troupe of actors led by the flamboyant George Hickock, comes to town to perform a play in the Green Queen Inn theater at the request of Alda Farnum. A cast member dies under mysterious circumstances. Can the characters solve the murder? More importantly, can they finish the play titled {@i The Prince in Gold}?

entries.name: The Lottery
entries: A stranger comes to town, promising a great prize for people who willingly take part in a lottery. The stranger fails to reveal that, while the winner does receive a grand prize, someone—or several folks—lose the lottery and must pay a terrible price. The characters can intervene at risk of paying the price themselves.

entries.name: Town with a Secret Cult
entries: A secret cult operates within the shadows of Wickermoor Village, and behind every kind, smiling face could lurk one of its members. You can use the NPCs showcased earlier in this chapter as written, but are encouraged to adjust their alignments, allegiances, and goals in ways that best enhance your unique adventure of {@i The Crooked Moon}.

Because of the secretive and deceptive nature of the cult that serves the Crooked Queen and its direct connection to the prominent faith of the Old Ways, any NPC can secretly be a villain for the characters to uncover in a shocking twist. Alternatively, conniving NPCs that the characters believe to be sinister can be revealed to have been subtly working against Kehlenn's minions all along.

For ease of reference, below are the various groups of people in Wickermoor Village as written for the baseline adventure. Feel free to rearrange these lists as best suits your needs, keeping in mind the impact on Fateweaving Threads (see {@area Running the Adventure|078|x}) and future quest hooks. You are encouraged to prepare for the climactic confrontation with the cult of the Crooked Queen atop Rowan's Rise (see {@adventure Wicker's Vigil|CrookedMoon|16}), making sure to foreshadow and consider the connections that the characters make with NPCs throughout the adventure.

entries.name: Rumors and Rituals
entries: There are plenty of strange happenings and rituals that the characters can stumble upon in Wickermoor Village and its surrounding areas. The tables below feature examples to help you make the town feel real, superstitious, and dangerous.

entries.caption: Rumors
rows: A washerwoman has suddenly developed a crick in her neck and has reported hearing demonic voices.
A milkmaid has been accused of putting a wasting curse on the new wife of her ex-husband.
Local children have been growing patches of shaggy fur and are performing strange rites in the forest.
A visiting scholar writing his treatise on the Old Ways is breaking into homes in the name of research.
A woodsman is seeking help in hunting down a beast of the woods that stole his daughter's soul.
A pair of suspected assassins have been spotted in town, believed to be working for a cult of greed.
A heretical family has been banished from town, and their new homestead is terrorized by a witch.
A doomsday cult pops up in town, claiming that the moon will crash into Druskenvald in three nights.
A young woman is regularly visited by a strange man with a black cat who urges her to cross the river to join him.
A man was found frightened to death, clutching a marble finger in his hand and pointing directly ahead.
An old widow sends out invitations to her wedding, claiming to be marrying a trickster demon prince.
A group of suspiciously intelligent bluebirds roost in the church, and some think they are transformed humans.
Every night, fires dot the horizon, and the sound of distant drums and bestial bellowing is heard.
Youths seeking a strange dragon-like creature return with wide eyes, only able to speak in nonsense rhymes.
A hunter returned from the forest with a totally different personality, walking strangely and only whistling.
Townsfolk have strange dreams of flying through the stars and visiting alien landscapes and worlds.
A slovenly cook is accused of filling his pies with rats, children, and other terrible ingredients.
A fisherman's wife claims her husband was drowned by humanoid fish creatures in the river.
A farmer accidentally dug up an ancient relic while plowing his fields, and soon his family fell ill.
An inspector seeks a missing teenager who disappeared after being crowned harvest queen at a festival.

entries.caption: Rituals
rows: A public battle to the death is fought between two villagers with their children strapped to their backs.
Villagers make wicker effigies of exotic animals and race them through the streets of the town.
Large turnips hang above every doorway in town, painted to look like the people who live or work there.
A child-sized doll is fitted with a chainmail shirt and thrown into the river as an offering to "water spirits."
The pelt and head of an enormous bull are draped over a pole, and the townsfolk dance around it erratically.
A condemned murderer is executed by disembowelment, and his entrails are hung in the branches of trees.
To appease the "honey spirits," a volunteer from town is covered in a swarm of bees and stung for hours.
Following a funeral, the deceased is fastened to a horse and sent off into the moors for a "last ride."
As a rite of passage, a teenager is given a spear and sent into the woods to hunt and kill a bear alone.
A young couple is married before a large oak, receiving a blessing from the "ancestor spirits" within.
Nightly bonfires roar on the outskirts of town, offering bones from the evening's dinner to the flames.
In a mock rebirth ritual, a villager is drowned in the river and resuscitated to claim a new lease on life.
Townsfolk climb dangerously tall trees in the woods to collect rare herbs and burn them in honor of "plant spirits."
To honor the "bird spirits," the entire town gathers and sings a song that lasts a full twenty-four hours.
A criminal is punished by being pressed beneath heavy stones to see if they can survive a full night.
After the death of a villager, their qualities and deeds during life are etched in runes upon a stone.
The townsfolk consume hallucinogenic mushrooms and experience strange, shared visions.
The corpses of hares decorate the town to appease the "fertility spirits," which are then turned into a great stew.
To not be a burden, an elderly couple jumps from the clocktower to their death and are honored.
A great feast is held at the center of town, and the only food served are the bloody hearts of farm animals.

data.name: The Crooked House

entries: There was a crooked man who lived in a crooked house. He had two crooked children, and he had a crooked spouse. He bought a crooked axe which brought a crooked smile, And the bodies are all stacked up in a crooked bloody pile.

Sitting atop a gloomy hill and choked by the gnarled overgrowth of decades of disrepair is a twisted house that has known only evil. With not a single right angle in its bizarre construction, the abandoned manor is an uncanny monument to the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}. Her minions infest the place, and the wicked weasel hag, {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}, is its primary corruptor. She twists the souls of the living and dead trapped within the crooked walls. Only with the death of this hag can the horrors of the Crooked House be put to an end.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: The Crooked House stands as a haunted manifestation of {@area Kehlenn's|021|x} ancient power, twisted and alive with malevolent energy. It warps all who dwell within, unravelling and corrupting their very souls in preparation for sacrifice.

Victims' shattered souls and suffering feed the house, which reconfigures itself after each cycle of torment, shaping anew for the next doomed inhabitants. With each renewal, the gruesome process repeats itself—an eternal vessel for the Crooked Queen's insatiable hunger for sacrifice.

Steeped in the blood of its past, the Crooked House, now called Druskenvald Manor, readies its horrors for the unlucky pair that now call this place home. The Crooked Queen's influence lingers, her vile energy feeding the house, and the tormented spirits within turn their gaze toward new prey.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: The Crooked House bends and contorts into its true twisted, ruined, and haunted form with the helpless Druskenvalds trapped inside. {@area The Crooked Man|1ab|x}, {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}, and the repulsive creatures within await new souls ripe for sacrifice. Characters drawn to the house by the {@area Quest Hooks|1ba|x} later in this chapter have these goals:

items: Enter the Crooked House in search of {@area Phillip|01f|x} and {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} after first meeting The Crooked Man.
Conduct a sance to commune with the spirit of {@area Joseph Patrini|1b1|x}, who can point the characters to the hag in the attic.
Investigate the house and face the spirits within to collect all six mementos from the ghosts of the slain {@area Lockwood Household|1ac|x}.
Find the secret door to the attic and use the mementos to gain access to the Cauldron Room ({@area area H17|22a|x}).
Destroy the {@creature Weasel Hag|CrookedMoon24} Vessla Browntooth.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with the {@area history of the Crooked House|1a6|x} and the tragedy that befell the Lockwoods to help improvise the spectral encounters, including the sance with Joseph Patrini. Reading through the {@area locations of the Crooked House|1c8|x} will prepare you for the characters' investigation, no matter the order they choose.
This chapter is designed for four level 3 characters.

entries.name: A Haunted History
entries: Seventy years ago, the Lockwoods took their fateful carriage ride to Wickermoor Hollow, leaving behind the crowded streets of Cyril (see the {@book Druskenvald|CrookedMoon|1} chapter of {@book The Crooked Moon Part One|CrookedMoon}). {@area Eustace Lockwood|1ab|x} believed he was bringing his family to a peaceful valley, free from the city's toils, where nature would cradle them.

Their new manor, perched ominously atop a hill, loomed over a quaint village. Rebuilt by local hands upon the bones of its predecessor, it was grand yet unsettling. The builders didn't question the hidden attic that appeared in the altered architectural plans—an attic soon claimed by {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}, her evil familiar, {@area Filthy Jasper|22e|x}, and her swarm of twisted weasels.

The house was built atop the ruins of an ancient locus of {@area Kehlenn's|021|x} primeval power, making it the ideal dwelling to corrupt and trap souls, all of which would feed the power of the Crooked Queen. And such an elaborate and crooked construction provided the hag with ample opportunity to torment the numerous inhabitants over the years.

For a short time, the Lockwoods flourished. Eustace, his wife {@area Petunia|1ad|x}, children {@area Sally|1ae|x} and {@area Arthur,|1af|x} and Petunia's elderly mother {@area Keziah|1b0|x} enjoyed the manor's deceptive warmth. Their servants, the Patrinis, shared in their bliss, as did their son {@area Francis|1b3|x}, Sally's best friend of the same age.

But the joy was fleeting. Illness and nightmares crept in—the work of Vessla's vile enchantments. No medicine, not even the most skilled healers of Wickermoor Village, could combat the mounting corruption. Eustace, plagued by nightmarish visions, succumbed to madness, slaughtering his family and the Patrinis. The body of Francis was never found.

Families came and went, all drawn to the village's quiet charm. Yet, the tale always ended in tragedy. Eventually, the cursed manor was seemingly abandoned, falling to the village when no one dared return. Yet, no matter whether the manor was occupied or not, the circular window at the highest point of the house always shone with an eerie glow during the Witching Hour.

{@area Mayor Wendel Somerton|161|x}, blind to the horrors, gifted the estate to the Druskenvalds, a move suggested by {@area Randall Graham|168|x}, the town's scheming barber and doctor. Graham, knowing the house's sinister nature and eager to see the Druskenvalds consumed, sought to unleash the house's malice on the new residents.

entries.name: The Weasel Hag
entries: Vessla commands numerous twisted weasels that live in the walls. The Crooked House itself is haunted by a plethora of specters and monsters brought to life by the bewitching power of the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}.

entries.name: Vessla Browntooth
entries: {@creature Vessla Browntooth|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Weasel Hag|CrookedMoon24}) is the youngest of the three hags that form the {@area Vermintoll Coven|024|x}. As with her sisters, she is a crooked Fey from the primeval times of Kehlenn's reign, becoming more crooked with every passing year. She delights in the vermin that earned the coven its names, particularly favoring the weasels that scurry and scrape throughout walls of the Crooked House.
Vessla is the shortest and meanest of the trio, with a nose that is as long and pointed as her teeth and many other unsavory features that evoke the weasels she cherishes and commands.

Her witchcraft specializes in the corruption and siphoning of mortal souls, which manifests through horrific nightmares and phantasmal visions. This power is enhanced by the hoard of humanoid teeth, collected by her loyal weasels and her beloved familiar, {@area Filthy Jasper|22e|x}.

Recently, she captured {@area Phillip|01f|x} and {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} after they settled into the manor home, and she began performing an elaborate ritual to prepare their souls for sacrifice. What she doesn't know is that the sacrificial lamb is Vessla herself, as planned by her sisters, Golub and Stonoga, as part of the long-term machinations of the Crooked Queen.

entries.name: Filthy Jasper
entries: {@creature Filthy Jasper|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Weasel)|CrookedMoon24}) is an abominable Monstrosity, weasel-like but disturbingly human in his features, with unsettling hands that mimic those of a man. Formed from Vessla Browntooth's nightmarish magic, Filthy Jasper obeys her every whim and leads the swarming weasels through the Crooked House and Wickermoor Village.

As wicked as his creator, Filthy Jasper revels in human suffering, particularly that of children. An eager collector of humanoid teeth for Vessla's rituals, he savors the act of tearing them from skulls with his own hands.

entries.name: NPCs of the Crooked House
entries: More than weasels and hags live and lurk within the Crooked House. The residents that call it home span generations, and many are among the unliving.

entries.name: The Crooked Man
entries: The origin of the first {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24} has faded into seldom-repeated whispers, but his current form is the twisted spirit of Eustace Lockwood, the patriarch who slaughtered his family 70 years ago. After the bloodbath, Eustace hanged himself, urged on by Vessla Browntooth. She crammed his broken corpse into a narrow crawlspace beneath the house, snapping nearly every bone to make him fit.

From that cursed night onward, his soul was bound to the {@area Crooked Queen's|021|x} will, his spirit as distorted as his crumpled remains. Eustace now stalks the manor as a crooked specter in a tattered suit, twisted beyond recognition. Even when not with the house, his bond to it and the queen remains unbroken. With each soul claimed by the house, the queen's power deepens in Wickermoor Hollow.

The Crooked Man's aim is to free the Crooked Queen from her prison and restore her reign over Druskenvald. As her loyal minion, he roams Wickermoor Hollow like a shadow, aiding the schemes of the {@area Vermintoll Coven|024|x} and the {@area cult of the Old Ways|039|x}, drawing ever closer to unleashing the queen's malice.

entries.name: The Lockwood Household
entries: After Eustace Lockwood's bloody rampage, the spirits of his murdered household became trapped in the Crooked House, where they remain to this day. While the house has claimed many souls over the years, the ghosts of the Lockwood Household's six victims manifest more strongly than the others.

entries.name: Petunia Lockwood
entries: The dour but dutiful wife of Eustace Lockwood, Petunia, had been looking forward to moving to a more agrarian community. Her true love was in tending all manner of plants, especially her beloved bergamot trees. She viewed the Lockwood Estate as her chance to finally enjoy her husband's wealth—which was the only reason she married him.

entries.name: Sally Lockwood
entries: Sally was Eustace and Petunia's first child, but she never received much attention from her parents. Suffering from regular nightmares, Sally developed phobias and paranoias at a young age. The only time she felt safe was when she was surrounded by her dolls and other toys.

On the night of the murders, Sally managed to escape the Crooked House before succumbing to her wounds on the path down the hill. Her spirit eventually reincarnated into the dog now called Shuck (see {@area Shuck|1b8|x} below).

entries.name: Arthur Lockwood
entries: Arthur was born in Cyril but spent most of his short life in Wickermoor Village. He was a sickly baby, but no doctors that the Lockwoods hired could discover an underlying illness. His regular wailing led to him being left in the nursery for most hours of the night.

entries.name: Keziah Endicott
entries: Keziah, Petunia's elderly mother, was widowed at a young age, and she moved in with the Lockwoods. Coming from a wealthy and eccentric family, she developed many hobbies over her long life—landscape painting, taxidermy, and raising albino peafowl. Her active social life intrigued many strange folk from the town with a strong reverence for the Old Ways.

entries.name: Joseph Patrini
entries: Joseph came from a long line of butlers and took the profession very seriously, so he unquestioningly followed his employers to Wickermoor Village. He brought his wife, son, and love of music. While the Lockwoods abandoned Pholsense's faith of the Silver Path (see the {@book Druskenvald|CrookedMoon|1} chapter of {@book The Crooked Moon Part One|CrookedMoon}), Joseph never wavered and believed the divine would protect him in his strange new home.

entries.name: Gail Patrini
entries: Gail found less joy in being a housekeeper than her husband, but she relished being a mother. She never trusted her employers and found Keziah's strange hobbies especially unsettling. Her intuition allowed her to save her son on the night of her death, sacrificing herself so that Francis survived.

entries.name: Francis Patrini
entries: Francis, a clever and funny child, was the precocious son of Joseph and Gail Patrini. He was best friends with Sally Lockwood and would unsuccessfully try to get the girl to go on small adventures with him despite her inherent fears.

He was saved from the murderous Eustace Lockwood by his mother but was deeply traumatized by the experience. He became unable to speak coherently, and the memories of his former life became fragmented, eventually becoming known to all in Wickermoor Village as {@area Old Rusty|16c|x}.

entries.name: The Jenkin Family
entries: The Jenkin family serves as caretakers for the Druskenvalds during their stay, having long tended the homes of Wickermoor's elite. Three years ago, {@area Mayor Somerton|161|x} assigned them to the old Lockwood Estate, an honor laced with dread. Like the villagers, they had heard the whispered tales of the cursed house. Nevertheless, they moved in, preparing for the Druskenvalds.

entries.name: Walter Jenkin
entries: A handsome and affable sort, Walter Jenkin (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}), lost his voice within weeks of arriving. No healer could explain the sudden silence. Now, he communicates through writing and sign language, which his family also knows and can translate. Entering the manor makes him nervous, sensing its malice, though he never speaks of his fears.

Known for his loyalty and dutifulness, Walter has an almost reverent respect for Mayor Wendel Somerton and his other former employers. And in this new position, he has already become devoted to the Druskenvalds, despite having only just met them.

entries.name: Gilly Jenkin
entries: {@creature Gilly Jenkin|CrookedMoon24} (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) has known Walter since they were children, and they have loved each other just as long. She is not as devoted to the Druskenvalds as her husband; her concerns lie more with their daughter. She was pregnant with Dani when they first became employed by Mayor Somerton over a decade ago, and she is overly protective of the girl. Gilly feels the presence of the strange forces in Wickermoor Village, and she fears her daughter Dani has some sort of strong connection to these powers.

entries.name: Dani Jenkin
entries: {@creature Dani Jenkin|CrookedMoon24|Dani} (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM}) was born to Walter and Gilly within a couple of weeks of their move to the mayoral manor to serve Mayor Somerton's family. Now ten years old, she senses the ghosts and disturbing forces around her, knowing things a child shouldn't. Though she cannot yet control her abilities, her bond with the powers of the Old Ways grows.

entries.name: Shuck
entries: A red-furred dog that never leaves Dani's side, {@creature Shuck|CrookedMoon24} (Neutral Good {@creature Wolf|XMM}) was a stray before the Jenkins took him in. Unbeknownst to the family, Shuck is the reincarnated soul of Sally Lockwood, a victim of the Crooked House who escaped just before her death. Shuck guards Dani fiercely. If any of the characters are evil, or if they use supernatural abilities that are in any way associated with the Crooked Queen, Shuck growls at them if they get anywhere near Dani.

entries.name: Wisp
entries: The estate's gray cat has earned Walter's affection but terrifies Dani. The cat is no ordinary feline; it is a shapeshifted {@creature Ketgrinn|CrookedMoon24}, a Fey in service to {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}. {@creature Wisp|CrookedMoon24} stole Walter's voice and torments Dani by speaking to her when they are alone. Shuck loathes Wisp, sensing his true nature, and stays close to protect Dani from the lurking evil. If the ketgrinn's true form is exposed and slain, Walter's ability to speak is restored.

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: Although technically renamed to the {@area Druskenvald Estate|188|x} by {@area Mayor Wendel Somerton|161|x}, all of the townsfolk of Wickermoor Village just call it the Crooked House. It is a monument of local lore and suspicion, so there are many reasons to investigate it.

entries.name: Dinner with the Druskenvalds
entries: If the characters accepted {@area Phillip Druskenvald's|01f|x} invitation to dinner after arriving in Wickermoor Village, the couple will have been awaiting them for a fine meal prepared by the Jenkins. This chapter is written under the assumption that the characters followed this quest hook to visit Druskenvald Estate.

entries.name: Weaselly Weasels
entries: While exploring {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}, the characters notice a surprisingly large number of weasels scurrying about the town, eventually seeing {@area Filthy Jasper |22e|x}himself scampering off holding a human tooth. {@area Randall Graham|168|x}, the barber-surgeon, approaches the characters and tells them he has seen the creatures stealing pulled teeth from his shop and scurrying up the hill to the Crooked House. He urges the characters to help put an end to the infestation.

entries.name: A Trip Up the Hill
entries: When the characters leave the village and head northwest toward the hill that holds the {@area Druskenvald Estate|1a6|x}, they are approached by {@area Old Rusty|16c|x}, the village groundskeeper. Read or paraphrase the following:
An old man with wild red-gray hair and filthy clothes scrambles toward you. His eyes darting wildly, he forces words out through labored breathing.
"Death. Doom. Pain. The Crooked Man. The Crooked House. The Crooked Queen. They feed. They laugh. Every step leads to his return. Its return. Her return. Disintegration. Annihilation."

The characters can try to calm Old Rusty, but even if he's made calm, he has nothing coherent to offer the characters. Rusty, whose true identity is {@area Francis Patrini|1b3|x}, was just a child when the Crooked House took his family away 70 years ago, and the traumatic experience left him forever changed.

entries.name: Learning More
entries: If the characters attempt to learn more about the Crooked House and its history, either now or at some other point when they're in {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}, they don't get far. Most of the superstitious locals are so terrified of bringing evil upon themselves that they will not even speak of it out loud.
Even the {@area Newcomers|03c|x}, who pride themselves on reason, dismiss talk of cursed houses as mere fairy tales, unwilling to believe in the supernatural so close to home.

They claim that while some of the families there have had bad luck, those same families may merely have been treating the place as a temporary vacation home before moving away. They genuinely believe—or hope—that the Crooked House is just a house, no matter how spooky its name and reputation are.

The most sinister members of the Followers of the Old Ways (see {@area The Crooked Moon|039|x} and {@area Wickermoor Village|199|x}) know the true history and encourage the notion that the house is perfectly safe. They need the house to feed on as many spirits as possible to quicken the return of the Crooked Queen.

entries.name: Meet the Jenkins
entries: When the characters ascend to the Druskenvald Estate, read or paraphrase the following:

At the top of the hill is a fence with its gate standing open. Beyond the fence is a well-maintained estate featuring a pond, two barns, and a stately, three-story manor home with a wrap-around porch.
While it is not in perfect condition, it is larger and better maintained than many structures in the village. Three people emerge from the nearest barn and wave in your direction.
These people are the Jenkin family: {@area Walter|1b5|x}, {@area Gilly|1b6|x}, and {@area Dani|1b7|x}. At Dani's side is a red-furred dog called {@area Shuck|1b8|x}.

entries.name: The Conversation with the Jenkins
entries: The Jenkin family approaches the characters to greet them, knowing that the Druskenvalds invited the characters to dinner. Use the details below to guide the conversation. Remember that Walter Jenkin can't speak, but he uses hand signs to communicate with his wife and daughter, who can translate. When his family is not with him, he communicates by writing in a small, worn notebook he keeps in his pocket.

items: The Jenkins are on their way to town to buy some necessities and a book for Dani—a rare outing, as they grow food on the estate.
The family has met the Druskenvalds, who just moved in last evening, but {@area Phillip |01f|x} and {@area Adela |020|x} haven't been seen yet tonight.
They were surprised at the arrival of the Druskenvalds—they weren't sure if Phillip and Adela would ever visit—but are pleased to finally meet them.
The Jenkins have a positive outlook on the people of {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}, especially {@area Mayor Somerton|161|x}.

entries: When the conversation ends, the Jenkins wish the characters a pleasant visit with the Druskenvalds, and they pass through the gate and head down the hill toward Wickermoor Village.

Immediately after they part, the gray cat {@area Wisp|1b9|x} strolls placidly out of the bushes, stares for a second at each of the characters individually, lets out a long and sneering "Mrrrreoww...," and then walks away.

entries.name: There Was a Crooked Man
entries: When the characters approach Druskenvald Manor itself, read or paraphrase the following:

As you get closer to the large manor house, a wave of nausea slams into you. Before your eyes, the pleasant, albeit uncanny faade of the building shifts. The house's appearance becomes shadowed and patchy, with mold and rot spreading across its walls. The angles and lines of the walls, eaves, windows, and roofs shift into jarring and impossible angles. It is a house out of a nightmare.
The tidy gardens nearest the house are quickly overgrown with weeds and thistles. Petals, bright and flourishing just seconds before, wilt and drop away. The house now shows decades of disrepair.
A twisted form appears from nowhere on the porch and waves to you. It calls out, "Welcome to the Crooked House, friends. We've been expecting you."

As the characters get closer, describe to them the form of {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man}: a tall, lanky, contorted version of a person. His limbs jut off at odd angles, and his neck bends to the side in the manner of a hanged corpse. Clad in a tattered suit and a bent-top hat that covers his eyes, he smiles with an impossibly large grin filled with crooked, yellow teeth.

entries.name: A Crooked Chat
entries: If the characters strike up a conversation with The Crooked Man, be careful not to give away too much about the plot of the adventure too soon. Let the hints and the foreshadowing start in vague and unsettling means. Some answers he might give to those asking about him include:

items: "Who I am is unimportant. What I am is for you to find out. I am your destiny. You will be crooked too."
"Phillip and Adela are inside, waiting for you. They are getting to know the house. Or, more accurately, the house is getting to know them."
"Phillip, Adela, you, and all your kind are a curse upon this once beautiful land. You will return from whence you came in blood and fire."
"Go on in and enjoy the refreshments I've prepared for you. Phillip and Adela will be with you shortly."

entries.name: Farewell for Now...
entries: If the characters attempt to attack The Crooked Man in any way, he invokes the power of the Crooked House and simply disappears. Otherwise, after The Crooked Man has said everything he has to say, he doffs his hat toward the characters, gives a mocking bow, and vanishes. As if on command, a cacophonous boom of thunder shakes the house, and a violent storm rolls in. The sky opens up with pouring rain and howling winds.

The Crooked Man appears to the characters at least once per floor (see {@area The First Floor|1d3|x}, {@area The Second Floor|1fb|x}, and {@area The Third Floor|20c|x} later in this chapter), but no matter what the characters do, he will not attack them throughout their investigation of the Crooked House. Additionally, you can have him appear and disappear at your discretion to maintain tension and dread throughout this chapter.

entries.name: The Crooked House Features
entries: Unless otherwise noted, the Crooked House has the following features:

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Ceilings are 10 feet high.

entries.name: Crooked Teeth
entries: The Crooked House is filled with human teeth pried from its myriad victims or collected by weasels from under pillows. When a creature fails a Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, rather than spotting or finding nothing, they discover a single human tooth no matter what they're searching for.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Locked ({@dc 15}) or stuck doors (as noted in area descriptions) can be broken down as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action with a successful {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Hallways
entries: Hallways within the Crooked House are 5 feet wide.

entries.name: Indestructible
entries: The Crooked House's structure and windows have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The house's interior locations are unlit. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in the dark.

entries.name: Mementos
entries: Mementos required to gain entry to the Cauldron Room ({@area H17|22a|x}) have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage.

entries.name: Uneven Footing
entries: The unnaturally crooked floors make it difficult to move quickly through the house. Creatures other than the house's denizens that take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or treat the house as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} until the end of the turn.

entries.name: Windows
entries: The windows are sealed and unopenable by any means. Additionally, the windows magically obscure what is inside the house, showing only darkness within when looking through from outside.

entries.name: The First Floor
entries: The first floor of the Crooked House is where the characters first encounter the hauntings of the manor and start to discover the horrors that have happened there.

{@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man} appears in the hallway following the sance in the Parlor ({@area area H3|1dc|x}), brandishing an axe that he swings wildly at the characters. His blows never connect, however, and he shouts, "I cut them down, one by one!" before disappearing.

entries.name: First Floor Locations
entries: Below are the rooms that can be found on the first floor of the Crooked House, corresponding to The Crooked House (First Floor) map.

entries.name: H1: Porch
entries: {@i First Floor}

A deafening crash of thunder rolls through the ancient timbers, rattling the very bones of the house. Lightning splits the sky, striking just feet from the porch as the air crackles with energy. The wind howls, whipping rain in relentless sheets, threatening to drench you to the core.

The porch offers no refuge; the storm seems alive, clawing at you from every side. With nowhere else to go, the Crooked House beckons. The front door creaks open of its own accord, a low groan of invitation—or warning—drawing you inside to investigate.

entries.name: No Escape
entries: A creature that steps off the porch takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Lightning and 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Thunder damage, and appears back on the porch where it tried to leave.

entries.name: H2: Foyer
entries: {@i First Floor}

This ruined foyer might once have been quite grand in its design but now languishes in the decay of decades of neglect. Above, a crooked chandelier sways gently, casting flickering shadows across cracked tiles that stretch toward three closed doors. A staircase twists unnaturally along the wall, leading to a second-floor balcony that looms in darkness. Every inch of the walls is consumed by portraits—families, lifelike yet haunted, with wide, terror-filled eyes that seem to follow your every movement.
The ceiling of the Foyer rises to 20 feet high.

entries.name: Cursed Paintings
entries: These paintings immortalize the families sacrificed within the Crooked House over centuries. Most of the name plaques have been worn away, but with closer inspection, the characters can uncover the tragic history through a few noteworthy portraits described below.

entries.name: The Lockwoods
entries: The patriarch in this portrait bears an unsettling resemblance to {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man}. The plaque, though weathered, reveals the names: Eustace Lockwood, his wife {@area Petunia|1ad|x}, their daughter {@area Sally|1ae|x}, their infant son {@area Arthur|1af|x}, and Petunia's frail mother, {@area Keziah|1b0|x}. Standing beside them are their servants—{@area Joseph|1b1|x} and {@area Gail Patrini|1b2|x}, along with their son {@area Francis|1b3|x}.

items.name: The Druskenvalds
items.entry: The familiar faces in this portrait are rendered in a chilling light. Though the characters cannot know it, this painting foreshadows the Druskenvalds' doom. {@area Adela|020|x} stands uncharacteristically stoic, adorned with a woven wicker choker and vibrant red and orange flowers in her hair. {@area Phillip|01f|x} is weeping, a black crown of six points atop his head and a crescent moon pin glinting from his right lapel.

items.name: The Characters
items.entry: The most shocking of all is the final portrait—it features the characters themselves. They grin widely in the frame, but their mouths are empty, void of teeth, their hollow smiles a haunting omen.

entries: Vessla Browntooth laid curses on the portraits. A character who examines the paintings must succeed on a {@dc 10} Charisma saving throw or take 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Psychic damage and be cursed. When the cursed character rolls a 1 on a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, a {@creature Boogleswarm|CrookedMoon24} emerges from cracks or holes in the walls and attacks that character immediately. That character can't trigger the curse's effect again until they finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. This curse lasts for 24 hours or until the character leaves the Crooked House.

entries.name: H3: Parlor
entries: {@i First Floor}
When the characters enter the Parlor, read or paraphrase the following:

This parlor contains furnishings with once-elegant upholstery now caked with dust. On a circular table by the cobweb-choked fireplace is a wooden spirit board of impeccable craftsmanship. A small heart-shaped planchette rests atop it, engraved with the initials "A.D."

This spirit board clearly belongs to Adela Druskenvald and can be used to conduct a sance that can give the characters critical information to unravel the mysteries of the Crooked House. A character who succeeds on a {@dc 10} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check knows that to begin the sance, two or more characters must place a hand on the planchette and ask if there is a spirit in the room.

If two or more characters agree to use the spirit board, it summons the spirit of Joseph Patrini, the servant who was murdered by Eustace Lockwood 70 years ago. A pleasant fire crackles to life in the fireplace, and the planchette moves to "HELLO."

The spirit board has numbers, letters, and the words "YES," "NO," "HELLO," and "GOODBYE." If one of the characters using the spirit board asks a question, the spirit of Joseph Patrini will answer to the best of his ability.

His memories are muddled, clouded by time and the horrors he's witnessed, and though far from omnipotent, he remembers the night of Eustace Lockwood's rampage with grim clarity. He knows of the hag lurking in the attic and the six cursed mementos that will unlock the hidden chamber where she waits.

You can decide what information to provide and what to hold back, but if clever questions are asked, be sure to reward the characters with useful information. Use this opportunity to provide clues, foreshadow, and increase the tension. Below are some possible questions and answers to guide your own play:

entries.name: Who are you
entries: PATRINI

entries.name: Are Phillip and Adela here
entries: YES

entries.name: Where are they
entries: UPSTAIRS

entries.name: How did you die
entries: MURDER

entries.name: Who killed you
entries: EUSTACE LOCKWOOD

entries.name: Who is responsible for this
entries: HAG

entries.name: Where is the hag
entries: ATTIC

entries.name: How do we get to the attic
entries: 6 MEMENTOS

entries.name: What are the mementos
entries: GEM KEY CUP DOLL BEAR PIN

entries.name: Where are they
entries: EVERY FLOOR

Roll {@dice 1d10} every time the characters ask a question. On a 1, every character using the board takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) Psychic damage. For each damage roll after the first, increase the damage die as follows: {@dice 1d6}, {@dice 1d8}, {@dice 1d10}, and to a maximum of {@dice 1d12}.

As the sance draws to its close, Patrini offers one final, urgent message. This is your chance to reveal any critical information the characters may have overlooked. If they have gathered all the necessary clues, Patrini's final words are etched in chilling clarity: "FIND MY SON HE LIVES." This refers to {@area Old Rusty|16c|x}, the groundskeeper of Wickermoor Village.

The planchette slowly drags itself to "GOODBYE," and the fire in the hearth extinguishes with a hiss, plunging the room into a suffocating darkness. Any attempts to resume the sance are met only with cold, dead silence.

entries.name: Mementos
entries: A list of the locations of the six mementos needed to break the barrier to reach {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x} is included in {@area area H16|220|x}.

entries.name: H4: Gallery
entries: {@i First Floor}
When the characters enter the Gallery, read or paraphrase the following:

This circular room, built into the base of the manor's turret, houses a modest gallery. Paintings of sweeping landscapes and dour busts of forgotten historical figures dominate the space, their placards forever faded from the decades of neglect. The most prominent piece in this collection sits in an alcove at the far end of the room. Carved from weathered marble is a larger-than-life statue of an albino peacock. One eye socket is empty, and the other features a dull red bloodstone.

The landscapes in the room were all feverishly painted by {@area Keziah Endicott|1b0|x} in the final year of her life, inspired by her dreams in the Crooked House. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who inspects the paintings and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check discovers her signature and that each one contains hidden weasels, centipedes, and pigeons, all grotesque.

The peacock statue animates and attacks (use the {@creature Basilisk|XMM} stat block, except it is a Construct) when a creature attempts to remove its bloodstone. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 of each round, the twisted spirit of Keziah appears and randomly selects a character, who must succeed on a {@dc 10} Charisma saving throw or vanish and be drawn into a demiplane inside the landscape painting. While there, the character has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition and can't be targeted by attacks, spells, or other effects. At the end of their next turn, the character is expelled from the painting and lands in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it with the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. When the peacock is defeated, it crumbles to pieces, and the shade of Keziah vanishes with an unsettling cackle.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The red bloodstone gem eye of the peacock statue is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic.

entries.name: H5: Music Room
entries: {@i First Floor}

A scattered array of decaying instruments surrounds the wooden dance floor at the room's center, its boards blackened with age and splintered by time's cruel hand. On the wall, a large oval mirror hangs, its long, jagged crack twisting the room's reflection into a crooked mockery, where, through the fractured glass, everything appears stretched and warped. At the far end, a harpsichord stands, its lid propped open like a yawning casket, its rusted wires stretched like the brittle tendons of some forgotten corpse. The yellowed ivory keys lie exposed, tangled with cobwebs.

When a character steps onto the dance floor, the harpsichord begins playing a discordant melody that can be heard throughout the first floor of the Crooked House, and the mirror shows the room filled with distorted spectral dancers while the song plays. These are spirits of people sacrificed in the Crooked House over the years.

Roll Initiative! Any creature that can hear the music must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, the creature must use all its movement on its turn to dance erratically without leaving its space and takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Psychic damage. The creature repeats the save at the end of its turn, ending the effect on itself on a success. For every three consecutive turns a creature dances in this way, it gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level.

items.name: Weasels
items.entry: When {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is rolled, 7 ({@dice 3d4}) {@creature Weasel|XMM|Weasels} scurry out of the walls and attack, speaking with one voice: "Vessla Browntooth will sacrifice your souls!"

entries.name: Harpsichord
entries: The harpsichord has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage. To stop the discordant music, a character must sit down at the harpsichord and attempt to play a different song. The character must make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) check. On a success the music stops, ending the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition caused by the music. If the character is not proficient in any type of Musical Instrument, they experience a supernatural ability to play this harpsichord with the assistance of {@area Joseph Patrini|1b1|x}, the benevolent spirit that the characters can commune with in the Parlor ({@area area H3|1dc|x}).

When the discordant melody ends, the shimmering blue spirit of Patrini appears at the harpsichord and plays a melancholic song, wistfully singing about better times and the fall of the Lockwood household. The lyrics are as follows:

{@i How I long to see the glow of fire's face in my window.} {@i How tender she'd dispel the night and fill my heart with amber light.} {@i Those radiant hours now fade in me slowly, and time, bereft, drifts icy and lonely.} {@i Where shrieking death stripped life from their bones, and all light now gone from a house I called home.} {@i Let there come a wind to drive light in and let life in my home again.}
The spirit of Patrini then fades, and a single black ivory key pops out of the harpsichord, clattering to the floor.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The black ivory harpsichord key is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic.

entries.name: H6: Dining Room
entries: {@i First Floor}
When the characters enter the Dining Room, read or paraphrase the following:
A grand dining table commands the center of the room, its surface unnervingly clean amidst the dust-choked neglect that clings to the surrounding chairs, sideboard, and cabinets.

But most unsettling of all is the feast spread across the table—a garish display of roasted boar, poultry, fish, and other meats, laid out on gleaming silver platters. Plates of sauted vegetables, bowls of rich gravy, and trays of sweets complete the banquet, their aroma intoxicating, almost too perfect. The air is replete with the scent of the feast, but beneath the savory allure lingers a sense of apprehension, as if the meal is waiting for more than just a bite.

The food and tablecloth come to life when the characters approach the table, twisting into a putrid-smelling abomination and a smothering cloth. An {@creature Ochre Jelly|XMM} and an {@creature Animated Rug of Smothering|XMM} attack the characters until they're destroyed.

entries.name: Feast of Fury
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), one of the foul food items makes a ranged attack against a random character within the Dining Room as it flies toward them. Roll on the Phantom Feast table to determine what food or implement attacks.

entries.caption: Phantom Feast
rows: Sugar Bowl. +5 to hit; 6 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}) Bludgeoning damage; target has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.
Roast Fish. +4 to hit; 4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2}) Bludgeoning damage; target has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.
Lobster Claw. +5 to hit; 9 ({@dice 1d12 + 3}) Slashing damage.

Creampuff. +4 to hit; no damage; character is suffocating with no chance to hold their breath. The character, or another creature within reach, can take a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to clear the dessert from their throat and end the suffocation.

Beef Tongue. +4 to hit; no damage; character must succeed on {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} and {@condition Grappled|XPHB} conditions (escape {@dc 15}), and they have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can rifle through the food and succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to find a cloudy {@item Pearl of Power|XDMG} and a gold ring worth 75 GP.

entries.name: H7: Kitchen
entries: {@i First Floor}

The kitchen lies in utter ruin, its floor littered with shards of broken pottery and rusted cutlery. A heavy metal shelf has collapsed, ripping chunks of plaster from the wall and crushing a table beneath its weight. Nearby, a hulking brick oven stands ominously, its iron door sealed shut by a thick, rusted lock.

Suddenly, the greasy stench of burning flesh fills the air as black smoke seeps through the cracks around the oven door. Muffled screams and frantic pounding echo from within, as though something—or someone—is trapped inside.

This is no ordinary fire, but a cruel ruse crafted by the malevolent spirits bound to the Crooked House. The agonized sounds lure the characters into action, tempting them to open the Lock or force the door. The moment they try, the trap is sprung. The iron door bursts open with a thunderous crash, revealing the shrieking, flaming souls trapped within. A wave of blistering heat and acrid smoke floods the Kitchen, choking and unrelenting, as the trapped spirits scream their torment into the air.

Each creature in the Kitchen must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Fire damage and 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Acid damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Then the burning spirits disappear, and the oven goes cold.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a creature that examines the Lock before interacting with it can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to notice the faintly glowing glyph, which can be disarmed as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check. Failing the check by 5 or more sets off the trap.

entries.name: H8: Conservatory
entries: {@i First Floor}

Rain hammers against the glass walls and ceiling of the conservatory, while desiccated vines and withered shrubs choke the space. Benches are interspersed throughout the ruin, and one faces a shockingly vibrant tree—its green fruit the only sign of life in the decayed room. Seated upon the bench is a pale woman in a black mourning gown, a faded green ribbon tied around her neck. In her hands, she cradles a delicate porcelain teacup filled with dark liquid, her gaze lost in distant memories.

This is the spirit of {@area Petunia Lockwood|1ad|x} manifested. She uses the {@creature Wight|XMM} stat block, except her alignment is Neutral and she only has the Life Drain action.
