She gazes wistfully at the thriving bergamot tree—the same one she tended in life, whose fruit flavored the tea she holds. Petunia doesn't notice the characters until they speak or approach her directly.

Petunia's fragmented memories cling only to the life she once knew; she remembers nothing of the horrors that have befallen her family. The twisted nature of {@area The Crooked Man|1ab|x}, {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}, and the primordial power of the Crooked House remain beyond her understanding. The characters will need her cup, a precious heirloom, as one of the six mementos to break the barrier to the attic, but Petunia will not part with it easily.

As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can convince her to give them the cup with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check, made with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if they appeal to her love for her children, {@area Sally|1ae|x} and {@area Arthur|1af|x}. If Petunia hands over the cup, she implores them to help her children before fading peacefully into the gloom. If the characters show Petunia both the wooden doll from {@area area H10|200|x} and the blue teddy bear from {@area area H13|20e|x}, they succeed automatically.

However, should the characters try to intimidate Petunia or forcefully take the cup, her sorrow twists into rage. She attacks, her grief transforming into fury as she seeks to drag the characters into her eternal mourning.

entries.name: The Green Ribbon
entries: The green ribbon Petunia wears falls away if she is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or if a character forcibly removes it. To remove it, Petunia must have the {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB}, or {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition, and a character must take the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength or Dexterity check (the character's choice). When the ribbon comes undone her head rolls from her body, causing blood to spray around the room. Creatures within a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from her are drenched in her blood and must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Necrotic damage. Once her head rolls off, she is destroyed and fades away.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Petunia's {@item Green Ribbon|CrookedMoon24} falls to the ground and is left behind after she fades away, whether in peace or violence. The white porcelain teacup is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic.

entries.name: The Second Floor
entries: The second floor is where the characters continue their investigation and collection of the mementos needed to eventually reach {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x}.

The {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24} appears in the hallway following the exploration of the Master Bedroom ({@area area H12|207|x}), swinging from a noose fastened to the ceiling. He slams into the walls and shakes the whole house, exclaiming, "I couldn't live with the guilt!" before disappearing.

entries.name: Second Floor Locations
entries: Below are the rooms that can be found on the second floor of the Crooked House as shown on The Crooked House (Second Floor) map. This floor is accessible from the stairway in the Foyer ({@area area H2|1d8|x}).

entries.name: H9: Sitting Room
entries: {@i Second Floor}

This formal sitting room looks over the foyer past the cracked wooden railing, providing a direct view of the tilted dust-covered chandelier. The finely crafted furniture is now shrouded by cobwebs, and the shelves that flank the window are filled with all manner of antiques. An ancient grandfather clock ticks away despite the decades of dereliction.

As the characters begin to investigate the room, the clock hands spin violently and then stop at 12 o'clock. The chimes strike out, and on the twelfth chime, each character on the first or second floors must succeed on a {@dc 10} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, a character gains the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. A character in the Sitting Room that is {@condition Frightened|XPHB} in this way can't leave the room by any means. At the same time, a shrieking spirit covered in biting weasels emerges from the clock. The {@creature Boogleswarm|CrookedMoon24} consumes the apparition in an instant and then turns on the characters.

The minute hand on the clock moves rapidly back around to 12 o'clock. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20, the clock chimes, warning of what's happening. On the fifth chime, another spirit emerges with a new boogleswarm ravaging it. The clock continues to chime while the characters are in the room.

As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can disable the gears on the clock with a successful {@dc 10} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}. The clock has AC 15, HP 5, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage. Disabling the gears or destroying the clock stops more spirits and weasels from appearing.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: All that is left of the devoured spirits is a gold pocket watch worth 100 GP with the words "Remember the Third" etched into the back.

entries.name: H10: Children's Room
entries: {@i Second Floor}

This children's bedroom has a pair of tiny beds flanking a darkened window. Toys are strewn carelessly across the floor. A large, weathered toy chest sits against the wall, facing a child's armoire, while in the corner, the closet door hangs slightly ajar.

Suddenly, from a pile of letter blocks, a small wooden doll clambers forward, its painted face chipped and its yarn hair frayed. It trembles with fear, raising its tiny arms toward you, its voice soft and innocent: "Please! Please check for monsters!"

The doll contains a fragment of {@area Sally Lockwood's|1ae|x} soul forever bound to the Crooked House, despite her escape and eventual reincarnation into {@area Shuck|1b8|x}. It is terrified of the bogeyman that it believes is waiting to devour it. There is indeed a {@creature Lurker in the Dark|CrookedMoon24} hiding in the shadows of the room, which must be destroyed before the fragment of Sally's soul can be soothed.

There are six possible spots where the lurker might be hiding. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can check one of these locations and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. On a success, roll on the Lurking Shadows table. If the result is the same as the location being checked, the character finds the lurker, which attacks until it is destroyed. If the result doesn't match, the character finds nothing but hears a scraping sound from the location rolled.

entries.caption: Lurking Shadows
rows: In the Closet
Under the Left Bed
Under the Right Bed
In the Toy Chest
In the Armoire
Outside the Window

entries: If the lurker is discovered outside the window, it begins combat by using Dark Teleport to appear next to the character who discovered it. If it isn't revealed in six attempts, the lurker attacks from the ceiling, surprising the characters. Once the lurker is destroyed, the wooden doll climbs onto the left bed and settles in comfortably before becoming inanimate as the soul fragment is put to rest.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The wooden doll is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic. The characters gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} for putting Sally to rest.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who looks through the closet and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check notices an eye move on a satchel ({@item The Bag|CrookedMoon24}) hanging behind dusty children's clothes. The first character who touches the satchel automatically becomes attuned to it. If the character is already attuned to three magic items, they must choose one of those to which their {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} ends.

entries.name: H11: Bathroom
entries: {@i Second Floor}

This oddly warm and humid bathroom is filled with steam, nearly shrouding a crumbling sink and cracked bathtub with clawed feet. There are streaks of mold across the tiled walls and floor that fill the room with a pungent odor.

When the characters investigate the bathtub, they find that the inside is stained a bright red, and blood begins bubbling up from the drain in the tub. The door slams shut and locks as the room rapidly fills with putrid blood.

entries.name: The Blood Rises
entries: Roll Initiative! The level of blood rises dramatically on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), completely filling the room on the fourth round. Once the room completely fills, each creature in the Bathroom must hold its breath or begin suffocating.

It is not possible to plug the drain, and the only way to escape is out the way the characters came in. The door is locked ({@dc 20}). Unlocking or breaking down the door lets the foul blood empty out into the hallway in a gush, and any creatures in the room end up in the hallway with the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

items.name: Weasels
items.entry: When {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is rolled, 7 ({@dice 3d4}) {@creature Weasel|XMM|Weasels} scurry out of the walls and attack, speaking with one voice: "Vessla Browntooth will drink your blood!" The weasels are unhindered by the blood.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A wooden bath toy in the form of a yellow duck washes out with the blood. It acts as a {@item Figurine of Wondrous Power, Silver Raven|XDMG|Figurine of Wondrous Power (Silver Raven)} but with a duck instead of a raven.

entries.name: H12: Master Bedroom
entries: {@i Second Floor}

A large bed with a torn canopy is the centerpiece of this room that's complete with a bent wardrobe, pock-marked nightstands, and a cracked vanity. The far end of the room features a double door that leads to a second-story balcony. Beside the door stands a dusty writing desk, atop which sits a beautiful black leather journal adorned with silver embossed initials that read "P.D."
Beneath the faded covers of the master bed, a human-sized shape squirms frantically, as if in the throes of a terrible nightmare.

The creature under the covers is {@area Vessla Browntooth's|1a8|x} familiar {@area Filthy Jasper|22e|x} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Weasel)|CrookedMoon24}), who writhes and wriggles in one of {@area Phillip Druskenvald's|01f|x} suits along with twelve {@creature Weasel|XMM|Weasels}. They attack when the covers of the bed are pulled back, or if he is attacked in some way before that happens. Jasper and the weasels speak with one voice: "Vessla Browntooth will live in your nightmares!" Dozens of human teeth are scattered throughout the bedding.
When Filthy Jasper is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, he attempts to escape the room through a window, the balcony doors, or a hole in the wall, easily passing through if he makes it that far.

entries.name: Journal
entries: Phillip Druskenvald's journal is locked ({@dc 10}), or it can be broken easily as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action.

Reading the journal reveals that the moment Phillip entered Wickermoor Hollow, he lost the fearsome powers of a lord of death that he possesses everywhere else in Druskenvald. He has no guesses as to why this happened and has a feeling of dread that grows larger every night. {@area Adela|020|x} has pleaded with him to try to leave Wickermoor Hollow before the {@i Ghostlight Express} returns, but Phillip talked her into agreeing to stay so they both might face their fears and come out stronger in the end.

Phillip has his doubts but is willing to try to uncover the reason he's lost his powers. He also has learned from the Jenkins about how dangerous and deadly life in Wickermoor Hollow is, especially away from the village. He wants to help the people of the hollow and earn back the trust he lost by neglecting the minor province for so long.

You can use this opportunity to include any additional information about Druskenvald, Phillip and Adela, and the Crescent Court that you wish to convey (see {@book Druskenvald|CrookedMoon|1} chapter of {@book The Crooked Moon Part One|CrookedMoon} and The {@i Ghostlight Express}).

entries.name: Balcony
entries: The double door that leads to the second-floor balcony is locked ({@dc 15}).

entries.name: No Escape
entries: A character who jumps or climbs off the balcony takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Lightning damage plus 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Thunder damage and appears back on the balcony.

entries.name: The Third Floor
entries: The third floor is where the characters finally discover the secret door to the attic.

The {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24} appears in the hallway following the exploration of the Nursery ({@area area H13|20e|x}), bent and folded into a nearly rectangular shape. He shuffles across the floor as the sound of snapping bones fills the air, proclaiming, "She stuffed me into a crack in the foundation!" before disappearing.

entries.name: Third Floor Locations
entries: Below are the rooms that can be found on the third floor of the Crooked House as shown on The Crooked House (Third Floor) map. This floor can be accessed by the staircase on the second-floor hall near the Children's Room ({@area area H10|200|x}).

entries.name: H13: Nursery
entries: {@i Third Floor}

The moment the door creaks open, an infant's wail pierces the air, sharp and relentless, clawing at your nerves. The room, a nursery, is filled with ordinary furnishings, yet the centerpieces—the mahogany crib and cradle—are riddled with countless tiny holes. The cradle rocks violently, and within it, a squirming, shrieking infant shimmers with a spectral blue glow, its cries filling the room with an overwhelming sense of dread.

This is the spirit of {@area Arthur Lockwood|1af|x}, trapped within the cradle, his ghostly form writhing with distress. No matter what the characters attempt, Arthur remains inconsolable—his cries never ceasing, echoing in the space like a terrible, oppressive weight. Only his beloved blue teddy bear in the crib can calm him.

entries.name: Stuffed Animals
entries: When the characters investigate the crib, they find four worn stuffed animals: a black goat, an antlered bunny, and a round crow, all of which surround a blue teddy bear. If any of them are moved, touched, or otherwise disturbed, the goat, bunny, and crow animate and attack. Use the {@creature Quasit|XMM} stat block for the three stuffed animals. When defeated, they revert to their inanimate form, purged of the malevolent spirits that possessed them.

On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), Arthur's wails grow loud enough that all creatures within the Crooked House can hear them. Creatures other than the house's denizens that can hear the crying must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.

Once Arthur has his bear, he can finally be soothed as an {@action Influence|XPHB} action with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check to talk to him gently, or a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) check to sing him a soothing lullaby.
When Arthur finally stops crying, he raises his hands up to the character who succeeded in calming him down. Once the spectral baby is picked up and held, he falls asleep and fades peacefully.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The blue teddy bear is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic. The characters gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} for putting Arthur to rest.

entries.name: H14: Library
entries: {@i Third Floor}

This cluttered library is filled with sagging bookshelves close to bursting with dusty tomes. More books litter the stained rug below. A cobweb-choked liquor cart leans precariously against a once-sturdy desk at the center of the room.
A leaning stack of old books rests on the desk, and sitting atop that, a gray cat observes you with large golden eyes. It opens its mouth and speaks with the voice of a man. "Tell me a tale."

This cat is {@area Wisp|1b9|x}, the cat taken in by the Jenkin family that is actually a shape-shifted, Chaotic Evil {@creature Ketgrinn|CrookedMoon24}. He speaks with the stolen voice of {@area Walter Jenkin|1b5|x}, although the characters would have no way of knowing this. He is clearly alive and not a spirit.

Wisp is a minion of {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x} and is hoping to trick the characters into writing their stories into a book, giving the ketgrinn a tether to their souls. Wisp acts benevolent and lies as much as possible to encourage the characters to simply share a story with him. A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check reveals that the cat has wicked intentions.
If the characters attack, threaten, or show hostility toward Wisp, he shifts into his true form and attempts to escape out the window, which he can pass through effortlessly.

entries.name: Spin a Yarn
entries: If a character tells a story, Wisp deems the story acceptable if the character succeeds on a {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB}) check. As a story is told, one of the books on the table opens, and the pages are filled with words and illustrations matching what the character shared. After three books are filled, Wisp thanks the characters and winks at them before disappearing.

As the cat vanishes, a sense of magical whimsy washes over the characters. They can immediately expend {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} as if they finished a Short Rest, and they add a +4 bonus to each Hit Die expended.

entries.name: The Catch
entries: 5 minutes after Wisp leaves the library, any character who shared a story that was written in a book must succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw or have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, the character attacks the nearest creature using their most powerful attack or spell for 1 minute. A {@condition Charmed|XPHB} character makes a {@dc 10} Charisma saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on themself on a success.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Four of the bottles on the liquor cart are medicinal tonics ({@item Potion of Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing}).

entries.name: H15: Trophy Room
entries: {@i Third Floor}

This moldering trophy room is teeming with stuffed creatures of all varieties—standing on the floor, resting on tables, placed in display cases, or mounted on walls. Each of these trophies is frighteningly uncanny, with figures in unnatural poses, enormous glass eyes, and strangely bulging hides.

This is the threshold to the secret attic door, which is hidden beneath layers of shadow and sealed by a powerful magical barrier. Should the characters touch the trapdoor, these creatures defend the entrance to the attic.

entries.name: Secret Trapdoor
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to spot the trapdoor hidden in the ceiling. When the trapdoor is opened, it pulls downward, releasing a folding wooden ladder that leads into {@area area H16|220|x}.
When a character touches the trap door, read or paraphrase the following:

Without warning, the creatures around you begin to convulse and writhe—hissing, barking, howling, flapping, yipping—all merging into a maddening cacophony that claws at your mind. Amidst the frenzy, you feel a force burrow into your psyche—its source, which provoked this eruption of madness, remains veiled in the frenzy of limbs and snarls.

entries.name: Psychic Roar
entries: Roll Initiative! On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the stuffed brown bear within this room emits a pulse of psychic energy, and each character must succeed on a {@dc 10} Intelligence saving throw or take 1 Psychic damage.

On the second round, the DC increases to 11, and the damage increases to 2 ({@dice 1d4}). On the third round, the DC is 12 and the damage is 3 ({@dice 1d6}). On the fourth and subsequent rounds until the pulse is stopped, the DC is 13 and the damage 4 ({@dice 1d8}).

The characters can locate and destroy the instigating trophy causing the psychic pulse using various ability checks. A total of three successful checks allows the characters to locate the focus of this source: the brown bear in the northeast corner of the room. Each successive check helps the characters narrow it down more. The DC is 14, but after a successful ability check, further uses of the same check increase by 3.

For example, if the first character succeeds on a {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, the next Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check is {@dc 17}, and the third is {@dc 20}. However, if the second check attempted was an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check instead, the DC would only be 14 instead of 17. Therefore, different tactics working together are more effective than one tactic used repeatedly.
Use the following checks as a guide for what characters might attempt—and be flexible:

items: Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) to notice where the noises are loudest and the movements more visible.
Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) to discern patterns and direction in the noise and motion.
Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) to focus on the arcane energies and their most likely points of emanation.
Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Medicine|XPHB}) can observe the other characters in the room and how they are reacting to the pulse based on their location in the room.
Spells like {@spell Detect Magic|XPHB} can't find the exact source but can narrow the focus and count as one automatic success. The same spell can't generate another success.

entries: After three successful checks, or any alternative solutions to the problem you deem effective, the characters locate the stuffed brown bear.

items.name: Weasels
items.entry: When {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is rolled, 7 ({@dice 3d4}) {@creature Weasel|XMM|Weasels} scurry out of the walls and attack, speaking with one voice: "Vessla Browntooth will eat your flesh!"

entries.name: Spirit Inside
entries: When the characters identify the instigating bear, they also discover that a woman has been sewn inside with only her face sticking out of the bear's neck beneath its crooked snout. This is the spirit of {@area Gail Patrini|1b2|x}, who joins the bestial chorus with her own roars.

As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a creature can rip open the taxidermized bear, freeing the spirit and the many pounds of sawdust the bear had been stuffed with. Gail looks confused and says nothing but pulls herself free from the hide. She then removes a silver pin from her hair and stabs it into the bear's nose before fading with a bewildered and strangely bestial grunt.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The silver hairpin is one of the six mementos needed to break through the barrier into the attic.

entries.name: The Attic
entries: This is where {@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x} lives and performs her vile magic. She has captured {@area Phillip|01f|x} and {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}, keeping them in a stupor of feverish nightmares. She has been performing a ritual in her Cauldron Room ({@area area H17|22a|x}) in preparation for the sacrifice of Phillip and Adela within. She has been alerted to the characters' coming by the weasels that scurry through the walls and has laid a trap for them.

entries.name: Attic Locations
entries: Below are the rooms that can be found in the attic of the Crooked House as shown on The Crooked House (Attic) map. This floor can be accessed through the trap door in the Trophy Room ({@area area H15|217|x}).

entries.name: H16: Secret Landing
entries: {@i Attic}

The cramped space at the top of the ladder is bathed in an eerie, blood-red glow, cast from runic symbols etched into the wooden walls, floor, and ceiling. Each marking pulses with a sinister energy, as if alive with some ancient, malignant force. On the wall opposite the trap door, a small door shimmers with the same haunting light, its glow flickering like a silent, unholy invitation into whatever darkness lies beyond.
This is the final attic chamber before {@area Vessla's|1a8|x} Cauldron Room ({@area area H17|22a|x}). The door and the wall it's built into are

entries.name: Mementos
entries: A character who examines the symbols finds six empty circles in the runic markings perfectly sized for the six mementos the characters have been collecting throughout the Crooked House:

entries.name: Gem
entries: {@area Keziah Endicott's|1b0|x} bloodstone, found in the Gallery ({@area area H4|1e9|x}).

entries.name: Key
entries: {@area Joseph Patrini's|1b1|x} harpsichord key, found in the Music Room ({@area area H5|1ec|x}).

entries.name: Cup
entries: {@area Petunia Lockwood's|1ad|x} teacup, found in the Conservatory ({@area area H8|1f7|x}).

entries.name: Doll
entries: {@area Sally Lockwood's|1ae|x} doll, found in the Children's Room ({@area area H10|200|x}).

entries.name: Bear
entries: {@area Arthur Lockwood's|1af|x} teddy bear, found in the Nursery ({@area area H13|20e|x}).

entries.name: Pin
entries: {@area Gail Patrini's|1b2|x} hairpin, found in the Trophy Room ({@area area H15|217|x}).

When the six mementos are carefully placed into the vacant slots within the glowing runic circles, the room fills with a rising, arcane energy. The air crackles, and the barrier before you shimmers, wavering as if resisting for one final moment, before fading into nothingness with a soft, eerie hiss. The door, now unlocked, creaks open, revealing a dark passage.

This passage leads to the Cauldron Room—where Vessla Browntooth awaits. The final confrontation looms, her presence already thick in the air, beckoning the characters toward the showdown that will decide all.

entries.name: H17: Cauldron Room
entries: {@i Attic}

The floor of this secret attic room is covered with human teeth that crunch beneath your feet. At the center of the chamber looms a massive cauldron, its bubbling contents glowing an eerie red, casting flickering shadows across the walls. Bound and slumped against either side of the cauldron, barely conscious, are Phillip and Adela, their wrists raw from the ropes that bind them.
Beyond the cauldron, a cloaked figure sways and moves in strange, erratic jerks, as though her joints do not bend quite right. Her back remains turned, oblivious to your arrival.

The cauldron gurgles violently, the vile red ichor within roiling over the rim. Each drop that spills hisses against the floor, eating away at the wood with a harsh, acidic burn, filling the air with a noxious stench. Time is slipping away, and the hag, Vessla Browntooth, is just moments from completing her profane ritual.

{@area Vessla Browntooth|1a8|x} ({@creature Weasel Hag|CrookedMoon24}) lurks here, waiting and ready to strike, having been warned by her precious weasels. The cloaked figure is really Adela, suffering the horror of nightmarish visions. She has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} and {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} conditions, and her {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0. The hag Vessla has taken Adela's form, and lays on the floor pretending to be {@condition unconscious|XPHB}.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character within 10 feet of the false "Adela" or the cloaked figure can examine one or both and succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check to see through the ruse.

entries.name: Surprise
entries: If a character approaches Vessla, who is in the form of Adela, without succeeding on the check to inspect her, the hag surprises the characters when she attacks. The first time she hits a creature with a Bite attack, if that creature hasn't yet taken a turn in the combat, she can also dunk the creature's head into the bubbling cauldron. The target takes an extra 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Acid damage.
Whether Vessla manages to surprise the characters or not, read or paraphrase the following once combat begins:
The weasel-like hag hisses and lunges forward as she shrieks in a shrill voice, "Your souls will join the sacrifice, and you are damned to forever wander the halls of the Crooked House!"

entries.name: Filthy Jasper
entries: If {@creature Filthy Jasper|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Weasel)|CrookedMoon24}) escaped earlier in {@area area H12|207|x}, the familiar is here to assist his master in the battle. Any damage he took previously remains.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Moon|070|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the character this card was pulled for receives three Twists of Fate after defeating Vessla Browntooth. Once per turn, when a creature the character can see makes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, the character can expend one {@area Twist of Fate|081|x} to replace the {@dice d20} roll with a 1 or a 20. When all three twists are expended, the boon vanishes.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 4, if they are still at level 3, when they defeat Vessla Browntooth.

entries.name: Conclusion: Haunted No More
entries: After the characters have defeated Vessla Browntooth, read or paraphrase the following:
Vessla Browntooth's eyes fill with a sudden realization mixed with terror and rage as she draws her final breath, whispering out "Sisters..." before collapsing into a pile of human teeth.

Suddenly, the Crooked House begins to shake and creak. With the terrible crunching of breaking wood and creaking nails, the house takes on a new shape that is still crooked but vastly less so. The years of disrepair fade, and its new form is a manor home fit for the Druskenvalds.

With the hag defeated, {@area Phillip|01f|x} and {@area Adela|020|x} regain their senses and thank the characters, both thrilled to be alive. All they remember is preparing for dinner and then passing out and experiencing horrific nightmares until rescued.

Most of {@area Vessla's|1a8|x} work in the Cauldron Room vanished when the house returned to its more pleasing configuration, but scratchings in the attic reveal that this hag was just the first of three in the {@area Vermintoll Coven|024|x}. The names of her sisters are among the scratchings: {@area Stonoga Blackstinger|3d7|x} and {@area Golub Graygullet|656|x}. Hundreds of human teeth remain, littering the floor.

Despite the horrors the characters witnessed in the Crooked House, Phillip decides to stay in the mansion while in Wickermoor Village. Phillip is hopeful that whatever curse has been afflicting him will now be lifted. He pays each character 75 GP for their assistance. Phillip and Adela insists the characters get some rest and take their time exploring Wickermoor Village.

When the Jenkins return to the Druskenvald Estate, they are mortified to discover what had transpired but are relieved that the haunting has been purged. If the characters mention the library encounter with {@area Wisp|1b9|x}, the family finds it hard to believe but are unable to find the cat from then on.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: Back in the village, little has changed, and none of the townsfolk noticed anything strange about the Druskenvald Estate.

{@area The Crooked Man|1ab|x} visited the nefarious members of the Followers of the Old Ways, and informed them that the final plans are in motion and the return of the Crooked Queen is near (see {@area The Crooked Moon|02c|x}). The secret cultists try to conveniently "run into" the characters around town and go out of their way to gain their trust.

With Vessla Browntooth dead, the weasels that lived in the walls of the Crooked House have scattered and fled into Wickermoor Village, still influenced by their master's spirit, which is tethered to Wickermoor Hollow. They can be found scurrying through the back alleys and in the walls of the town, particularly lingering around {@area Randall's Barber Shop|168|x} to steal pulled teeth.

data.name: Fields of the Crow

entries: The crows sing. The fields remember. With every rustle of the stalks, every whispered secret, I feed. Come now. Let the stalks say your name. Let the crows sing your story. I'll harvest what you hide.

A demon has come to Foxwillow. Once a quiet town cradled by endless cornfields, now these fields devour any who dares enter. They belong to {@area Raum|239|x}, {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24}—a demonic scarecrow with the head of a crow, cursed with an insatiable hunger for secrets. His very being is nourished by forbidden truths, yet he doesn't merely feed on them. He weaves them into chaos, turning neighbor against neighbor, sowing discord as effortlessly as seeds. Only the destruction of Raum can save this once-peaceful town.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: East of {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4} lies the town of Foxwillow, known far and wide as the breadbasket of Wickermoor Hollow. The people of this idyllic town are friendly, rural folk. They worship the {@area Patient Lady|03a|x}, dutifully tend to the fields, help one another, and never speak ill of other souls... to their faces, at least. But evil lurks below the faade.

Secret resentments have multiplied in recent months, darkening Foxwillow like the shadow cast by a murder of crows. People have grown suspicious of others, certain their neighbors harbor vile secrets. Crops have failed (sparing only the corn), insects swarm, and cattle waste away and die, while the Foxwillow folk blame each other for negligence, laziness, and stupidity.

It began six months ago when {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x} disappeared. A living scarecrow, Jericho had wandered Foxwillow for generations, crafting effigies for the fields and singing as evening fell. When he vanished into the corn, no trace of him remained. Whispers of murder spread, and hidden grudges tore the town apart.

As blame grew, the crops withered—except for the cornfields to the east. Worse still, more townsfolk disappeared, their places taken by grotesque scarecrow effigies (see {@area The Harvest Terror|237|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: Foxwillow is a haunted husk of a town. None dare trust enough to band together, nor is anyone brave enough to venture into the corn where the lost have vanished. Characters drawn to the town by the {@area Quest Hook|254|x} later in this chapter have these goals:

items: Venture to Foxwillow with the quest-giver, {@area William Lodge|23f|x}.
Stop the {@area survivors in Foxwillow|23e|x} from turning on each other.
Offer secrets to {@area Raum|237|x} (their own, or secrets learned within Foxwillow) to gain entrance to the demonic corn maze demiplane known as the {@area Fields of the Crow|292|x}.
Survive the dangers of the Fields of the Crow and find Raum.
Destroy Raum, {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24}.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with Raum, the key NPC, to infuse his menace throughout. A casual reading of the {@area Foxwillow locations|26f|x} helps when you improvise interactions. Lastly, reviewing the climactic battle, {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x}, ensures a smooth and gripping final encounter.
{@i This chapter is designed for four level 4 characters.}

entries.name: The Harvest Terror
entries: A strange and wonderful creature named Ol' Jericho Sticks, a sentient scarecrow, came to Wickermoor Hollow years ago. The scarecrow, a wandering tunesmith, held a secret inside of him, literally and figuratively: a crow demon lurked within Jericho's straw-stuffed body and was the true and terrible power that gave him life.

entries.name: Ol' Jericho Sticks
entries: Jericho was a haunted scarecrow—but a friendly one. He traipsed about the farmlands around Foxwillow, singing songs to drown out the sounds of sorrow within him. The people of Foxwillow loved the straw-stuffed drifter who wove through the rows of straw and stover, serenading the fieldhands on his banjo as they worked.

But eventually, even music was not enough to resist the voice inside his head. As the decades passed, the demon that Jericho called "Virgil" grew in power and slowly spread his discord to the people of Foxwillow. As a result, the townsfolk became more suspicious of him, filling the scarecrow with increasing self-doubt. Virgil preyed on this uncertainty, manipulating the wounded psyche of his host until Jericho gave in to the whispers.

When Jericho realized the demon inside him was gaining control, he retreated into the cornfields to keep his beloved Foxwillowers safe. Tragically, the struggle was short. His soul was devoured by Virgil, and the two merged into a new demon in the crumpled scarecrow body. He is now Raum, {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24}, a crow-like Fiend with a body of straw and rusted metal.

entries.name: The Scourge of Foxwillow
entries: Raum {@i (rah-OOM)} loves to destroy all that Jericho loved to create. He stalks the rural lands of eastern Wickermoor Hollow, wielding sharp blades and sharper words to drive fear into the hearts of all who live there. He takes special glee in luring people from Jericho's beloved Foxwillow into his demiplane of endless corn mazes, the Fields of the Crow, to steal their bodies, souls, and secrets.

Jericho is gone forever, but tiny scraps of his kindly consciousness still cling like rotten flesh to Raum's vile bones. If the characters learn the tender secrets of Ol' Jericho Sticks, what's left of him fights back and aids them (see {@area Gathering Information|272|x} and {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: Raum's Curse
entries: Raum feeds on secrets and delights in destruction. Learning secrets sustains him and grants him greater power. Not only do they increase his demonic magic, but they also empower him to manipulate mortal hearts. He has two primary means of harvesting secrets:

entries.name: Black-Feathered Spies
entries: Murders of crows gaze hungrily upon Foxwillow in numbers great enough to make bare trees look flush with black leaves when they gather. They are always listening, waiting to report back bits of information to Raum.

entries.name: Gateway to the Stalks
entries: The second method is the gateway to the Fields of the Crow. All who approach it of their own free will are addressed by Raum directly. They are bidden to sacrifice a damning secret if they wish to gain entry to Raum's domain. This sacrifice empowers Raum's game statistics (see {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} at the end of this chapter). At your discretion, this secret sparks nasty rumors about the character who divulged it back in Foxwillow and Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: NPCs of Foxwillow
entries: The town of Foxwillow is largely abandoned. Most of its people have been lured into the cornfield and vanished. All missing folk have been replaced in town by eerie scarecrows, described wherever they are in town (see {@area Areas within Foxwillow|275|x} later in this chapter). However, there are five noteworthy NPCs still in town.

These NPCs have complicated relationships and hide many secrets from one another that prevent them from trusting each other. When the characters meet the NPCs in town, use these descriptions and the Foxwillow Relationship Chart at the end of this section to help you roleplay them.

entries.name: William Lodge
entries: A tenant farmer of the wealthy Thatcher family, William (Neutral Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) lives on the outskirts of Foxwillow and tends grains and gourds while raising livestock. As such, he has a close relationship with both the people of Foxwillow and of Wickermoor Village, which he often travels to monthly for market.

entries.name: Changing William's Attitude
entries: Though {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters when they meet him, his attitude increases one step to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} if they agree to join him in saving Foxwillow. His attitude decreases one step to {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} if they intentionally cause destruction or loot the town (such as looting the statue in {@area area J2|277|x}) but increases one step if they take action to help (such as putting out fires when the town is burning).

His attitude increases one step if the characters demonstrate selfless heroism or emotional tenderness. His attitude decreases one step if they are selfish or try to {@action Influence|XPHB} him to learn a secret from him and fail their Charisma check.

entries.name: William's Secret
entries: Though unmarried himself, William had an affair with another farmer's wife, Martha Langtree, who soon had a son with him. This son is the middle Langtree child, Isaac.

entries.name: Learning His Secret
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character convinces William to reveal this secret with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Martha Langtree
entries: Martha (Lawful Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) is a widow of ten years who works her farm with the help of her three children Adelaide, Isaac, and Rosemary. Lean and toned from years of hard work, she has a brash personality and is often called a force of nature by the townsfolk.

Martha loves all her children dearly but worries for them. Adelaide has acted strangely since Ol' Jericho Sticks vanished, then Rosemary vanished a week ago. Just this dusk, Isaac went missing too and Adelaide seems unconcerned. Martha is at her wits' end and inadvertently started a brawl in the Old Windmill (see {@area Foxwillow in Flames|256|x} later in this chapter) while William was out of town seeking aid.

entries.name: Changing Martha's Attitude
entries: Despite the horrors occurring at her doorstep, Martha is easy to befriend. She becomes immediately {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} if they save Jonah from death in the {@area The Burning Mill|25e|x} encounter. Otherwise, she is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}.

Her attitude increases one step if the characters demonstrate selfless heroism or emotional tenderness. Her attitude decreases one step if they are selfish or try to {@action Influence|XPHB} her to learn a secret from her and fail their Charisma check.

entries.name: Martha's Secret
entries: Farmer Malachai, Martha's husband, was a violent drunk, and Martha accidentally killed him while defending herself. She has kept this secret ever since to protect her children.

entries.name: Learning Her Secret
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character convinces Martha to reveal this secret with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. This secret is in addition to her extramarital role in William's secret ({@area see above|241|x}).

entries.name: Adelaide Langtree
entries: Adelaide (Chaotic Evil, human {@creature Cultist|XMM}) is the eldest child of Martha at twenty-five years old. She was a difficult child who played over-competitively with the other children and enjoyed morbid practical jokes to peeve her unpleasant father, like hiding rat carcasses in his boots overnight. Jericho was her best friend because she had a hard time making friends with other kids her age.

As she grew older, Adelaide's antisocial behavior deepened. Jericho vanished on her twenty-fifth birthday, and ever since, she's wandered into the cornfields after her nightly work, only returning when it's time for bed. Some whisper she killed Jericho, while others claim she's searching for her only friend. None who followed her into the corn have ever returned.

Three weeks after Jericho's disappearance, she found him—now the monstrous, crow-headed demon, Raum. The Harvest Terror spoke with Jericho's voice, calling himself her best friend, vowing to love her if she revealed her secrets. She confessed witnessing her father's abuse and her mother's fatal act.

The demon Raum told her that he is an angel sent to reveal the evil secrets in Foxwillow. Confused, but seduced by his words, Adelaide has spent recent months gathering secrets and luring folks into the cornfields, where Raum spirits them away to wander forever in the Fields of the Crow.

entries.name: Changing Adelaide's Attitude
entries: Adelaide is fully in Raum's thrall. She can't be swayed from being {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.

entries.name: Adelaide's Secret
entries: In her communion with Raum, Adelaide has learned William's secret—that her brother Isaac is really her half-brother. She's been manipulated into believing that her mother's infidelity and her half-brother's birth are the real causes of her fear and suffering in childhood. She was goaded by Raum into murdering Isaac, and she hid his corpse in the basement of the Old Windmill ({@area area J1|25e|x}), where it is incubating a demonic servant of The Harvest Terror.

entries.name: Learning Her Secret
entries: Adelaide's murderous secret is revealed when the characters find her brother's corpse in the Windmill Cellar ({@area area J9b|28a|x}). If her mother Martha is told of what happened, Martha weeps and gives the characters a handmade brass locket her brother made for her to try and earn her love as a child.

entries.name: Jonah Sawyer
entries: Jonah (Neutral Good, human {@creature Tough|XMM}) has a reputation as a rugged, broad-shouldered man with a humor as hefty as his sinewed frame. As Foxwillow's butcher, he's often seen in a bloodstained apron striding through town. His signature platform shoes, worn to keep his feet dry from pigs' blood, earned him the nickname "Heels." His only daughter, Liza, has gone missing in recent nights.

Though he's truly not responsible for all Foxwillow's ills, Jonah has been on edge lately, burdened by guilt over the town's curse and the disappearance of his daughter. In a fit of rage, he cursed William Lodge, and his shame has made him antagonistic toward his neighbors (see {@area Foxwillow in Flames|256|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: Changing Jonah's Attitude
entries: Suspicious by nature, Jonah is difficult to befriend. If characters talk with him about breaking the curse, he asks if they think whoever caused the curse was evil, or just misguided. His attitude increases one step to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} if they say they'll be sympathetic to the curse-maker or that they'll keep an eye out for Liza. If they suggest that they'll kill the person who cursed Foxwillow, he becomes fearful and {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, refusing to speak at length.

entries.name: Jonah's Secret
entries: Jonah has harbored resentment for William Lodge for years, though he no longer recalls why. By all accounts, William is well-liked and even sells livestock to the butcher. But Jonah recently discovered William had been selling him scrawnier stock than he sells to Siv Harga in Wickermoor Village, who pays a higher price for well-cared-for prize beasts.

In a fit of ire, Jonah slaughtered a lamb and invoked an old folk hex his grandmother once whispered about. He cursed William's fields and herds and—to his horror—the curse took root. Now, Foxwillow's crops and livestock wither—save for the demon-infested cornfield, which thrives unnaturally. Jonah, wracked with guilt, grows defensive, fearing the town's ruin rests on his shoulders.

entries.name: Learning His Secret
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, characters convince Jonah to reveal this secret with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Isaac Langtree
entries: A boyishly handsome man of twenty-one, Isaac Langtree ran the Hooded Lantern, his family's tavern, but he continued helping his mother on the farm when able. He vanished the night before the characters arrived, but not into the cornfield. He was lured into the basement of the Old Windmill ({@area area J1|25e|x}) by his sister Adelaide and ritualistically murdered. His corpse is there still.

entries.name: Isaac's Secret
entries: Charm and good looks made him popular in town, but he secretly despised the quaint, folksy ways of his rural neighbors. He had developed an especially intense dislike of manual labor after apprenticing as a butcher under Jonah Sawyer in his youth. Each market night, he skimmed money from his mother and stashed it under a floorboard in the tavern in preparation to leave for a life on the road. He was trying to convince his sister Adelaide to skip town with him when she killed him.

entries.name: Learning His Secret
entries: Isaac's duplicitous secret is revealed when the characters find his secret cache under a floorboard in the Hooded Lantern ({@area area J4|27b|x}).

entries.name: Scarecrow Townsfolk
entries: Most of Foxwillow's people have vanished, lost in the Fields of the Crow. Their bodies, twisted under Raum's control, are now grotesque scarecrows—burlap stuffed with straw and pumpkin heads carved into haunting mockeries of their former faces. Their spirits, however, are doomed to wander the endless maze of cornstalks. Only Raum's destruction frees the lost spirits and turns the scarecrows back into people.
These scarecrows litter the town, sitting slumped in homes and shops, grim reminders of those they replaced. Descriptions of several scarecrows are found in each area.

entries.name: Jumpscarecrow!
entries: If the investigation of the town is slowing down, {@dice 1d3} {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24|Pumpkin Heads} spring to life and attack. After the scarecrows are defeated, have a {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} NPC rush up and share a Vital Clue or Optional Clue they've learned (see {@area Investigating Foxwillow|26f|x} later in this chapter) to give the characters a new lead.

These scarecrows are the missing townsfolk's mortal bodies. If a pumpkin head is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by Fire damage (burning the body) or Bludgeoning damage (squashing the pumpkin head), the mortal body is also destroyed in a similarly gruesome way when it reverts back to its original human form after Raum is defeated. Other types of damage typically just muss the straw or burlap, leaving the mortal body with scars but no lasting wounds once reverted.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: The many ills of Foxwillow (described in the {@area Chapter Background|235|x}) have finally driven one man to flee his town and seek aid in Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Foxwillow's Cursed!
entries: In Wickermoor Village, the characters are approached by {@area Jeremiah Stover|18d|x} and introduced to his friend {@area William Lodge|23f|x}, a man from Foxwillow who has told Jeremiah his tale of fear and woe. Jeremiah asks William to repeat it and pleads with the characters to listen. William Lodge is a salt-of-the-earth, middle-aged farmer with a folksy accent and an earnest love for his village in his eyes. He lives on one of the failing farms on the outskirts of town, so he doesn't know the whole story, but he explains what has happened as best he knows it,

items: {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x}, the living, singing scarecrow, vanished from town six months ago. Ever since, townsfolk have been accusing one another of murdering the beloved handyman and songster. (If asked for more information on Jericho, William explains that no one knows how the friendly strawman came to be, but he's been beloved by Foxwillow since before William was born.)

After a few months, no one in town trusted each other, and recently everything started going wrong. All crops but the corn failed, livestock withered and died, and strange sigils started appearing in the cornfields.
Then, only weeks ago, townsfolk began going missing, seemingly replaced by mysterious scarecrows.
Hardly anyone is left in Foxwillow, and most everyone has barricaded themselves inside their houses. No one sets their suspicions aside to work together.

entries: Jeremiah explains that while the farmers of Wickermoor Village produce as much food as possible, they still rely on the grain Foxwillow produces to feed the town. If the characters break the curse upon Foxwillow, save its people, and salvage the harvest, Jeremiah rallies the town to chip in and pay them each 50 GP.

If {@area Phillip Druskenvald|01f|x} is with the characters at the time or learns of the request from them later, he offers to match the 50 GP from his own funds and says he wants to take a more active role in helping the people of Wickermoor Hollow since it's technically his responsibility as Lord of Druskenvald.

If the characters have more questions, William says he'll be happy to talk about the villagers and the specifics while they travel, offering passage on his horse-drawn cart; it'll take them a couple nights to reach Foxwillow, so there'll be plenty of time.

entries.name: Foxwillow in Flames
entries: The journey to Foxwillow is about 2 nights at a Normal pace. At the end of the trek, they find Foxwillow aflame, with lifelike scarecrows brawling in the streets. It happened like this:

items: {@area Jonah Sawyer|24b|x} called {@area Martha Langtree's|243|x} daughter {@area Adelaide|247|x} a "creep" and a "killer" to Martha's face in the town square.
Martha, already on edge due to the disappearance of Rosemary last week, threw a punch at Jonah, who retaliated.

Their anger awakened the hatred lingering within the bodies of the scarecrow townsfolk (see {@area Scarecrow Townsfolk|252|x} earlier in this chapter). As they fought in the square, the scarecrows came to life and joined the brawl.
Horrified, Martha and Jonah fled to the windmill. In their haste, the butcher dropped his lantern. Flour in the mill went up like tinder, setting the whole structure ablaze.
The windmill's burning, spinning sails spread the fire to nearby houses.
{@area Raum's|239|x} scarecrows continue to fight until Martha and Jonah apologize to each other.

entries.name: Arriving in Foxwillow
entries: The characters arrive at the outskirts of Foxwillow amidst this conflagration.

For hours, your cart has creaked through barren fields littered with ragged scarecrows, wilted wheat, and rotting pumpkins. The air carries the bitter scent of smoke, and ahead, a fiery glow consumes the horizon—the town is burning. William urges the horses faster.

Moments later, you arrive in the town square, where a wild brawl unfolds among a dozen farmers. Two buildings—the town hall and a small shop—are engulfed in flames, set alight by the blazing windmill, now a spinning tower of fire. William turns to you, eyes wide with horror, and pleads, "By the Lady! Please save Foxwillow!"

The brawlers are all scarecrows of the townsfolk dressed in their clothes and with eerie carved or painted faces (see {@area Scarecrow Townsfolk|252|x}, earlier in this chapter), though their pumpkin heads are obscured by hair, hats, or bonnets from a distance. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, characters scrutinize the townsfolk and discern what the scarecrows are with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. A character within 5 feet of a brawler sees the truth automatically.

The solution to ending this brawl is to save the people who started it: Martha Langtree and Jonah Sawyer. They're fighting in the Old Windmill (see {@area The Burning Mill|25e|x}). Likewise, the town continues to burn until the windmill fire is put out.

The characters are under no obligation to stop the fight or put out the fires, but William urges them to help and mentions the pump west of the town square (see {@area Getting Water|25c|x} below). It's a good idea, too: they have an easier time entering the Fields of the Crow and finding Raum if they've met Martha.

entries.name: Navigating the Brawl
entries: Using {@area the Foxwillow map|257|x}, the characters must pass through Magpie Square ({@area area J2|277|x}) to reach the Old Windmill ({@area area J1|25e|x}). Each brawling townsperson is a {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24} animated by Raum's demonic influence.

The scarecrows exclusively fight each other unless their attention is drawn by casting a spell, attacking one of the pumpkin heads, or putting out the fires in areas J5 and J8. During this event, scarecrows are found in:
Magpie Square ({@area area J2|277|x}): Three pumpkin heads hurl each other about and kick up the mud in the streets, making the town square {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

General Store ({@area area J5|27e|x}): Two pumpkin heads toss bottles and bags of cornmeal while the building burns around them. A creature that ends its turn in the store takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) Fire damage.
Town Hall ({@area area J8|285|x}): Three pumpkin heads smash chairs over each other. The fire hasn't spread past the roof yet.
The scarecrows in other areas of town are inanimate.

entries.name: Firefighting
entries: Fire is raging in the General Store ({@area area J5|27e|x}) and the Town Hall ({@area area J8|285|x}). If these buildings aren't doused, the fire spreads through the densely packed town square and burns Foxwillow (and all the scarecrows in it) to the ground.

entries.name: Putting Out a Fire
entries: Putting out the fire in areas J5 and J8 requires at least 10 gallons of water to be hurled on each area's blaze.

entries.name: Getting Water
entries: The best way to put out these fires is by casting the {@spell Create or Destroy Water|XPHB} spell or using other magic that creates water. There is also a water pump west of Magpie Square ({@area area J2|277|x}). William assists the characters by operating the pump to fill buckets of water. Characters who grab a filled bucket can take the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to douse an area's flames with 1 gallon of water.

entries.name: Drawing Attention
entries: Putting out a fire causes all the {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24|Pumpkin Heads} in that area to attack the characters responsible.

entries.name: The Burning Mill
entries: {@area Isaac's|24f|x} corpse is in the basement of the windmill, but the roar of the fire and the collapsed debris obscures his remains. When the fire ends, the characters can find his body in the basement ({@area area J9a|288|x}). {@area Adelaide|247|x} is missing and under {@area Raum's|239|x} influence (see {@area Into the Fields of the Crow|292|x}).

{@area Martha Langtree|243|x} and {@area Jonah Sawyer|24b|x} are trapped in the windmill. If they die without setting their anger aside, the scarecrows remain fueled by hate and fight until they're destroyed. The Windmill map (see below) shows the interior of the windmill, including its four floors and basement.

entries.name: Burning
entries: Spaces marked with Xs on the map are burning. A creature that enters a burning space for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or take 5 ({@dice 2d4}) Fire damage.

entries.name: Townsfolk
entries: Jonah Sawyer is on the fourth floor, trying to fend off a slowly approaching {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24} that has taken the shape of his daughter, Liza. Martha is on the first floor, trying to clear rubble blocking the door.

entries.name: J1a: Windmill Exterior
entries: Read or paraphrase the following when the characters reach the door to the windmill:

The windmill's sails spin wildly, spewing cinders all around. A portion of the wall above the door has collapsed, blocking the door with burning debris. You hear rubble being shifted and a woman yelping in pain from the other side of the door.

Two 5-foot squares in front of the main doors and two more 5-foot squares behind it are filled with burning rubble. The door opens outward, and all four squares of rubble need to be cleared for the characters to enter.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: A space of rubble is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}, and as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, characters clear it with a successful {@dc 15} Strength check. It is also cleared by bringing a 5-foot space of rubble to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} (AC 8, HP 20, {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage, and {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Cold, and Thunder damage). A creature that touches the rubble without tools takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) Fire damage.

entries.name: Alternative Route
entries: The source of the rubble is the wall above the door. There is a 5-foot-wide hole in the wall 10 feet above the ground. This space is burning.

entries.name: J1b: Windmill First Floor
entries: Inside the burning mill is Martha Langtree. Her hair singed, her hands burned and hastily wrapped in torn cloth, she stammers her thanks. Shaking, she admits the fire was her doing—a fight with Jonah led to a lantern falling, igniting the mill. Then, in terror, she recounts how a grotesque scarecrow burst through the door before the wall collapsed, chasing him upstairs. "You have to help Jonah!" she pleads, fleeing the windmill.

entries.name: J1c: Windmill Second Floor
entries: This floor is burning, and the flames have spread to block the path to the stairs leading up.

entries.name: Time Pressure
entries: There are no foes in this room, but roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} when a character ascends to this floor and keep them in {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} order the entire time they are in the windmill. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 of each round, describe how the windmill trembles as the strain of its wildly spinning sails threatens to tear the fire-weakened structure apart. Each creature in the mill must make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@dice 2d4}) Fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 0 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of the ninth round after the characters enter this floor of the windmill, the entire structure collapses. When it does, each creature in the windmill falls to the bottom floor, taking 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Fire damage from the collapse, plus 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Bludgeoning damage for each floor they fell.

entries.name: J1d: Windmill Third Floor
entries: This floor has collapsed, leaving nothing more than smoldering support beams and the wildly spinning central shaft and driven gears.

entries.name: Spinning Cog
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the cogs spin 180 degrees, moving any creature on the cog to the space opposite of the space they were on.

entries.name: J1e: Windmill Fourth Floor
entries: The cramped top floor of the windmill is dominated by a single horizontal beam that supports the mill's main shaft and the gears which turn it. This beam is burning, and Jonah Sawyer is on the far side. A {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24} is on the side closest to the ladder the characters are ascending. The scarecrow is menacing Jonah as it tries to find a way around the fire. He's been reduced to 15 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. Jonah begs the characters to not destroy the scarecrow, as its face is twisted into the visage of his missing daughter, Liza.
The characters must get Jonah out before the mill collapses (see {@area area J1c|267|x}).

entries.name: An End to the Brawl
entries: The resolution to the burning mill depends on if Jonah survived or not.

entries.name: If Jonah Survived
entries: Once Martha and Jonah escape the windmill, they exchange apologies. Martha, trembling, apologizes for striking Jonah, and he begrudgingly admits fault for insulting Adelaide, especially with Rosemary missing for a week. To their shock, all remaining scarecrows collapse as they speak. Regardless of the fate of the Liza scarecrow, Jonah takes a moment to mourn his daughter. He sees it as a punishment for cursing Foxwillow.

Martha then tells the characters that, to her knowledge, all residents of Foxwillow but her, Jonah, and William have gone missing. Her children, Isaac and Adelaide, haven't been seen tonight. Martha believes they're hiding, as everyone else who vanished was replaced by a scarecrow. She also suspects any who might remain have locked themselves inside their homes, refusing to emerge until the terror has passed.
Jonah privately confides that he shouldn't have insulted Martha's daughter, though he adds that Adelaide has always been withdrawn, and the curse on Foxwillow has only deepened her isolation.

Martha returns to the Hooded Lantern ({@area area J4|27b|x}) and is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} to the characters (see {@area Townsfolk Attitude|270|x} below). She asks them to speak to her there if they need help investigating the town. Jonah likewise returns to his shop ({@area area J6|280|x}) but is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters. William Lodge heads to the Town Hall ({@area area J8|285|x}) after reuniting with Martha and Jonah.
If there are still fires in town, Martha, Jonah, and William work together to put them out.

entries.name: If Jonah Died
entries: Without being able to apologize to Jonah, Martha's anger at him keeps the scarecrows alive. They continue to stalk the town. Whenever the characters roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} while in Foxwillow, two {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24|Pumpkin Heads} join the combat on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 of the second round.

Martha and William hide in the Town Hall ({@area area J8|285|x}). Any remaining fires slowly burn out. The town hall's sturdy roof prevents serious damage to it, but all other buildings in the town square eventually burn to the ground if no one tends to them.

entries.name: Investigating Foxwillow
entries: Once {@area Martha|243|x} and (possibly) {@area Jonah|24b|x} have been saved from the windmill, the characters begin their investigation regarding the curse and learn how to enter the {@area Fields of the Crow|292|x}. They interview the townsfolk to gain vital clues and optional secrets.
It is possible to skip the windmill and the investigation in town by proceeding directly to the Fields of the Crow, but it would be at the cost of the town and the only people left in it.

entries.name: Townsfolk Attitude
entries: All of the Foxwillow NPCs (except William Lodge) are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward each other and the characters during the {@area Foxwillow in Flames|256|x} section, above. However, the townsfolks' attitudes change based on the actions during the brawl and while investigating the town. Their attitude affects how easily the characters {@action Influence|XPHB} them to aid them or divulge information, which is vital to gaining the upper hand in their battle against {@area Raum|239|x}.

entries.name: Starting Attitude
entries: After the brawl, the NPCs of Foxwillow have the following attitudes, which are tracked on the Foxwillow Relationship Chart.

items: {@area William Lodge|23f|x}: {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}
{@area Martha Langtree|243|x}: {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} ({@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} if Jonah survived)
{@area Adelaide Langtree|247|x}: {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}
{@area Jonah Sawyer|24b|x}: {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}

entries.name: Gathering Information
entries: By the end of their investigation, the characters must learn several key clues, and they might also learn optional secrets that aid them in the battle against {@area Raum|239|x}. It's your job to naturally supply the must-know information and the players' job to decide if they want to dig deeper or press on. Ultimately, you want the players to use their wits but not get stuck.

entries.name: Vital Clues
entries: Be sure to convey these points clearly. Any NPC in town is quick to communicate the information below, especially if the pace of the investigation is dragging:

items: The demonic happenings only started after the scarecrow {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x} went missing.
A few people who later went missing reported a horrific birdlike monster stalking the fields and heard a name whispered to them: Raum.
Whenever someone goes missing, a scarecrow wearing their clothes with a pumpkin head carved or painted in their likeness appears in their home or workplace.
Cornfields surround the town, but people only go missing after they venture into the cornfields to the east of Foxwillow.
Just before people vanish into the cornfield, they have been seen whispering to the stalks as the wind rustles through them.

entries.name: Optional Clues
entries: The NPCs also know optional clues that aid in navigating the {@area Fields of the Crow|292|x} or fighting Raum. They only reveal these secrets if they're {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} with the characters. You decide which questions succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma check to get an NPC to divulge this information:

items: The Old Windmill had a cellar ({@area area J9b|28a|x}) that Adelaide and {@area Isaac|24f|x} used to play in as children. She had been spending more time there as of late.
Jonah is poised to answer Raum's call and vanish into the corn in search of his daughter after being attacked by a scarecrow bearing her face in the Old Windmill ({@area area J1e|26b|x}).

The living scarecrow called Ol' Jericho Sticks liked to sing a song called "Virgil's Birdcage," which was about a kindly man with an angry crow for a heart, and only singing and dancing could keep the nasty crow asleep. The librarian loved the tune and would always ask Jericho to play it for her.
The General store owner loved Jericho's music so much that he secretly commissioned a master luthier to make Jericho a new banjo.
The people of Foxwillow had become so fond of Jericho that they asked William Lodge to petition the mayor to make him a citizen.

entries.name: Foxwillow Locations
entries: {@area The Foxwillow map|257|x} shows the center of Foxwillow, but the true heart of the town lies in the farmlands the characters passed to reach the square. The town center holds all the information needed, while the cursed fields beyond are barren. Farmhouses scattered across the land are either abandoned by those who vanished into the corn or sealed shut by frightened farmers unwilling to speak. There's little left to see here (though for creating your own regions within Foxwillow, see the {@area Outside of Town: Pastures|291|x} section later).

entries.name: J1: Old Windmill
entries: This area is only visited during the {@area Foxwillow in Flames|256|x} encounter earlier in this chapter. After the windmill burns out, see the Burned-Out Windmill ({@area area J9|287|x}).

entries.name: J2: Magpie Square
entries: Foxwillow's market square is called Magpie Square by its townsfolk because of a stone statue of a flock of magpies painted in lifelike piebald colors.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, anyone who inspects the statue and succeeds on a {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds that the magpies' eyes are made of tiny black onyx stones. Working for 10 minutes to remove the eyes produces eighteen onyx marbles each worth 10 GP.

entries.name: J3: Foxwillow Schoolhouse
entries: All twenty seats in this schoolhouse are filled with child-sized scarecrows, and an effigy of a human woman stands before the blackboard, chalked with lyrics for a children's song called "Tubers and Treacle."

entries.name: Clue
entries: Drawn on the blackboard beneath the lyrics is an eerie image of a crow head emerging through tall stalks. The bird is speaking to a group of children and holding out a stick hand toward them, as if expecting payment.

entries.name: J4: The Hooded Lantern
entries: This inn was run by {@area Isaac Langtree|24f|x}. The door is locked, opened with a successful {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, and the interior is tidy. He wasn't taken by force. All the rented rooms hold a scarecrow effigy of various travelers but no clues. {@area Martha Langtree|243|x} takes shelter here after the fire has fully burned out.

entries.name: Searching the Reception
entries: Those who spend 10 minutes searching the inn and succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check find an upturned board behind the counter with a hidden compartment below.

entries.name: Isaac's Secret
entries: Underneath the floorboard is a sack of 300 SP and 1,000 CP embezzled from Martha Langtree. Outside of the sack is a single black coin with a feather icon on one face. The coin crumbles to corn kernels when touched, and whoever touched it hears Raum's raspy voice whisper, "What mother doesn't know won't hurt her. I'll pay her back someday."

entries.name: J5: General Store
entries: The local General Store's roof collapsed during the fire. Sifting through the rubble, the characters find two scarecrows of the shopkeepers with their pumpkin heads caved in.

entries.name: A Tender Secret
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, characters who succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check find a beautiful banjo buried unharmed in the rubble. Attached to it is a note that reads, "Keep it secret from Jericho 'til next market night. He can't know how much we spent ordering this six-stringer for him."
Finding this secret strengthens the character who finds it in the battle against Raum (see {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: J6: Butcher's Shop
entries: {@area Jonah Sawyer|24b|x} takes refuge here once the brawl subsides (assuming he didn't perish in the windmill). The shop's storefront leads to a back room, heavy with the metallic stench of blood. A search reveals no meat left left—Foxwillow's livestock have withered. Only crows remain, and a few pitiful, plucked bird carcasses hang limply in the shop, a grim reminder of the town's decay.

entries.name: Investigating the Shop
entries: Jonah won't let anyone into the back room. If a character manages to get in, as a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a successful {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds the following:

items: A ritual circle drawn in dried calf's blood hidden under a rug
A cow skull, a chicken skull, and a lamb skull on a shelf, all marked with a bloody thumbprint
A bundle of dried wheat, barley, and flax, bound in a blood-drenched rag

entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, those that succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check realize that these are components for a ritual curse that causes crops to wither and animals to waste away. It couldn't cause the horrors surrounding the scarecrows and the vanishings. Confronting Jonah with this evidence causes him to reveal his secret but reduces his attitude by one step.

entries.name: Jonah's Plan
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, those who succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check realize something is bothering Jonah. He keeps toying with a crow feather. If Jonah is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, he tells the characters that he's going into the cornfields in a few hours. Seeing a scarecrow with his daughter's face chilled him, and he decided he must save her. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a successful {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check convinces him not to go. On a failure, he suggests that he become bait for whatever is lurking in the field so the characters can sneak in after him.

If Jonah isn't on {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} terms with them, a successful group {@dc 12} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check allows them to follow him to the edge of the cornfield.

entries.name: J7: Library
entries: The Library is small and doesn't have many books in it. However, it has hundreds of town records, maps showing the boundaries of local farmers' property, and other civic documents. A scarecrow of the librarian has been shoved into an empty bookshelf.

entries.name: A Tender Secret
entries: Clutched in the librarian scarecrow's hand is a gorgeous transcription of a song titled, "Virgil's Birdcage," one of Jericho's classics. If taken, she awakens as a {@creature Pumpkin Head|CrookedMoon24} and attacks. If the scarecrow is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it mutters, "He loved this song... I wanted to give him this..."
Finding this secret strengthens the character who finds it in the battle against Raum (see {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: J8: Town Hall
entries: Foxwillow's Town Hall looms in the heart of the settlement, where the farming folk once gathered at twilight. A crooked billboard stands outside, covered with weathered papers that cling to it stubbornly. William Lodge, who usually holds meetings here, now scours the building for clues while the characters investigate.

entries.name: A Tender Secret
entries: If William is asked if he's found anything, he admits he hasn't found much, except for something strange: the mayor had granted Ol' Jericho Sticks official citizenship, complete with a "birth certificate." William hands it over with a shrug, unsure of its significance.
Finding this secret empowers the character against Raum in the final battle (see {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: J9: Burned-Out Windmill
entries: When the characters arrive in town, this windmill is a towering inferno thanks to a lantern that was knocked over during a brawl. The burning windmill is described in {@area The Burning Mill|25e|x}, above. This section describes the windmill after the battle.

entries.name: J9a: Charred Foundations
entries: Not much remains of the old windmill after the blaze.

entries.name: Scritch-Scratch
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, those who examine the area and succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check hear scratching sounds from beneath a charred rug covering a trapdoor to the cellar (see {@area area J9b|28a|x}).

Opening the trapdoor reveals a ladder and a {@creature Ravencraft|CrookedMoon24} that's trying to push the trapdoor up and escape. The macabre creature is the work of {@area Adelaide Langtree|247|x}, and it croaks and caws at the characters but doesn't attack unless provoked. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}) or Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check shifts its attitude to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}. After being calmed, it agrees to serve one of the spellcasting characters as a familiar.

entries.name: J9b: Windmill Cellar
entries: A dark secret is buried here: the body of {@area Isaac Langtree|24f|x}. The characters may have learned that Isaac vanished recently by speaking to his mother {@area Martha|243|x}, or they may not know who this is and ask about him.

entries.name: Clue on the Corpse
entries: Those who investigate Isaac's body find a note clenched in his rigid fist. It reads:
"Isaac, come meet me in the windmill cellar where I used to hide when we played as kids. Remember? I've learned something amazing."

entries.name: Cause of Death
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, anyone who examines the body and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check determines that Isaac was killed by a knife, probably a kitchen knife, with a cut to the throat.
