His chest was then gruesomely carved open. While investigating the corpse, a song is heard being sung from within Isaac's chest called "Virgil's Birdcage," which is about a nasty crow living in the chest of a kindly man. Investigating further reveals a monster (see below).

entries.name: Carrion Demon
entries: When Adelaide sacrificed Isaac in Raum's name, The Harvest Terror planted a demon within his ribcage. When the characters investigate the body, crows shoot out of Isaac's chest and caw at the characters before bloodily mutating into a {@creature Corvodaemon|CrookedMoon24} and a {@creature Crowstorm|CrookedMoon24}. The Fiends fight to the death and prioritize any character who tries to flee.

entries.name: Isaac's Locket
entries: As described in {@area Adelaide's Secret|249|x} in the NPCs of Foxwillow section earlier in this chapter, Isaac made a locket for his older sister as a child, which his mother now possesses. If the characters tell Martha of Isaac's death and show her the note, she realizes that Adelaide must have killed him. She tearfully gives the characters the locket to help protect them against the monster her daughter has become. It acts as a {@item Cloak of Protection|XDMG}.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@i The Hanged Man} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the {@item Banjo of Ol' Jericho Sticks|CrookedMoon24} can be found propped up against the stone of the windmill's foundation.

entries.name: Outside of Town: Pastures
entries: At the edge of the town square, a cluster of farmhouses encircle a courtyard with an old water pump. Acres of pasture stretch beyond, anchored by the Langtree farm. Lazarus Thatcher, a wealthy farmer, once formed this cooperative with twelve families, but now none remain. All have vanished into the cornfields, replaced by eerie scarecrow effigies.

entries.name: Into the Fields of the Crow
entries: To the east of Foxwillow is a cornfield with overly tall stalks that sway and whistle in the wind. The outer edge of this cornfield is a supernatural border; everything within is a nightmarish, demonic demiplane that morphs according to {@area Raum's|239|x} whims.

entries.name: Entering the Cornfield
entries: The Fields of the Crow are guarded by a looming and impenetrable wall of stalks. When approached, two large, orange eyes with pupils in the shape of four-pointed stars appear through the stalks and a raspy, croaking voice whispers:
"Lay bare your secrets. Lighten your burden. Do this and you may enter my land of dreams."

If a character tries to force their way through, they push into the corn only to find themselves emerging from the same spot they entered. The thing in the rows laughs gratingly and repeats its offer after the character is forced out. The thing recoils if attacked and retreats into the stalks for 1 hour, after which it returns to repeat its offer to any who approach.

entries.name: Dark Wings, Dark Words
entries: The cornrows are entered by revealing a dark, personal secret to the presence lurking within, or by slipping through with another who paid in secrets before the threshold seals. Sharing the secret feeds Raum, granting him greater strength and control over the character (see {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x} later in this chapter).
Those who share someone else's secret can also enter. This grants Raum extra power, but no control over the character.

entries.name: Sneaking In
entries: When someone enters the Fields of the Crow, the stalks remain open for them, and only them, for up to 1 minute. However, those who make a successful {@dc 18} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check slip through unnoticed by Raum. If this check fails, they are ejected from the corn as described earlier.

entries.name: Fields of the Crow Features
entries: The Fields of the Crow have the following features:

entries.name: Impenetrable Boundary
entries: The Fields of the Crow is a hellish corn maze. Trying to push through or damage the stalks causes the wind to howl and the stalks to thrash at the intruder. The stalks have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage, and if the intruder is within 5 feet of the stalks, they are pushed 10 feet away and must make a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw, taking 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Infinite Stalks
entries: Corn stalks grow as tall as redwoods, and creatures that fly can soar upward forever and never reach the top. Despite constantly moving upward, every time a flying creature reaches 120 feet above the ground, they are suddenly 60 feet above the ground.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: A nightmarish swirl of orange clouds stretches like writhing tendrils from an orange harvest moon that fills half the sky and obscures the stars. The entire area is bathed in Dim Light, tinged pumpkin-orange by the moon.

entries.name: Sounds of Murder
entries: Hollow echoes of thousands of overlapping cawing crows fill the area.

entries.name: Navigating the Maze
entries: When the characters enter the Fields of the Crow, {@area Raum's|239|x} voice rings out upon the wind:

"Such strong wills have entered the rows. I can feel your souls struggle to cling to your flesh. Now you scurry like rats in a maze. No more than three creeping hours until you are lost forever. Come to me in the heart of the fields. Feed me your secrets and drift into eternal sleep."

After entering the demonic realm of Raum, the characters experience a reality warp into a waking nightmare as they are trapped in an infinite corn maze. They must reach the center of the maze to find and destroy Raum. Along the way, they find wandering spirits of the people of Foxwillow. Destroying Raum saves these spirits, but freeing them from their listless wandering grants the characters boons in the final confrontation.

entries.name: Time Pressure
entries: While in the Fields of the Crow, the characters feel, with growing dread, their sense of self slowly slipping away. After three hours, the characters' souls are ripped from their bodies, condemned to wander the Fields of the Crow for eternity. Their bodies transform into scarecrows, forever trapped in Foxwillow. This could mark the end of the campaign—unless a path to salvation remains. Perhaps a new band of adventurers is introduced, guided by the willful spirits of the fallen, or {@area The Crooked Man|1ab|x}, acting for the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}, offers salvation at a dreadful price.

entries.name: Which Way?
entries: This maze has no map. Instead, those lost inside must choose the correct path at three Junctions to reach Raum. Each Junction is a 50-foot-radius clearing with three new paths to choose from: Left, Right, or Center. To discover which path is correct, a {@action Search|XPHB} action and a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check allows the characters to discern which path has the loudest cawing of crows. On a failure, they only learn which path is the quietest (narrowing their options down to two). If the check fails by 5 or more, the crass cacophony of the crows surrounds them, making it impossible to discern the paths. The correct order of paths to follow is:

items: First Junction: Left Path
Second Junction: Right Path
Third Junction: Left Path

entries: When the characters enter the maze, they travel through the winding, 5-foot-wide paths of the maze for 10 minutes before reaching a Junction with three paths and a random encounter (see "{@area Random Encounters|2a0|x}" below). If they choose the wrong path at any Junction, they wander for 10 minutes before reaching a Dead End (also a 50-foot radius clearing in the corn maze and a random encounter). They must then backtrack to the last Junction to choose again.

If they choose the correct path, they wind through the corn maze for 10 minutes before reaching the next Junction. When they choose the correct path from the Third Junction, they travel for 10 minutes before reaching the center of the maze. See {@area The Wicked Harvest|2a9|x}, for the final battle against Raum.

entries.name: Random Encounters
entries: Each time the characters enter a Junction or Dead End for the first time, roll once on the Cornfield Encounters table and once on the Cornfield Environment table below to determine what creatures are in that Junction or Dead End and what environmental effects are in play. Roll again if you roll a result that's already been used. After all encounters and environments have been rolled, any further random encounter results in a Crowstorm with Disorienting Crowsong.

entries.caption: Cornfield Encounters
rows: Controlled by Secrets
Crowstorm
Familiar Faces
Lost Soul

entries.name: Controlled by Secrets
entries: Adelaide Langtree ({@creature Corvodaemon|CrookedMoon24}) is here. As a chosen disciple of Raum, she has the power to manipulate characters who have given up their secrets to Raum to buy entrance to the maze. Should the characters find themselves here, Adelaide can cast {@spell Dominate Person|XPHB} at will (spell save {@dc 14}), targeting only someone who paid their own secret to enter the maze and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability. This use of the spell plays on the character's fears about their secret coming to light, so targets that have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition automatically succeed on the saving throw.

entries.name: Crowstorm
entries: The twisting maze of moving corn narrows, and suddenly the characters are surrounded by screeching crows from all sides. An enraged {@creature Crowstorm|CrookedMoon24} attacks in a frenzy. The characters can defeat or evade the crowstorm to proceed through the maze.

entries.name: Familiar Faces
entries: Two Foxwillowers are chained to stout, blood-stained wood poles in the center of the Junction. Their heads are bowed, and they call weakly, begging for help when they see the characters. Choose whichever two villagers the characters formed the best relationship with. The figures are imposters created by Raum's stolen secrets and crow spies. The imposters use the {@creature Doppelganger|XMM} stat block and immediately begin reading the character's surface thoughts with {@b Read Thoughts}.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the figures and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check—made with {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} if the character is more than 10 feet away—notices subtle, unsettling warps of facial features that give away the disguise. Anyone that doesn't succeed on the check is surprised when the imposters attack.
The imposters' chains vanish and they attack as soon as someone comes within reach, or when they realize their ruse failed. When defeated, they dissolve back into whisps of nightmare and fade away.

entries.name: Lost Soul
entries: The spirit of someone from Foxwillow is being tortured for any secrets it has left to hide by two {@creature Corvodaemon|CrookedMoon24|Corvodaemons}. The spirit has AC 14, HP 40, and a {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} of 20 feet. It fails all ability checks and saving throws and can't take actions. Only one demon attacks the spirit each turn, and they only use their Feeding Frenzy action when attacking the spirit; the other demon focuses on the characters. If someone destroys the demons or escapes from them to the next Junction before the spirit is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and devoured, it thanks them and promises to aid them against The Harvest Terror before fading away. Each character gains {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}.

entries.caption: Cornfield Environment
rows: Blood Rain
Body of Crops
Disorienting Crowsong
Shadows of the Lost

entries.name: Blood Rain
entries: The ground shakes and thunder booms as a storm suddenly arises. Blood rains down in sheets, the thick liquid blinding and stinging eyes. The air becomes heavy and hot, and the stinking smell of copper becomes suffocatingly thick. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition while in this Junction.

entries.name: Body of Crops
entries: The corpses of people Raum has not yet returned as scarecrows form a nauseating crop circle in the middle of this clearing. Corn sprouts from the corpses in various states of decay—stalks rip out of chest cavities, biceps, and even mangled faces with lifeless, staring eyes. Choose twelve spaces in this Junction to place these corpses when the characters first enter it. A character who comes within 5 feet of a gruesome corpse or starts its turn within 5 feet of one must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level from horror and disgust.

entries.name: Disorienting Crowsong
entries: A murder of crows circles above the corn maze clustering thick enough to blot out the orange moon, and their song becomes a disorienting cacophony. At the start of each character's turn while in this Junction, roll {@dice 1d6} and subtract the number rolled from their attack rolls and spell save DC until the start of their next turn. Anyone who paid a secret hears Raum taunting them about it in the crowsong and must roll {@dice 1d10} instead.

entries.name: Shadows of the Lost
entries: Shadowy, insubstantial figures rise out of the ground in this Junction—screaming images of all the people that The Harvest Terror spirited away into the Fields of the Crow. At the start of each of their turns, a character must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Psychic damage. Those who have paid a secret to enter the maze have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on this saving throw.

entries.name: The Wicked Harvest
entries: {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24} lurks at the heart of the cornfield, weaving the secrets given to him by his crow messengers into fiendish straw, which he uses to stuff his fiendish scarecrow body. Use {@adventure the Circle of Secrets map|CrookedMoon|6|Map: Circle of Secrets} for this battle.

entries.name: Demonic Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the demonic influence suffusing the Fields of the Crow causes one of the following effects; it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Glean Secrets
entries: The fields steal fragments of a victim's secrets and whisper them to Raum. Wisdom Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, one creature in the clearing. Failure: The target's attack rolls against The Harvest Terror have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following turn.

entries.name: Stalking Corn
entries: Demonic corn snakes around an intruder. Strength Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, up to three creatures in the clearing. Failure: The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

entries.name: Phase 1: A Feast for Crows
entries: In phase one of the fight, {@area Raum|239|x} conjures thousands of demonic crows to his side to gather the full power of his hoarded secrets over the course of three rounds. Read or paraphrase the following when the characters enter this arena:

You break free from the maze's twisting paths and step into a large crop circle where the corn is carved into arcane sigils and demonic eyes. At the center stands a scarecrow—burlap head, straw hat, and a rusty cage for a chest. Slowly, it swivels toward you, and in a trembling, terrified whisper, it says, "Virgil is coming! Too late for me. No, gosh, no... he's here! You gotta get out of—!"

The scarecrow's body erupts into a great abomination of black feathers, twisted metal, and ragged burlap, a horrific demon that lets out a high pitched screech followed by rapid clicking. A guttural voice crows out, "Feed me your secrets, your flesh, your souls, your power!" Raum, The Harvest Terror, spreads four black wings and lunges forward with its rusted claw and scythe appendages raised high toward the fiendish harvest moon above.

The desperate cries are the last vestiges of {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x}, still trapped deep within Raum, {@creature The Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24}. Roll Initiative! This first phase of the battle is to stop The Harvest Terror from devouring secrets in the form of the amber-eyed crows, limiting his power. Three crows that break off from the mass are {@creature Corvodaemon|CrookedMoon24|Corvodaemons}. The demons seek to shred the intruders, prioritizing anyone attacking or catching amber-eyed crows (see {@area Growing Murder|2b0|x} below). The demons have the following special considerations:

items: The demons lack the Multiattack action.

If a corvodaemon takes any damage, it vanishes in a swirl of feathers and black mist. It reforms in an unoccupied space of The Harvest Terror's choice on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 0 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties).

entries.name: Growing Murder
entries: A dense murder of amber crows surrounds The Harvest Terror in a 5-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} with the following effects:

items: A creature other than a demon has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls while in this area.
A creature that ends its turn in the area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Devourer of Secrets
entries: While the murder of crows persists, The Harvest Terror can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to catch and devour one of the amber-eyed crows. Each time it does, the following occurs:

items: The Harvest Terror gains 10 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}. Each crow beyond the first increases this number by 10.
The {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} of crows increases by 5 feet.

entries: The characters can stop Raum from devouring crows in two ways:

entries.name: Catching
entries: A character can catch a crow with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} to grapple it, catch it in a Net, or any other method that you deem acceptable. To grab a crow by hand, a character must enter the murder.

entries.name: Destroying
entries: An amber-eyed crow is a Tiny Fiend with AC 14, HP 5, and +0 to any {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} it is forced to make. It automatically succeeds on Dexterity saving throws against areas of effect and takes no damage from such effects that would deal half damage on a successful save.

Each time a crow is caught or destroyed, it vanishes in a puff of amber motes, and the characters hear a whispered secret, such as "I always loved you," "I took it," or something similar, with no indication of who the secret belonged to.

entries.name: Ending the Phase
entries: When The Harvest Terror devours three amber-eyed crows, or when six crows are destroyed or captured, the swarming murder explodes into feathers and its effects end. Any remaining corvodaemons have 20 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and no longer vanish when they take damage. Move on to the next phase, {@area Demon of Secrets|2b5|x}, below.

entries.name: Phase 2: Demon of Secrets
entries: Fully empowered by secrets, Raum seeks to feast on the interlopers' flesh and souls.

entries.name: Foxwillow's Tender Secrets
entries: Not all secrets are sinister. If the characters have discovered any of the tender secrets of the Foxwillowers' love for Ol' Jericho Sticks while investigating (see {@area Optional Clues|274|x} earlier in this chapter), read or paraphrase the following:

A memory flares in your mind of a joyful secret that the people of Foxwillow kept for Ol' Jericho Sticks. As the memory fades, an amber strand of straw winds around your wrist, radiating protective warmth.

When The Harvest Terror reduces a character to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the amber strand shatters, immediately restoring half of that character's maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. Each character can benefit from this effect only once.

entries.name: The Heroes' Dark Secrets
entries: Those who paid their own secret for entrance to the Fields of the Crow have granted Raum special power over them. The Harvest Terror gains one additional use of Legendary Resistance for each secret that was paid by the characters (not by NPCs such as Jonah) to enter the Fields of the Crow.

entries.name: Defeat of The Harvest Terror
entries: When The Harvest Terror is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

Raum lets out a piercing wail, exploding into a storm of fiendish straw and black feathers. As the cloud fades, a faint image of a scarecrow emerges, strumming a sorrowful tune on a banjo. He gazes at you with a sad smile, tipping his hat.

"Bring 'em home safe," he murmurs. "They'll come out of the corn, so long as their bodies ain't too damaged." He glances up as the moon shifts from orange to white. "I'm sorry, didn't mean for any of it. Virgil's words were sweet. Didn't know what I was doin'. Not sure if it helps, but... well. Show's over."

With a final bow, he vanishes. Your vision blurs, and when it clears, you stand at the edge of the cornfield. The stalks have shrunk back to normal. Silvery spirits emerge, drifting dazedly toward their bodies in Foxwillow.
The iron cage that made up Raum's chest remains behind and thrums with magical power. It can be used as an {@item Amber Birdcage|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 5, if they are still at level 4, when they destroy Raum.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Chariot|05a|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the {@item Scythe of the Harvest Terror|CrookedMoon24} can be removed from the broken scarecrow body of Raum.

entries.name: Conclusion: Out of the Maze
entries: The {@area Fields of the Crow|292|x} have been banished from Druskenvald, and now the corn can be harvested as usual. After a few nights of uneasy rest, the people of Foxwillow return to their work, sending shipments to Wickermoor as though nothing had happened. But something did happen, and it cannot be forgotten.

{@area Martha's|243|x} youngest, Rosemary, is among the saved, as is {@area Jonah's|24b|x} daughter Liza—if her scarecrow wasn't lost to the flames. Regardless of {@area Adelaide's|247|x} fate in the maze, she never returns from the Fields of the Crow. Martha grieves for her two eldest but finds solace in their vengeance and the souls that were spared.

William thanks the characters for their help and sends them to Wickermoor Village with a letter for {@area Jeremiah Stover|18d|x}, detailing their heroic deed. Before they leave, he offers to host a feast in their honor, sharing the crops they saved. Whether they stay or move on is their choice.

If the characters ever return to Foxwillow or meet a familiar face at the market in {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}, they'll find the town's dark secrets have been laid bare. The people, haunted by their ordeal, have shed tears, and those bonds unbroken by secrets are now stronger, forged in shared suffering.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: Jeremiah Stover cries the news of the victory in Foxwillow after reading William's letter, easily gathering the reward owed to the characters. Whether or not Phillip had previously offered, upon hearing the news, he matches the reward from his own purse.

{@area Sister Rain|18d|x} arrives in Wickermoor Village, seeking members of the Fold of the Patient Lady to help in Foxwillow. Jonah Sawyer's curse still hangs over the land, and Sister Rain hopes to bring the Patient Lady's blessings to heal the withered crops and livestock. She extends an invitation to the characters, believing they can assist.

{@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} approaches with a painting from {@area Gaston Doray|18d|x}, hauntingly similar to Raum's demonic realm. She reveals it came from a prophetic vision and hands them a second vision-inspired painting: a swarm of bats in the mountains beneath a blood-red moon.

data.name: The Crimson Monastery

entries: In the flames, there is purity and salvation. From the flames, she speaks. Her voice rings out, like the bell of our great cathedral, with truth, love, and beauty that only the divine can know. Cast by the flames, her shadow spreads and dances, as does her holy word. Under her shadow, we are but weeds in the garden of paradise. But through the flames, our ashes may sprout a brilliant, blood-red rose.

Within the stone walls of the Crimson Monastery lies a beating and repulsive heart. Led by one of the Fallen, the blood-stained fallen knight Marius Renathyr {@i (MAIR-ee-iss REN-uh-theer)}, the zealous and self-righteous adherents of the Crimson Faith swarm across Wickermoor Hollow, claiming all outside their faith to be impure, and that only conversion to the worship of their esoteric goddess, the Crimson Rose, will set them on the path to purity. Those who do not convert are kidnapped and burned at the stake, and those who resist are slaughtered.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: The Crimson Monastery looms high above Wickermoor Hollow in the mountain range called the Howlers, leering down at the town of Dawn's Gate, which now trembles whenever the charging riders and baying bat hounds of the Sanguine Hunt thunder down the mountainside in search of fresh blood to spill. Any infraction against {@area Father Renathyr's|2c2|x} obsessive code of virtue and purification makes that person a target. The people of Dawn's Gate yearn for freedom from fear.

At the center of this twisted faith lies Viraxys {@i (vih-RAK-seez)}, a devil who calls herself the Crimson Rose. Renathyr, once a noble knight, was tainted by her, turning his piety into relentless zealotry. Should her corruption be exposed, the Crimson Faith would crumble into chaos.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} must die! Or so believe the people of Dawn's Gate, who suffer most at the hands of his zealots. Characters who are drawn to the monastery by the Quest Hook later in this chapter have several goals:

items: Discover the whereabouts of Gareth Creed.
Discover the truth of Viraxys, the Crimson Rose.
Slay Father Renathyr, {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}.
Disband the Crimson Faithful.

entries: While investigating the order, characters may avoid combat through deception or stealth. However, the confrontation with Renathyr and the corrupting devil Viraxys inevitably ends in battle.

Before running this chapter, you should read about the {@area NPCs of the monastery|2cb|x}. Because the characters will be watched, knowing the clergy's methods of investigation and reactions to what they observe—whether the characters are hostile, deceptive, understanding, or stealthy—makes running the monastery more organic. Further, combing through the room descriptions of The Crimson Monastery {@area the Crimson Monastery|2e0|x} will help you build tension and dread for your players, better equipping you to react to what the characters choose to do.
Finally, reading through the boss encounter "{@area Bloody Tears|335|x}" will help you run the final battle of this chapter in a dynamic and thrilling way.
This chapter is designed for four level 5 characters.

entries.name: The Crimson Abbot
entries: Father Marius Renathyr is the leader and abbot of the Crimson Monastery. His name is whispered by the villagers of Dawn's Gate and rapturously exulted by his flock. Though he was once a human knight of unimpeachable character, Father Renathyr is now a vampire sustained by the blood of his converts. His noble zeal was twisted into fear and cruelty by the devil that saved his life and granted him his vampiric immortality.
The tragedy of Marius Renathyr is inexorably tied to that of Lethica Nightborne, another of the Fallen (see chapter {@adventure Memory's Rest|CrookedMoon|10}). This is the beginning of that tale.

entries.name: The Knight's Tale
entries: Sir Marius Renathyr was once a knight-errant of another world. His armor gleamed gold, his banner a lionhearted red. Cast into the fallen land of Druskenvald by means unknown, his conviction toward righteousness was undeterred. He gathered knights to his side to protect the innocent from monsters and wicked men.

One such innocent was a traveling priestess named Lethica Nightborne, a devotee to a goddess of sheltering night called the Nightmother. Accosted on the road by cruel men, Marius rescued her and delivered her safely to her cloister. Love blossomed between the knight of light and the priestess of darkness, but Marius remained chaste and returned to his questing.

Marius's return to the cloister became frequent as their love burned, yet Marius's sacred mission took its toll. Over the years, his kindness dulled, making way for zeal and wrath. It was this wrath that attracted a devil named Viraxys, who preyed upon men with wickedness; mortals acting upon their evil impulses by inflicting sorrow corrupted their souls, making them a delicious ambrosia on which she fed. Marius had slain his fair share of her puppets over the years, but now she saw her chance to make him into a puppet himself.

Seeking to ensnare him, Viraxys set a small army of bandits against Marius, leaving him near death. Whispering falsely as a goddess, she offered immortality in exchange for his blood and his service in her quests. Marius accepted and was made immortal—a vampire. His knightly sword transformed into a blood-soaked blade, a symbol that he was now her champion. Marius returned to his wife and revealed his affliction. Though Lethica loved him, his shame blinded him to her devotion.

Bloodthirst overtook him. In a moment of lost control, he nearly fed on his wife. Though regaining his senses in time, the guilt was too great, and Marius abandoned his love, wandering until he reached the town of Dawn's Gate. There, Viraxys led him to a small monastery, where his knightly charm and renewed zeal for the Crimson Rose corrupted the monks into followers of his false goddess. Four years passed before Lethica found him again, now as Father Renathyr, fanatical leader of the Crimson Faith. Horrified, she fled to the Isle of Mourn.

Her story continues in "{@adventure Memory's Rest|CrookedMoon|10}," but Renathyr's must end here. He crusades now against all the sins of the world, real or imagined, and brings terror to Dawn's Gate and beyond.

entries.name: Parley with the Abbot
entries: Father Renathyr spends his waking hours searching for those who will accept the teachings of his goddess, the Crimson Rose, or destroying those who reject his faith—either with fire or by feeding. In public, he masks his true form with {@spell Disguise Self|XPHB}. He meets with the faithful, leading spirited services and offering devotion to his goddess in the Sanguine Cathedral ({@area area M12|319|x}), and he offers private guidance to those who seek it atop the bell tower ({@area area M14|320|x}). As abbot, he meets with each of his key clergy and initiates to ensure the piety of Dawn's Gate, and that the townsfolk seek out nonbelievers.

In the late hours of night, Renathyr takes his own form of communion with his goddess, feeding in secret within a private sanctum beneath the monastery ({@area area M16|32e|x}). Outwardly, he may appear compassionate and wise, the exemplar of a pious leader. Inwardly, he broods with growing bitterness, driven by the unquenchable need to deliver more souls to Viraxys.
If the characters meet Renathyr and speak with him, these are his answers to some common topics:

entries.title: Father Renathyr and Sir Marius Renathyr

entries.name: Missing Persons
entries: "We may take in those in need of our protection or atonement for wrongdoing, but we do not keep anyone prisoner. You are more than welcome to walk our halls if you do not trust my word." This is a lie, and a successful {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check reveals it as such.

entries.name: The Pyre
entries: "The pyre before you will only burn the wicked—those whose souls are tainted by impure, mortal blood. Those who accept the Crimson Rose into their hearts will be purified willingly, as part of our Crimson Faith. It saddens me that there are those whose pride is so great they refuse our goddess's gift, for they leave me only one way of purifying them."

entries.name: Your Crimson Goddess
entries: "The Crimson Rose. I am her champion. In my darkest hour, she saved me from death and whispered to me the truth: that mortal blood is impure and the source of all suffering in this sorrowful land. It must be cleansed."

entries.name: Entry to the Monastery
entries: "By all means, my children. Think of it as home. We keep neither property nor secrets in this sacred community. All that is ours is yours."

entries.name: Duchess
entries: {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} believes Duchess, the blade he keeps at his side, is sentient. The sword claims to be a divine tool bestowed by the Crimson Rose upon her champion so that he may cleanse the evil of this realm. Father Renathyr mutters to it constantly, both in response and unbidden, and has become addicted to heeding its commands.

In truth, it possesses no sentience of its own and is a conduit for Viraxys. She orchestrates Father Renathyr into committing acts of depraved cruelty to feed upon the tormented souls of those slaughtered by the Sanguine Hunt and burned alive by his {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x}. While she dines well upon the souls of the innocent, Renathyr remains her crowning achievement; it is no small joy for her to make someone fall, but to make someone as devoted as Renathyr fall is ecstasy.

entries.name: NPCs of the Monastery
entries: The Crimson Monastery is filled with zealous acolytes of the Crimson Rose. Many are cowards who chose to convert to this cruel cult to avoid being slain by the inquisitors of the Sanguine Hunt, but most are well-meaning people who were brainwashed by the order's overwhelming false love and black-and-white morality.

entries.name: The Bloodless
entries: The most devoted inner circle of this faith are vampires, turned by {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} personally in a ceremony of ascension called the Rite of Bloodletting. They call themselves "The Bloodless," and their pale skin is a blessed sign that they are devoid of the impure blood that sullies mortal souls. They stalk the halls of the monastery and menace the town of Dawn's Gate as part of Renathyr's crusade to spread his depraved faith. All the Bloodless besides Renathyr's priors use the {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24} stat block.

These vampire supplicants are so brainwashed that they would follow this path even if they learned the truth: that their goddess was a devil in disguise. However, the general faithful would not accept this revelation and would turn against them if it were revealed.

entries.name: Renathyr's Priors
entries: {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} has elected his three closest confidants as priors of the Crimson Monastery: Houndmaster Jaeger, Friar Olaf, and Inquisitor Cromwell. In this role, they act as Renathyr's "lieutenants," forming the leadership of the faith and overseeing their respective duties. They are, without a doubt, the most faithful of the Bloodless, and any one of them could succeed Renathyr and keep the Crimson Faith alive if he is slain.

In return for their service, Father Renathyr has granted them a grotesque gift. Through profane rituals and blood magic, Renathyr has transformed each of his priors into {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24|Night Creatures}. The priors are gifted with a potent disguise to keep their nature hidden from the Crimson Faithful and only shift into their true forms when "killed" (see "{@area Houndmaster Jaeger|2ce|x}," " {@area Friar Olaf|2d0|x}," and "{@area Inquisitor Cromwell|2d2|x}" below).

If the characters arrive at the monastery during a Night of Flames (see "{@area Investigating the Village|2dc|x}" below), the priors are in the Courtyard of the Rose ({@area area M4|2f9|x}) to witness the burnings. Afterward, they retreat to their individual quarters. Each prior is described in further detail below.

entries.name: Houndmaster Jaeger
entries: Sigmund Jaeger served {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} as a squire during Renathyr's time as a knight, raising hunting dogs to track down men and monsters alike.

When the knight founded the Crimson Faith, Jaeger was the first Renathyr sought and the first to convert. The houndmaster had a loving family once, but—like Renathyr—he abandoned them, tempted by the promises of the Crimson Rose. He took only his hounds with him, which he turned into batlike hybrids using blood magic. Now a prior of the Crimson Monastery, Jaeger rears and trains the {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds} and {@creature Warhorse|XMM|Warhorses} used to track down the faithless.

entries.name: Meeting Jaeger
entries: Jaeger resides within his cabin ({@area area M3|2f7|x}) and trains his bat hounds near their houses ({@area area M2a|2f6|x}) outside the monastery walls. He treats the characters as treasured guests, so long as they show interest in the Crimson Faith. The moment they refuse the faith, he attacks, siccing his bat hounds on them.

Jaeger is a Neutral Evil, human {@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}, but when he is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, he takes on his true {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24} form with full HP.

entries.name: Friar Olaf
entries: As a young monk, Friar Olaf of the Silver Bells was the leader of the monastery before Renathyr took it over and became his second convert thereafter. In its early years, the cloister was called Silverbell Monastery, for it overlooks the Silverbell River in the valley below, and it was dedicated to the Patient Lady. There, Olaf and his monks tended to the infirm and to outcasts, but he longed in his heart for glory. He demanded payment from his charges and commissioned a great silver bell for the monastery inscribed with his name so that he would be remembered forever.
Renathyr's arrival stoked Olaf's hunger for reverence and immortality. It was simple to urge Olaf onward from stipends of coin to sacrifices of blood.

entries.name: Meeting Friar Olaf
entries: In his role as prior, Olaf is most often found leading sermons in the Sanguine Cathedral ({@area area M12|319|x}), though he may also be in his chambers ({@area area M8|310|x}). He is feared, not beloved, by the people of the Crimson Faith, making him the perfect foil to the adored {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}. He makes a show of kindness toward the characters as potential new converts but will gladly feed on anyone who questions him if he thinks they will not be missed.
Olaf is a Neutral Evil, human {@creature Priest|XMM}, but when he is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, he takes on his true {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24} form with full HP.

entries.name: Inquisitor Cromwell
entries: Leona Cromwell was once a child of Dawn's Gate, learning her letters and numbers under the shadow of Friar Olaf. Yet, over the years, her contempt for the pompous friar festered, driving her away from the monastery. She wandered to Wickermoor Village, picking up odd jobs and eventually working as a town guard. Her fate changed course when a group of highwaymen took her captive. Marius Renathyr came to her rescue and drove the bandits to the marshes south of Moonsong Lake. Rather than flee, she used her skills with a blade to slay their leader and demanded obedience from the weakened crew.

For years, she was known as Leona the Relentless, leading raids through Wickermoor Hollow. But the guilt of her deeds gnawed at her soul. She learned that the great Sir Marius who saved her life years prior had hung up his sword, and she traveled to his Crimson Monastery to repent. {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}, a twisted reflection of the knight he once was, spoke of the Crimson Rose, offering redemption for her tarnished soul. Stricken with guilt but unwilling to let go of the power she craved as a bandit queen, Leona accepted his gift.

Now, as prioress and head inquisitor of the Crimson Monastery, she leads the Sanguine Hunt with ruthless devotion; whenever their hooves echo through Wickermoor Hollow, it is Leona's blade that cuts the path.

entries.name: Meeting Inquisitor Cromwell
entries: Cromwell is often away from the monastery, but the first time the characters visit Dawn's Gate, she is present for the Night of Flames in the Courtyard of the Rose ({@area area M4|2f9|x}). After the pyre is cleared, she spends her time in her chambers ({@area area M9|312|x}) planning her next hunt. Cromwell is suspicious of the characters, for she knows all too well how people of great strength resist the call of the Crimson Rose. She resents their resolve and tries to kill them if goaded even mildly. If Renathyr is defeated while she is absent, she may return to revive his faith later—if you wish to create subsequent adventures in this region.

Cromwell is a Neutral Evil, human {@creature Knight|XMM}, but when she is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, she takes on her true {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24} form with full HP.

entries.name: Crimson Faithful
entries: Most of the Crimson Faithful are simple people who have been taken in by Renathyr and his vampiric minions' charisma. These initiates make up a majority of the congregation in the Crimson Monastery and are simple believers without rank or station. They revere the Bloodless as leaders of the faith, holding great respect for their closeness to {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}.

They are kept from thinking too deeply about the atrocities they commit, as their blood loss causes them to drift absentmindedly through their nights. They regularly sacrifice their impure blood in phony rituals of purification. They have a {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} attitude toward any newcomers until given a reason to think differently. Unless otherwise noted, Crimson Faithful are Lawful Evil, human {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}.

entries.name: Losing Favor
entries: The characters are immediately welcomed in as prospective converts. However, if they commit three actions to upset the faithful, such as those listed below, all clergy members turn {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward them within the hour. Being caught committing one more infraction turns them all {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, and they attack on sight:

items: Harm or threaten a member of the clergy.
Steal from a member of the clergy.
React negatively or disagree with the clergy's torture, teachings, or bonfires.
Attempt to remove, kidnap, or free any creature from the monastery grounds without permission from {@area Jaeger|2ce|x}, {@area Olaf|2d0|x}, {@area Cromwell|2d2|x}, or {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}.
Trespass anywhere in the monastery.

entries: Anyone seen killing a member of the faithful instantly becomes an enemy of the faith. All the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} who witness or hear of the killing immediately become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}.

entries.name: Regaining Favor
entries: Characters who have frustrated the Crimson Faithful enough to turn them {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} can make them {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} again by committing three of the following actions and succeeding on a {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check:

items: Respond positively to torture or corporal punishment against the faithless.
Respond positively to or agree with the teachings of the Crimson Rose.
Respond positively to or agree with the bonfire killings the clergy commit.

entries.name: Atonement
entries: If the Crimson Faithful become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, there's only one way to win back their trust: repent. Characters attacked by {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} members of the Crimson Faithful aren't killed but are instead captured and bound in the Dead Larder ({@area area M11|315|x}). They are held for up to three nights without food before they are mounted upon a pyre at the next Night of Flames, where they must recant their wickedness or burn.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: The characters may travel to the Crimson Monastery of their own volition, but this adventure starts from Wickermoor Village with the following Quest Hook.

entries.name: The Missing Pilgrim
entries: The characters are approached by Weston Murdoch and are told a concerning story about two followers of the Brightsinger named Melina and Gareth. They traveled together to the village of Dawn's Gate after hearing tales of the beautiful bell of Silverbell Monastery, but they found that it had changed. The villagers praised someone called the "Crimson Abbot" with strained smiles, and when a stable hand took Gareth aside to tell him a secret about the village, neither the boy nor Gareth returned.

Melina fled the village and told Murdoch, hoping that he might know someone brave enough to find Gareth and solve the mystery of {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}. Murdoch describes Gareth Creed as a tall, dark-haired, short-bearded man with gray eyes.

Traveling to Dawn's Gate requires crossing the Silverbell River by either bridge or boat and following its southern side for about 3 nights until the burnt copper glow of the village's lights are visible. Characters who camp within walking distance of the settlement are ambushed during the Midnight Hour by an {@creature Alpengrendel|CrookedMoon24} that has come down from the Howlers to hunt.

entries.name: Arrival in Dawn's Gate
entries: To reach the Crimson Monastery, the characters must first pass through the dour village of Dawn's Gate. Once a shining example of hope in the shadows of Druskenvald, the village had clung to the belief that the Patient Lady might one night deliver sunlight to Wickermoor Hollow. But that hope has long withered, buried alongside the optimism of the town's founders.

Now, the village ekes out a living through hunting, farming, and mining silver and iron from the nearby mountains. Worship of the Crimson Rose is enforced with unwavering severity. Each night, the monastery's bell calls the village to prayer at the Twilight and Evening hours. Any who worship another god, hide their sins, fail to kneel, or speak ill of the Crimson Faithful are swiftly taken to the monastery—and never seen again.

entries.name: A Cold Ale at Briar Public House
entries: Being a small community, there is little here for outsiders. Briar Public House was opened to provide a drinking spot for locals, but it also offers food and lodging for travelers and merchants who find their way into the small village. Briar Public House is owned and operated by {@creature Kristoff Gruber|CrookedMoon24} (Neutral Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}), a portly, gruff man whose sour disposition belies his caring nature.

entries.name: Investigating the Village
entries: The people of Dawn's Gate never speak ill of the Crimson Faithful in public. In fact, a successful {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check reveals insincere smiles and furtive looks over their shoulders. They speak truly that Dawn's Gate rarely suffers the monsters or brigands that plague other parts of Wickermoor Hollow, but it's clear they fear something else.

entries.name: Missing Person
entries: Those who ask around the village for clues about the missing pilgrim, Gareth from Wickermoor Village, are stonewalled by smiling villagers. They say that they saw someone of that description come through the town, but he asked too many questions. If they wait until the Evening Hour bell, they see a huge bonfire alight in the mountains, and the villagers become slightly more talkative (see below).

entries.name: The Night of Flames
entries: Every three nights, the Sanguine Hunt thunders through town and up the mountainside, returning from their raids. That evening, a fire burns atop the hill, its light visible for miles around. During this time, the villagers of Dawn's Gate speak more freely, since all the Crimson Faithful in the village have returned to the monastery. They whisper that they are being watched, and that those who are taken to the monastery for "purification" are never seen again. That includes a man who matches Gareth's description.

entries.name: Impromptu Ambush
entries: The characters may decide that intercepting the Sanguine Hunt on their next outing is the best course of action. The Sanguine Hunt returns to the monastery during a Night of Flames, and when the Twilight Hour bell rings on the following night, their departure from the monastery back into Wickermoor Hollow echoes across the countryside.

This unit of the Sanguine Hunt is an inquisition force of three Lawful Evil, human {@creature Knight|XMM|Knights} led by Head Inquisitor Cromwell (Neutral Evil, human {@creature Knight|XMM}) all on {@creature Warhorse|XMM|Warhorses}. One knight grips the leash of a vicious {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24}, ready to be sicced on anyone foolish enough to turn tail in the Sanguine Hunt's presence. If Cromwell is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, she transforms into her true {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24} form and presses the attack.

If the characters attack the Sanguine Hunt as they pass through Dawn's Gate, five villagers wielding shovels and cleavers (Neutral Evil, human {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} with descriptive changes but still use the Scimitar action) attack the characters to prove their loyalty to the Crimson Faith, but the rest of the villagers watch with rapt attention, hoping the characters triumph over the riders.

Cromwell is a fanatic and, if addressed or captured, speaks glowingly of {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}, the noble knight who hung up his sword to serve the Crimson Rose and purify the sullied blood of mortals in her name. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, characters who press her for secrets about the cult and succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}) check learn each of the following pieces of information:

items: The Crimson Faithful worship the Crimson Rose, a goddess who speaks directly to Father Renathyr through the blade {@area Duchess|2ca|x}, which marks him as her champion. All of Druskenvald will be cleansed of evil and made pure again if its people convert.

The leaders of the Crimson Faith are the Bloodless—mortals blessed by the Crimson Rose. Their bodies have been made pure by being drained of blood. Though they must drink blood to survive, unclean mortal blood is purified when it touches their lips.

Cromwell and her Sanguine Hunt bring the sacred word of the Crimson Rose to worshipers of other gods or any whose actions they deem impure. Those who repent may join the Crimson Faithful. Those who do not are taken to the monastery and encouraged to repent on a Night of Flames.

entries.name: The Crimson Monastery
entries: Stone walls rise high into the night, its imposing and spiked silhouette jutting against the night sky. The monastery gazes down upon Dawn's Gate and the Silverbell River from atop its mountainous perch, hiding a blood-drenched order behind its battlements.

entries.name: Crimson Monastery Features
entries: Unless otherwise stated, the indoor areas of the Crimson Monastery have the following general features:

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Rooms and hallways are 15 feet tall.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The side of doors that face hallways and common areas are covered in spikes. A creature who attempts to break down the door from its spiked side takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) Piercing damage. All doors are unlocked unless stated otherwise.

entries.name: Locks
entries: Some doors within the Crimson Monastery are locked and can only be opened with a skeleton key or picked using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check. Renathyr and his priors possess skeleton keys.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Unless otherwise stated, areas within are lit by candles and torches and are {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Bloodstone Structure
entries: The material of the monastery prevents blood from drying on its surface, creating an easy trail for those who smell blood to follow. Creatures missing any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks, and creatures that are {@status Bloodied|XPHB} automatically fail Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Blood-Red Windows
entries: All the windows in this monastery are made of uniformly red stained glass arranged into mesmerizing, rose-petal patterns. Candlelight that spills out bathes the area around it in an eerie red hue.

entries.name: Eternal Night
entries: The blessing of the Crimson Rose protects her Bloodless worshipers. Sunlight from spells or other magical effects doesn't harm vampires within the walls and grounds of the monastery.

entries.name: Retreating From the Monastery
entries: If the characters become overwhelmed and need to retreat from the monastery, the situation changes by the time they return, based on the Crimson Faithful's attitude toward them.

entries.name: Friendly
entries: The characters are welcomed back as old friends and chided not to leave again unless commanded, lest they accidentally spread wickedness throughout the world.

entries.name: Indifferent
entries: They are scolded for leaving and made to lead a Night of Flames to atone for their departure.

entries.name: Hostile
entries: The gates are barred against the characters, and the Crimson Faithful attack on sight to drive them away.

Some adjustments to areas may be necessary depending on the actions of the characters. A character who offended or acted against a clergy member might discover someone they are close to has been taken and held within the Dead Larder ({@area area M11|315|x}), or {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} may greet the characters personally upon their return if they have made themselves beloved among the congregation.

entries.name: Crimson Monastery Locations
entries: The following areas are keyed to The Crimson Monastery map. The descriptions of these areas assume that the characters have arrived on the night of a Night of Flames (see "{@area Investigating the Village|2dc|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: M1: Monastery Grounds
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

You travel up a winding pass through the slate-gray mountains for what feels like hours. Then, through a copse of dead trees, you see it: the high stone walls of a monastery with a bell tower rising stories above. Thousands of bats swarm in and out of the belfry, spreading out on a night flight into the valley below.

At the center is a grand cathedral, its magnificent stained-glass windows casting crimson light into the mountain pass, lighting a path toward the monastery's sealed gates. Blood-red banners hang from its walls, emblazoned with a golden rose.

A pair of armored warriors keep watch atop the battlements, but they haven't noticed you yet. To one side of the gates is a clearing that holds a stable, a cabin, and several strangely large wooden boxes.
Two {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Warrior Veterans} watch the gate. If the characters approach it, read or paraphrase the following:

One of the warriors on the battlements raises a hand in greeting. "New guests! Please, come. We have warm beds and food for the weary. What brings you here? Were you drawn by the grace of the Crimson Rose?"

If the characters respond that they're visiting, are curious about the monastery's faith, or seeking someone, they are welcomed into the Courtyard of the Rose ({@area area M4|2f9|x}). If they approach with hostility, make threats, or otherwise make any aggressive or violent action, the guards call for aid and attack. Three {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics} from area M4 open the gates at the start of the next round.

entries.name: Sneaking In
entries: The outer walls of the monastery have several footholds made of vines or loose stonework that make them climbable. To scale unnoticed by the guards, the characters must succeed on a group {@dc 17} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: M2: Stables
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

This wooden structure is where Inquisitor Cromwell and the Sanguine Hunt stable their {@creature Warhorse|XMM|Warhorses} during the night of a burning. There are also four {@creature Riding Horse|XMM|Riding Horses} here. These horses are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} and suspicious of new people but become {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} and ridable with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}) check ({@dc 20} for a warhorse).

One corner of the stables is a small armory where the various weapons, shields, and sets of armor of the Sanguine Hunt are stored. Three members of the Sanguine Hunt (Lawful Evil, human {@creature Knight|XMM|Knights} with an AC of 10) named Landers, Marla, and Fremont are doffing their armor and celebrating the successful capture of the faithless, who are now captive in the courtyard ({@area area M4|2f9|x}). They are here with a stable hand (Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}).

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Justice|062|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Shield of Marius Renathyr|CrookedMoon24} can be found within the armory, hanging in a place of honor as if it hasn't been used in years.

entries.name: M2a: Bat Hound Kennels
entries: A copse of dead trees surrounds the stables. Built into the base of the trees are wooden boxes 10 feet long on all sides with a hole in one face large enough for a mastiff to clamber through. These overlarge bat houses are home to Houndmaster Jaeger's fearsome {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}. During the Dusk and Twilight Hours, eight bat hounds reside here, though none are present from the Evening Hour through the Witching Hour, when they are hunting in the surrounding foothills or lingering in the Watchful Belfry ({@area area M14|320|x}). They are aggressive but can be distracted with bloody treats (see {@area area M3|2f7|x}).

entries.name: M3: Jaeger's Cabin
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

Adjacent to the stables is Houndmaster Sigmund Jaeger's personal cabin. The fastidious houndmaster keeps a rustic and tidy home, though there are bloodstains all over the floor—when he feeds on the blood of the faithful, he feeds his "table scraps" to his hounds.

If the characters come here during a Night of Flames while Jaeger is gone, his worktable is festooned with bloody butchers' tools and covered in the scraps of a freshly hacked Humanoid corpse. If they arrive after he's returned, he greets them with cultish familiarity but tries to shoo them toward Friar Olaf or {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Next to the table is a crate containing training tools and bloody treats for the hounds. If a treat is thrown (up to 30 feet), any bat hounds within 60 feet of the treat rush to it and fight any other hounds for {@dice 1d3} rounds before one of them wins the treat. That hound is distracted for {@dice 1d10} minutes as it chews on the blood-soaked meat.

Additionally, characters who search the cabin and succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check find Jaeger's workbook that contains his notes on utilizing blood magic for a variety of processes, including the creation of {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}, the enchantment of weapons, and the general transference of vitality from one person to another. It also includes his observations on the behavior of the monastery's people, including a note that Father Renathyr spends the Witching Hour in the bell tower every night.

entries.name: M4: Courtyard of the Rose
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

Scattered throughout the monastery's courtyard are stone statues—angels, priestesses, and mourners—dripping with slick, red liquid. Foreboding walls enclose the space, and the red-stained windows and bell tower loom like glaring eyes. In the center, an unlit pyre stands with six stakes, each holding a bound, sobbing figure.
A crowd in red robes surrounds them, waving torches and shouting, "Glory to the Crimson Rose! Blood from the thorn, beauty from the petal!"
Atop a staircase, a man in crimson and gold robes watches silently, waiting for the moment to address the crowd.

The man presiding over this congregation is {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} ({@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}). If the characters enter through the main gates, he throws his arms wide and invites them forward (see "Renathyr's Greeting" below).

entries.name: Crimson Congregation
entries: The crowd consists of fifteen {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics}, eight {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Warrior Veterans}, and three dozen adult and child noncombatants (Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}).

Additionally, six of the Bloodless (see "{@area NPCs of the Monastery|2cb|x}" for their description) are present: Houndmaster Jaeger ({@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}), Friar Olaf ({@creature Priest|XMM}), Inquisitor Cromwell ({@creature Knight|XMM}), and three {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24}. If Jaeger, Olaf, and Cromwell are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, they transform into {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24|Night Creatures}.

entries.name: Renathyr's Greeting
entries: Father Renathyr greets the characters and bids them watch the purification. He meets them on their first visit, answering questions they may have while coloring his answers in ways that present the monastery as a sanctuary and safe place to reside and rest. He even offers meals and warm beds should they need them.

entries.name: Burning at the Stake
entries: The six {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners} about to be burned at the stake are from small towns and settlements across Wickermoor Hollow. One of them is a Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM} named {@creature Gareth Creed|CrookedMoon24} (see "{@area Quest Hook|2d8|x}" earlier in this chapter). These events play out in order, unless the characters intervene:

items: Renathyr genteelly commands Friar Olaf to preach to the captives and incite them to repent.

{@area Olaf|2d0|x} approaches the pyre and accusingly brandishes a lit torch. He tells each of the captives in turn that their lives are worth living, if and only if they accept that their impure mortal blood makes their souls wicked. Only by opening their hearts to the Crimson Rose are they set on the path to purification. If not, their blood must be purified in holy flame.

All but one of the captives, in turn, agree to convert, eliciting manic cries of prayer from the crowd. The gathered worshipers climb onto the pyre and untie the five who accept. These noncombatants join the congregation, shaken.
Gareth, however, refuses. Renathyr frowns, Olaf grins wickedly, and the congregation jeers. Olaf repeats himself, Gareth refuses again, and Olaf lights the pyre.
Renathyr preaches for 1 minute as the flames climb higher, speaking on the futility of clinging to impure mortal blood and how such pride is the source of all Wickermoor Hollow's many sorrows.

Gareth then begins to burn alive, dying in agony over the course of another minute. The congregation falls into a reverent silence. The faint scent of sulfur fills the courtyard as his body is consumed.

After Gareth dies, several of the faithful clean up the pyre, and Renathyr concludes his sermon and bids the characters welcome to the monastery. He urges them to rest, and he will speak to them in his Sanguine Cathedral ({@area area M12|319|x}) after the Twilight Hour bell.

entries.name: Interrupting this Cruelty
entries: If the characters interrupt the Night of Flames, Renathyr urges them to be silent, unless they succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check attempting to convince Gareth to recant and save himself. It takes an additional successful check for Gareth to concede (the DC lowers to 10 if the character mentions Melina). Recanting, Gareth is freed like the others and rejoins the congregation, though he will flee to Wickermoor Village as soon as he is safe to get away.

If the characters attempt to dissuade {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} or the crowd, or if they try to free Gareth, Renathyr commands his congregation to subdue them (the veterans in the crowd try to grapple them), before finally ordering the crowd to attack. With his sermon completed and the order given, he retreats to the Bloody Sanctum ({@area area M16|32e|x}) to commune with {@area Duchess|2ca|x} until early Twilight.

entries.name: No Victory
entries: A fight against the entire congregation is doomed to failure. Their best hope is to fight, retreat, and approach with stealth. If the characters are all defeated, they are knocked {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} rather than killed, and they awaken as captives in the Dead Larder ({@area area M11|315|x}).

entries.name: M5: Monastery Halls
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

The stone halls of the monastery are lit with eerie crimson torches. Wooden doors line one side of the passage, while the other has windows that face the inner courtyard of the monastery. Red-and-gold banners line the walls, and droning prayers echo throughout the halls.

entries.name: First Floor
entries: These halls encircle the main courtyard and connect all the rooms on the first floor.

entries.name: Second Floor
entries: Spiral staircases in two corners of the first floor of the Monastery Halls lead to a hallway that connects all rooms on the second floor.

entries.name: Prying Parishioners
entries: Members of the Crimson Faithful walk trancelike through these hallways periodically. Whenever the characters make a loud noise (such as shouting or casting {@spell Thunderwave|XPHB}), or if a golden opportunity to foil their plans presents itself, roll on the Monastery Halls Encounters table below. How these encounters play out is up to you based on the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x}'s attitude toward the characters.

entries.caption: Monastery Halls Encounters
rows: Friar Olaf ({@creature Priest|XMM}) and three {@creature Priest Acolyte|XMM|Priest Acolytes}
Inquisitor Cromwell ({@creature Knight|XMM}) and two {@creature Knight|XMM|Knights}
Houndmaster Jaeger ({@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}) and three {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}
Three {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24}
One {@creature Knight|XMM} and two {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}
Two {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics} and four {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}
Two {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Warrior Veterans} and one {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24}
Voices pass in the hallway; no one notices you.

entries.name: M5a: Refectory
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

This humble room of simple stone walls and rustic, wooden tables and benches is a refectory where the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} take their meals. Eating in quiet is highly encouraged, with only pre-meal and post-meal prayer and light discussion about the Crimson Rose permitted.

entries.name: Disruption
entries: If the peace of mealtime is violated by the characters, an encounter from the Monastery Halls Encounters table above occurs.

entries.name: M5b: Prayer Nooks
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

Two small rooms with sparse furnishings are used for quiet prayer for solitary worshipers or small groups. Large windows in each space provide a surprisingly beautiful view of the valley below the foothills and a comprehensive look at Dawn's Gate.

entries.name: Disruption
entries: If the quiet prayer is interrupted by the characters, an encounter from the {@adventure Monastery Halls Encounters table|CrookedMoon|7| Monastery Halls Encounters} above occurs.

entries.name: M6: Monastic Cells
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}
A small and bare room containing simple furniture: a table, a chair, a bed, and a footlocker. The only decoration in this room is the monastery's rose crest carved across the stone floor.
These rooms serve as sleeping quarters for {@dice 1d3} members of the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x}. No one is here during the Night of Flames.

entries.name: Who's Here
entries: From the Evening Hour through the Witching Hour, there is an 80 percent chance for someone to be sleeping here. From the Twilight Hour through the Nightfall Hour, there is a 25 percent chance someone is resting, eating, or being amorous here. Choose if the people present are {@creature Priest Acolyte|XMM|Priest Acolytes}, {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics}, {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}, {@creature Knight|XMM|Knights}, {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Warrior Veterans}, or {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24}. A single window looks out onto the monastery grounds. If the characters accept the offer to sleep at the monastery, they are shown to separate cells.

entries.name: Second Floor
entries: Above this floor is a second, identical set of cells that can be accessed from the second floor of the Monastery Halls.

entries.name: M7: Scriptoriums
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}
Simple wooden writing lecterns occupy the center of the room, and shelves filled with tomes and scrolls line the walls.

entries.name: Who's Here
entries: During the Evening Hour there's a 10 percent chance one of the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} is reading or copying a manuscript. This rises to a 50 percent chance during Twilight Hour through the Nightfall Hour. No one is here during the Night of Flames.

entries.name: Reading the Texts
entries: The so-called holy scripture of the Crimson Faith in these scriptoriums is a mix of ramblings by people brainwashed by Renathyr's cult, copies of {@area Olaf's|2d0|x} self-righteous sermons, and heartachingly sad messages from members of the faithful who miss their families. A few are surprisingly persuasive texts written by Renathyr on the virtue of surrendering your will to the divine power of the Crimson Rose. A successful {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check reveals that Renathyr's writings speak of a "{@area Holy Vein|329|x}" and a "{@area Bloody Sanctum|32e|x}" beneath the sanctuary where he communes with the Crimson Rose.

A successful {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check reveals that Renathyr describes himself and his most trusted clergy as "the Bloodless," and cryptically, poetically describes that the Crimson Rose's blessing allows him to purify the blood of the faithful by drinking it.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chamber contains five sets of ornate Calligrapher's Tools worth 50 GP each, seven blank {@item Book|XPHB|Books}, 50 sheets of {@item Paper|XPHB}, and a few texts with useful information. Five Books are general religion texts, and one copy of The Rosen Testament, the core scripture of the monastery's religion. The testament is a Book worth 250 GP due to its artistry and illumination, and functions as a useful reference for information about the Crimson Faithful or vampires.

entries.name: M8: Olaf's Chambers
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

Compared to the cells that other members of the faithful live in, {@area Olaf|2d0|x}'s private study and bedroom is opulent and well-furnished. The door to this chamber is locked. Extravagant stained glass windows look over the eastern battlements.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Tucked away in a drawer within Olaf's writing desk is his personal missal, a liturgical book that contains the prayers and rituals of the Crimson Faith. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines the room and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds the missal. Those who take time to read it find details on the ritual to enter the secret chamber beneath the monastery where the Bloodless receive the gift of the Crimson Rose, and where he, {@area Cromwell|2d2|x}, and {@area Jaeger|2ce|x} had been anointed as the goddess's chosen. To access this chamber, a hidden goblet beneath the altar in the cathedral must be filled with a pint of blood.

entries.name: M9: Cromwell's Chambers
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

{@area Cromwell|2d2|x} treasures her private room, though she is rarely around to use it, and she keeps the door locked when she is not inside. It contains trophies of all manner of hunts and kills over her time as the leader of the monastery's inquisitors. Her chambers possess the same amenities as one of the monastic cells but also includes a chest for her trophies and windows that overlook the eastern battlements. The lid to her chest of trophies is locked by Cromwell's skeleton key and can be picked using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Beneath a bevy of furs, horns, claws, and bones of largely sentimental value within the chest is a small jewelry box filled with rings, necklaces, and other trinkets. The jewelry amounts to 300 GP worth of diamonds and 200 GP worth of rubies. All were looted from people she killed or captured. Cromwell keeps hold of these trinkets to pay for any expenses incurred while riding afield.

entries.name: M10: Kitchen
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

The Kitchen is where the food is prepared for the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x}. Meat from the Dead Larder ({@area area M11|315|x}) is kept as bloody as possible and is often served to the bat hounds. Bones are ground into meal to pad out the horse's feed. The fat is also used, cut away, and repurposed into the candles that are lit throughout the monastery.

entries.name: M11: Dead Larder
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}
The air in this room is frigid and pungent with the stench of flesh. Around the walls, corpses hang on meat hooks amidst other stacks of stored foodstuffs. The floor is slick with congealed blood.

This room's floors, walls, and ceilings are made of metal plating, all of which are cold to the touch. Several corpses, some animal, some human, and one {@creature Alpengrendel|CrookedMoon24}, hang here on meat hooks. Blood coats the floor an inch thick.
This room stores any unconsumed food, unprocessed corpses, and still-living people captured by the monastery.

entries.name: Captives
entries: {@action search|XPHB|Searching} the room finds four captive human {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners} shackled to the wall with {@item Manacles|XPHB}, barely conscious and alive with 4 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} levels. A red-bearded man named Axel Farley speaks for the group, who are members of the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} that lost faith in Renathyr's teachings and followed him into his Bloody Sanctum. What they saw traumatized them so awfully that they shudder when they speak of it. They say the sanctum has walls which ooze blood and that they all heard an awful whispering voice call to them. No righteous goddess would have a sanctum so heinous. Farley knows:

items: Exactly where the entrance is in the Sanguine Cathedral ({@area area M12|319|x}), hidden beneath the altar.
That {@area Olaf|2d0|x} knows the ritual to open the entrance, and searching his quarters ({@area area M8|310|x}) might give more critical information.

entries.name: Food Supplies
entries: Food here is preserved by the ice the Crimson Faithful cut from the mountains above the monastery every few weeks. The slain alpengrendel hanging here had attacked the last ice-harvesting expedition.

entries.name: M12: Sanguine Cathedral
entries: {@i Area open to visitors}

You step into a grand cathedral with a domed ceiling. Marble statues of angels adorn the stained-glass windows, but the white stone is slick with red liquid. The droning hymns of the Crimson Faithful echo, amplifying the voices of the worshipers seated in the pews.
An altar, covered with roses and candles, stands at the back. A corpse rests on a platform, its blood flowing into a golden bowl. A stone pulpit separates the altar from the pews.
On the east and west walls are doors leading further into the monastery.

The Crimson Faithful are called here at the Twilight and Evening Hours each night by the bells to listen to either {@area Friar Olaf|2d0|x} ({@creature Priest|XMM}) or {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} ({@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}) deliver a cloying sermon about surrendering one's wicked desires and filling one's mind only with the purity of the Crimson Rose. However, members of the Crimson Faithful can be found worshiping and singing the praises of their goddess at all times of night.

entries.name: Bell Tower Gate
entries: The door on the eastern wall of the cathedral leads to the Bell Tower Ascent ({@area area M13|31e|x}) of the monastery. The door to it is locked and can be opened with any skeleton key.

entries.name: Thirsting Altar
entries: Anyone near the altar smells a metallic tang and hears dripping water, which conceals the only passageway to the Bloody Sanctum ({@area area M16|32e|x}). As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines the altar and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds a golden chalice hidden behind the altar's dossal. A crust of dried blood mars the surface within the chalice.

Filling the chalice with blood causes the altar to glow with crimson light and shift, sliding forward to reveal a hidden shaft beneath. Otherwise, the altar is fastened to the stone floor. The revealed vertical shaft leads 40 feet down into the Holy Vein ({@area area M15|329|x}). A character with blood can offer their own to fill the chalice, taking 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Necrotic damage to fill the goblet. They can also use the blood of any of the Crimson Faithful.

entries.name: Meeting with Renathyr
entries: The characters may seek to speak with Father Renathyr before or after one of his sermons. If so, Renathyr will instead invite the characters to meet with him privately in the belfry after he delivers his sermon (see {@area area M14|320|x}).

entries.name: M13: Bell Tower Ascent
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

The Crimson Monastery bell tower rises two stories above the rest of the structure and looms above the common grounds. The stairs begin on the first floor, and the second floor is occupied entirely by the spiral staircase. The third floor is a landing where five {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds} rest during the Evening Hour through the Witching Hour. If roused by anyone other than a vampire, they attack and fight until {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, after which they flee through the windows back to their houses ({@area area M2a|2f6|x}).

entries.name: Heading Up
entries: At the top of the stairs is a 20-foot-tall ladder, which leads to a trapdoor that opens to the belfry (area M14).

entries.name: M14: Watchful Belfry
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

You step through the trapdoor onto a wooden platform clumsily fastened to the stone supports. Above, four pillars converge into arches, forming the dome of the bell tower. At the center, a massive silver bell sways gently in the wind, its pull rope tied to a pillar.
