From this height, Wickermoor Hollow stretches out before you—from the shores of Moonsong Lake to the distant lights of Wickermoor Village. The gravity of the monastery's influence is clear as it spreads its faith across the land.

Braziers flicker here, shedding an ominous red and orange light throughout the space. Hundreds of bats roost in the rafters overhead, casting eerie shadows that seem to writhe in the dancing fire. The faint smell of sulfur drifts on the hot air that passes through the flames.

Renathyr only visits the belfry for two reasons: to meet with those who have ingratiated themselves with him and the other members of the Crimson Faithful, and privately during the Witching Hour every night to gaze upon the mist rising from Moonsong Lake.

The characters are invited to join {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} here if they remain in good favor with the Crimson Faithful (see "{@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x}" earlier in this chapter) for a full night after their arrival. But even if they surprise him here during the Witching Hour, he'll be open to a more intimate conversation.

entries.name: The Abbot's History
entries: Renathyr is willing to talk about his goals and his past with those he feels are good candidates to join his clergy. If someone asks about his time before becoming abbot of the monastery, he'll grip the hilt of his sword and mutter before changing the subject.

entries.name: Why Do You Come Here
entries: "The flames bring clarity. From up here, the view is... different, as though the world has been cleansed for a brief moment. You will understand, in time."

entries.name: What Do You See from this Bell Tower
entries: "I see the land I swore to protect, trembling under the weight of its sins. I also see the life I left behind. But no matter how long I stare, it is only a reflection."

entries.name: How Do I Become a Member of Your Clergy
entries: "There is no single path. The Crimson Rose calls to those ready to hear her voice. We are all tested, in different ways."

entries.name: Is There Nothing That Will Make You Stop
entries: "Stop...? Stop cleansing the evil from this realm and spreading the love of the Crimson Rose? Never."

entries.name: Calling for Aid
entries: If combat breaks out here, Renathyr rings the bell, alerting all within the monastery to something unexpected, and he casts {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} on his first turn to teleport to the Bloody Sanctum ({@area area M16|32e|x}). When the bell rings, eight {@creature Swarm of Bats|XMM|Swarms of Bats} swoop down from the rafters and attack.

Combat in the belfry is easily visible from the courtyard. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) each round after the bell rings, roll {@dice 1d4} on the Reinforcements table below and increase the modifier (X) by 1 for each round that has passed. Once an entry has been rolled, treat future rolls of it as "no reinforcements."

entries.caption: Reinforcements
rows: No reinforcements
Three {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}
One {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM} and four {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}
Two {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24}
Houndmaster Jaeger ({@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}) and two {@creature Bat Hound|CrookedMoon24|Bat Hounds}
Friar Olaf ({@creature Priest|XMM}) and four {@creature Priest Acolyte|XMM|Priest Acolytes}

entries: Reinforcements stop arriving on round 10 of combat, if the characters are captured, or if they flee, such as by using rope to rappel down the tower or running past reinforcements in the Bell Tower Ascent ({@area area M13|31e|x}).

entries.name: Trapdoor
entries: The only entrance to the tower is a single wooden trapdoor that leads to the Bell Tower Ascent (area M13).

entries.name: M15: Holy Vein
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

You splash into a murky pool beneath the altar. In this dark room, the smell of wet earth and iron is almost overpowering. Unworked walls of rough stone rise to a low ceiling only six feet above you. The passageway is filled with three feet of sticky, inky liquid, leaving you little breathing room.
The passageway is completely dark. If the characters create a light, read or paraphrase the following:
You see now the truth: it is not water that you travel through. It is blood.

This passageway was once used by {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} to enter his sanctum, but as his vampiric curse strengthened, he found he could come and go as he pleased. He sealed and hid the entrance, now only using it when bringing victims to feed upon in the sight of his devil goddess, Viraxys.

The entirety of this passageway counts as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}, as the blood and cramped conditions make traversal slow and arduous. The blood in the tunnel drenches and stains other creatures, but it slides away from Father Renathyr's body and clothes when he emerges from it.

entries.name: Sickening Gore
entries: When a creature that isn't a Fiend or an Undead ends its turn in the blood, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until it leaves the blood.

entries.name: Bloody Guardian
entries: A large stone door partially submerged in blood stands at the end of the Holy Vein and leads to the Bloody Sanctum (area M16). It is magically sealed with the effects of an {@spell Arcane Lock|XPHB} spell. When a character examines the door or tries to open it, the blood before the door begins to bubble and roil. As a security measure, a blood elemental(use the {@creature Water Elemental|XMM} stat block, except its Slam attack deals Necrotic damage) emerges from the sanguine river and attacks anyone who tries to enter the sanctum that isn't Bloodless. Dousing this blood elemental in {@item Holy Water|XPHB} destroys it instantly.
Destroying the blood elemental removes the enchanted protection from the stone door, and it can be pushed open with a successful {@dc 13} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: M16: Bloody Sanctum
entries: {@i Area closed to visitors}

The rough stone transitions to polished walls, and the ceiling rises into a larger chamber, lit by a chandelier. The circular room's smooth stone walls surround a blood channel that runs along the edges. At the center stands a circular altar, etched with a rose and covered with dried roses. On the altar is a painting of an elven woman. A leather-bound journal rests beside the painting.

This 40-foot-high, vaulted chamber is the private sanctum of {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}. It is here where he converses freely with his supposed goddess through {@area Duchess|2ca|x}, speaking to him of the conquests to come. When not performing his duties as abbot, Father Renathyr retreats here to commune without prying eyes.

entries.name: Renathyr is Present
entries: If the characters arrived here shortly after the pyre was cleaned, Renathyr is here and attacks the characters (see "{@area Bloody Tears|335|x}," below). Renathyr leaves for the belfry ({@area area M14|320|x}) just before the Witching Hour on a Night of Flames.

entries.name: Renathyr is Absent
entries: If the characters snuck in and arrived here before the crowd in the courtyard dispersed, Renathyr is not here. However, if the characters touch either the painting of his wife (see "Treasure" below) or the rose on the altar beneath it, his devil goddess, Viraxys, alerts him to intruders, and he casts {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} to intervene (see "Bloody Tears" below).

entries.name: Sickening Gore
entries: Blood from the Holy Vein ({@area area M15|329|x}) fills the outer channel to a depth of 4 feet—Medium and smaller creatures must swim. Wading in the blood is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. When a creature that isn't a Fiend or an Undead ends its turn in the blood, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until it leaves the blood.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The painting on the altar is of the wife Renathyr abandoned—Lethica Nightborne. It's of fine craftsmanship and has a haunting quality, easily worth 500 GP to a collector in Wickermoor Village. The roses crumble if touched, and that character gains {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 24 hours.

entries.name: Journal
entries: Renathyr's journal contains an account of everything described in "{@area The Crimson Abbot|2c2|x}," at the beginning of this chapter as Renathyr recalls it. In early entries, he knows he has become a vampire but is unaware that he is being manipulated by a devil. After the entry detailing the time his wife came to the monastery to save him but was turned away, Renathyr became convinced that he was tricked by a devil. Despite this realization, he now believes he is too far gone to atone. He only follows the wretched path he has been set upon. The pages become increasingly difficult to read as they become smudged or stained with blood until eventually the pages are completely smeared with red.

entries.name: Bloody Tears
entries: This section assumes that the characters confront {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} ({@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}) in the Bloody Sanctum (area M16). If confronted elsewhere, he casts {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} on his first turn to teleport to the sanctum.

entries.name: Viraxys's Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), Viraxys exerts her power using one of the following options; she can't choose the same option two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Blood Torrent
entries: Blood surges and grasps {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}'s foes. Dexterity Saving Throw: {@dc 15}. Up to three creatures within 30 feet of the blood pool. Failure: The target is pushed up to 15 feet in a horizontal direction of Viraxys's choice, and its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

entries.name: Sanguine Shield
entries: An undulating swirl of blood surrounds Father Renathyr. The first time he takes damage during a turn before {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round, reduce the damage taken by {@dice 2d6} (to a minimum of 1).

entries.name: Phase 1: Under Her Shadow
entries: Use {@adventure the Bloody Sanctum map|CrookedMoon|7|Map: Bloody Sanctum} for phase 1. When {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} confronts the characters, read or paraphrase the following:

The Crimson Abbot's face twists in rage. He clutches his blackened sword, which surges with crimson light. His image shimmers and he grows to towering height, monstrous wings sprout from his back, and his face becomes a bestial mask of hate and hunger.
"This heresy will not stand, unbelievers. I have tried to show you the beauty of the Crimson Rose, but you reject the truth. We all walk under her shadow, and now you will die beneath it!"
Father Renathyr prioritizes anyone who has offended the Crimson Faithful, or him personally, the most. He targets that character until someone else angers him by doing one or more of the following:

items: Deals Radiant damage or uses magic to create sunlight
Touches or damages the portrait on the altar
Insults his goddess or his faith
Fights in a way that reminds him of his past life as a knight by wearing heavy armor and wielding a sword and shield

entries: Renathyr does not yet assume his true form and attempts to quickly destroy the characters. He repositions himself during combat so that he is targeted by as few attacks as possible—ideally only taking damage from the character he's attacking.
When Father Renathyr is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, his goddess infuses him with power, transitioning the battle to the next phase.

entries.name: Phase 2: Beneath a Blood Moon
entries: Use {@adventure the Sanguine Cathedral map|CrookedMoon|7|Map: Sanquine Cathedral} for phase 2. Read or paraphrase the following. If phase 1 took place somewhere other than the Bloody Sanctum, modify the description to have a great torrent of blood swirl out from Renathyr and engulf all the combatants.

A mocking feminine laugh fills the room as shadows in the chamber take the form of a shapely horned woman with burning eyes the color of rose petals. "Arise, my champion. Ascend beneath my blood moon," she says as the blood that fills the sanctum seethes and churns and erupts like a geyser, hurling you up in a crimson torrent.

When your vision clears, you are within the Sanguine Cathedral. Blood pours from the altar and weeps from the eyes of the statues. Above you, silhouetted by an unnaturally red moon and showering the cathedral in gore with each dreadful wingbeat, is a bat-like monster garbed in Father Renathyr's shredded vestments and wielding a malefic sword. Tears of blood stream down its face.

Renathyr has assumed his true form, empowered by his devil goddess's wrath, and fights in the Sanguine Cathedral dedicated to her glory. Three bipedal figures made of blood rise to fight by his side, sent by Viraxys to aid her champion. These blood effigies use the {@creature Crimson Clergy|CrookedMoon24} stat block, but they have 10 HP.

The honorable man Marius Renathyr once was is now gone—he is nothing more than a vessel for his sorrow, hatred, and hunger. He unleashes that full fury on the characters, fighting until they—or he—are destroyed.

entries.name: Blood Pool
entries: Blood bubbles up from the shaft beneath the altar and flows from the altar itself, covering the stones within 60 feet of it. Viraxys can use the Blood Torrent effect on this pool.

entries.name: Viraxys's Influence
entries: Viraxys continues to affect the battle as in phase 1 and gains the following option:

entries.name: Endless Minions
entries: If there are fewer than 3 blood effigies alive, one more rises from the blood coating the cathedral. It acts on the {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count of the others or immediately after {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24} on his {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count.

entries.name: Hellfire
entries: When Renathyr is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following.

Renathyr wails in pain, and his blood-streaked sword flies from his hands and embeds itself far into the stone altar. He collapses into the morass of blood on the floor—and the blade suddenly emits a thunderous wave of crimson light and force. All of the candles in the cathedral erupt into a hellish blaze, and the stench of brimstone fills the air.

The stained glass windows shift, becoming the mosaic visage of a voluptuous devil leering at the scene, and a sultry voice slithers from the image: "What a pathetic disappointment you are, Renathyr. But perhaps, you who slew him would replace him? His mission remains incomplete, and I can sense your hunger for power. Cast aside your petty concerns, turn away from the weaklings huddled around you and become the bloody instrument of my will."

Viraxys, the Crimson Rose herself (see "{@area The Crimson Abbot|2c2|x}" at the beginning of this chapter), speaks through and shows her true form in the windows of the cathedral, offering the characters infernal power. She claims to be a goddess, but those who succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check see through her deception and know she is clearly a vile Fiend. A {@spell Detect Evil and Good|XPHB} spell or a Paladin's Divine Senses reveals the blade to be a desecrated object with a fiendish resonance—she is a devil of deceit and desire. She might say:

entries.name: About Renathyr's Defeat
entries: "You are stronger than him and more controlled. You would use my power more effectively."

entries.name: After Being Called a Devil
entries: "Ha! You are cleverer than him, too. Yet with the {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} making her move, can you afford to pick and choose your allies?"

entries.name: If Her Power is Accepted
entries: "And you are most wise. Though you are not yet ready to become Bloodless, as he was, you soon will be. Wield my blade. Kill in my name. Do great deeds—heroic deeds in my name. Die in my name. I will gift you peace and power."

entries.name: If Her Power is Refused
entries: "We shall see. Once you are broken, once my true power has bled you dry, then we shall see how proud and noble you still are."

entries.name: Accepting Infernal Power
entries: Characters who consider accepting feel an almost insurmountable hunger for the blood spattering the cathedral, and for that coursing through the veins of their companions. This is a pivotal decision, with dire consequences. Take a moment to impress that upon the player through their character's sensation of Viraxys's temptations. If a characters accepts, that hunger overwhelms them. Viraxys laughs with wicked glee and purrs, "Now you are mine."

The character claims the sword and becomes a {@creature Vampire|XMM}, and their alignment changes to Evil if it wasn't already. The character then becomes an NPC under your control and attempts to escape in the form of a bat or red mist. This is a grave decision, but it can serve as a dramatic end to a character and introduces a new enemy to harry the remaining characters as you see fit.

entries.name: Refusing Infernal Power
entries: If the characters refuse Viraxys's power, the devil hisses, "You are too weak to claim my gift. You lack resolve and are damned." Then, the hellfire in the cathedral snuffs out, the stained-glass windows shatter, and the essence of Viraxys leaves the Crimson Monastery forever. The blade once called Duchess remains entombed in the altar.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 6, if they are still level 5, when they defeat Father Renathyr.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@i The Hierophant} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2} and a character did not accept the gift of Viraxys (see "Accepting Infernal Power" above), the {@item Sword of the Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24} can be pulled from the altar by a character, containing an echo of the devil's power but lacking the overwhelming corruptive influence it once had.

If {@i The Hierophant} card was pulled during the "Fated Tarot Reading" in Running the Adventure but a character accepted Viraxys's gift (see "Accepting Infernal Power" above), the {@item Sword of the Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24} is removed as a possible Fabled Heirloom the characters can claim.

However, you can add another Fabled Heirloom to the adventure if you wish. Later in the adventure when appropriate, {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} can sense that fate has somehow changed. She will offer to perform another tarot reading in Druskenvald Manor for the character who had originally pulled {@i The Hierophant}. Perform the "Fated Tarot Reading" in Running the Adventure once more, but remove cards that have already been drawn by characters or connected to artifacts located in chapters that have already been played through.

entries.name: Conclusion: The Bell Tolls for Thee
entries: When the presence of Viraxys fades from {@area the Crimson Monastery|2e0|x}, the Crooked Moon turns back to its familiar white hue, and the blood moon is gone. Following the death of {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}, the surviving Bloodless scramble to position themselves as Renathyr's successor, preaching piecemeal to nearby congregators. The fate of the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} hinges upon the characters' next choices.

entries.name: Power Vacuum
entries: The death of {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x} is only the beginning of the fell tale of the Crimson Monastery if the characters aren't careful to eliminate the cult's leadership. If more than one of Renathyr's priors survive, a schism rages within the cult for a year, leading to many senseless deaths among the faithful until only one leader survives, in this priority:

items: {@area Friar Olaf|2d0|x} (defeats both rivals due to his influence)
{@area Inquisitor Cromwell|2d2|x} (defeats only Jaeger with strength of arms)
{@area Houndmaster Jaeger|2ce|x} (not capable of defeating either rival)
Another member of the Bloodless (only if all three priors have been slain)

entries: If only one of the priors survived, they thank the characters for saving them from Renathyr's evil, then swiftly consolidate power before any of the faithful learn that their goddess is, in fact, a devil.

entries.name: The Cult Dismantled
entries: If the characters declare before the {@area Crimson Faithful|2d4|x} that their goddess, the Crimson Rose, is a devil and display proof (such as {@area Father Renathyr|2c2|x}'s monstrous, bat-like corpse or his journal found in {@area area M16|32e|x}), the Crimson Faithful rebel against the Bloodless. This may happen in one final encounter immediately following the fight with Renathyr or in a longer guerilla battle following a retreat to Dawn's Gate. Either way, the influence of the Crimson Faith is undone by this revelation. In addition, the Crimson Faithful disband if all Bloodless are slain (the number of total Bloodless is up to you).

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: If Gareth was rescued, the Brightsingers celebrate his return. If he was slain, they hold a funeral at the Abandoned Church ({@area area V19|17e|x}), praising him as a martyr. Weston Murdoch even proposes sainthood for him.

If the Crimson Faith is disbanded, many former followers leave Dawn's Gate for {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}, eager to begin anew. All three religious groups view this as an ideal opportunity to convert new members.

Phillip Druskenvald is thrilled to hear about the good work that the characters are doing in helping the people of Wickermoor Hollow. He invites the characters to a lavish dinner at the Druskenvald Estate, promising the house won't turn crooked this time. Adela is on a trip to help the people of Foxwillow, so she is not present.

data.name: The Drowned Crossroads

entries: Now, don't call me a villain just because I'm a gamblin' man. After all, you came here to roll the dice yourself. No sir, you and I are just a couple of sinners. The only difference between us is that you have nothing, and I have exactly what your heart desires. Now won't you go ahead and shake this humble sinner's hand?

Murkwater Bend is one hell of a place to make your fortune. Prosperity and riches of all varieties come easy to the free folk who call the lawless swamp town on stilts home. But the misfortune that follows comes just as easily, the sinister cost of the deals made with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}—a crocodilian gambler and magician.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: The treacherous swamp known as the Drowned Crossroads sits at the lowest point of Wickermoor Hollow. The people of the stilt-town of Murkwater Bend favor freedom and vice, enjoying the natural separation from the strict laws and social customs that govern the valley's other regions.

Years ago, a sudden strike of prosperity came to Murkwater Bend, with gold flowing freely and luck seemingly being on the side of the swamp-folk. People came from all over Wickermoor Hollow in hopes of finding their own fortune in the bayou.

But luck doesn't hold out forever, and the good times were not meant to last. In recent years, the people of Murkwater Bend have been struck with terrible misfortunes, and some whisper of the whole swamp being jinxed. Instances of accidents, disease, and financial ruin have increased dramatically, with no end to the bad luck in sight.

Even worse, the hex has brought the Drowned Crossroads to unnatural life, with the swamp itself rising up to drag unsuspecting travelers into its murky depths. In the Midnight Hour, haunting brass music can be heard throughout the mire, and the distant lights of a ghastly riverboat drift through the gloom, always just out of reach.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: Murkwater Bend is jinxed, and its people are being swindled into bad deals that cost them their very souls. Characters drawn to the town by the Quest Hook later in this chapter have these goals:

items: Find a cure for {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}, whose hand is afflicted with a withering hex.
Discover the source of the town's misfortune by treating with Vander Boone.
Brave the Drowned Crossroads to find {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}, then make a bargain with him or purchase his wares to earn passage aboard the {@i Dead Man's Hand} riverboat.
Disrupt the soul-powered boiler in the riverboat's Boiler Room.
Destroy Mister Crossroads, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with Mister Crossroads, the key NPC, to weave his sly malevolence throughout. Study the rules to Liar's Dice (see "{@area Test of Luck|36c|x}" later in the chapter) to efficiently oversee tense games of chance. Carefully read through the list of {@adventure Dark Bargains|CrookedMoon|24}, {@area Cursed Curios|a1e|x}, {@area Paranormal Potions|a5c|x}, and {@area Familiars|967|x} to make the meeting with Mister Crossroads in his Sinner's shack as enticing as possible. Lastly, reviewing the climactic battle, "{@area Bayou Boogie|3bc|x}," ensures a thrilling final encounter filled with twists and turns.
This chapter is designed for four level 6 characters.

entries.name: The Grinning Sinner

entries.title: Mister Crossroads and Captain Briggsy Kratch

entries: Captain Briggsy "The Kutlass" Kratch gave up a life of piracy when he lost his crew to the violent waves of Druskenvald's ravenous ocean. The crocodile-folk himself was only able to survive through the fate-bending power of his patron, an ancient death spirit known as Snake Eye Jack. Leaving the sea behind, he found himself bouncing between bounty hunts and other dangerous jobs armed with his patron's jinxcraft and the sigil-etched cutlass that once gave him his piratical moniker.

In time, he made a home in the swamp, known as the Drowned Crossroads, feeling at ease around the scoundrels that lurked within. The rogues of the swamp did not care for the crocodile man, and the common folk of the bayou feared his strange magic and garishly hexed sword. They even coined ugly legends about him that claimed he devoured children and stole souls.

Work dried up, attempted cons and thievery failed, and Briggsy found himself penniless, purposeless, and reviled. This potent cocktail of isolation, resentment, and bad luck made him deeply resent his patron, believing that Snake Eye Jack had turned his back on Briggsy despite the years of service. Through the bitterness, the cunning croc-folk came up with a plan.

One night at the Midnight Hour, Briggsy rowed into the bayou and tossed his hexed cutlass overboard at the exact point where the two ancient roads had once crossed centuries ago. This offering summoned Snake Eye Jack, a many-armed man of shadow and bone with serpents' eyes glowing a neon green and pink. Briggsy challenged his patron to a game of dice, making an offer the death spirit could not refuse.

The pair diced all night, and through Briggsy's guile and treachery, he beat Snake Eye Jack and bound him in a hexed coffin. Claiming the full power of his former patron for himself, the croc-folk became a master of misfortune and jinxcraft, conjuring forth a magical blunderbuss with his new abilities. However, the cost was great. His body rotted as if he had been dead for weeks, and his left arm withered to bone.

Briggsy didn't mind. He moved into an abandoned shack on stilts at the heart of the swamp and decided to become what the people of Murkwater Bend believed him to be: the bogeyman of the Drowned Crossroads.

entries.name: Heart's Desire
entries: From then on, Briggsy called himself {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}, but many of the folk who called upon him for favors and charms dubbed him {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} after his crocodile smile and tricksy magic. People of the swamp come to Mister Crossroads for simple jinxes and curses, but the croc-folk's favorite "associates" are the truly desperate.

He makes deals with these unfortunate souls, whether they're someone trying to escape a hell of their own making or in search of their wildest dreams. Shortly after sealing the pact through a signed contract or a simple handshake, the luck of the new victim would turn around, and they would get exactly what Mister Crossroads promised.

But the Grinning Sinner is clever, and there are always loopholes in every deal. After weeks, months, or even years, the luck runs out, and the joy and fortune granted by the jinxcraft turns to ash. Eventually, each and every one of them experiences a terrible misfortune that costs them their life and grants their soul to Mister Crossroads, which he uses to fuel the soul-binding magic that keeps Snake Eye Jack bound within his hexed coffin. As added insult, their lifeless corpse rises as an Undead thrall to join his crew of the damned.

entries.name: Captain of the Damned
entries: When {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} isn't making deals in his swamp shack, he captains the opulent {@i Dead Man's Hand} riverboat, which thrums with his jinxcraft power. Acquired from a foolish gambler—{@area Elias|357|x}—the riverboat moves about the Drowned Crossroads, mooring at random locations each night, only able to be found by those who have made a deal with Mister Crossroads.

Keeping the riverboat fueled and Snake Eye Jack bound requires a constant supply of damned souls. His most recent and precious catch is {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} herself, who made a foolish bargain with Mister Crossroads in desperation to avoid her most terrifying visions and prophecies of calamity. {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} current target and most vexing foe is {@area Vander Boone|358|x}, the self-proclaimed "Bayou King" of the Drowned Crossroads (described in "{@area NPCs of the Drowned Crossroads|356|x}" below).

Between Elias's riverboat, Adela's powerful soul, and Vander's large following, Mister Crossroads hopes to stack his crew with hundreds of new corpses and stock up on enough soul-stuff to keep Snake Eye Jack imprisoned forever.

These grand schemes are motivated by fear and doubt. He knows that, should his former patron ever break free, his own doom would come swiftly, and the soul he traded to Snake Eye Jack many years ago would be tormented for all time.

entries.name: NPCs of the Drowned Crossroads
entries: The Drowned Crossroads may be a sinister swamp, but its people are a vibrant tapestry of outsiders. Within Wickermoor Hollow, Crossroaders are often labeled as scoundrels, thieves, or gamblers—and many are—but most swamp-folk are regular fisherfolk, traders, hunters, trappers, and artisans who've learned the secret ways of surviving in the wetlands. Some important swamp-dwelling characters in this adventure are featured below.

entries.name: Elias Greaves
entries: Elias {@i (eh-LYE-us)} Greaves was a gambler from the world of the living who dreamt of wealth and influence far beyond his station. Seemingly blessed by Lady Luck herself, he won big at every gambling hall he visited, eventually growing bored and craving a new challenge. He found a way to board the {@i Ghostlight Express} and travel to Druskenvald, where he met Phillip and Adela.

Despite his powerful new friends, his luck ran out in the lands of death, and his fortune was quickly spent. Soon, he was stuck playing low stakes games aboard the{@i Laughlin Lullaby}, a riverboat that traveled up and down the Silverbell River in Wickermoor Hollow. In desperation, he made a deal with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} to turn his luck around.

After shaking the croc-folk's hand, his luck instantly turned around, and he even won ownership of the riverboat in a poker bet. He renamed it {@i Dead Man's Hand} in reference to the skeletal left hand of his new patron. The gambler enjoyed years of prosperity, but as always, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} exploited the man's greed and the fine print in the deal, and it all came crashing down.

When Mister Crossroads came to collect, he claimed Elias's soul, his walking corpse, and the fine riverboat, which the trickster turned into his base of operations. He then threw the gambler's spirit into a soulfire boiler to power the hexes that kept Snake Eye Jack imprisoned in the jinxed coffin. Elias was special. As a living soul who traveled aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}, his spirit would burn bright and long, keeping the Grinning Sinner's game going for years.

Elias's shambling corpse mindlessly serves aboard the {@i Dead Man's Hand}, but it was recently reawakened when his old friend {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} made a deal with Mister Crossroads. A fragment of his soul stirred in his withered hand, which ripped free from the animated corpse and crawled through the swamp in search of help against the Grinning Sinner.

entries.name: Vander Boone, the Bayou King
entries: Folk often come to Murkwater Bend to trade or scheme, but prize fights draw in the largest crowds. Vander Boone (Chaotic Neutral, human {@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}) was one such prize fighter, a brigand-turned-boxer renowned throughout the swamps. He was popular and successful, but he longed for more. He wanted real power, real control, and real respect.

One night, just short of a year ago, Vander met {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} and asked for the power to rule the Drowned Crossroads. All would pay tribute to him and seek his approval. But when {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} extended his hand, Vander pulled back, shook his head, and told Mister Crossroads he would do it himself. The flabbergasted croc-folk swore that Boone would regret his decision as he walked away.

Vander has declared himself the Bayou King and named himself the protector of the Drowned Crossroads. He has amassed a small legion of small-time thugs, decked them out in stylish purple-and-black uniforms with his prize money, and created a protection racket in Murkwater Bend. Unlike most bandit captains, however, Vander has proved to be a surprisingly canny leader. He understands the motivations of the countless rogues within the town and strives to keep them in balance.

He was surprised when everyone readily paid his taxes, leaving him with the job of managing the town while maintaining its lawlessness as much as possible. Recently, however, the Grinning Sinner has sent his Undead crew across the swamp to hunt down the Bayou King. Vander's crew clashes with Mr. Crossroads' minions nearly every night, and though the Bayou King has been steadily losing ground and has retreated to his fort in Murkwater Bend, his noble defense of the village has made him more beloved than ever.

entries.name: Lyla Webb
entries: A native of the Drowned Crossroads born to a family of fisherfolk, Lyla {@i (LYE-luh)} Webb (Chaotic Good, human {@creature Priest|XMM}) had dreams that were much bigger than a life of catching catfish. She set off from home at a young age and eventually discovered a community in the swamp that worshipped Snake Eye Jack and held him as a beneficent spirit who made sure that luck was always on their side. She learned their ways and became a skilled jinxcraft practitioner, using her magical abilities to help the people of the bayou as well as aid her work as a trader.

Now an adult, she has become a shrewd and resourceful businesswoman who has numerous contacts throughout the Drowned Crossroads and a knack for fencing stolen goods that the rogues of the swamp bring her. Her skill in business, helpful magic, and wisdom beyond her years have made her widely respected by all the folk of the swamp, and the Bayou King has appointed her as his chief advisor and emissary.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: The characters may travel to Murkwater Bend of their own volition, but this adventure starts with {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} seeking the characters' help after her bad deal with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}.

entries.name: The Withered Arm
entries: {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} visits the characters wherever they are staying during the darkest part of the Witching Hour. Dressed in a black fur coat, wide brimmed hat, and long woolen gloves, she is clearly trying to seem incognito despite just how out of place her outfit is. She speaks in a pleading whisper, asking the characters to have a private meeting.
When Adela is alone with the characters, read or paraphrase the following:

Adela looks around to make sure there is no one else watching or listening before slowly removing the long woolen glove off her left hand and pulling up the sleeve of her fur coat. The arm underneath is incredibly withered, nearly skeletal, and her fingers are gnarled inward. The skin has turned to a corpse flesh gray all the way to the elbow.
"I made a big mistake..."

Adela then makes her confession. Following the events in Foxwillow, she had offered to join the pilgrims of the Patient Lady to help the townsfolk start rebuilding their lives after the destruction of {@creature Raum|CrookedMoon24}. However, this was a lie so she could secretly go to the Drowned Crossroads after a terrifying vision and prophecy. She's just returned from her trip after making a deal with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}.

The prophecy stated, "You and your king shall leave this place on ashen winds when the Crooked Moon snarls with rage and not a night before," which shook her to the core. In desperation, she secretly sought out the magician in the swamp after hearing tales from her new confidant Gaston Doray.

Mister Crossroads promised that Phillip's power would return when it was time to leave the valley, and all it cost was her wedding ring. In desperation, she accepted. After leaving the Drowned Crossroads, she had forgotten the path she took to get there, and her entire left arm began withering away. This affliction can only be reversed if her wedding ring is recovered and returned to her finger or if Mr. Crossroads is killed, though Adela doesn't know this..

She pleads with the characters to head to the swamp and find a cure for her arm, offering them 150 GP each in return. She also asks them to keep the arrangement secret and to not tell Phillip, promising an extra 50 GP each for their discretion.

After the characters are finished talking to Adela, she leaves to return to the Druskenvald Estate, telling them that she must keep up appearances so Phillip doesn't worry. The characters are then free to gather supplies and travel to the Drowned Crossroads.

entries.name: Journey to the Crossroads
entries: The trek to the Drowned Crossroads takes three nights through treacherous terrain, followed by three nights slogging through the swamp to Murkwater Bend.

entries.name: Into the Swamp

entries: The ground beneath you grows sodden and foul-smelling, and before you rises a looming wall of cypress and tupelo trees, their branches reaching out like skeletal fingers, casting long shadows over the murky, stagnant waters beyond.

The path forward is treacherous, choked by overgrown plants, flooded with stretches of black water, and surrounded by the teeming wildlife and lurking monsters that call the swamp home. The characters won't get to Murkwater Bend without a fight. Along the way, the characters face three encounters with opportunities for a Long Rest between each. For these encounters, use {@adventure the Swamp Encounters map|CrookedMoon|8|Map: Swamp Encounters}.

entries.name: First Night
entries: When the characters are ready to camp, an animated, withered hand approaches the characters, sensing their connection to Phillip and Adela. The hand once belonged to {@area Elias Greaves|357|x} and bears a fragment of his soul.

Any character who touches the {@item Withered Hand|CrookedMoon24} automatically becomes attuned to it. If the character is already attuned to three magic items, they must choose one of those to which their {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} ends. If the characters ignore the hand, it tracks them for two nights, reappearing each time they take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. If it fails to make contact before the characters arrive at Murkwater Bend, it returns to the {@i Dead Man's Hand} to rejoin Elias's body.

An hour after the hand first appears, a {@creature Bayou Beast|CrookedMoon24} shambles out of the mire and attacks the characters, drawn by the jinxcraft of the cursed appendage. A character who examines the remains of the beast and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check determines that the creature was a manifestation of the swamp, crafted by powerful jinxcraft magic and animated with a hexed wooden mask.

entries.name: Second Night
entries: While crossing a particularly deep stretch of swamp water, the characters are ambushed by two {@creature Giant Crocodile|XMM|Giant Crocodiles} and four {@creature Crocodile|XMM|Crocodiles}. A character is surprised unless they succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check.

Jinxcraft glyphs are etched in the hides of the Beasts, and as a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the sigils and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check determines the carved symbols have made the crocodiles larger and more aggressive than normal.

entries.name: Third Night
entries: The characters come across the remnants of a battle between Undead and surprisingly well-dressed bandits. A character who succeeds on a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB}) check deduces that the slain brigands are the crew of a local kingpin who calls himself the {@area Bayou King|358|x}.

As the characters investigate, an eerie green fog rolls in, and a group of eight {@creature Ghoul|XMM|Ghouls} led by a {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24} emerge from the swamp and attack, claiming that {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} will defeat the Bayou King, seemingly mistaking the characters as allied with the gang leader.

entries.name: Murkwater Bend
entries: Once the characters have dealt with the threats and dangers on the trail to Murkwater Bend, it takes just another few hours to get there.

entries.name: Greeted by Lyla, the King's Emissary
entries: The characters are spotted by a sentry as soon as they enter the town. Read or paraphrase the following:

Suddenly, the thick bayou foliage parts, revealing a town built on stilts that rise up from the murky water and thick, dark mud of the swamp. Amidst the bald cypress trees, a twisted tangle of shacks, huts, and larger structures looms, linked by swaying wooden walkways and frayed rope bridges.
As you enter the town, you spot a wooden fort at its center flying a flag of purple and black. New buildings cluster around the fort, with piles of freshly cut planks strewn across the muddy ground.

Two sharp whistles echo through the air, and the gate creaks open. A young woman in a purple coat festooned with jewelry and charms hails you. "You'll want to be inside, strangers," she says matter-of-factly.

The person calling to them is {@area Lyla Webb|359|x}. Although she has considered deposing {@area Vander|358|x} should he prove to be a cruel and foolish leader, her primary goal is the destruction of {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}. She can tell that the characters could be useful allies in the fight against {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} and tries to guide them into an audience with the Bayou King.

entries.name: What Lyla Knows
entries: Lyla is an excellent judge of character. She knows that the Bayou King is dangerous, but {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} magic is worse. She especially loathes that he has imprisoned her patron and twists his power to the croc-folk's own sinister aims.

Lyla knows everything that the Bayou King does (see "What the Bayou King Knows" later in this chapter) but doesn't see it as her duty to explain. If pressed for information, you can use the information below to guide Lyla's conversation with the characters:

items: Locals now shelter within the walls of Vander's fort to avoid the rampant spread of shambling dead.
Lyla scoffs at Vander's self-avowed title, "Bayou King." She once knew him as a destitute pit fighter.
She only describes her connection with Snake Eye Jack to someone with similar magic or aligned goals.

entries.name: Seat of the Bayou King
entries: The characters are led through the large fort, past plenty of the Bayou King's gang but also common folk seeking shelter from the Undead attacks. This is where {@area Vander Boone|358|x} oversees his "duties" in Murkwater Bend, primarily in waging the fight against {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}.

entries.name: Meeting the Bayou King

entries: This throne room is a cramped, dingy hall filled with mismatched but surprisingly plush furniture from across Druskenvald. The hall echoes with the voices of three dozen rogues bickering about what steps to take against the shambling dead rising from the swamp.
A half dozen thugs in weathered leathers and purple-and-black suits stare brutishly at the crowd with hands on their sword hilts.

Presiding over the hall is a hulking figure resting his bulk upon a cushioned chair atop a short, raised dais. The bald head of the figure, adorned with a purple top hat, gazes pensively out a window.
Lyla interrupts the man's reverie. "Vander, I've brought the travelers at the gates. They're armed, and they look like they've fought their way through the Sinner's goons."
This man is {@area Vander Boone, the Bayou King|358|x} (Chaotic Neutral, human {@creature Bandit Captain|XMM}).

The fort currently holds around 30 {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners} from around Murkwater Bend and 10 {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} (scoundrels and thieves of the swamplands) who have paid the king tribute in exchange for refuge from the Undead here. Finally, six of the Bayou King's personal enforcers (Chaotic Neutral, human {@creature Tough|XMM|Toughs}) keep the peace.

entries.name: What the Bayou King Knows
entries: Vander sees the characters as potential allies who might be able to help him with the current problems facing the town. Use the details below to guide the conversation with the Bayou King:

items: Murkwater Bend used to prosper until misfortune befell the town.
{@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} and his Undead minions assail stragglers in the swamp and cause "freak accidents" outside of the fort.
That wily and rotten croc-folk can only be destroyed while he is aboard his accursed riverboat.
To board the {@i Dead Man's Hand}, you must make a deal with {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} or purchase one of his trinkets.
The Sinner's shack can be found if you take the north road out of Murkwater Bend—just listen for the music.
Vander feels responsible for the people of the Drowned Crossroads, so he won't risk getting cursed by making a deal.
Be friendly to the deceitful deal-maker until you learn his secrets.

entries.name: Test of Luck
entries: After conversing with the characters, the Bayou King looks them up and down and challenges them to a game of Liar's Dice to test their worth.
"Any of your gang gamblin' men?" the Bayou King says with a smirk. "I want you to prove me somethin'. That you've got a gambler's stomach. You're going to need it.

"Ya' see, the Grinnin' Sinner's a dicin' fella. He lives in a nasty ship chock fulla his rottin' goons, and every last one of 'em's packin' blades. I don't think there's any way of killin' this croc without taking a big risk.

"So why don't you prove you got a gambler's stomach? Play me. Liar's Dice. Win, I double whatever it is you got paid to come all the way out to the Murk. Lose, you owe it to your king to kill that jinxed crocodile."

entries.name: Victory or Defeat
entries: Resolve the game's outcome quickly to move things along or draw it out with cross talk at the table to increase the tension (see "{@area Liar's Dice Rules|371|x}" below).

{@i Victory}. If one of the characters wins the game, the Bayou King smiles proudly and asks the characters how much they're being paid. If they honestly reply that Adela is paying them 150 GP apiece (200 GP if sworn to secrecy), he scowls at the price but accedes to pay them that upon delivering proof of {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} demise.

If they lie about the price, they must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check to convince him. Naming a price of 300 GP apiece or higher imposes {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on this check. On a success, he agrees to pay whatever price they name, up to a maximum of 300 GP.

{@i Defeat}. If the Bayou King or Lyla wins, Vander smiles and shakes his head. He admits the characters may not have the luck of a master gambler but believes that they may have enough moxie to muscle through. After all, they owe him now to kill the Grinning Sinner.

{@i Time to Rest}. After the game, Vander lets the characters rest in the fort, offering a small room to share with enough bedding for all of them. Before retiring for the evening, he invites the characters to eat and drink with him, providing an opportunity for the characters to learn more about the Bayou King, the Drowned Crossroads, and the Grinning Sinner. The downtime of the dice game and remaining evening are enough for the characters to take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Screams in the Night
entries: After the characters bid goodnight and retire, they're jolted awake by piercing screams echoing through the fort. {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} Undead thralls have infiltrated Murkwater Bend, scaling the fort walls. When the characters reach the throne room, read or paraphrase the following:

Outside, shrieks split the night air as the throne room descends into chaos. The Bayou King's scoundrels scramble for weapons, casting fearful glances toward the door. Suddenly, it flies open, and a blood-streaked sentry stumbles in, gasping, "They're here... Over the wall..." before collapsing in a heap.

Vander Boone turns to you, his voice a fierce growl: "Get outta' here! Take the north road and head to the Sinner's shack. Keep running 'til you hear his cursed strings playin' in the swamp. Board his riverboat, cut that grinnin' croc down, and end this nightmare!"

The Bayou King will hear no protest. If the characters enter the village's streets and fight, even against his wishes, you can draw your own map of the streets and challenge them with four {@creature Ghast|XMM|Ghasts} led by a {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24}. Another similar group arrives on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 of the fifth and tenth rounds of combat. Staying to fight is foolish, and Lyla Webb joins the fray to spur them on to defeat {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} and free Snake Eye Jack.

Otherwise, the characters flee as the town dissolves into a frenzied melee. Waves of the living dead stagger through the streets, their hollow eyes seeking only to kill. Amid the chaos, the characters slip past the carnage unscathed and take the north road, where wooden walkways give way to a soggy, mud-choked path leading into the stinking mire.

entries.name: Liar's Dice Rules
entries: The rules of Liar's Dice are simple, and {@area Lyla|359|x} is content to explain them to the characters if they're unfamiliar. The players in this game are {@area Vander|358|x}, Lyla, and the characters.

items: Each player has a set of five 6-sided dice, and each round they roll them in secret and look at their own dice (rolling in cups is recommended).
1s are considered wild and can be used as any number. For instance, a player with two 4s and two 1s would actually have four 4s.
The first player (starting with Vander in round one) makes a bid on how many dice of a certain face were rolled by all players in total. For example, Vander starts by safely bidding "two 2s".

After each bid, the next player to the left can challenge the bid, and all players reveal their dice. If the challenged player overbid, they lose a die for the rest of the game. For example, if there was only a single 2 showing between all players (unlikely, but possible), Vander would permanently lose a die in all future rounds. If the challenged player did not overbid (if there were two or more 2s for example), the challenging player permanently loses a die for the rest of the game instead. Once the challenge is resolved, players reroll their dice, and the player who lost a die makes the first bid in the new round.

If the next player to the left doesn't wish to challenge, they must raise either the number of dice ("three 2s"), the face ("two 3s"), or both ("four 4s"). There is no limit to how high either number can be raised in the next bid, other than the natural cap of 6 for the face portion of the bid.
This process of bidding and challenging continues around clockwise with play always passing to the next player on the left.
When a player loses all five of their dice, they are eliminated from the game.
The winner of the game is the last person with any dice remaining.

entries: You will know both Vander and Lyla's dice. That's okay—they know how to communicate under the table to gain an advantage.

entries.name: Special Rules
entries: Characters with certain skill proficiencies can manipulate the game to their advantage, letting the characters be better gamblers than their players. Show the players the following rules.
If you have proficiency in the listed skill or tool, you can use that special trait on your turn. You can use any combination of these traits up to a total of three times during the game:

entries.name: Hard Read ({@skill Insight|XPHB})
entries: Before you bid or challenge, one opponent of your choice must reveal their dice to you, and only you.

entries.name: Deft Hands ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB})
entries: Before you bid or challenge, you can change one of your dice to any number.

entries.name: Sly Reveal ({@skill Stealth|XPHB})
entries: Before you bid or challenge, show your dice to one opponent. They can choose to show you theirs.

entries.name: Poker Face ({@skill Deception|XPHB})
entries: When an opponent challenges a bid you made this turn, you can succeed on a Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check against {@dc 15} or the other player's Wisdom score, whichever is higher, to make them balk and withdraw their challenge.

entries.name: Daring Dicer (Gaming Set: Dice)
entries: Immediately after rolling your dice, you may change any number of your dice to the face of your choice.

entries.name: Fated Luck (Any)
entries: Before you bid or challenge, you can reroll all of your remaining dice.

entries.name: Variant: Quick Liar's Dice
entries: If you'd prefer an alternative to playing a game of Liar's Dice within your game session, you can leave the game to ability checks using tools.

Using the guidance in the Gaming Set tool, you can call for {@dc 20} Wisdom checks using proficiency with Dice to determine the winner of the game. Any gambler who fails to meet or exceed 20 loses, and if multiple gamblers succeed on the check, the gambler with the highest total wins.

To add a bit more nuance, you can allow Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) checks using the Dice instead, with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if the player has proficiency with both Dice and the {@skill Deception|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: To the Sinner's Shack
entries: The north road out of Murkwater Bend winds its way toward the heart of the swamp, becoming soggier and more overgrown with each passing mile. Folk call it the Marshwinder Road, and it's the only way to traverse a far distance through the Drowned Crossroads without a boat.

After traveling through the treacherous muck of the swamp for six hours, only spying the occasional hut, boathouse, or fishing shack, the characters finally hear the musical call of {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}.

The winding, soggy road leads deeper into the swamp. The dense canopy swallows the moonlight, and the eyes and sounds of wild creatures follow you, yet you're certain none of the shambling dead pursued you. After a few hours of trudging along the muddy, overgrown path, you suddenly hear the low mournful wails of a stringed instrument sailing across the black water to your left.

As you turn, you see the source of the melancholic tune: a dilapidated one-room shack on stilts stands above the waterline, a ladder hanging down from its porch. Its windows are filled with the warmth of an inviting fire, and pairs of light-filled bottles float atop the swamp's surface to act as glowing buoys that form a path along the water to the shack.

The water here is 4 feet deep and can be waded through, although the thick mud below makes each foot of movement cost 4 feet. If the characters stay between the glowing jars that act as navigational beacons, they arrive at {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} shack without issue.

If any character leaves the designated pathway lit by the jars, whether through the water or on top of it, the swamp comes to life with the glow of jinxcraft and a {@creature Bayou Beast|CrookedMoon24} attacks.

entries.name: Between the Deals
entries: At the top of the ladder is a modest porch overlooking the black pool below. A rickety rocking chair creaks with a gentle sway, and a large steel guitar rests on its seat, shifting back and forth with each rock. The windows glow with a warm orange light, yet through the glass, you see only shadows. The door is unlocked. When the characters open the door, read or paraphrase the following:

The door groans open, and the inviting orange light proves to be a cruel illusion. Inside, the shack is cluttered with strange trinkets and knick-knacks, and bottles glow with an eerie neon green and magenta light that emanates from the sigils that adorn them. Against the back, a narrow wooden staircase spirals upward, vanishing into the unseen shadows above.

The vast collection of {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} consists of {@area Cursed Curios|a1e|x} and {@area Paranormal Potions|a5c|x}. In addition, carved idols and woven dolls resembling creatures can conjure {@area Familiars|967|x}. There is a weathered paper price tag for every item in the shack, each reading "3 CP."
When the characters touch one of the items, call out to {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}, or turn to leave the shack, Mister Crossroads himself walks heavily down the stairs.
Heavy footfalls descend the stairs in the back of the shack. A hefty, grumbling belly laugh follows them. "Well, well, well..." says the voice from the stairs. "Just who I was expecting."

The figure steps into view: a broad, built, and corpse-like crocodilian in a simple brown coat over a red vest, with his left hand nothing but bone. A feathered top hat sits atop his head. He flashes a toothy grin. "I'm Mister Crossroads," he drawls. "Have you come to partake in my wares? Or perhaps you'd care to make a deal. Let's have a civil conversation, shall we? I am a gentleman after all."

entries.name: Parley with the Sinner
entries: In this conversation, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} is trying to charm and befriend the characters so they don't disrupt his plans with Adela. Use the guidance below to steer the conversation with Mister Crossroads:

items: He tries to appear charming and disarming, brushing off threats and insults as a joke.
If asked about his undead-looking state, he waves it off as a simple skin condition. It is true he is not Undead—he simply has his own withering curse.
He invites the characters to the {@i Dead Man's Hand} as guests, promising an endless night of food, drinks, and gambling. He even offers a few free games on the house.
The Sinner's shack is a place to make quick deals and sell magical trinkets. He has all {@book Dark Bargains|CrookedMoon|6} on offer, costing a handshake.
If asked about Adela, he swears he made a fair deal, and she just failed to read the fine print.
Mention of the {@i Ghostlight Express} increases Mister Crossroads' interest. A successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check makes it clear it's a suspicious curiosity.

entries: Mister Crossroads is insistent about the characters taking a deal or trinket in order to get them aboard his riverboat and curse them to stay forever.

entries.name: Take One
entries: Each character can only choose one item or deal (Dark Bargain, Potion, Curio, or Familiar). Attempts to purchase or shake down for more are refused, and anything stolen after the first trinket turns to swamp water as soon as it leaves the shack.

entries.name: Making a Deal
entries: If every character accepts a deal or purchases a trinket, he bids them adieu and tells them he'll see them aboard the Dead Man's Hand, which is just down the road. He adds that they'll be his honored guests while in the casino (see "{@area Dead Man's Hand|38c|x}" later in the chapter) before disappearing into a burst of magenta fire.

entries.name: Refusing the Sinner
entries: If the Grinning Sinner's hospitality is outright refused, or if the characters attack him, he shakes his head regretfully before grinning, making his escape, and calling forth his minions (see below).

entries.name: Swamp Stalkers
entries: If the characters reject {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} or attack him, read or paraphrase the following:

The croc-folk pulls out a pocket watch with his skeletal hand and examines it. "My, my. Look at the time! It's a shame we couldn't make a deal, but I must retire to the {@i Dead Man's Hand}. It's just down the road!"

With a snap of his bony fingers, brilliant magenta flame whips up around him, and he's gone in an instant. A moment later, the door of the shack explodes in a hail of splinters as a hulking beast made of interwoven swamp plants and hexed charms lurches into the building. A loud buzzing fills the room as it enters.

This monster is a {@creature Bayou Beast|CrookedMoon24} and is joined by six grotesquely large and jinxed mosquitoes (use the {@creature Stirge|XMM} stat block). When defeated, the monsters dissolve into muck.

All of the trinkets remain in the shack, but if a character tries to leave with more than one, all but the first trinket that character took turn to swamp water. Any character who didn't take a Dark Bargain or buy a trinket can steal one now. If they do, 3 CP (or a larger denomination coin or gem if that's all they're carrying) vanishes from the character's possessions or from those of the person closest to them if they're not carrying any money, and the character will be able to gain passage aboard the {@i Dead Man's Hand}.

entries.name: By the Lagoon
entries: Once each character has earned passage on the {@i Dead Man's Hand}, nothing stands in their way from finding it and getting aboard. {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} was telling the truth—surprisingly—and the riverboat is currently moored in the bayou just a few miles north along the Marshwinder Road. When the characters make the trek, read or paraphrase the following:

With each step, the muddy path becomes more treacherous and choked with foliage, but you finally hear your destination before you see it. Distant jazzy brass music fills the night air, almost in a greeting as you come to the edge of a mangrove-shrouded lake.

Moored at the center of this bayou is an enormous riverboat, glowing with vibrant neon colors and shimmering with the haunted visage of a ghost ship. Its sigil-etched paddle wheel is motionless, but the tall twin funnels belch magenta flame sporadically.

Any character who hasn't earned passage aboard the {@i Dead Man's Hand} doesn't hear the music and only sees a wrecked and ruined riverboat split into two pieces, faded letters reading "LAUGH" on the portion of the hull still emerging from the black water. A character must return to the shack and retrieve a trinket to board the boat.

A {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24} approaches in a coffin boat perfectly sized to fit all the characters. It is dressed as a chauffeur and has copper pieces in its eye sockets and one in the center of his forehead. It greets them on behalf of Mister Crossroads and offers them passage to the {@i Dead Man's Hand}.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Wheel of Fortune|060|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Cutlass of Briggsy Kratch|CrookedMoon24} can be found glowing just below the surface of the bayou.

entries.name: The Dead Man's Hand
entries: The haunted riverboat casino drifts between realms, lingering on the shadowed crossroads of Druskenvald and the land of spirits. Here, the hexing power of Snake Eye Jack reaches its peak, with {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} former patron still bound within.

As the characters explore, they may encounter the ship's original owner, the now-Undead {@area Elias Greaves|357|x}, and uncover the tale of the {@i Dead Man's Hand} and the Grinning Sinner's plan for {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}. Upon entering the Captain's Quarters ({@area area B8|3af|x}), the ship warps into a grand, garish arena—the stage set for a final showdown with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}.

entries.name: Dead Man's Hand Features
entries: Areas within the riverboat casino have the following features unless its description says otherwise:

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Exterior areas have {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} shed by paper lanterns and glowing jinxcraft sigils etched all over the exterior of the riverboat. Interior areas have {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} from chandeliers and mirrored walls. All of these lights glow with vibrant neon colors and are fueled by burning soulfire that {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} has collected; a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check realizes this.

entries.name: Music
entries: Bright and upbeat jazz music plays throughout the entire riverboat, magically projecting from the band that plays in the Gambling Hall (see {@area area B3|3a0|x}). It is surprisingly catchy, no matter one's musical tastes. Creatures who can hear the music have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on saving throws to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Jinxcraft Sigils
entries: Every location has glowing jinxcraft sigils etched into the walls, floors, and ceilings that keep Snake Eye Jack imprisoned and use his spectral essence to fuel the operations of the Dead Man's Hand. This fills the riverboat with his power over luck, both good and bad. Attack rolls score {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB|Critical Hits} on a roll of 19 or 20, and they automatically miss on a roll of 1 or 2. This is cumulative with features such as a Champion Fighter's Improved Critical (who would score {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB|Critical Hits} on a roll of 18, 19, or 20).

entries.name: Gamblers
entries: Dozens of people from across Wickermoor Hollow and the rest of Druskenvald sit at casino tables, playing cards or dice or betting on enchanted horse figurines made to race, or they mingle at the ship's well-stocked bar. They are all cursed—enthralled by the seductive power of the casino. They are {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} and happily lead characters around and share their favorite games, but they know little about the ship or its campaign and direct them to ask the Undead casino staff (who they seem to think are still living people). Gamblers become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to anyone who interferes in their games.

entries.name: Curse of the High Roller
entries: When a character who isn't yet cursed by the casino finishes a game of chance here, they must succeed on a {@dc 8} Wisdom saving throw or be cursed and have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition (by the Grinning Sinner). While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, they are enthralled and want nothing more but to gamble, drink, flirt with patrons, and otherwise keep enjoying the area of the casino they're currently in. They can repeat this saving throw after 10 minutes, ending the effect on a success. A character who fails two of these repeat saves in a row becomes fully captivated, makes no more saving throws, and has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on all {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} made to harm casino patrons or otherwise disrupt the convivial atmosphere of the riverboat while cursed. The curse is then permanent until broken by a {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} spell or similar magic, or if the Grinning Sinner damages the character, forces them to make a saving throw, or dies.

entries.name: Dead Man's Hand Locations
entries: The following areas are found on {@adventure the Dead Man's Hand map|CrookedMoon|8|Map: Dead Man's Hand}.

entries.name: B1: Dead Man's Gangplank
entries: When the characters arrive at the {@i Dead Man's Hand}, read or paraphrase the following:

The ghastly riverboat is moored at the center of the bayou with its gangplank lowered onto a small muddy island beside it. Eerily vibrant and colorful light pours from the ship's upper decks, and jaunty music drifts across the water as if the party inside never stops. Two hulking undead bellhops laze about at the top of the gangplank.

The gangplank leads to the upper level of the riverboat. At its top are two {@creature Ogre Zombie|XMM|Ogre Zombies} dressed as bellhops poised to take guests' luggage and escort them through the boat.

entries.name: Honored Guests
entries: If the characters are {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}' guests, the bellhops are {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the characters and escort them to the Gambling Hall ({@area area B3|3a0|x}) to wait. See the "Honored Guests" section in that area for more.

entries.name: Intruders
entries: If the characters defied Mister Crossroads earlier and gained passage through stealing or resorted to violence, these guards are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and attack on sight. They are dull-witted brutes, however, and as an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can convince the zombies to let the characters pass with a successful {@dc 16} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: B2: Top Deck
entries: The Top Deck circles the entire length of the ship.

The top deck of the riverboat is crowded with well-dressed Druskenvalders from across the land, chatting and sipping from champagne flutes, whiskey tumblers, and rum bottles, savoring the open air beyond the smoky, crowded gambling hall. Doors to the hall are never far away. If not for the Grinning Sinner's ominous influence, the cheerful conversations and the eerie, flickering glow of paper lanterns might almost lure you into their revelry.

entries.name: Hollow Conversation
entries: The gamblers here are vapid and have nothing to share with the characters, except to urge them to go drink and gamble. A character afflicted by the Curse of the High Roller (see "{@area Dead Man's Hand Features|38d|x}" earlier), however, perceives this conversation as the deepest, most compelling conversation they've ever heard.

entries.name: The Cursed Gambler
entries: If the characters have the {@item Withered Hand|CrookedMoon24}, its original owner can sense its presence and seeks them out. After the characters do anything here, such as chatting with a gambler, taking a drink, or investigating for anything out of the ordinary, they are noticed by Elias Greaves (use the {@creature Ghoul|XMM} stat block), who shambles his way to them.

A gaunt waiter in an ill-fitting suit hobbles across the deck toward you. As he nears, a foul stench fills the air, and you notice the hollow pits where his eyes should be, his skin peeling in strips. This man is long dead, yet his focus is fixed on you. His left arm ends in a stump, which he waves as if to speak, his jaw working uselessly, struggling to form sounds.

entries.name: What Elias Knows
entries: {@area Elias|357|x} can't speak. His soul is burning in the Boiler Room ({@area area B4|3a3|x}) to power "his ship." If the characters show him the hand, the hand (which has a fragment of Elias's soul in it) reacts and tries to lead them to the Boiler Room. The body does not follow unless the characters move it themselves.

entries.name: Examining Elias
entries: If the characters roll up the loose sleeve on his left arm and inspect his stump, it is clear that the hand once belonged to Elias—a chilling sign of what could happen to the current bearer of the {@item Withered Hand|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: B3: Gambling Hall
entries: Entering this hall from the Main Deck leads the characters onto a balcony overlooking the main ballroom, which they can descend into from a set of stairs. The guests are living but cursed human {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}, while the dealers and bartenders are all Undead {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24|Ferrymen}. In the corner of the room is a small stage where five {@creature Skeleton|XMM} musicians form a jazz band, playing upbeat music on a trumpet, trombone, piano, clarinet, and drum set.

Countless gamblers fill this space playing every game of chance imaginable. At any time, the room is filled with {@dice 1d12} {@creature Ghoul|XMM} waiters and {@dice 1d4} {@creature Ogre Zombie|XMM|Ogre Zombies} dressed as bellhops. They attack the characters on sight if they weren't invited and even attack invited characters if they disrupt the atmosphere, such as by hassling the guests or breaking a chandelier. If combat breaks out, the guests flee screaming to the Top Deck ({@area area B2|399|x}) while the crew fights to the death.

entries.name: Honored Guests
entries: After being led in by {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} guards, the characters are asked to wait here until their host is ready for them and to enjoy several games on the house. The house covers 100 GP worth of antes, food, and drinks. The food is delicious; see {@area area B6|3ad|x}. The drinks are a staggering 5 GP apiece. If the characters wait here for half an hour and haven't all been afflicted by the Curse of the High Roller, Elias finds them (see "The Cursed Gambler" in {@area area B2|399|x}). If the characters ignore him, after three hours, the bellhops return and escort them to the Captain's Quarters ({@area area B8|3af|x}).

entries.name: Joining a Game
entries: The characters can play cards or dice with the cursed gamblers. To represent these games, the characters ante between 1 and 20 GP and make a {@dc 20} Wisdom check with an appropriate Gaming Set, winning double their ante on a success or losing it on a failure. See "Curse of the High Roller" in the "{@area Dead Man's Hand Features|38d|x}" section earlier for the consequences of playing, win or lose.

entries.name: B4: Boiler Room
entries: The Boiler Room pulses with the unnatural power of jinxcraft, its soulfire boiler casting a ghostly magenta glow across the tight, shadow-filled corridors. Undead laborers shuffle about, mending broken pipes, hauling crates, and carrying out the grim tasks required to keep this sinister casino running. Trapped within the boiler lies the tormented soul of {@area Elias Greaves|357|x}. Freeing him releases Elias from {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} grip, granting the characters a powerful advantage and cutting off the soul-fueled hexes that bind Snake Eye Jack, signaling {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}' inevitable downfall.
However, the disruption immediately alerts the Sinner to the characters' presence (see "Don't Grieve for Greaves" below).

entries.name: Soulfire Boiler
entries: This coffin-shaped, sigil-etched boiler is tended by a mighty spirit called the Soulfire Engineer ({@creature Wraith|XMM}). She serves the Grinning Sinner by incanting jinxcraft hexes that eternally regenerate Elias's soul to keep the magenta soulfire burning. She demands the characters leave if they enter the boiler room and attacks if they remain or retaliate. When {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is rolled, the boiler belches forth 5 {@creature Specter|XMM|Specters} and a {@creature Soulfire Stoker|CrookedMoon24}, and they join the fight.

entries.name: Blasting Furnace
entries: When combat breaks out here, the flames in the boiler blaze and belch out through the furnace doors and gaps in the plating. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), creatures in the room must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The Soulfire Engineer, stoker, and specters are immune to this effect.

entries.name: Don't Grieve for Greaves
entries: When the last of the spirits is defeated, read or paraphrase the following:
The fiery spirit wails in fury and flares out, extinguishing the boiler's magenta flames along with it. Behind the steel hatch of the darkened furnace is a floating mote of ashen green light.

The ashen mote is Elias Greaves's soul. When a character opens the boiler, the {@item Withered Hand|CrookedMoon24} tries to scurry up their body, jump into the boiler, and touch the mote. If it does so, it then runs back to Elias's body, taking the soul with it. Once the soul and the body are reunited, neon light returns to Greaves' eyes, and he can speak once more. If a character is attuned to the hand, this does not break the {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB}.

He runs to meet the characters while they are still in the belly of the ship and wearily thanks the characters for freeing his soul. He answers any questions they may have about who he is, what happened to him, what he knows about Mister Crossroads and Snake Eye Jack, and how the {@i Dead Man's Hand} came into his possession (see "{@area NPCs of the Drowned Crossroads|356|x}" earlier in this chapter).

Through the awakening of his hand, he deduced the Grinning Sinner's plan in his deal with {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}. He knows his own soul was able to power the boiler because he traveled aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express} in life.

With his soul running out of anima to drain for the boiler, his usefulness has been running out. Mister Crossroads plans to swap Adela's soul into the boiler once she succumbs to the withering curse. Such a powerful soul would fuel the {@i Dead Man's Hand} and Snake Eye Jack's prison for all time.

{@i Elias's Gift}. Elias's soul is tattered and weary, and he wishes to depart so he can finally rest. As a parting gift, he casts {@spell Death Ward|XPHB} on two characters. He apologizes that he can't break the curse on his {@item Withered Hand|CrookedMoon24} but entrusts it to the accursed character and hopes they can avoid his fate.

He also hands over Adela Druskenvald's wedding ring, which his hand had pickpocketed from Mister Crossroads and hid in Elias's pocket for safekeeping before making its journey to the characters. He hopes that returning it will heal Adela. After a final farewell, the light in his eyes goes out, and his body collapses, finally at rest.

entries.name: Alerting Mister Crossroads
entries: The Grinning Sinner senses when his ship's boiler goes cold. He gathers his crew and storms the Gambling Hall 10 minutes later, preparing to confront the characters. This causes the following changes to area B3:
