items: All gamblers and dealers are expelled from the hall. They either crowd around the windows on the Top Deck ({@area area B2|399|x}) or retire to their quarters ({@area area B7|3ae|x}).
{@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} is there. See "{@area Roll the Bones|3b6|x}," later in this chapter for how he acts.
He is backed up by 6 {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24|Ferrymen} and 20 {@creature Ghoul|XMM|Ghouls}. Fighting him directly in the {@area Gambling Hall|3a0|x} is a bad idea.
He doesn't initially resort to violence and offers to settle their differences with a game of Liar's Dice (see "{@area The Grinning Sinner's Challenge|3af|x}" later in the chapter).

entries.name: B5: Coin Vault
entries: The riverboat's cavernous coin vault is a soggy hold filled with sacks full of coins wagered by the casino guests. The room is dimly lit by swinging neon lanterns on the walls.

entries.name: Iron Cage
entries: The heavy wooden door to this room is locked ({@dc 15}). Beyond the door is an iron cage that encases the whole room, with metal bars 1 foot apart. The door to this cage has a sturdy Lock ({@dc 20}).

entries.name: Vault Guardians
entries: It's easily the best-guarded room in the riverboat. The Coin Keeper ({@creature Wight|XMM}) guards this area with the aid of 4 swamp-covered {@creature Ghast|XMM|Ghasts} and 8 {@creature Ghoul|XMM|Ghouls}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Within this room are a sack of gold coins (500 GP), three sacks of silver coins (each one containing 500 SP), and twelve sacks of copper coins (each one containing 500 CP).

entries.name: B6: Galley
entries: The boat's Galley is managed by Undead chefs and waiters. Despite the dead kitchen staff, it's surprisingly well-run, and the food they serve is beautiful and delicious. The drinks are delightful and strong enough to dull the pain of combat, granting the drinker {@dice 2d4} {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: B7: Crew and Guest Quarters
entries: The crew quarters, where the riverboat's crew once lived, are now empty. The Undead who now serve {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} have no need for sleep.

The adjacent guest quarters are about half filled at any given time. Amidst the darkness of Wickermoor Hollow, the guests cursed by greed and malaise drift in and out of the Gambling Hall ({@area area B3|3a0|x}), resting only when {@condition exhaustion|XPHB} overwhelms them. Searching this room reveals nothing of value.

entries.name: B8: Captain's Quarters
entries: {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} is found here if he hasn't been drawn elsewhere, presiding over the particulars of his operation on a huge desk etched with jinxcraft markings. Whether or not the first meeting with {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} ended in violence (see "{@area Between the Deals|37e|x}" earlier in this chapter), he welcomes the characters as friends. Even if the characters insulted and attacked him, the prideful magician wants payback, but he sees himself as a gentleman, not a killer. He gives them a good offer, and only attacks in retaliation.
Read or paraphrase the following when the characters arrive here:

The captain's cabin seems less like a room in a stately riverboat and more like a nautical museum. A black flag with crossed bones and a crocodilian skull hangs on the wall behind Mister Crossroads' desk, surrounded by tattered flags from countless other crews. A ship in a bottle sits on the desk. Hanging proudly on the wall is a huge blunderbuss, etched with sigils that glow neon green and magenta.
If Mister Crossroads is here, also read or paraphrase the following, possibly improvising extra remarks based on the characters' actions within the boat so far:
The corpse-like crocodile-man sits at his desk and marks your arrival. He stands, putting on his feathered top hat and a winning smile, and clears his throat.
"Welcome to my humble establishment, friends. I do hope you've enjoyed our games of chance and refreshments."

entries.name: The Grinning Sinner's Challenge
entries: To settle their differences, Mister Crossroads offers them a chance to win fair and square. Best him in a winner-takes-all game of {@area Liar's Dice|371|x} (see "{@area Test of Luck|36c|x}" earlier in this chapter) between the characters and him.

His wager: the ship and everyone aboard it. Without it, he goes back to being a small-time con. He'll even cure Adela of her withering curse. The characters' wager: their potent souls, primed by their experience aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}, to burn in the boiler room until there's nothing left but ash. If they balk at this, he offers them the bribe a second time.

entries.name: Accepting the Challenge
entries: If the characters accept, he shows them a toothy grin and assembles his crew in the Gambling Hall (see {@area "Roll the Bones|3b6|x}" below).

entries.name: What's His Angle
entries: A character who makes a successful {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check can tell that the Grinning Sinner is not a man of his word. He's selfish, prideful, and a sore loser.

entries.name: Rejected
entries: If the characters attack the Grinning Sinner or decline his offer despite his insistence, he snarls and vanishes in a burst of magenta fire. He then appears in the Gambling Hall ({@area area B3|3a0|x}), transforming it into a glowing neon pocket dimension and prepares for a fight, but not before giving them one last chance to settle their differences with a game of dice (see "Roll the Bones" later in this chapter).

entries.name: Roll the Bones
entries: {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} views himself as a refined gentleman and is loath to resort to violence. This encounter with Mister Crossroads has two stages. The first part is a high-stakes game of {@area Liar's Dice|371|x} (see {@area area B8|3af|x}). If the characters win this game, he loses his composure and attacks them, but the characters gain a boon in the fight. If they lose, they probably won't want to give up their souls without a fight.

This encounter begins when the characters enter the Gambling Hall ({@area area B3|3a0|x}) after accepting his challenge in the Captain's Quarters (area B8). It can also occur if they raise his ire by destroying the boiler in the Boiler Room ({@area area B4|3a3|x}). In that case, he makes his challenge here but is fully prepared for them to refuse and start a fight.

entries.name: Part of the Crew, Part of the Ship
entries: Read or paraphrase the following when the characters arrive in the Gambling Hall ({@area area B3|3a0|x}) and the above conditions are met:

The gambling hall is completely transformed. The game tables have been rearranged, with one taking center stage—a massive coffin on four legs, carved with glowing sigils and the image of a many-armed skeleton with dice eyes, each showing a single pip.

The room itself has stretched, growing larger and taller than before, with towering, colorful windows set in walls etched with leering skeletal serpents and strange symbols, all bathed in flickering neon hues of green and magenta. Gamblers watch from the balcony and top deck while Mister Crossroads smirks at you from the center. Dozens of his undead thralls stand at his side, his hexed blunderbuss slung over his shoulder.
He grins, teeth gleaming. "They say the saints don't play dice, but we know that sinners do. Liar's Dice. Winner takes all. You know what's at stake, so sit and let's play."

The gambling hall has been transformed into a huge, warped version of its former self, glowing neon and filled with slithering shadows. The dicing table is more than just a place for games—it's the coffin prison of Snake Eye Jack, the true heart of the riverboat's power. If the boiler is disrupted and Elias Greaves' soul set free, the sigils fade over time, and the coffin shudders as Jack stirs, preparing to exact his vengeance.
Any number of characters can join the game, but at least one must play. {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} adds a {@dice d6} to his dice pool for each character who joins.

entries.name: Special Rules
entries: All the Special Rules in the game of {@area Liar's Dice|371|x} they played against the Bayou King still apply (see "{@area Test of Luck|36c|x}" earlier in this chapter). The game continues until only one player, the winner, remains. Or it would, if it weren't that the moment {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} is eliminated, he roars in fury and flips the table, forfeiting the game.

entries.name: The Grinning Sinner's Strategy
entries: {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} makes big bets. He starts by bidding the number of his most common die plus 1 (for example, if he has three 4s, he bids four 4s). However, he also begins the game with more dice than the characters, which lets him bid aggressively.

entries.name: Spin the Wheel
entries: The game ends when either all the characters have lost, and {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} draws his blunderbuss to claim their souls for the boiler, or when {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} is eliminated, flips the table, and attacks (see "Bayou Boogie" below).

entries.name: Bayou Boogie
entries: Whether the characters win or lose, and even if they accept a deal, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} doesn't intend for them to leave the {@i Dead Man's Hand} alive. After warping the gambling hall into a jinxcraft casino, he unleashes the mighty power of Snake Eye Jack and the swamp itself to destroy them so he can claim their souls for the soulfire boiler. Use {@adventure the Jinxcraft Casino map|CrookedMoon|8|Map: Jinxcraft Casino} for both phases of this two-phase battle.

entries.name: Features of the Jinxcraft Casino
entries: In addition to the features of the Dead Man's Hand, the transformed gambling hall has the following features:

entries.name: Balcony
entries: A large set of stairs leads to a second-floor balcony 20 feet above the gaming floor that wraps around the entire room.

entries.name: Jinxcraft Dimension
entries: This room is its own demiplane created with the power of Snake Eye Jack. Anything that passes through a broken window emerges from the window directly opposite on the far wall.

entries.name: Larger Than Life
entries: The {@area Gambling Hall|3a0|x} in this dimension has grown unnaturally. The gaming floor is 60 feet by 90 feet. The ceiling is 60 feet tall, giving {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} plenty of room to fly out of reach.

entries.name: Swamp Water
entries: Bayou water floods the gaming floor to a depth of 2 feet, making it {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Rolling Snake Eyes
entries: If one or more characters beat {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x} at his game of Liar's Dice, Snake Eye Jack—the croc-folk's former patron—begins to break free to unleash his hexing wrath on the magician that deceived him so long ago. He grants the characters a boon of fortune.

Roll 2 d20s and record each number. During the battle, the players can choose to use one of the recorded numbers when a creature makes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. The creature uses the number as if it were rolled on the {@dice d20}. Each number can be used only once. The boon fades away when {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} or the characters are defeated.

entries.name: Snake Eye Jack's Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), Snake Eye Jack is forced to cause one of the following effects; Jack can't use the same option two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Ferrymen
entries: If there aren't any {@creature Ferryman|CrookedMoon24|Ferrymen} in the battle, three appear to aid {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}. These Undead minions only have 10 HP.

entries.name: Rotten Luck
entries: One creature within 30 feet of Snake Eye Jack's coffin is cursed until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round. When the cursed creature makes an attack roll, it must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the total.

entries.name: Shackling Grasp
entries: Shadowy, skeletal hands stretch out from Snake Eye Jack's coffin. Strength Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, up to three creatures within 30 feet of the coffin. Failure: The target has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 15}) until Jack uses this option again. A target that fails the save can choose to succeed instead by taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Necrotic damage.

entries.name: Phase 1: All In
entries: Whether the players win or lose the dice game, or if they rejected Mr. Crossroads' offer entirely, read or paraphrase the following:

The Grinning Sinner stares you down and draws his jinxcraft blunderbuss with his skeletal left hand. His eyes burn and his teeth flash. "Mister Crossroads don't lose. Not with stakes like these. Your souls are mine."

He raises his blunderbuss to the sky, and the jazz music turns ominous and discordant. The room trembles and the tall riverboat windows shatter. The bayou spills in from all sides and begins to flood the gambling hall as creeping swamp plants slither in and spread across the walls.

The crew of the {@i Dead Man's Hand} wail in agony, falling to their knees. Swirling energy flows from their bodies into his weapon, withering the crew into motionless husks as they return their borrowed life to him. He cackles with glee and smiles a wicked smile. "Come take a chance, my friends!"

{@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} attacks and fights to the death. He calls the coffin that serves as the dice table and Snake Eye Jack's prison to him and begins to ride it (see his Coffin Rider trait).

entries.name: Phase 2: Double Down
entries: When he's {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24|Grinning Sinner's} desperation overtakes his good sense.
Wild desperation fills the eyes of Mister Crossroads as he snarls in frustration, stomping violently on the coffin he rides atop. "Come on, Jack! I know you're holding out on me!"
The sigils on the coffin glow brighter as you somehow feel luck itself start to bend and twist all around you, and slithering shadow snakes and hands wriggle out from beneath the coffin's lid.

He draws deeply on Snake Eye Jack's power, glowing with magenta and green energy. He has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls, but attack rolls made against him also have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

Snake Eye Jack continues to use his influence as in phase 1, but now wisps of shadow that vaguely suggest skeletal hands or snakes leak out from under the coffin lid and reach toward the Grinning Sinner before dissipating.

entries.name: Defeating the Grinning Sinner
entries: When {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the final strands of jinxcraft binding his patron unravel, and Snake Eye Jack claims his soul.

Mister Crossroads bellows in despair, tumbling into the waters below. For a brief moment, a magenta shade of the croc-folk rises from his fallen form, eyes wide with terror. The jinxed coffin bursts open, releasing a rumbling laugh as a dozen skeletal arms and shadowy serpents reach out, seizing his soul and dragging it into the unknowable depths within. The lid slams shut, now etched with a crocodile skull and crossbones.

The air fills with the scent of rum and smoke, and as your vision blurs, you find yourself back in the gambling hall of the real {@i Dead Man's Hand}. The lights have faded, and the casino's manic energy has vanished. Mister Crossroads' corpse lies slumped at the room's center, blunderbuss clutched in his cold hands, his lifeless eyes staring in terror.

With the death of {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}, his Undead thralls emit a collective sigh and crumble into dust, and the demiplane collapses, returning anything in it to the true {@i Dead Man's Hand}. Dozens of confused gamblers, now free from their delirium, seek a way off the riverboat.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 7, if they are still level 6, when they defeat the Grinning Sinner.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Emperor|054|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Blunderbuss of the Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24} can be pulled from the cold clutches of Mister Crossroads, still enchanted with jinxcraft and fully functional.

entries.name: Conclusion: Out of the Haze
entries: The road back to Murkwater Bend is now safe. The crocodilian trickster and his cursed crew are gone, and even the bayou's creatures have returned to their usual, less sinister ways. The gamblers accompany the characters back to town, soon dispersing to find their way home—wherever in Druskenvald that might be.

{@area The Bayou King|358|x} and {@area Lyla|359|x} survive, though their crew suffered massive losses to protect them and their town. Vander, somber and reflective, contemplates the true weight of rulership. Lyla believes he'll make a fine king someday—and not just for scoundrels. She reminds him to pay up if he owes the characters, and he urges them to collect their reward from whoever sent them.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: With the death of Mr. Crossroads, {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}'s withered arm is healed. If the characters return her wedding ring, she gratefully accepts it and pays what she owes, having successfully deceived Phillip and restoring a sense of normalcy to their anxious lives for now. If the characters keep the ring, it's worth 1,000 GP. Yet, Adela's ordeal emboldens the cultists of the Old Ways. They begin manipulating her confidant, Gaston Doray, aiming to sway him to their cause. This perceived weakness also draws the attention of {@area The Vermintoll Coven|024|x}, whose living members, Stonoga and Golub, double their efforts to corrupt the village's people.

Some of the rescued gamblers without homes settle in Wickermoor Village, bringing games of chance to the Green Queen Inn, where locals soon join in. {@area The Brightsingers|03b|x} preach temperance, sending missionaries to the Drowned Crossroads.

data.name: Skitterdeep Mine

entries: "I can't go no further. It's the mines. The hills 'round here are snaked full of tunnels, and she's down in there. I hear her. She was never 'round these parts until the big cave-in 'bout seventy years back. My pa used to tell me about it.

Fifty men got trapped down there, and from the twilight hour to the witching hour, the hills were full of her centipedes, big as hounds, all skittering down into that mine. Pa said there was some screaming down there for a while, then nothing. She's a special kind of evil."

A skittering infestation scrapes beneath the soil, burrowing ever deeper into the heart of Wickermoor Hollow and its people. From the depths of what was once Glitterdeep Mine, rich with veins of gold, silver, and iron, the contamination spreads. Seventy years ago, a suspicious cave-in occurred, and the few rescuers who returned spoke of terrors before they condemned the mine, leaving it abandoned.

Now called Skitterdeep Mine after its many-legged inhabitants, it is mentioned only in hushed tones, with wary glances over shoulders in fear of the crawling minions and the hag rumored to have brought ruin upon its darkened tunnels.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: A trio of ancient hags known as {@area The Vermintoll Coven|024|x} has long wrought their wicked magic upon the fields, forests, and villages of Wickermoor Hollow. Seventy years ago, the {@creature centipede hag|CrookedMoon24} Stonoga Blackstinger corrupted Skitterdeep Mine—a once thriving source of precious ores.

Using illusion, hearty food, and strong drink, she wormed her way into the miners' trust. Then, she poisoned and twisted them all into grotesque abominations and collapsed the tunnels, trapping the wretched souls within. A cadre of knights attempted a rescue, but they too fell to Stonoga's influence as she warped their flesh to create new minions.

Over the years, fear and superstition shrouded the Skitterdeep Mine. Travelers still vanish near its entrance, taken as material for her pestilent experiments. The infestation has now spread beyond the mine, skittering throughout the walls, beneath the earth, and within the bodies of Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: Wickermoor Hollow is infested with countless centipedes that devour foodstuffs, spread disease, and even burrow into the bodies of the townsfolk. The source of the infestation is the {@creature centipede hag|CrookedMoon24} {@area Stonoga Blackstinger|3d8|x}, who seeks a new supply of human flesh for her twisted experiments deep within her abandoned mine. With each passing night, the vermin that have taken over town claim more victims and devour more food stores, threatening widespread death and famine. Characters drawn to the mine by the Quest Hooks later in this chapter have these goals:

items: Discover and trace the source of the tunneling vermin to Skitterdeep Mine, and face the horrors within.
Destroy Stonoga Blackstinger and end the Skitter Plague.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with the centipede hag Stonoga Blackstinger, the key NPC. Review the {@area Quest Hooks|3da|x} to provide a compelling reason for the characters to venture to the abandoned mine. Finally, read through the {@area locations of Skitterdeep Mine|3eb|x} so you are ready to improvise encounters as the characters explore.
This chapter is designed for four level 7 characters.

entries.name: The Centipede Hag
entries: Stonoga Blackstinger {@i (stoh-NOH-guh)} commands countless swarms of large, squirming centipedes that skitter throughout the mine. Hideously misshapen miners, knights, and other victims of her fleshcrafting also wander the tunnels and serve their maker without question.

entries.name: Stonoga Blackstinger
entries: Stonoga Blackstinger ({@creature Centipede Hag|CrookedMoon24}) is the middle sister of {@area the Vermintoll Coven|024|x}. Her unnaturally tall and lanky body has morphed overthe years to more closely resemble the centipedes she favors, losing her nose and most of her toes and stretching her neck out by several feet.

Just as it was her sister Vessla's role in the coven to twist souls in preparation for sacrifice to the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}, Stonoga is tasked with corrupting bodies. She cares not for the matters of mind and spirit, as all life to her is simply meat to be molded beneath her jagged fingers. But despite this, she has a jovial disposition, taking glee in savoring the suffering of her victims.

Unlike her sisters, she prefers to hide away in the deepest, darkest holes in the earth where she can be embraced by the squirming swarms of her beloved centipedes. It is in these places that never see the light of the moon where she conducts her alchemy, witchcraft, and fleshcrafting.

Stonoga has been waiting for the night that her younger sister Vessla is slain, a moment foreseen and deemed a necessary sacrifice by her older sister Golub. The two older hags conspired to allow the weasel hag to be butchered in the Crooked House, but Stonoga has no idea that she herself was deceived. Golub Graygullet believed the middle sister needed to die too, as whispered by the Crooked Queen with the promise of being elevated within the inevitable crooked court of Kehlenn. Golub will aid the characters in hunting down Stonoga if she can.

entries.name: Slippery Oswald
entries: {@creature Slippery Oswald|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Centipede)|CrookedMoon24}) is a rough approximation of a centipede the size of a hound, with grotesquely human-like hands at the end of each appendage and an unsettling human grin. The familiar of {@area Stonoga Blackstinger|3d8|x}, he shares his mistress's glee in the horrid reshaping of flesh into new forms. He can command the squirming hordes of centipedes that crawl throughout Wickermoor Hollow.

Rather than being a collector of body parts like his weasel counterpart Filthy Jasper, Oswald prefers to create grotesque homes out of his master's victims. He burrows deep into Humanoid carcasses and rearranges the rotting innards to his liking, often lurking within for weeks at a time. Sometimes, he even digs into a healthy person to corrupt and prime their body for flesh shaping while they still live.

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: Wickermoor Village is crawling with centipedes as a sudden illness rips through its people. The sick only have a few nights to live before succumbing to the affliction. A solution must be found before it's too late.

entries.name: Infestation
entries: The village is infested with thousands of centipedes sent by Stonoga Blackstinger. These vermin consume food stores, burrow into the flesh of the living, and spread a magical contagion that afflicts those bitten by the creatures (see "Skitter Plague" below).

After the characters finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in Wickermoor Village, four {@creature Skitterswarm|CrookedMoon24|Skitterswarms} emerge from the walls and floor of wherever they are staying and attack. Creatures hit by the swarms' attacks must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be afflicted with Skitter Plague. Dozens of small mundane centipedes crawl throughout the floorboards as well.

When the characters step out into the streets of Wickermoor Village after dispatching the skitterswarms, many people are gathered here having fled their homes from centipede infestations. When asked about what's going on, the plight is consistent across the townsfolk's stories:

items: They awoke with dozens of centipedes crawling in their beds, many having been bitten.
Their stored food is infested with centipedes, and much of it has been eaten.
Some larger, more grotesque, and especially vicious centipedes have dug into certain people's skin.
People quickly started falling ill, coming down with fever, breaking out into mauve-colored pustules, and vomiting black bile.

entries: Over the next few hours, ten more villagers succumb to the unknown malady, all with similar stories. If nothing is done, the Skitter Plague will become an epidemic.

entries.name: Skitter Plague
entries: {@i Magical Contagion}

Skitter Plague was created by the hag Stonoga Blackstinger, and it spreads through the bites of her grotesque centipedes. A creature bitten by any kind of centipede under Stonoga's control must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or suffer the following effects {@dice 1d4} hours after infection:

entries.name: Fever
entries: The creature gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level that can't be removed until the contagion ends on the creature.

entries.name: Crawling Blisters
entries: Blisters that feel like crawling centipedes form on the creature's skin. When the creature finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, it takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) Necrotic damage, and its Hit Point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. The creature dies if this effect reduces its Hit Point maximum to 0. The reduction can't be removed until the contagion ends on the creature. A Humanoid that dies from this contagion explodes into a {@creature Skitterswarm|CrookedMoon24} at the next Midnight Hour, the corpse's flesh and bones turning into a malleable putty-like substance that can be split apart and carried by centipedes back to Skitterdeep Mine.

entries.name: Fighting the Contagion
entries: A {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} spell suppresses the effect of the contagion for 24 hours. Nightly at the Twilight Hour, an infected creature makes a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. After the creature succeeds on three of these saves, the contagion ends for it.

entries.name: Trail of Corruption
entries: The characters can investigate the town to find where the centipedes are coming from by succeeding on a group {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check, discovering a sprawling network of tiny tunnels in the earth that seem to be coming from the northwest of Wickermoor Village.

After deducing the direction from which the centipedes are burrowing into town, the characters are approached by Mrs. Oakum (see chapter {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}), who works for Siv Harga at the butcher shop. She tells the characters that the centipede infestation perfectly matched stories that her father used to tell her about the old abandoned mine in the wooded hills northwest of Wickermoor Village. Use the details below to guide the conversation with her:

items: Her family used to live in a small community of hill-folk that worked in mining, logging, and trapping.
Decades ago, the old Glitterdeep Mine had a terrible cave-in that trapped dozens of miners within.
Thousands of huge, monstrous centipedes were seen skittering in the hills and into the mine.
A large rescue party was organized, but those who went into the mine never returned.
The rumor among the community was that it was a hag that caused the tragedy.
Swearing vengeance, a posse of riders was rallied to kill the hag and her minions, but they were never heard from again.
Fear of vile magic and the loss of work in the mine caused the community to dwindle.
Folks who know the old story have called the abandoned mine Skitterdeep for years.

entries: Mrs. Oakum offers to guide the characters through the hills but says she won't get too close to the mine, fearing the hag that lurks in the depths. If the characters accept her help, the journey to the mine is the ideal opportunity to have her true identity as a {@creature Werewolf|XMM} be revealed through an inadvertent transformation, whether it be through danger that the characters experience or hunger triggered by a forest creature.

If the characters don't take it upon themselves to investigate the mine, Morgan the apothecary (see chapter {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}) requests their assistance. They stress that if nothing is done, the sickness will overwhelm the town, and there will not be enough healers to tend to the ill—made worse by the indifference of the de facto surgeon Randall Graham, who believes the situation will resolve itself without taking drastic action. If necessary, Morgan offers the characters a {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG|Potion of Healing (greater)} each to find the cause of the sickness and eliminate it.

Characters who monitor the health of afflicted villagers over the course of the night, or Morgan the apothecary if the characters don't think to, realize that the illness is likely fatal over the course of several nights.

entries.name: Sisterly "Love"
entries: If the characters are not in Wickermoor Village when you wish to initiate the events of this chapter, a carrier pigeon finds them wherever they are, delivering a letter from postmaster Theodora Mayville. She informs them of the town's infestation and her own suspicion that the centipedes were coming from Skitterdeep Mine.

She claims that she sent out a rider, who normally delivers large parcels, to investigate the mine, but he never returned. Theodora implores the characters to head to the mine themselves and put an end to the infestation, offering 50 GP to each character once the plague is halted.

This is a ruse by {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24} (see "{@area The Crooked Moon|024|x}") to lure the characters into finding and killing her sister {@area Stonoga|3d8|x} as a sacrifice in honor of the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}. If the characters follow this quest hook, they are confronted by a lone {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24} when they are three miles out from the mine—the flesh-crafted parcel rider that Theodora had sent to his doom.

entries.name: Skitterdeep Mine
entries: Skitterdeep Mine is about 8 hours of travel away from the village at a Fast pace through the wooded hills northwest of town. It once provided gold, silver, and iron for the people of Wickermoor Village, but has become a place of death and decay. When the characters arrive at the mine, read or paraphrase the following:

Old, weathered buildings sit beside a large hole dug into the earth, the darkness within an inky black. A wooden beam extends from one of the structures, which holds a heavy chain lowered into the abyss. Not far from the shaft, broken iron minecart rails lead to a lumber-reinforced tunnel entrance built into a wooden ridge. The stench of rotting meat and sweat hangs in the air.

entries.name: Skitterdeep Mine Features
entries: Unless otherwise noted, Skitterdeep Mine has the following features:

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Ceilings are 10 feet high in mine shafts and tunnels, and 15 feet high in rooms and chambers.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The mine's interior locations are unlit unless otherwise noted.

entries.name: Hag Mark
entries: {@area Stonoga|3d8|x} has marked all the denizens of the mine (the mark is a cluster of blisters that resembles a centipede), which makes them immune to the Oppressive Gloom feature as well as the Putrid Miasma in {@area area S6|413|x}.

entries.name: Oppressive Gloom
entries: Thanks to Stonoga's magical tampering, all light sources have their radius halved. Furthermore, {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}'s range is reduced to 15 feet. Stonoga and creatures she has marked can see normally.

entries.name: Skitter Plague
entries: When a creature in the mine is hit by an attack from a {@creature Giant Centipede|XMM} or {@creature Skitterswarm|CrookedMoon24}, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be afflicted with Skitter Plague (see "{@area Skitter Plague|3ea|x}" above).

entries.name: Skitterdeep Mine Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to {@adventure the Skitterdeep Mine (Side) map|CrookedMoon|9|Map: Skitterdeep Mine (Side)} through {@adventure the Deep Drift map|CrookedMoon|9|Map: Deep Drift}.

entries.name: S1: Warehouse

entries: A broken sign hangs on the door to the warehouse. The faded letters once read "Glitterdeep Mine," but the first two letters have been painted over by a vandal, so it now reads "Skitterdeep Mine" in weathered writing. The door hangs mostly open in the frame, revealing a long aisle filled with damaged shelves and scattered rubble.

The room stinks of sweat and sewage, and a thin, greenish haze hangs in the air. You hear the sound of guttural snoring and wet lip smacking and see their source. Four humanoid figures sleep on sheets of rusted metal, horribly mutated and warped with distended bellies, mole-like claws, huge bulging eyes, and stringy wispy hair.
Broken shelves line the warehouse interior, and debris clutters nearly every possible space.

entries.name: Debris
entries: The warehouse is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} due to the great piles of detritus.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There are four {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|Deepdrecks} asleep amidst the broken items here at any given time. These flesh-crafted abominations are what remain of the lost miners. Resting deepdrecks have no interest in fighting and will flee to warn {@area Stonoga|3d8|x} of intruders if awoken—though they will defend themselves if cornered.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who spends 10 minutes searching the debris finds two trinkets lost in the rubble, and with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, also finds a metal lockbox. The lock is rusted through and can be opened with light effort. The box contains three citrines (50 GP each) and a {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG|Potion of Healing (greater)} labeled "Emergency."

entries.name: S2: Machine Shop
entries: Areas S2a, S2b, and S2c are all part of one larger building. The following description is for the whole shop:

The smell of oxidized metal emanates from this rusted ramshackle building. Warped gaps in wall planks and molded holes in the roof seem to belch thin green gas. A heavy chain runs from inside the southern portion of the building to a scaffold over a mineshaft before it descends into darkness.
The chain runs from the Winch House ({@area area S2c|3fd|x}) and into the Main Shaft ({@area area S3|400|x}).

entries.name: Doors
entries: Each of the locked doors in this building can be unlocked with the iron key around the neck of the {@creature fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24} on the lift in area S3.

entries.name: S2a: Tool Storage

entries: This room contains dozens of old mining implements and scattered refuse. Most of the visible floor is covered in smudged, filthy handprints, which have disrupted the dust and dirt that cling to every inch of this area.
The mining implements here are mostly useless, ruined by decades of exposure.

entries.name: Handprints
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines the area and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check learns that the handprints lead to and from the door to the southern room ({@area area S2b|3f9|x}), as if a creature were walking on its hands. If the characters have already seen a {@creature fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24}, they can easily deduce that more such creatures lurk in the next room.

entries.name: South Door
entries: The south door is locked ({@dc 15}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who looks through the debris and succeeds on a {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds a {@item Maul|XPHB}, as well as a {@item Dungeoneer's Pack|XPHB} with a flask of {@item Alchemist's Fire|XPHB} and a flask of {@item Oil|XPHB} strapped to the side. A character who spends 5 minutes thoroughly searching succeeds on the check automatically.

entries.name: S2b: Fleshdobbin Lair

entries: This filthy room stinks of mold and stale sweat. Four piles of rubbish are draped in rotten blankets and old cloth. You hear a squelching whinny as two large abominable creatures stir. They have the silhouette of horses but seem to have the flesh and loose anatomy of humans. They hobble about the room on four limbs, drooling large drops of putrid saliva onto the stained floor.
The piles are fleshdobbin beds, covered with the horse blankets and rotten wine-red surcoats of the horses and knights these creatures once were.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24|Fleshdobbins} are presently inside the lair. They are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to intruders and attack without hesitation.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Both doors here are locked ({@dc 15}).

entries.name: S2c: Winch House
entries: The door leading into this room is locked ({@dc 15}).
A heavy chain winds around a massive winch and runs out through a port in the wall. A control box with a lever stands next to the machinery.
A Small creature can wriggle through the chain port with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check, and a Tiny creature can squeeze through the port without a check.

entries.name: Winch
entries: The controls for the winch are simple enough to operate, but doing so causes it to emit a loud groan and series of shrieks that alert all other creatures in the mine to the presence of intruders. For the next 2 hours, denizens of the mine are alert and watching. {@area Stonoga|3d8|x}, {@area Slippery Oswald|3d9|x}, and the {@creature deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|deepdrecks} attempt to hide and set ambushes during that time. {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24|Fleshdobbins} can't be bothered to hide, as they delight in brashness.

The winch can be disabled using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check, and it has AC 17, HP 10, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage.
If the platform is brought up to the ground level, the creatures on the lift of the Main Shaft (see area S3) ride the platform up and investigate, attacking any intruders on sight.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the winch and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check realizes the danger of operating it, and that a flask of {@item Oil|XPHB} poured on the mechanism will prevent it from making noise.

entries.name: S3: Main Shaft

entries: A rusted chain extends from a ramshackle building to a scaffold over a square mineshaft, then descends into the darkness. The hole in the earth belches a foul-smelling gas of a greenish hue.

The chain runs from the winch mechanism ({@area area S2c|3fd|x}) and suspends a lift platform. The shaft is a 15-foot square tunnel cut straight down into the rock. It drops 100 feet from the surface to the rough bottom just below {@area area S6|413|x}.

entries.name: Chain
entries: A creature can climb the chain with relative ease (no ability check required).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24}, two {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|Deepdrecks}, and ten {@creature Giant Centipede|XMM|Giant Centipedes} lurk on or around the lift.

entries.name: Lift
entries: The lift is 30 feet below the surface, at {@area area S5|40d|x}. It's a platform composed of a series of wooden planks bolted to the top of three iron beams, and it is controlled from the winch house (area S2c).

If more than 2,500 pounds of weight is placed on the lift and chain, the winch breaks and spins free, sending the lift, any creatures on it, and the chain hurtling to the bottom of the shaft. If the centipedes are on the lift, they scuttle off onto the walls of the shaft. If the lift falls, it is smashed into splinters and alerts the denizens of the mine as described in area S2c. The winch is destroyed and useless.
Any creatures on the lift when it falls also fall and take damage from the fall if they hit the bottom of the shaft.

entries.name: Rotting Stench
entries: Characters smell a noxious odor from below, radiating from area S6, where a Putrid Miasma has entirely consumed the tunnels.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The fleshdobbin wears an iron key to the doors in the Machine Shop ({@area area S2|3f1|x}) on a leather cord around its neck.

entries.name: S4: Old Drift
entries: If the characters enter the Old Drift from the surface, read the following:

Overturned minecarts litter the entrance of this tunnel bored into the ridge. The timber scaffolding built around the opening is discolored, rotten, and termite-eaten. Vegetation has grown overmuch of the start of the drift that has been unused for some time. An especially foul stink wafts up from the tunnel.

This was once the main working drift of the mine long ago, before the terrible cave-in that doomed so many miners. An exit from the drift was cut as a secondary air source and access for minecarts. {@area Stonoga|3d8|x} and her minions haven't bothered concealing the old entrance further.

entries.name: Rotting Stench
entries: An odor of decay lingers faintly throughout and wafts from the far entrance, radiating up from {@area area S6|413|x} where Stonoga's miasma has consumed the tunnels.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Five {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|Deepdrecks} wander these tunnels, grinding through the stone and dirt, searching for precious metal nuggets to curry favor with Stonoga. Unless they were alerted by the lift moving in area S3, they are utterly immersed in their work and have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks made to notice intruders.

entries.name: Patrolling Spy
entries: Every 3 ({@dice 1d6}) minutes, a {@creature Giant Centipede|XMM}—squeezed into a {@item Ring of Evasion|XDMG} it wears around its middle—skitters through the tunnel. If the centipede spots intruders, it scurries off to report their presence to Stonoga in her laboratory ({@area area S7|419|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Removing the centipede's {@item Ring of Evasion|XDMG} requires killing it. Scattered along the drift are enough serviceable mining implements to assemble a set of {@item Mason's Tools|XPHB}.

entries.name: S5: Crosscut

entries: Boxes of large gems and sacks full of glittering nuggets of precious metals line the available space—a massive treasure hoard. Despite the shiny trove of precious stones and metals, this chamber stinks with the smell of rotten meat.

{@area Stonoga|3d8|x} stores some of her valuables that have no immediate practical use to her in this tunnel, along with a different type of treasure: rotten flesh and bones she may be able to use in her fleshcraft experiments. To safeguard these "riches," she set her familiar and a magical trap to guard them.

entries.name: Illusion
entries: The gems and precious metals here are false, save for one box (see "Treasure" below), and are protected by an intangible illusion that makes the eyeballs, tongues, knucklebones, and various organs appear as gemstones, fine silks, coins, gilded chalices, and delicate necklaces. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a creature that examines the false treasure and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check can see through the uncanny illusion for what it really is, leaving it as a ghostly apparition to them.

entries.name: Creature
entries: When he's not at Stonoga's side or tormenting {@creature deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|deepdrecks}, {@area Slippery Oswald|3d9|x} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Centipede)|CrookedMoon24}) lurks here, burrowed in a lumpy pile of intestines. He knows that he can hide deep within the illusory treasures and remain undisturbed by the deepdrecks and {@creature fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24|fleshdobbins}, who have been trained to avoid this space. While within the hoard, he has the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition against a creature that has not seen through the illusion. He ambushes the characters if they disturb him and fights without fear, knowing that if he dies, Stonoga can summon him again.

entries.name: Magical Trap
entries: The entrance to the Crosscut has a single eyeball hanging by its optic nerve above it, noticeable by creatures that take the {@action Search|XPHB} action and succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. If anyone other than Stonoga or Slippery Oswald takes treasure from the Crosscut past the eyeball, the Main Shaft ({@area area S3|400|x}) fills with a {@spell Hypnotic Pattern|XPHB} spell (save {@dc 15}) for 10 minutes, and a mental {@spell Alarm|XPHB} spell alerts Stonoga, Slippery Oswald, and any remaining fleshdobbins to the presence of intruders.

Stonoga can end or reset the trap's effects at any time (no action required) from anywhere in the mine. The eyeball trap can be disabled with the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and a successful DC15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check or a successful {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} spell ({@dc 15}), or it can be broken (AC 13, HP 5, {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Amidst the boxes and sacks full of parts is a single real box of gold and silver nuggets worth 450 GP.

entries.name: S6: Deep Drift

entries: The shaft ends at a rough floor a few feet below a long tunnel filled with a chartreuse haze. A heavy bronze door nearby is cast in dim, pulsing greenish-purple light that illuminates the mist. The sound of trickling water echoes from farther down the dark tunnel. The stench here is oppressive, stinking like a combination of rotting flesh, sweat, and sewage gas. The walls themselves are slick and seemingly soft to the touch, squirming before your eyes.
The deepest level of the mine, 100 feet below the surface, is the hag {@area Stonoga Blackstinger|3d8|x}'s lair and laboratory.

entries.name: Putrid Miasma
entries: When a creature first enters the area, and again every 10 minutes thereafter until it leaves the miasma, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition. While {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} in this way, the creature repeats the saving throw every hour. On a failure, it gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. On a success, the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition ends. Denizens of the mine are immune to the miasma (see "{@area Hag Mark|3e4|x}" above).

entries.name: Bronze Door
entries: The unlocked bronze door is 3 inches thick and leads to Stonoga's Laboratory (area S7). It's remarkably difficult to hear sounds through the door, so only impacts on the door itself alert Stonoga to a commotion outside.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature Fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24} and a {@creature Skitterswarm|CrookedMoon24} keep guard outside the bronze door, and two {@creature Deepdreck|CrookedMoon24|Deepdrecks} dwell within the walls near the glowing sigils (see below). If combat breaks out, the deepdrecks roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} and join the fight on the second round. If the fleshdobbin dies, any remaining deepdrecks try to pound on the bronze door to warn Stonoga.

entries.name: Gruesome Sigils
entries: The tunnel leads to a chamber where connective tissues and entrails have been formed into a rough knotted pattern on the ground. These sigils writhe as if alive, releasing clouds of foul gas that condense like dew on the walls and seeps through the soil. Stonoga crafted the sigils, which are the source of the Putrid Miasma choking the mine and fueling the magical contagion of Skitter Plague.

If the sigils are destroyed (AC 17; HP 30; {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage; {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to all other damage except Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Force), the toxic fume dissipates. They can also be destroyed with a successful {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} spell ({@dc 15}) or disabled as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action with a successful {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check. If she's alive, Stonoga knows when the sigils are destroyed or deactivated.

entries.name: S7: Stonoga's Laboratory

entries: Behind the heavy bronze door is a filthy laboratory, dimly lit by sickly bruise-colored flames. Shelves line the walls, cluttered with bottles and flasks, and benches are strewn with parchments, soiled blades, and surgical tools. A malformed corpse lies on a table here and is in the process of being dissected and fused with the corpse of a rat-like bipedal figure.

The corpse is {@area Stonoga|3d8|x}'s latest project to create a better {@creature fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24}, using the rat-folk corpse of an unfortunate traveler her minions took from the road (Walder Pye, a plagueborn traveler from Bubonia).

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The lab is lit with {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Putrid Miasma
entries: The miasma filling the Deep Drift (area S6) persists here.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If she hasn't been alerted to the presence of the characters, the {@creature Centipede Hag|CrookedMoon24} Stonoga Blackstinger is deep in ritual research for her horrid experiments. If she is alerted, or when battle breaks out, three {@creature Skitterswarm|CrookedMoon24|Skitterswarms} writhe from the walls and floor to join their mistress. If {@creature Slippery Oswald|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Centipede)|CrookedMoon24}) is still alive, Stonoga calls to him telepathically, and he joins the battle as well.

She's a putrid creature, delighting in the corruption of living flesh, blighting it with disease and poison, and twisting it into freakish new forms through her foul magic. Despite her and morbid appetites, she is unnervingly jovial, savoring lively conversation before choosing to massacre the intruders so that their flesh may be crafted into horrid new designs.
When Stonoga is defeated, read or paraphrase the following:

With a sickening pop, Stonoga Blackstinger's pitch black eyes pop out of her head, and her grotesquely long neck snaps and curls up like a dead centipede as she collapses to the floor. Her corpse immediately begins losing form as her own flesh turns to a malleable sludge that oozes across the ground.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stonoga wears a {@item Necklace of Adaptation|XDMG} in the form of a gold centipede on a cord around her neck. Scattered on her workbench are four {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG|Spell Scrolls}: {@spell Alarm|XPHB}, {@spell Inflict Wounds|XPHB}, {@spell Invisibility|XPHB}, and {@spell Sleep|XPHB}. Her scrawled notes contain useful information summarized in "Conclusion: Exterminated" below.

The apparatus scattered across the shelves is a set of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB} and a large glass jar contains a {@creature fleshdobbin|CrookedMoon24} head preserved in a translucent, cloudy gel. The gel is 4 doses of {@item Keoghtom's Ointment|XDMG|Restorative Ointment}.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Star|06e|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the character this card was pulled for gains a feat of their choice for which they qualify after defeating Stonoga Blackstinger.

entries.name: Conclusion: Exterminated
entries: Once {@area Stonoga Blackstinger|3d8|x} is slain, {@area Slippery Oswald|3d9|x} dies alongside her if he was not killed previously. The poisonous mist (see "Putrid Miasma" in {@area area S6|413|x}) lingers if they haven't already stopped it, though Stonoga's frantic notes and the noxious miasma rising from the symbols reveal that the sigils in the Deep Drift (area S6) are the source of the magical contagion.

Once the sigils are destroyed or deactivated, the Putrid Miasma dissipates, and the spreading Skitter Plague fades from Wickermoor Village. With the death of Stonoga, the thousands of centipedes skitter off into the wilds, ending the infestation. Those afflicted with Skitter Plague begin to recover over the course of the next hour.

Among Stonoga's notes, the characters discover that she gleefully awaits the death of the younger Vessla Browntooth and delights in the conspiracy she has with the older Golub Graygullet, who she claims hides in disguise among the humans of Wickermoor Village. This leads the characters to their next clue on the final member of {@area The Vermintoll Coven|024|x}.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: The townsfolk that had fallen ill recover miraculously and are grateful to the characters for saving their lives. Morgan the apothecary is relieved the townsfolk didn't perish and offers the characters potions from their shop that are appropriate for the needs and requests of the characters (see "{@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}").

{@area Phillip Druskenvald|01f|x}, meanwhile, rolls up his sleeves, determined to better help Wickermoor Village now that the hag and her minions have been scoured from the mine. Alongside Mayor Somerton, he eagerly lays plans to re-open Glitterdeep Mine, envisioning a rebirth of prosperity for the town. He sends out word, seeking laborers with iron resolve, skilled artisans, and guards unafraid of the shadowed depths. His promise of generous wages from his own coffers stirs the townsfolk, and soon, hammers and saws ring out in preparation.

data.name: Memory's Rest

entries: Do not tremble. Do not recoil. You are caught between fear and agony. The world has been so unkind, hasn't it? I know. I know exactly how to take care of you. I can take your pain away, and when I am finished, you will be...better...

Memory's Rest Sanatorium stands as a monument to grief. To outsiders, it promises solace and a retreat from life's troubles. But behind its iron doors lurks a nightmare. Beneath the polished facade and soft-spoken promises, {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} pursues her sinister ambition: {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}. The concoction claims to cure all ailments—but at a terrible cost. Those who undergo its treatment lose more than their pain; their bodies mutate, their memories fade, and they become hollow vessels for Lethica's cruel vision of salvation.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: Memory's Rest Sanatorium rises from the mists of Moonsong Lake, a sanctuary for those seeking relief from their troubles. Its founder, {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}, has transformed the Isle of Mourn into a place of healing—or so its reputation would suggest. In truth, the sanatorium's wards are filled with pained silence and the anguished cries of those seduced by this mask.

To perfect her serum, Lethica and her staff—the corrupted nurses, surgeons, and horrors born of her failures—have turned the sanatorium into a prison. Patients vanish often. Those who do not return have succumbed to the mutagenic effects of {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x} and have transformed into abominations in the image of the true source of the serum.

An eldritch horror known as {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24} has been imprisoned by the matron in the caverns beneath the sanatorium. This otherworldly being's ichor serves as the base of the Lethic Serum, and its alien mind gives endless inspiration for Lethica's abominable experiments, treatments, and goal of twisting the bodies and minds of everyone. Only through the death of the widow can the people be spared this sickening evolution.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} is a place of suffering, alchemy, and unspeakable transformation. The characters are tasked with uncovering its secrets and ending Lethica's sinister dreams. To prevail, they must navigate the halls of the sanatorium, confront its many horrors, and face {@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24} herself. Characters drawn to the sanatorium by the {@area Quest Hook|43f|x} later in this chapter have several goals:

items: Learn what is happening to patients in Memory's Rest Sanatorium.
Create an antidote to {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}
Find Lethica's secret Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}) and the cavern below.
Slay Matron Lethica, the Weeping Widow.

entries: Before running this chapter, study its most important NPC, the Weeping Widow, to understand her motivations and methods. Familiarize yourself with the sanatorium's layout, key areas, and inhabitants so you are prepared to run encounters in whatever order the characters explore. Finally, review the climactic battle, "{@area The Chemical Evolution|4d8|x}," to ensure a satisfying and epic finale.
This chapter is designed for four level 7 characters.

entries.name: The Weeping Widow
entries: {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}, {@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24}, was once a priestess of night but forsook her faith to pursue twisted science infused with otherworldly power. She seeks to "free" all people from their pain and sorrow, believing that erasing suffering is the only path to peace. She holds all she meets in contempt and disgust, using her seemingly noble purpose to manipulate and recruit a staff that is both loyal and adoring.

entries.name: Tragedy of the Widow
entries: Long ago, a white-haired elf named Lethica Nightborne was a high priestess of a goddess of evening, peace, and healing who takes the form of a barn owl. Her duty was to heal those sick in body or mind, which she achieved through blessings from her goddess, as well as the brewing of natural remedies. She found joy bringing peace to countless souls, but her life would be made complicated when she encountered her husband-to-be.

After meeting the traveling knight Sir Marius Renathyr, Lethica discovered a happiness greater than she ever thought possible. Their romance was passionate, and their marriage filled Lethica with purpose. Lethica believed she and her chivalrous love would make the world a better place.

Fate had another plan. After her husband bared his vampire fangs and attempted to feed upon her (see {@adventure The Crimson Monastery|CrookedMoon|7} chapter), he fled in shame. She followed him and uncovered the extent of his wickedness, shocked to learn his soul was damned and pledged to a devil. The knight she knew and loved was dead, and her new life as a widow was one of endless grief.

To ease her suffering, she redoubled her commitment to the restorative pursuit that had once brought her such comfort. She found the Isle of Mourn, drawn by stories of crystalline pools in the caverns beneath the earth said to have miraculous healing powers. The legends were true, and after she verified the water's potency, she began construction of a hospital on that very site, where she vowed she would bring an end to all pain.

Lethica used the waters of the pools to heal the sickly, but her joy did not return. She was hollow and bitter, and she grew resentful of her goddess for failing to prevent her tragedy. Disavowing her goddess and the Nightborne name, she turned toward scientific practices that allowed her to develop more potent medicines as the hospital continued its construction.

entries.name: Eater of Memory
entries: Lethica discovered she was a natural scientist and that her brilliance was unmatched. However, despite numerous breakthroughs, she could not cure every affliction. In particular, she found that several of her patients suffered from painful memories just as she did. This scientific dead-end troubled her until inspiration struck while she walked the endless caverns beneath the fledgling hospital.

She came across the ruins of a dead civilization that worshiped an eldritch being from beyond the stars who endlessly hungers for memories. For years, she studied the etchings of a forgotten language, learning how to make contact with a being known only as {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}. Lethica had finally found the secret that would allow her to unlock the full potential of her medicine.

In the cavern beneath the hospital, she performed a ritual that summoned forth the White Worm. By accepting its parasitic offspring within her form, Lethica appeased the creature and formed a psychic bond with it. Her skin turned pallid, her blood violet, and her tears an inky black that forever ran down her face and stained her cheeks. Then, Lethica activated the trap she had set, using her potent science to imprison the weakened grub and constantly drain its alien gore. This ichor, infused with the water of the enchanted pools, formed the base of {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}, her greatest work.

When injected, the serum removed a subject's memories, feeding them to The White Worm to keep it alive. While it remedied physical afflictions, it also warped the body into something wholly alien. Lethica saw this transformation as a cure to suffering and committed to spreading it to everyone, whether they sought it or not. This became the sole purpose of the completed hospital, which she dubbed {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x}.

Despite her proclaimed noble goal of freeing her patients from their pain, Lethica is equally motivated by a hatred that others should enjoy a blissful life when she cannot. Her foul experiments seek to perfect the serum and produce it at such a scale that the waters of Wickermoor Hollow would transform all living things within. She has even created a variety of apparatuses to pump the serum into the pools below the sanatorium.

entries.name: Parley with the Widow
entries: {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} spends her waking hours immersed in her alchemy and overseeing the operations of {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x}. She meets with visitors to offer reassurances, veiled in kindness and empathy, while quietly assessing whether they can be swayed, used, or eliminated. She is most commonly met in the Matron's Office ({@area area L4|468|x}), presenting herself as a visionary who carries the burden of humanity's pain. She spends the remainder of her time in her quarters ({@area area L19|4a4|x}) or her Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}).

Any challenge to her authority or questioning of her methods is met with unwavering confidence. She maintains a calm and composed demeanor, speaking with the precision of a scholar and the gentleness of a healer. Do not be fooled, however; she is cold and ruthless, convinced her work will liberate the world from suffering—no matter the cost.
If the characters meet Lethica and speak with her, these are her answers to some common topics:

entries.name: Who Are You
entries: "I am Matron Lethica, steward of this hospital. You may think of me as a healer—one who is unafraid to confront the hardships others dare not face."

entries.name: Why Do You Operate This Place
entries: "To salve the sorrows of this senseless world. I brew the antidote to pain itself."

entries.name: What Set You on This Path
entries: "My own loss drives me. My own sorrow. All the memories which I long to forget but mustn't. I cannot be idle until I have erased the pain from others."

entries.name: Why Do You Cry
entries: "A side effect of my work. Nothing more." A successful {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check determines this to be a lie.

entries.name: Have You Tried Lethic Serum Yourself
entries: "I must not. I endure so others may heal."

entries.name: What is the Lethic Serum
entries: "An alchemical distillation of my own design. It has yet to fail to erase the pain of those who accept its tranquility. It is the key to salvation."

entries.name: NPCs of the Sanatorium
entries: The sanatorium's staff and inhabitants form a tortuous hierarchy under {@area Matron Lethica's|426|x} control. Unquestioningly loyal orderlies carry out their duties under the watchful eyes of {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x}. {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x}'s surgeons operate as a well-oiled machine of experimental horrors. Even {@area Hugo|432|x}, Lethica's hulking enforcer, bears the scars of her cruel obsession.

entries.name: Hugo, the First Experiment
entries: Hugo is {@area Matron Lethica's|426|x} ward, bodyguard, and the ultimate proof of her alchemical ambitions. Born of a cursed fomorian bloodline, Hugo's immense strength was overwhelmed by debilitating pain and horrific visions so severe that they harmed those around him and threatened to end his own life. His suffering drove him to Lethica during the earliest days of the hospital, where she promised comfort and relief through her alchemy. She kept her word—quieting the agony of his curse—but at the cost of turning him into a mutated servant entirely dependent on her.

The first step in silencing Hugo's torment was to close his three eyes with needle and thread. In a short time, Hugo's body became riddled with scars from countless surgeries. Metal tubes and implanted reservoirs ensure constant delivery of the alchemical cocktail that suppresses Hugo's pain and emotions, though this was no mercy. Viewing Hugo as the perfect test subject due to his rapidly healing biology and seeming unwillingness to die, Lethica pushed his physical and emotional limits to advance her alchemical mastery. Despite this, Hugo's devotion to Lethica is absolute—she soothed his pain and, in his eyes, everything she does is justified.

entries.name: Meeting Hugo
entries: Accustomed to his own form of veil, Hugo relies on his other senses to navigate the world. He is attuned to the sanatorium and immediately rushes to pacify any commotion within its walls, though he mostly stalks the {@area Second Floor|491|x} to avoid disturbing new arrivals.

entries.name: Hugo's Fate
entries: Despite his near-death experience and agonizing transformation, fragments of Hugo's sympathy and kindness survive. If he still lives when Matron Lethica is destroyed, Hugo is left adrift, overwhelmed by the loss. If approached with compassion and empathy, Hugo might abandon his violent ways and seek peace beyond the borders of Wickermoor Hollow, learning to forget the horrors he witnessed and discovering that he no longer needs Lethica to be free.

entries.name: Sarah Godlee and the Orderlies
entries: Nurse Sarah Godlee was one of the first to accept {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x} and serves as the second-in-command to {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}. Unlike the other orderlies, she wears no mask, as her form was only mildly contorted by the serum. Freed of the troubles that hindered her former life, she now runs the sanatorium's night-to-night operations as its undisputed enforcer. While Matron Lethica cloaks her methods in gentleness, Godlee prefers intimidation, control, and cruelty.
Godlee thrives on power, both over the orderlies under her command and the patients she claims to care for. She sometimes pilfers valuables from the patients to indulge her sense of authority.

Nurse Godlee deeply admires Matron Lethica to the point of obsession, finding her employer's decades-long grief over her husband a constant source of pain. She wishes for Lethica to let go of her past and forget Marius Renathyr just like the patients of the hospital. She believes removing collected mementos to be the right step, but would never dare cross her matron. However, she will find common cause with the characters if they can convince her they wish to help.

entries.name: Meeting Nurse Godlee
entries: When the characters first enter the hospital, Nurse Godlee is overseeing the patients' mealtime in the Common Room ({@area area L9|47e|x}) on the First Floor. During waking hours, she retires to her quarters ({@area area L17|49d|x}) to watch over the Airing Grounds ({@area area L10|483|x}) or tour the sanatorium to instruct {@area Hugo|432|x} and the other orderlies.

entries.name: The Veiled Orderlies
entries: All fifteen of the orderlies who now preside over the sanatorium were formerly patients. Each of them wears the same, matching uniform. They also don stark white porcelain masks to conceal the unsightly deformities left by the Lethic Serum. While they are still capable of reasoning, the orderlies obey the commands of Matron Lethica and Nurse Godlee without question.

entries.name: Doctor Belkin and the Surgeons
entries: Doctor Belkin is the architect of Memory's Rest's most horrifying experiments. When Belkin was first exposed to {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}, its effects on him were unique. His mind opened to {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24|The White Worm's} influence, and he was found the following night in the caverns below the hospital having removed the top of his own skull—a colony of pale, writhing larvae now burrow within, driving his every thought. The White Worm had revealed the "truth": salvation lies not in erasing trauma but in perfect symbiosis with the worm's parasitic gifts.

Belkin is a fierce disciple of {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}, and he believes in spreading the White Worm's influence to elevate all beings to a higher state of existence. His experiments focus on creating mutated hosts for more worms, ensuring their spread to the wider world. His reverence for his alien deity is immense, and Belkin is always looking for new converts to worship the worm. He will find common cause with the characters if made to believe they are genuinely interested in serving the eldritch entity.

When operating on the first floor of the sanatorium, the doctor hides his exposed brain with a surgery cap, bringing a calming demeanor to his nervous patients. He will treat the characters with kindness, but if he perceives the characters as a threat to the White Worm, he will unleash his experiments and surgeons to eliminate them.

entries.name: Meeting Doctor Belkin
entries: Doctor Belkin spends most of his time in the Experimental Wing of the {@area Second Floor|491|x} monitoring his trials and testing subjects he thinks are strong enough to survive his extreme procedures. To maintain appearances, Belkin also conducts medical examinations for new admissions, using these moments to evaluate potential candidates for his operations.

entries.name: The Wormhost Surgeons
entries: Belkin's six acolytes have survived similar procedures under his scalpel. They are now extensions of his will, hosting their own colonies of parasites. To conceal their deformities, they wear bloodied surgical smocks, masks, and caps, though the faint squish of the larvae beneath their flesh often betrays them.
The surgeons work in chilling synchronization, communicating in low, guttural gurgles. While outwardly loyal to Belkin, their true allegiance lies with the White Worm.

entries.name: Patients of Memory's Rest
entries: The patients (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}) of {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} represent a wide spectrum of suffering from every corner of Wickermoor Hollow. Each has been admitted seeking relief, only to become unwitting subjects in Matron Lethica's experimental pursuits. All patients within Memory's Rest are under the effects of {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}, which relieves whatever malady brought them here but erases their memories and identity. The patients in the {@adventure Patient Register|CrookedMoon|10|Patient Register} table could be met by the characters during their stay in Memory's Rest, though it is not comprehensive.

You choose where a patient is within Memory's Rest at any given time, whether they are alone or escorted, and what their condition is. Consider also incorporating NPCs the characters already know to raise the stakes, making their presence in Memory's Rest a personal and urgent surprise. You can plan the patients schedules in advance or improvise their behavior in response to the characters' choices and actions.

entries.caption: Patient Register
rows: Catherine Winthrop
Clings to an arm they feel should be missing, though it isn't.
Samuel Blake
Fixates on mirrors, his gaze locked as if searching for something.
Thomas Adams
Stares endlessly into reflections, mirroring his twin's silent fixation.
Victor Lane
Claims they feel "tendrils" beneath their skin.
Emily Hale
Draws spirals obsessively.
Wendy Holden
Frequently whispers apologies to unseen figures.
Agnes Thorpe
Dreams of being suspended in a bright cave.
James Pelham
Writes the same name over and over: "Kehlenn."
Geoffrey Barnes
Freezes mid-action and resumes minutes later as if no time has passed.
Thomas Redding
Insists they are awake even when asleep.
Emily Voss
Speaks with their shadow constantly.
Harold Stiles
"Listens" to the lights.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: The characters are alerted to the existence of {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} by a farmer whose relative went to seek treatment and seemingly has become a different person.

entries.name: All Is Well
entries: While the characters are in Wickermoor Village, they are approached by Amos Dority, a farmer from the outskirts of the town who is drawn to them due to their deeds in {@adventure Skitterdeep Mine|CrookedMoon|9}. He tells the story of his cousin, who had long suffered a chronic affliction and sought care at a hospital on the western side of Wickermoor Hollow. This cousin can be any of the patients listed in the Patient Register table (see "{@area Patients of Memory's Rest|43e|x}" above).

Amos became concerned after receiving a letter allegedly penned by his cousin despite it sounding nothing like them and having completely different handwriting. In this correspondence, the cousin said, "{@area Matron Lethica|426|x} has healed me and given me purpose," claiming they would not be returning home to the farm before assuring Amos that "All is well."

Not trusting this sudden change, he implores the characters to find his cousin to discover the truth. Before parting ways, he hands them a brief pamphlet for "{@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x}," which features a peaceful hospital on the beautiful Moonsong Lake that specializes in finding treatments for all known and unknown ailments of body and mind.

entries.name: Memory's Rest Sanatorium
entries: With the pamphlet for Memory's Rest, the characters have the information they need to set off for the hospital. With this document and the letter from Amos's cousin, by all accounts the place sounds quite peaceful and pleasant.

entries.name: Across Moonsong Lake
entries: The journey from Wickermoor Village to Moonsong Lake is neither quick nor easy. Though the lake is well marked on maps, it takes about three nights to reach from the village due to the boggy terrain. Eventually, the road vanishes, and the characters find an abandoned trail.

On the side of the road, an overgrown and long-forgotten trail beckons. You press through the thicket of briars, the mud beneath sucking at your feet, dragging you down with each step as you struggle deeper into the mire.

After an hour of fighting through mosquito-ridden marshland, you reach the rocky shores of Moonsong Lake. The fading light on the surface of the water illuminates two things: a rowboat on the shore and a large structure on an island in the center of the lake.
The boat is moored to a simple wooden stake, fits six Medium creatures, and has a pair of oars. It is sturdy and can make the three-mile trip to the island without leaking.

If the characters spend too long on the lake's surface, jump into the water, or throw anything overboard, they draw the attention of a {@creature Lake Dredger|CrookedMoon24}, which attacks if provoked in any way. Should they evade its jaws, the characters arrive, cold and wet, on the banks of the Isle of Mourn.

The shore that surrounds the Isle of Mourn is a tangle of overgrown reeds, black irises, and algae that gently ripples with the shallows. The grounds themselves are a neglected garden of overgrown willow trees and hedges.
You emerge from your boat onto a small, weathered dock. Four other rowboats rock against the slick pier, making sporadic hollow thuds.
Soft purple light beams from the somber windows of the two-storied brick structure. A fountain lies dormant in the center of a small courtyard, featuring a weathered barn owl statue at its center.
"Memory's Rest: Sanatorium for the Afflicted" is etched in bold, serifed letters above two heavy iron doors at the entrance.
Searching the broken fountain yields a single silver coin.

entries.name: Memory's Rest Sanatorium Features
entries: Areas within Memory's Rest Sanatorium have the following features unless its description says otherwise:

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Rooms and hallways have 12-foot-high ceilings, though doors and entryways are just 10 feet high with transom windows for ventilation.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Rooms and hallways are bathed in violet {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} that seeps from narrow glass tubes running along the ceilings and walls.

entries.name: Locks
entries: Some doors within the sanatorium are locked and can only be opened with a ward key or picked using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check. Lethica and her staff all possess ward keys.

entries.name: Reinforced Glass
entries: Windows and glass within the sanatorium have AC 15, HP 15, a damage threshold of 10, and sound can't pass through them.

entries.name: Exploring the Sanatorium
entries: {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} operates with strict protocols designed to maintain control and secrecy. Newcomers are always escorted by orderlies ({@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses}) or other staff and are directed to specific areas on the {@area First Floor|45d|x} only. Patients who have been admitted are permitted to move unaccompanied, but they may not enter Restricted areas like the Nurse Stations ({@area area L5|46f|x}), Elevators ({@area area L6|476|x}), or the Pharmacy ({@area area L8|47a|x}). Access to the {@area Second Floor|491|x} is strictly prohibited without being escorted by staff.

Characters who want to explore the sanatorium freely must rely on diplomacy (such as gaining the trust of {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} or {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x}) or avoid detection (through stealth or by donning disguises).
