Use the guidelines and staff schedules provided in this section to track the staff's attitudes toward the characters as they explore and to inform how encounters unfold.

entries.name: Hospital Staff
entries: There are sixteen {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses}, including Nurse Sarah Godlee, who support the sanatorium's night-to-night needs. They take shifts every 8 hours. Five orderlies remain stationary in their apartments ({@area areas L14|493|x}) on the Second Floor at any given time, resting and awaiting their duties. The remaining ten orderlies attend patients on the First Floor in pairs, wait for visitors in Reception ({@area area L1|45f|x}), or assist Lethica when a patient is being treated with {@area Lethic Serum|450|x} in the Restraining Room ({@area area L15|495|x}).

There are seven {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24|Wormhost Surgeons}, including Doctor Belkin, who live and work at Memory's Rest. They visit the First Floor to examine new patients and perform surgeries only when necessary, spending most of their nights in the Experiment Lab ({@area area L26|4c0|x}).

entries.name: Visiting Hours
entries: Visitors are welcome from the Twilight Hour through the Nightfall Hour. Sanatorium staff are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward guests that don't disturb the placid atmosphere of the hospital. The first time a visitor performs an action that violates the Code of Conduct for Visitors causes staff to issue a stern warning. A second transgression causes staff to become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, and they attempt to subdue the characters with Lethic Serum. This Code of Conduct is displayed prominently on polished wooden plaques along many of the sanatorium walls.
Performing either of the following actions causes the staff to instantly become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, regardless of their previous attitude:

items: Attacking sanatorium staff or patients
Being found in the Elevators ({@area area L6|476|x}) or on {@area the Second Floor|491|x} without an escort
{@b {@i Maintain Tranquility}.} Refrain from using bright lights or making loud noises.
{@b {@i Respect the Healing Process}.} Avoid mentioning the patient's past. Focus on the present and future.
{@b {@i Follow Staff Orders}.} Please comply with any instructions given by sanatorium staff to ensure the safety of our facility.
{@b {@i Observe Restricted Areas}.} Unauthorized entry into these areas is prohibited.
{@b {@i Avoid Disruptive Behavior}.} Any other actions deemed subversive by our staff may lead to repercussions.

entries.name: The Lethic Serum
entries: A single vial of this serum—a deep, viscous purple liquid—can be loaded into a syringe or injector as an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. When it is injected into a Humanoid as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Poison damage and must make a {@dc 21} Constitution {@variantrule saving throw|XPHB}. On a failed save, the target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} becomes 0, it has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 8 hours, and it has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition while {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} in this way. The target repeats the saving throw at the end of every hour, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target succeeds on the initial save, it has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition for 1 hour. It repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Success or failure, for the next 24 hours, the target can't remember anything from before it was injected by the serum. Until the target's memories return, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks.

If a Humanoid is injected with the serum again while already {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} by it, the target loses all of its memories permanently and suffers a mutation in {@dice 1d4} hours as determined by the Serum Effect table below.

rows: The creature's insides transform into wormlike biology, which its body rejects, killing the creature instantly.

The creature becomes catatonic, gaining the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition for {@dice 1d4} days, after which it dies unless it is modified into a {@creature Hospital Horror|CrookedMoon24} by Doctor Belkin.
The creature transforms into a {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: The Solution
entries: Only an antidote can fully restore memories suppressed or removed by the Lethic Serum. A creature that has transformed into a mutant nurse can also be rejuvenated by the antidote, returning to its former self after a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

To concoct the solution, its ingredients must be found and combined in a special alchemical process. Characters can learn of this antidote through clues found in the sanatorium, reading Lethica's serum diagrams in her quarters ({@area area L19|4a4|x}), or by succeeding on a {@dc 21} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check after spending 1 hour analyzing a creature affected by the Lethic Serum. The antidote requires three ingredients:

items.name: Mnemonic Residue
items.entry: A silvery lavender ash harvested from the Crematorium ({@area area L18|4a0|x}), formed only by the incineration of creatures infused with Lethic Serum

entries.name: Noetic Extract
entries: A pale viscous fluid siphoned from brains preserved in Monster Containment ({@area area L22|4b1|x})

entries.name: Unrefined Ichor
entries: An amethyst-purple liquid produced by {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}, found in Lethica's Quarters ({@area area L19|4a4|x}), the Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}), or {@area the Grotto of Tears|4cd|x}

When all ingredients have been gathered, a character can craft the antidote in the Laboratory (area L27) or by using an Herbalism Kit or Alchemist's Supplies. A successful {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check or {@dc 13} Intelligence (Alchemist's Supplies) check produces 1 dose per 10 minutes of work and consumes the ingredients. Failure depletes one random ingredient but does not destroy the others.
As an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, the antidote can be loaded into a syringe or injector. It can be injected into a creature with a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action.

entries.name: Lockdown
entries: When Lockdown is triggered, {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} transforms into a prison designed to contain patients, alchemical secrets, and intruders alike. Lockdown ensures control is maintained and that any threat to Lethica's work is crushed.

At your discretion, Lockdown can be initiated whenever combat breaks out, a patient goes missing, a body is found, or a member of the staff suspects foul play. Covert panels are located every 20 feet along the corridors on both the {@area First|45d|x} and {@area Second Floor|491|x}, which require a ward key to activate. These panels can be forced open and activated with a successful {@dc 25} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}. Hidden switches are also located in the Matron's Office ({@area area L4|468|x}) and Nurse Stations ({@area area L5|46f|x}).

entries.name: Receding Light
entries: The glass tubes that illuminate Memory's Rest don't immediately blink off when Lockdown occurs. As the glowing steam within the tubes vents out of the facility and through the Engineering Room ({@area area L20|4a9|x}), its violet light rushes out of rooms over the course of 3 rounds and retreats down hallways as though being chased by the shadows (see "Creeping Dark" below).

entries.name: Wailing Siren
entries: As the light recedes, an ear-splitting alarm like a pained scream reverberates through the building and is loud enough to be heard across the entire island (see "{@area Engineering Room|4a9|x}" later in this chapter). It lasts 5 rounds before fading.

entries.name: Time-Out
entries: When the orderlies hear the siren, unless there is an immediate threat, they prioritize sedating all patients on the First Floor with their Inject action (dealing no damage), rendering them {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}. Once this task is complete, they begin a thorough search through the sanatorium to find and eliminate danger and to communicate with senior staff like {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} and {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}.

{@area Doctor Belkin and his surgeons|43a|x} congregate in the Experiment Lab ({@area area L26|4c0|x}) and Monster Containment ({@area area L22|4b1|x}) to keep their experiments out of danger during Lockdown. Unless the source of danger is obvious, {@area Hugo|432|x} ({@creature Serum Brute|CrookedMoon24}) patrols the main hallways and is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to any creature that isn't a staff member. Lethica calmly makes her way back to her Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}) in the event of a Lockdown to ensure her research is safe before returning to the sanatorium halls.
During Lockdown, Memory's Rest Sanatorium has the following features:

entries.name: Creeping Dark
entries: Magic that suppresses sight fills the hospital, halving the range of all light sources and {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}.

entries.name: Self-Acting Locks
entries: Closed doors lock themselves, or lock automatically when they are closed. Elevators cease to function.
Only Lethica can authorize the end of Lockdown, which is typically performed by Nurse Godlee in the Engineering Room (area L20).

entries.name: Subdued and Sedated
entries: If the characters are overwhelmed in combat, they are not killed. They awaken in the Sedation Hall ({@area area L16|499|x}), revived with 1 Hit Point. Their equipment is replaced with hospital gowns, and they are surrounded by Lethica and her orderlies. This is a disastrous scenario that can mark the end of the campaign without clever negotiation, luck, or external help.

entries.name: First Floor
entries: The First Floor of {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} serves as a "mask of legitimacy" to outsiders, offering genuine treatment to those who seek it and priming them for {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}. The floor is divided into two wings: a Behavioral Ward for mental treatment and Convalescent Ward for physical recovery.

entries.name: First Floor Locations
entries: The following areas are keyed to the Memory's Rest Sanatorium (First Floor) map.

entries.name: L1: Reception
entries: {@i First Floor}
Two orderlies ({@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses}) sit behind a desk, awaiting visitors. They pleasantly greet anyone who enters.

The room is lit by faintly humming glass tubes that glow with pale violet light. A polished desk with a call bell sits in the center of the room, behind which hangs a large, full-length oil portrait of a veiled elf woman. The placard beneath reads "Matron Lethica." Two orderlies sit behind the desk wearing smooth and expressionless porcelain masks.
One orderly stands rigidly, her hands folded neatly in front of her. "Welcome to Memory's Rest Sanatorium. Are you visiting a patient, or are you checking in?"

entries.name: First Arrival
entries: Characters are prompted to sign in at the front desk and explain their reason for visiting. They are also asked to review the posted Code of Conduct (see "{@area Exploring the Sanatorium|44b|x}" above). If the characters claim to be visiting someone, the orderlies will confirm the named patient in their register before escorting the characters to the Visitation Room ({@area area L2|462|x}). Characters who claim they are here for treatment are escorted to the Examination Room ({@area area L12|48a|x}).

As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check can convince the staff they are here to see Matron Lethica and are taken to the Matron's Office ({@area area L4|468|x}).

entries.name: L2: Visitation Room
entries: {@i First Floor, Behavioral Ward}
Plush chairs with floral upholstery and low tables are arranged in neat pairs. A barred window faces an interior lawn where gowned patients wander aimlessly.

If the characters are escorted in, two {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses} leave them here and retrieve a named patient that can be found on the {@area First Floor|45d|x} or grounds. They arrive minutes later with a patient in a wheelchair and a tea set with hot chamomile. The orderlies lock the door and stay to observe the interaction if they are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters.
Any interaction with a patient in the Visitation Room is the same:

items: They gladly accept and drink the chamomile tea (which is harmless).
The patient claims they are being well taken care of and are happy.
The patient can remember very few details about their past life, including what brought them here (see "{@area Lethic Serum|450|x}" earlier in this chapter).
They speak kindly of {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}, claiming her medicinal talents are truly miraculous.
They emphasize often and repeatedly how important peace and quiet is for their health.
They highly recommend a night's stay for wellness, if only to enjoy the calming and beautiful "moon porches."

entries: A successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check determines that the patient truly can't remember who they are or how they got here, that they are scared, and that they don't want to upset the peace. A character who succeeds on this check by 5 or more understands the patient has hidden something within the Moon Porch room ({@area area L3|464|x}).

The orderlies interrupt when the patient finishes their tea, after they answer five questions, or if the conversation gets overly excited. They'll depart with the patient and ask the characters to kindly leave the Isle of Mourn or admit themselves (in the Matron's Office, {@area area L4|468|x}) for treatment if they'd like to stay the night.

entries.name: L3: Moon Porch
entries: {@i First Floor, Behavioral Ward}

Padded chairs and settees offer a view of the lake through tall glass panels that stretch from floor to ceiling. Dozens of simple cots are pushed against the walls, in many of which are sleeping patients. Small tables hold scattered picture books and incomplete puzzles as the calming sound of chimes drifts through the air.
This long, spacious room features many of the beds where most of the patients sleep, as well as a variety of amenities with the intended purpose of maximizing tranquility and mental wellbeing:

items: Blankets and lap throws
Aromatherapy candles
Reading nooks
Serenity chimes
Posters featuring idyllic scenes and guided meditation exercises

entries: Despite these amenities, the cluttered furnishings and overcrowded sleeping arrangements give the Moon Porch an air of oppressive claustrophobia despite the expansive view. {@dice 3d12} patients linger about the space, most of whom have recently been medicated at the Pharmacy ({@area area L8|47a|x}) or Sedation Hall ({@area area L16|499|x}).

entries.name: A Plea for Help
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check locates a note written by one of the patients (at your discretion) hidden within a picture book. In addition to writing their own name over and over, it reads:
Don't forget. Don't take the meds. Don't let them take you upstairs. Don't forget. Don't let them know. Don't forget. Must get away! Don't forget. There must be an antidote! Find a way. Don't forget.

entries.name: L4: Matron's Office
entries: {@i First Floor, Behavioral Ward}

Every inch of this vast office is meticulously organized, illuminated by the steady glow of a violet-flamed candle. A broad polished desk at the far end dominates the space, lined with wooden shelves filled with records and medical texts. An elegant longcase clock ticks loudly, the only sound in the stifling quiet.

Characters may be escorted here by two {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses} if they've agreed to be admitted to the sanatorium or if they've convinced the staff there is an urgent administrative need only {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} can address.

entries.name: Scrawled Note
entries: A written record on the desk reads: "{@area The Lethic Serum|450|x} is a fragile triumph—efficacy tied to precise ratios and timing. Each patient endures its kiss differently. Refinements must continue."
When Matron Lethica arrives, read or paraphrase the following:

The door opens soundlessly, and a shrouded woman in an intricate gown of black lace glides into the room. Her face, framed by silken silver hair, is partially obscured by a delicate mourning veil. She approaches the desk with measured steps, her voice low and melodious. "Welcome to Memory's Rest. I am Matron Lethica. It is my solemn honor to guide all who come here toward peace."

Lethica does not sit; instead, she clasps her hands in front of her as if cradling some invisible weight. Her covered gaze tilts toward each of you, concealed yet undeniably aware. Closer now, you see her cheeks appear stained with tears. She speaks steadily and softly, like a secret shared in the dark: "Come now, let us see to your burdens. What brings you to my sanctuary?"

Matron Lethica ({@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24}) sees any newcomers as potential new subjects for her experiments. She insists everyone can benefit from her hospitality, even those blessed with good health, and wholeheartedly welcomes any who wish to stay at Memory's Rest or agree to undergo treatment. Use the guidance below to steer the conversation with Matron Lethica:

items: Lethica's goal is to get her guests to trust her by making them feel understood and probing for past trauma or grief she can offer to aid.
She offers the characters a soothing Tonic (see "Pharmacy," {@area area L8|47a|x}), which she is willing to drink herself.
If asked about her patients' forgetfulness, Lethica explains it is a necessary step in their recovery, allowing them to heal without reliving their suffering.
If asked about the Lethic Serum, Lethica explains she is hard at work developing many new treatments to help her patients.

entries: {@b The Widow's History}. Lethica is willing to talk about her purpose and her past, including her betrothal, though she only refers to Marius Renathyr as "Sir Marius" or "my late husband." If a character mentions {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24} or {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24|Father Renathyr}, she falls silent before stifling a sob and changing the subject. If pressed, she commands her orderlies to enter and escort the characters off the premises. Afterwards, Lethica travels to her quarters ({@area area L19|4a4|x}), looking to her mementos for comfort.

entries.name: Tour the Facility
entries: If Lethica suspects the characters are trying to investigate her operation, she invites them on a guided tour. During the trip, she casually guides them through the Behavioral Ward, Common Room ({@area area L9|47e|x}), and Convalescent Ward, answering any questions politely and succinctly, before leading them to the Recovery Rooms ({@area area L11|486|x}) where they can rest. She leaves to continue her research and informs {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} that the characters must be monitored at all times.

entries.name: Admitted to the Widow's Ward
entries: Lethica's onboarding process for admitting the characters is as follows:

items: She emphasizes that all patients must submit to treatment and to take their medication as instructed.
She instructs Nurse Godlee or another orderly to escort the characters for examination ({@area area L12|48a|x}) if they have not already been evaluated.
She asks the characters to wear gowns found in their Recovery Rooms during their stay. Their equipment is to be left in their rooms or with Nurse Godlee.

entries.name: If Combat Breaks Out
entries: If attacked while in the Matron's Office, Lethica triggers Lockdown (see "{@area Lockdown|455|x}" earlier in this chapter) from a switch beneath her desk. The longcase clock gongs incessantly to alert nearby staff. Lethica fights if she must, and she attempts to escape to rally reinforcements, leaving the characters to fend for themselves.

entries.name: L5: Nurse's Stations
entries: {@i First Floor, Restricted Area}

Dim violet light filters through narrow glass tubes lining the ceiling of this compact office. Shelves hold neatly arranged medical supplies and meticulously folded uniforms. A single cabinet is set into a simple wooden desk.
The Nurse's Stations serve as a resting and resupply area for the orderlies, equipped to maintain their efficiency and composure.

entries.name: Lockdown Preparation
entries: Each Nurse's Station contains a discrete Lockdown switch that can be triggered in the event of an emergency (see "{@area Lockdown|455|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Orderly Recovery
entries: A {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24} that enters a Nurse's Station on its turn or starts its turn there immediately recharges its Inject and Catalyst actions, and the nurse can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to regain {@dice 1d8} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.
Notes penned by Lethica can be found in each station:
"The masks are a kindness; do not remove them. The patients should believe they are cared for, not condemned. Maintain protocol. Stay paired at all times to prevent lapses in composure."

entries.name: Disguises
entries: Garb and masks worn by the orderlies can be pilfered here (and in {@area areas L7a and L7b|478|x}) and used as disguises. Characters in orderly disguises who succeed on a {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check may freely enter any room or floor in the sanatorium without needing to make Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks to avoid unwanted attention, so long as they explore in pairs.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The desk cabinet in each station is locked ({@dc 15} or ward key). Each contains two {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing} and a note reading "1756," the code to the Elevator in the Behavioral Ward ({@area area L6a|476|x}). Amongst the spare uniforms are 2 {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB|Healer's Kits}.

entries.name: L6: Elevators
entries: {@i First Floor, Second Floor, Restricted Area}

Heavy brass doors block the entryway to this metal service elevator. A small keypad beside the door features ten numeric buttons and a call switch. Within, a hand-lever juts out from the paneled interior. A plaque above reads: "Authorized Access Only."

The elevator doors on the First Floor refuse to open until the correct four-digit code has been punched into the keypad. The code for the lift in the Behavioral Ward (area L6a) is 1756, which can be discovered in the Nurse Stations ({@area area L5|46f|x}). The code for the lift in the Convalescent Ward (area L6b) is 9536, which can be learned from a patient in the Common Room ({@area area L9|47e|x}). Lethica and her staff know both codes.

On the Second Floor, no codes are required to open or close the doors to enter and operate the Elevator, though they refuse to function during {@area Lockdown|455|x}. Neither Elevator reaches {@area the Grotto of Tears|4cd|x} below.
The hand-lever can be flipped up or down as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, making the Elevator ascend or descend when the doors are closed. It takes 1 minute to reach either floor.

entries.name: L7: Functional Rooms
entries: {@i First Floor}
These stark, utilitarian rooms serve simple functions within the hospital.

items: Area L7a: Storage (nonmedical tools and cleaning supplies)
Area L7b: Laundry
Area L7c: Washroom (shower stalls and lavatories)
Area L7d: Kitchen
Area L7e: Pantry

entries.name: Disguises
entries: Garb and masks worn by the orderlies can be pilfered in areas L7a and L7b and used as disguises (see {@area area L5|46f|x}).

entries.name: L8: Pharmacy
entries: {@i First Floor, Behavioral Ward, Restricted Area}

Shelves of unlabeled brown and green glass bottles and metal tins gleam under the sterile light. A faint, chemical odor pervades the room. Opposite the shelves, a small counter holds a mortar and pestle, a measuring scale, and a rack of four injection needles. A barred dispensary window connects the pharmacy to the common room.

The door to the Pharmacy is always kept locked. It contains multiple pharmaceuticals developed by Lethica, all of which are based on {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}. Lethica and her orderlies know the contents of each bottle by sight. Characters who attempt to steal one of these medications find one at random, as determined by rolling on the {@adventure Unlabeled Medicine|CrookedMoon|10|Unlabeled Medicine} table.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The Pharmacy is also stocked with six {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing (greater)} and two sets of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB}, which are labelled. The four injection needles contain the same tranquilizer used by the {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24|Mutant Nurses} when they make their Inject attack and has the same effect.
A treatment schedule board hangs adjacent to the dispensary window next to which a file bin contains one of Lethica's records:
"Godlee—Do not let a patient miss even one dosage. Keep me informed regarding stock amounts and frequency of deliveries from the laboratory."

entries.caption: Unlabeled Medicine
rows: Tonic

A creature that ingests this medicine gains the benefit of a {@item Potion of Heroism|XDMG} but imperceivably receives the effect of the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell instead of {@spell Bless|XPHB} for the duration (the creature believes it is under the effect of the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell until after its next attack roll or saving throw).
Sedative

A creature that ingests this medicine rolls its maximum number of {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}. If the total rolled exceeds the creature's maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it has the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition for {@dice 1d8} hours, until it takes damage, or until someone uses an action to shake or slap it awake.
Hypnotic
A creature that ingests this medicine has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition toward all creatures for {@dice 1d4} hours, or until it takes damage.
Relaxant
A creature that ingests this medicine has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength checks and saving throws for {@dice 1d4} hours or until it finishes a Short Rest.
Suppressant

A creature that ingests this medicine has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for {@dice 1d4} hours, and it can't {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrate} on spells or similar effects while {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} in this way.
Euphoriant

A creature that ingests this medicine has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for {@dice 1d4} hours, and it can't knowingly speak a lie, as if under the effect of a {@spell Zone of Truth|XPHB} spell, while {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} in this way.

entries.name: L9: Common Room
entries: {@i First Floor}

The spacious common room is clean and orderly. Cushioned chairs and round tables huddle together in neat clusters, each with simple diversions. Patients sit in passive silence, pick at meals that require no cutlery, and line up at a small pharmacy window for their regimen.
Orderlies keep watch and tend to the patients, guiding them to and from the tables, the corridors, or through wide-open doors leading to an inner courtyard.
Characters are free to interact with the patients here in the Common Room so long as they follow the Code of Conduct. The patients exhibit odd behaviors:

items: A patient tears up pieces of a picture puzzle, reassembling the people portrayed in its scene into a single jumbled malformation.

A patient repeats the same numbers over and over, but only when addressed: "6...Go!...9...5...3...6...Go!...9..." (this is the code to the Elevator in the Convalescent Ward, {@area area L6b|476|x}, which is 9536).
A patient keeps a cloth napkin over their face and grows irritated if it is removed.

entries.name: Nurse Godlee
entries: When the characters enter, {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} ({@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24}) wastes no time introducing herself.

You are approached by an orderly who has no mask. Instead, she wears a porcelain eyepatch over her left eye, painted with the image of an eye that matches her right. She watches the room with hawk-like precision, and her lips form a tight smile as she speaks with you. "I trust you've read our code of conduct. I am Nurse Godlee, second to Matron Lethica. It is my duty to make sure your stay at Memory's Rest is a pleasant and nourishing one. And you are...?"

Godlee keeps her tone composed and professional, knowing that she can be off-putting to newcomers. She emphasizes strict adherence to the sanatorium's rules and procedures to gauge if the characters are potential assets or threats. If asked about {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x} or their methods, Godlee deflects by stating that Lethica's treatment is revolutionary and tailored for each specific patient's needs.

entries.name: Development
entries: The conversation with Nurse Godlee is interrupted when a patient rises unsteadily, clutching a tray of food before pitching the tray against the wall with a loud crash. Godlee maintains her composure, directing a nearby orderly to take care of the mess right away as another orderly rushes to the pharmacy window. She advises the patient that accidents happen and that we must remember to control ourselves.

A character who succeeds on a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check realizes that Godlee's words are more than a reprimand—they are a warning. Godlee is carefully concealing her true severity in the presence of the characters. When the orderly returns, Godlee offers the patient two pills (a Hypnotic and Relaxant) from the Pharmacy ({@area area L8|47a|x}) and waits until they have taken the medication. Afterwards, she wishes the characters well and excuses herself to log the incident at the Behavioral Ward's Nurse's Station.

entries.name: L10: Airing Grounds
entries: {@i First Floor}

The common room leads to an open yard, enclosed on all sides by the brick walls of the sanatorium. A circuitous gravel path winds through manicured hedges, stone benches, and flowering plants, made to resemble a palatial garden.

A solitary patient (Neutral, noncombatant human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) sits at the far end of the Airing Grounds, facing the southern wall while plotting their means of escape. They have managed to avoid taking their pills and have crushed them into a fine powder. The patient attacks any creature that comes within 5 feet, covering the target in a cloud of pulverized medication. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or suffer the effects of the Sedative, Relaxant, Suppressant, and Euphoriant from the Pharmacy ({@area area L8|47a|x}).
The patient screams and takes an action on each of their turns to {@action Dash|XPHB} in an attempt to flee the sanatorium. Roll Initiative!

entries.name: Hugo Intervenes
entries: When the patient screams, a louder bellow emanates from the {@area Second Floor|491|x}. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), {@area Hugo|432|x} ({@creature Serum Brute|CrookedMoon24}) vaults down into the garden through one of the inward-facing windows. If the patient is beyond Hugo's {@sense Blindsight|XPHB}, the other orderlies point the way. If Hugo gets within 10 feet of the patient, he grapples and subdues them easily. "Hugo will help," he sighs.

Hugo promptly carries the patient to a vacant Recovery Room ({@area area L11d|486|x}, the room with the Secret Entrance) and restrains them. The orderlies rush to calm any other patients who witnessed the incident to restore order, including the characters.

entries.name: L11: Recovery Rooms
entries: {@i First Floor, Convalescent Ward}
Each suite contains a narrow bed with crisp white sheets, a bedside table, and a metal chair tucked into the corner.

Most of the seven Recovery Rooms are occupied by current patients during sleeping hours. Nurse Godlee discreetly moves patients to the {@area Second Floor|491|x} Sedation Hall ({@area area L16|499|x}) if the characters admit themselves.

entries.name: Patient Logs
entries: File bins adjacent to each Recovery Room door contain written observations regarding each patient. Most of the information is mundane: name, diagnosis, chief complaints, and procedures performed. A character who spends 1 minute reading the logs and succeeds on a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check deduces that the patients are receiving genuine therapies for physical and mental ailments. Succeeding on this check by 5 or more reveals this is only to prepare them for "further treatment" on the Second Floor.

entries.name: Secret Entrance
entries: One room (area L11d) is noticeably cooler than the others, containing a hidden hatch beneath a bed leading to {@area the Grotto of Tears|4cd|x}. A character who spends 1 minute scouring the room and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds a panel of floor that can be pulled up to reveal a magical stone slab marked with strange carvings.

These are eldritch glyphs from the ancient civilization of eel-like entities that lived in the lake and once worshiped {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}, now used by {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x} to gain easy access to his object of devotion. When the proper incantation is uttered in {@language Deep Speech|XPHB}, the sigils glow violet and the stone depresses, revealing a roughly hewn staircase that leads to the southern tunnel of the Grotto of Tears. This incantation can be learned from Doctor Belkin himself, by studying Belkin's notes in his office ({@area area L23|4b5|x}), or by casting {@spell Identify|XPHB} on the stone.

entries.name: L12: Examination Room
entries: {@i First Floor, Convalescent Ward}
A single overhead lamp illuminates a metal examination table in the center of the room. Cabinets line the walls, their glass doors safeguarding medical tools and bandages.

When needed, {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x} ({@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24}) takes the Elevator ({@area area L6b|476|x}) down from the {@area Second Floor|491|x} to provide medical exams to any who seek them out. Before he enters, he consumes a {@item Potion of Mind Reading|XDMG} to better assess new potential candidates. He uses {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB} to learn what is in the mind of his subjects but does not probe deep enough to trigger a Wisdom saving throw so as not to raise suspicion.

A gaunt figure enters the room wearing a blood-streaked smock and protective coverings on his hands and head. His eyes, visible between the scrub cap and fabric mask, stare out with detached curiosity. He folds his hands together and rasps, "Apologies for the mess. My name is Doctor Belkin, and I am pleased to assist with your health assessment."

entries.name: Medical Assessment
entries: Belkin performs a quick medical examination, speaking in a stately, academic tone. Using hints that he gathers from the surface thoughts of each character, he asks fitting questions. A few queries and their resulting prescription (see below) include:

items: "Do you feel your strength waning?" (Tonic)
"Do you find it difficult to quiet your thoughts? Perhaps trouble sleeping?" (Sedative)
"Have you struggled with interpersonal interactions lately? Do you ever feel out of place?" (Hypnotic)
"Have you experienced any tension in your muscles or unexplained fatigue?" (Relaxant)
"Do you ever feel overwhelmed by your own thoughts or abilities?" (Suppressant)
"Are you often weighed down by melancholy or negative thoughts?" (Euphoriant)

entries: When each assessment is completed, Belkin offers characters with fewer than their maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} a restorative, gesturing to one of a half-dozen syringes resting on a nearby tray. "It is perfectly safe and quite effective." As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, the injection restores {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, grants an equal number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}, and makes the character slightly lightheaded ({@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom checks for {@dice 1d4} hours).

Based on the characters' responses, Belkin provides a prescription, instructing them to head to the Pharmacy ({@area area L8|47a|x}) for further treatment. He returns to the Second Floor to continue his experiments when the examinations are completed.

entries.name: L13: Operating Theater
entries: {@i First Floor, Convalescent Ward}

The operating theater can seat up to twenty-four observers. Two sets of stairs rise to the raked seats surrounding a bright central pit. A pair of physicians watch in silent curiosity as the operating surgeon performs their work on an unconscious patient, narrating their technique as they progress.

When the characters arrive, a {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24} operates on an {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} patient (Neutral, human {@creature Commoner|XMM} with 8 Hit Points) on the surgical table in the center of the room, their veins pulsing a strange violet color. Two additional wormhost surgeons sit in the stands. All three surgeons have caps and smocks that cover their mutations and modifications. The characters are invited to stay to observe the surgery.

entries.name: Medical Emergency
entries: The demonstrated operation begins successfully, albeit gruesomely, with the surgeons opening up the patient's abdomen to remove a pulsing purple growth. However, the surgery quickly goes wrong as the patient convulses and rapidly mutates, their skin turning pallid violet as a foot and an arm turn wormlike.

The patient lurches from the operating table and attacks the surgeons, who feign helplessness to not reveal their true form and power. This mutated patient uses {@creature Flesh Golem|XMM} statistics but is an Aberration, has 50 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, lacks the Lightning Absorption feature, and its Slam attacks deal an extra {@damage 1d4} Psychic damage.

If the characters kill the patient or knock them out, the surgeons apologize for the mishap and wheel them to the elevator to be added to {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x}'s experimental amalgam in the Experiment Lab ({@area area L26|4c0|x}). If the characters leave the Operating Theater without dealing with the mutated patient, the surgeons subdue the patient and take them to Monster Containment ({@area area L22|4b1|x}).

entries.name: Second Floor
entries: The Second Floor of Memory's Rest veils the truth of {@area Matron Lethica's|426|x} work from the world, where suffering and horrific mutations are ignored in the name of "healing." Like the {@area First Floor|45d|x}, it is divided into two wings: a Processing Wing where {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x} is tested and an Experimental Wing where those who survive its effects are contained and observed. The entire Second Floor is a Restricted area.

entries.name: Second Floor Locations
entries: The following areas are keyed to the Memory's Rest Sanatorium (Second Floor) map.

entries.name: L14: Orderlies' Apartments
entries: {@i Second Floor, Processing Wing}
The orderlies' apartments are cramped with narrow cots covered in thin blankets. There are no decorations, save for several full-length wall mirrors.

Each apartment houses a single {@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24} at a given time. They sit or stand idly until called to their duties or disturbed by intruders. Characters can sneak through the corridor past the orderlies with a successful {@dc 17} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. If alerted, they are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward anyone on the Second Floor who isn't being escorted by a staff member and will attempt to subdue any intruders with {@area Lethic Serum|450|x}.

entries.name: L15: Restraining Room
entries: {@i Second Floor, Processing Wing}

A heavy metal chair with thick leather straps is bolted firmly to the floor of this room. Restraints, nearly wrenched from their iron sockets, dangle ominously. Tables and shelves holding scalpels, rusted calipers, and a sinister-looking corkscrew-shaped tool surround the table.

You can hear the ragged breathing of the patient bound to the chair, their veins faintly glowing violet. They slump in the chair, barely conscious, their head lolling to one side. Their voice, hoarse with strain, cracks the stillness, "Please... stop..."

entries.name: Serum-Induced Mutation
entries: The patient strapped to the chair is undergoing the effects of a second dose of Lethic Serum (see "{@area The Lethic Serum|450|x}" earlier in this chapter) and has been left alone and restrained until the transformation is complete. They react to the presence of other creatures in the room. "H-help me... it's in me... burning...!" Their shouting threatens to attract attention from nearby staff unless they are quickly calmed or left alone. If calmed, the patient explains they have no recollection of who they are.
Nearby, a handwritten log reads:

Godlee—Administered second dose of Lethic Serum. This new compound promises to produce more stable results, but we must be patient to learn its outcome. Heightened emotional states may affect the results. Leave them here alone.

Sidenote—the ash in the cremator has begun to exhibit unusual properties. It resists dispersal, almost as though it retains a memory of the forms it once composed. I suspect the residue may be a result of traces of the serum in the bodies. Collect samples for further study.

A character who examines the patient and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check learns exactly how much time remains before the patient transforms. The patient has {@dice 1d4} hours remaining. Only the antidote to the Lethic Serum (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter), a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell, or the patient's death can halt the transformation.

entries.name: L16: Sedation Hall
entries: {@i Second Floor, Processing Wing}

Beds in stark hospital-white sheets line the walls of this wide, pale gray room. Deathly-still patients in hospital gowns breathe shallowly in each bed, separated only by thin curtains. They don't seem to mind the lack of privacy.

entries.name: Patients
entries: Three of the twelve beds in this room are occupied by a patient (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}). All patients here are suffering the immediate effects of the Lethic Serum and are {@condition Stunned|XPHB} until the effects wear off (see "{@area The Lethic Serum|450|x}" earlier in this chapter). While in this condition, they can only move their heads, their eyes don't focus, and their speech is languid and slurred. They have no desires, no memory of their past, and are perfectly tranquil. They do not resist being moved.

entries.name: Waking the Afflicted
entries: Not all the patients receive the Lethic Serum at the same time. They are kept in this state until they are ready to be moved back to the {@area First Floor|45d|x} or the next trial is ready (see {@area area L26|4c0|x}, Experiment Lab). A successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check determines if a patient is nearing the end of their sedation and can be woken without requiring {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} or similar magic, at your discretion.

Roll {@dice 1d6} if a patient is woken. On a roll of 1 or 2, the patient jerks back into consciousness and begins screaming for help, feebly attacking the characters before they realize what is happening. If the nearby orderlies are not alerted by screaming, the patient can share what they can recall in hushed whispers.
All woken patients understand the danger they are in and wish to leave as soon as possible, though they remain in poor condition from the effects of the Lethic Serum.

entries.name: L17: Godlee's Quarters
entries: {@i Second Floor, Processing Wing}

The room is impeccably ordered. Every item is placed deliberately. A narrow desk holds stacked ledgers beside a vase of tidy black irises. A compact bed occupies the corner, its linens tucked with military precision.

Nurse Sarah Godlee ({@creature Mutant Nurse|CrookedMoon24}) lives here in comfort, sleeping on a soft mattress with fine linen sheets. She refreshes her vase of irises every Twilight Hour while reviewing and updating her comprehensive patient registry, which is used as the master ledger in the sanatorium.

If Nurse Godlee sees the characters as useful for attempting to pull {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} out of her decades-long grief over her lost husband, she'll bring the characters here to speak in private (see "{@area Sarah Godlee and the Orderlies|436|x}" earlier in this chapter). As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can earn her trust with a successful {@dc 17} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check.

If they do, she'll discreetly instruct the orderlies to look the other way as the characters explore the sanatorium. She also confides that Lethica is easily pained when confronted by mementos of her past, which can be found in Lethica's Quarters ({@area area L19|4a4|x}), wishing for them to be destroyed so they no longer torture her employer.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check while searching the room uncovers Godlee's stash of valuables hidden beneath her bed:

items: A {@item Bead of Force|XDMG}
A {@item Wand of Magic Missiles|XDMG}
A tarnished brass {@item Ring of Water Walking|XDMG}
A {@item Diplomat's Pack|XPHB}
A variety of elegant jewelry totaling 250 GP

A small diary showcasing Godlee's admiration for and obsession with Matron Lethica, revealing that the way to enter her personal Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}) is to inject a dose of {@area Lethic Serum|450|x} into the eye of the owl painted on the wall of the second floor hallway.

entries.name: L18: Crematorium
entries: {@i Second Floor, Processing Wing}

Pushing through the doors, you are hit with the scent of smoke and charred remains. One side of this room houses two massive cremators, their brick interiors blackened from frequent use. Opposite, an array of square-doored lockers line the wall.

entries.name: Morgue Cabinets
entries: Each of the twelve cabinets contains a corpse in various stages of decay, many with telltale signs of {@area Lethic Serum|450|x}'s influence. Each body burned in the cremator (which takes 3 hours) produces enough Mnemonic Residue to craft 1 dose of antidote solution (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter). A character who searches the lockers and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds a ward key that was forgotten on the chest of a corpse.

entries.name: Rekindled Recollections
entries: The gray ashes within the furnace of the cremator glint with specks of purple. This is Mnemonic Residue, enough to produce 3 antidotes.
To collect the residue, a character can use an appropriate set of tools (such as a spoon from {@item Cook's Utensils|XPHB}) to scoop the delicate powder into a container.

entries.name: L19: Lethica's Quarters
entries: {@i Second Floor}

A large desk occupies one side of this room, its surface covered with alchemical notes and diagrams. The sparse furnishings suggest a place of work rather than welcome, with no chairs for visitors and shelves lined with neatly ordered books.
Beyond a narrow doorway lies a small, practical bedroom decorated in muted hues of grays, blacks, and purples.

{@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24} spends much of her time in her chambers when she isn't working in her Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}) or below the sanatorium (see "{@area Grotto of Tears|4cd|x}" later in this chapter).

entries.name: Serum Diagrams
entries: A character who spends 1 minute examining the diagrams and succeeds on a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check reveals countless revisions of {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x} and that it is distilled from the ichor of a being Lethica refers to as {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}. If they succeed on the check by 5 or more, the character also deduces how to concoct an antidote that cures a Humanoid of all ill effects of the serum (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Treasured Memories
entries: A shrine in one corner contains melancholic mementos of Lethica's life before she came to Memory's Rest:

items: A portrait of Lethica and Marius Renathyr, painted on the night they were wed
Her silver-and-purple-garnet betrothal ring—a {@item Ring of Protection|XDMG}
A blood-stained knight's tabard bearing heraldry depicting a rising sun
A weathered parchment bearing a faded sonnet of undying love
A small phial of Unrefined Ichor (see "The Solution" earlier in this chapter)

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The High Priestess|050|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Mask of Lethica Nightborne|CrookedMoon24} can be found among the mementos in the shrine.

entries.name: L20: Engineering Room
entries: {@i Second Floor}

The engineering room sprawls with metal pipes and violet-glass conduits that extend across the space, reaching the floor, walls, and ceiling. The room hums softly, while a central cylindrical unit hisses and wheezes. Its surface is a jumble of levers, switches, pressure gauges, and valves.

The Engineering Room powers all of the fluorescent lights that run throughout {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x}. The central unit maintains the pressure of condensed steam produced from heating the glowing waters of {@area The Grotto of Tears|4cd|x}. Unbeknownst even to Lethica, the tubes behave like alchemical receptacles and have been absorbing painful memories for years.

entries.name: Reset Protocol
entries: When {@area Lockdown|455|x} is triggered, the pressurized steam within the sanatorium's bulbs is suddenly released through a vent mounted on the roof which produces a deafening mournful wail like a siren. Violet fog settles over the Isle of Mourn as the sound fades. Restoring light to the sanatorium requires re-engaging the central unit by turning its lever switch to the "ON" position as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, which refills the tubes with illumination. The system can also be turned off from here by switching the same lever to "OFF," which triggers Lockdown.

entries.name: Memory Overflow
entries: Tampering with or breaking the central unit of the Engineering Room makes Lockdown impossible (the steam slowly dissipates over the next 24 hours), but doing so unleashes what has been gestating within; a viscous, violet liquid oozes forth from the machinery to form a {@creature Gibbering Mouther|XMM}. The voices of a thousand horrid memories babble from the gurgling sludge, which lurches forward and attempts to absorb the nearest creature. Roll Initiative! On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), and again for {@dice 1d4} more rounds thereafter, another gibbering mouther appears in the Engineering Room and attacks any creature other than gibbering mouthers it encounters.

entries.name: L21: Hugo's Quarters
entries: {@i Second Floor}

At first, this room feels more like the den of an animal than a living space. Nearly a quarter of the area is covered in a wide unkempt woven mat, surrounded by scattered trays bearing scraps of food and empty bowls. A high shelf on one side is crowded with vials and injectors.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: 8 feet up from the floor, a hardy shelf supports a line of vials alongside oversized syringes, though only three are full. The vials contain supplementary stabilizer compounds to help Hugo ({@creature Serum Brute|CrookedMoon24}) manage symptoms caused by his alchemical infusions:

items: Numbing Agent ({@spell Stoneskin|XPHB})
Alkaline Stabilizer ({@spell Protection from Energy|XPHB}, Acid)
Adrenal Stimulant ({@spell Enhance Ability|XPHB}, Strength)

entries: As an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, a vial can be loaded into an injector. It can then be injected into a creature with a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to grant it the effect of the corresponding spell (no {@status Concentration|XPHB} required), which deals {@damage 1d4} Piercing damage to the target that can't be reduced or prevented in any way. Attempting to extract or collect the compounds without using an injector destroys a vial's contents.

entries.name: Experimental Procedure File
entries: A character who explores the room and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notices a yellowing file folder tucked beneath one side of the woven bed. It includes a detailed record of Hugo's surgeries and transformation (see "{@area Hugo, the First Experiment|432|x}" earlier in this chapter), including notes describing the nature of his curse and dependency on it.

entries.name: L22: Monster Containment
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}

A reinforced glass chamber occupies the center of the room, its walls fogged with condensation. Against a far wall, rows of oversized jars contain floating brains suspended in luminescent fluid. Below the jars is a sign that reads: "Do not disturb." A curtain at the back of the chamber runs the full length of the room, mounted on tracks that allow it to slide open.

entries.name: Don't Tap the Glass
entries: The reinforced glass chamber holds a fleshy abomination (use {@creature Otyugh|XMM} stat block), its misshapen form blurred through the condensation, pacing in restless agitation. It occasionally presses its body against the glass as if testing the containment. A large, empty sipper bottle hangs from the top of the chamber, its nozzle bent and stained with a fluorescent violet residue. A small panel set into the wall beside the chamber holds the mechanism for opening the glass door. The smaller cages concealed by the curtain are empty.

entries.name: Abnormal Brains
entries: The brains within these jars once belonged to particularly intelligent patients. Doctor Belkin discovered that if he removed the brains of those patients and siphoned the thoughts of their active minds, he was able to collect a pale concentrate, called Noetic Extract, which he uses to nourish horrors like the one in the containment chamber. It is also a key component in producing an antidote to the Lethic Serum (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter).

Each active brain jar produces enough Noetic Extract for 1 dose of the antidote solution in a 24-hour period. These are automatically collected and dispensed in sealed vials by the mechanisms at the base of each jar. {@dice 1d6} vials of Noetic Extract are ready to be extracted when the characters arrive.

entries.name: L23: Belkin's Office
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}

Shelves line the walls, crowded with preservation vessels containing specimens suspended in cloudy fluid. A high-backed chair stands behind a broad steel desk, its surface a chaos of open journals, anatomical sketches, and surgical diagrams.
{@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x} ({@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24}) spends his time here when not experimenting or performing surgeries.

entries.name: Dormant Larvae
entries: A jar of parasitic worms suspended in fluid rests on the desk. They awaken and attack any nearby living creature if the jar is opened or broken (use the {@creature Swarm of Venomous Snakes|XMM} stat block, dealing Psychic damage instead of Poison).

entries.name: Anatomist's Journal
entries: A character who spends 1 minute studying Belkin's notes and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check uncovers the following:

items: A log entry describing Belkin's frustration that he has been unable to quell the experiments' ({@creature Hospital Horror|CrookedMoon24|Hospital Horrors}) fear of needles and other sharp implements
A sketch of {@area The Grotto of Tears|4cd|x}, including {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24} suspended with chains and tubes.

Exploration logs of the caverns beneath the hospital and the ancient ruins found within, noting that {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} herself first showed him the secrets of the White Worm there (see "{@area Eater of Memory|428|x}" earlier in this chapter)
A sketch of an eel-like entity—noted to have been the species of the ruined civilization that first worshiped the White Worm—and attempts to decipher their language

The incantation to activate the sigils that opens the secret passage to the Grotto of Tears from one of the Recovery Rooms ({@area area L11d|486|x}). Characters who can speak {@language Deep Speech|XPHB} can commit it to memory by spending 1 minute reading it. Otherwise, a character must succeed on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill History|XPHB}) check to learn it.

entries.name: L24: Surgeons' Rooms
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}
This cramped room is unsettlingly damp and completely unlit. Large, metal pods line every wall, each one slick with a slimy sheen that has a faint, violet hue.

There are six pods total in the room, three of which are occupied by sleeping {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24|Wormhost Surgeons}. They wake up if disturbed by a loud noise or additional source of light.

entries.name: Vision of the White Worm
entries: Roll {@dice 1d4} if an unoccupied pod is searched. On a 1, parasitic worms spill free from the pod and attack any creature that is not a surgeon (use the {@creature Swarm of Venomous Snakes|XMM} stat block, which deals Psychic damage instead of Poison). A creature that searches a pod comes in contact with the gel that coats its interior, and for 10 minutes, the creature can also see through the many eyes of {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24} in the Grotto of Tears below, as per the {@spell Clairvoyance|XPHB} spell (no {@status Concentration|XPHB} required, sight only).

entries.name: L25: Observation Chambers
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}

Two glass-walled chambers stand side by side, their interiors stark and sterile. The first chamber is empty save for a single chair bolted to the tiled floor, gleaming under the violet glow of the tubes overhead. The second chamber's chair is empty, but a patient cowers in the far corner of the room.
Both doors to the chamber are locked, and the walls and doors facing the corridor are reinforced glass.

entries.name: Chamber One
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines the chamber finds scratches etched into the floor tiles. The markings form a crude warning: "It hungers for memory."

entries.name: Chamber Two
entries: The cowering patient (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM}) is at the precipice of transformation into a {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24}; their exposed brain is visibly agitated with parasitic worms. For the next {@dice 1d8} hours, the patient has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition and their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0, after which the transformation completes. When another creature enters the chamber, the patient babbles incoherently, accelerating the transformation to 10 minutes.

A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check reveals that the parasitic worms can be destroyed without harming the patient by dealing Psychic damage (HP 10, with a damage threshold of 10) or drawn out by injecting {@area Lethic Serum|450|x} (which also destroys the worms).

If saved, the patient has no recollection of who they once were, but they remembers being selected for this transformation after inadvertently seeing Doctor Belkin use a hidden passage in one of the Recovery Rooms ({@area area L11d|486|x}).

entries.name: L26: Experiment Lab
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}

A heavy metal door conceals a haphazard workshop that reeks of antiseptic and charred flesh. {@status Bloodied|XPHB} instruments and organ jars clutter every surface. At the center of the room, an operating table isxby a stained linen sheet that is malformed by the mass beneath it.

If {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x} ({@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24}) is present when the characters enter, he is hunched over a glowing jar on one desk. It contains a unique blend of writhing alien tissues and serums that exhibit properties that fascinate Belkin.

Belkin doesn't immediately consider the characters a threat and is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward them. Unless he knows they have endangered his experiments or if {@area Lockdown|455|x} is in effect, he sees their arrival as an opportunity.

entries.name: The Experiment
entries: Doctor Belkin is preparing to conduct an experiment to produce his finest creation yet, which he hopes will serve as the next stage of evolution to be closer in nature to {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}. The abomination, a fused amalgam of former mutated patients, is concealed beneath a sheet on the operating table. He believes that the characters would serve as an ideal first combat test for this creature—and a satisfactory meal should the abomination destroy them.

entries.name: Belkin's Offer
entries: Belkin is always in search of new pupils and worshipers of the White Worm. Before unleashing his experiment, he offers them the chance to see truth beyond the reality of Druskenvald and witness the perfection of form. Characters who accept can undergo a 1 hour procedure that transforms them into a {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: The Creation Rises
entries: If any characters refuse the offer, attack the doctor, or speak ill of the White Worm, Doctor Belkin flips the switch to bring his horrific creation to life, which attacks the characters until it is destroyed. This vile amalgam of mutant and alien flesh uses the {@creature Chimera|XMM} stat block, but it is an Aberration and its Fire Breath deals Psychic damage. Belkin chooses to simply observe, but he joins the battle if attacked or when the creature is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}.

entries.name: Undulating Tissue
entries: If the contents of the glowing jar that Doctor Belkin was studying is released, it morphs into a {@creature Nameless Thing|CrookedMoon24} familiar and immediately bonds with the first creature that speaks after it emerges.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check reveals the following items tucked away in corners and cabinets:

items: A canister labelled "pheromones" (a {@item Philter of Love|XDMG})
Four {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing (greater)}
A sealed vial of {@area Lethic Serum|450|x}

entries.name: L27: Laboratory
entries: {@i Second Floor, Experimental Wing}

Both entrances to the Laboratory are concealed behind smooth walls, each bearing a mural depicting a barn owl roosting in a weeping willow. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines one of the murals and succeeds on a {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check spies that one of the owl's eyes has a small hole cut into the wall, ringed in metal. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character notes traces of dried purple fluid ({@area Lethic Serum|450|x}).

To enter the Laboratory, a full dose of Lethic Serum must be injected into this eye, causing the wall itself to move back on a mechanical arm, revealing the lab beyond. Only {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} and {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} know this fact.
When the characters enter the Laboratory, read or paraphrase the following:

You enter an alchemical laboratory and are met with a symphony of bubbling, dripping, and hissing. Everywhere you turn, an arcane apparatus can be found: Glass vials filled with glowing liquids twist into each other. Rows of stoppered flasks shimmer near flickering gas flames. A lattice of brass tubing snakes across the ceiling, feeding into various tanks and reservoirs.

A window runs the length of the far wall, offering a partial view of the inner courtyard below. Facing the window is a broad elevator platform, constructed from sturdy metal beams and reinforced wood slats.

entries.name: Alchemical Chaos
entries: The lab is crowded with workbenches, each covered in an assortment of alchemical experiments and processes. Only Lethica knows how to find exactly what she is looking for in this disorganized space. For each minute spent searching the Laboratory, an item is found as determined by the Laboratory Item table, with a maximum of ten items that can be found.

entries.caption: Laboratory Item
rows: A random medication (see {@area area L8|47a|x})
A jar of dormant larvae (see {@area area L23|4b5|x})
A random stabilizer (see {@area area L21|4ad|x})
A vial of Lethic Serum (see "{@area The Lethic Serum|450|x}" earlier in this chapter)

entries: A character looking for a specific item can also make a {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to try and find it within the clutter.

entries.name: Distilled Memory
entries: Dozens of crystal decanters containing glowing, violet-colored liquid can be found scattered throughout the Laboratory—Unrefined Ichor, harvested directly from {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}. Each container is labeled with a date and batch number. The substance is a key component in the antidote solution (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Plunge Platform
entries: The elevator platform on one side of the Laboratory descends to {@area The Grotto of Tears|4cd|x} 150 feet below. A lever to activate the lift juts out from the floor adjacent the platform. The descent takes 5 minutes, during which the platform creaks and groans. The shaft is pitch dark, with walls slick from the moisture of the waters below.

entries.name: The Widow's Wile
entries: In the corner of the Laboratory stands a mesmerizing orb of glass cradled on a pedestal, its surface alive with arcs of purple lightning. A creature that touches the orb experiences no ill effect and finds the orb cannot be moved. A character who succeeds on a {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notices a subtle foot lever at the bottom of the pedestal. When the foot lever is pressed, all creatures within the Laboratory not touching the orb are immediately teleported to the Grotto of Tears (see below).

If {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} ({@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24}) finds intruders in her Laboratory, she triggers this device the moment she deems them threatening. Once she has sent them below, she retrieves {@area Hugo|432|x} ({@creature Serum Brute|CrookedMoon24}) and patiently rides the elevator platform down to face them herself.

entries.name: The Grotto of Tears
entries: Read or paraphrase the following if the characters arrived by means of the "Widow's Wile" device ({@area area L27|4c7|x}), and then read the subsequent description:

Your vision suddenly blurs. The laboratory dissolves around you as if pulled apart by unseen hands. A rushing sensation fills your ears before clarity returns. You now stand on uneven stone, surrounded by the cold glow of an unfamiliar cavern.
Only read the following if the characters reach the Grotto of Tears by elevator lift or secret passage:

An indescribable smell fills this grotto that defies the laws of nature, its stone walls ridged and folded like brain matter. A narrow stone bridge extends across the bubbling, phosphorescent waters of subterranean pools, leading to a circular platform glowing in an otherworldly violet hue.

Above the platform hangs an enormous alien creature that can only be described as a pallid, bloated grub suspended by metal chains. Numerous tubes run from its punctured flesh to vats that line the cavern, pumping a grotesque violet substance that oozes unlike any known in the natural world. Globs of this eldritch gore drips onto the stone below.

This chamber is the torturous home of {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24}, a being of unknowable power (see "{@area Eater of Memory|428|x}" earlier in this chapter). In this weakened state, it can take no actions or {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}, and its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0. {@area Matron Lethica's|426|x} intense, alien psychic bond with the worm protects the lifeform and its restraints from all damage. If attacked or engaged, it lets out a piercing shriek that alerts Lethica to the presence of intruders.

entries.name: The Grotto of Tears Features
entries: Unless otherwise stated, the grotto has the following features:

entries.name: Blood of the Worm
entries: The violet fluid dripping from the punctured worm is Unrefined Ichor, a key component in the antidote solution (see "{@area The Solution|452|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Ceilings and Walls
entries: The cavern ceiling is 40 feet high. The walls of the cavern are natural stone worn to evoke wrinkled gray matter.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Water in this area glows an ethereal, almost fluorescent purple, flooding the area with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Mutation Tanks
entries: The most horrifically mutated patients are kept in glass tanks of highly distilled {@area Lethic Serum|450|x} after undergoing agonizing body modification to turn each of them into a {@creature Hospital Horror|CrookedMoon24}. These enhanced killers can be released by {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} to aid her in combat (see "{@area The Chemical Evolution|4d8|x}" later in this chapter).

entries.name: Plunge Platform
entries: A lever in the room's northern chamber activates the elevator to the Laboratory ({@area area L27|4c7|x}). The elevator takes 5 minutes to ascend.

entries.name: Serum Fermentation Vats
entries: A series of 10-foot-tall, verdigrised copper vats line the walls and are filled with worm organs, blood, tissue, and chemicals. Spidery lengths of copper pipe connect them to distillation boxes, and run into the waters of the grotto. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Investigation|XPHB}, or {@skill Nature|XPHB}) check can deduce that Matron Lethica is seeking to poison the valley's water supply with Lethic Serum. These vats are highly pressurized and can be used in combat (see "The Chemical Evolution" later in this chapter).

entries.name: The Chemical Evolution
entries: This section assumes the characters confront {@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24} in {@adventure The Grotto of Tears|CrookedMoon|10|Map: Grotto of Tears}.

If Lethica or {@area Hugo|432|x} are missing any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of this encounter, they are restored to full {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} now. If Hugo was killed earlier during this adventure but not destroyed, he joins Lethica here now, revived by her alchemy.

entries.name: The White Worm's Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24} unleashes one of the following psionic effects; the worm can't use the same option two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Homeostasis
entries: One condition or spell of up to level 3 affecting Lethica ends.

entries.name: Metabolic Reconstruction
entries: Lethica gains 10 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Psionic Guidance
entries: Lethica has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

entries.name: Phase 1: First Incision
entries: When {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} ambushes—or is ambushed by—the characters, read or paraphrase the following:
The Weeping Widow stands beside her hulking ward and quickly loads her syringe.
"You threaten my work. You would put a stop to bringing peaceful bliss to all of Wickermoor Hollow. Enough. You are beyond saving... Hugo. Send these fools into oblivion."

Matron Lethica ({@creature The Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24}) fights with all her cunning to annihilate her enemies. She and {@area Hugo|432|x} ({@creature Serum Brute|CrookedMoon24}) act on the same {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}. At the beginning of combat, Lethica injects Hugo with a serum that increases his size to Huge for 24 hours, then Hugo picks her up and places her on his back. She firmly grips his chain leash throughout the fight.

entries.name: Under Pressure
entries: Spaces occupied by pipes and vats are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. A creature in the same space as a pipe or a vat gains two effects:

items: It has {@table Cover|XPHB|Half Cover}.
If an attack against the creature misses, the attack targets the pipe or vat instead.

entries: If a copper pipe or vat (AC 13; HP 10; {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage) is destroyed, scalding steam and liquid sprays out. Creatures within a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the broken pipe or vat must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Acid damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, the area within the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB} with steam for 1 minute, or until dispersed by a strong wind.

entries.name: Phase 2: Desperate Measures
entries: When Lethica is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, she despairs and becomes willing to sacrifice her designs to survive. She commands the three {@creature Hospital Horror|CrookedMoon24|Hospital Horrors} to burst free from their mutation tanks and come to her aid. They act on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) and attack foes farthest from Lethica.

On her turn, if {@area Hugo|432|x} has not been {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, Lethica pulls at the leash that tethers her to Hugo, which opens his cursed eyes to the world and activates his Unleashed Eyes trait.

entries.name: Into Oblivion
entries: When {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

Matron Lethica lets out a shuddering wail as thick, black tears run down her face. Her composure breaks, and in her final moments, the widow truly weeps. Her frail form collapses as her violet blood pools beneath her.

A piercing, alien shriek fills the space as the grotto rumbles and the enormous white worm overhead strains against its restraints. With a creaking and crashing, the chains break from the stone, and the colossal creature plunges into the fluorescent waters below, disappearing from sight with supernatural speed.

entries.name: Alien Unchained
entries: With Lethica's psychic connection to the worm now broken, its reality-bending restraints shatter, and it escapes to the depths of Moonsong Lake to recover from its torture and imprisonment, gaining in strength until it must feed once more (see {@adventure Moonfall|CrookedMoon|19} chapter).

entries.name: Hugo's Redemption
entries: If {@area Hugo|432|x} still lives, he seeks immediate vengeance against those that destroyed Lethica. His veins pump with alchemical compounds and the sudden grief of losing his matron, but he can still be saved. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can attempt to calm Hugo and must make a {@dc 20} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check (with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if they deal no damage to Hugo on their turn). On a success, Hugo begins to calm, and the DC for subsequent checks is reduced by 3. After three successful checks, Hugo becomes {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} and breaks down into a sobbing mass of profound grief.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 8, if they are still level 7, when they defeat Matron Lethica.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Temperance|068|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Veil of the Weeping Widow|CrookedMoon24} can be pulled off the cold, lifeless face of Matron Lethica.

entries.name: Conclusion: Unforgettable Horrors
entries: Killing {@area Matron Lethica|426|x} puts an end to her vile experiments for good. Her absence, however, leaves {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} poised on a fragile edge.

entries.name: The Widow's Wake
entries: Without the presence of Matron Lethica, {@area Nurse Godlee|436|x} (if she lives) is devastated, but still craves control over all who remain. However, she quickly runs out of {@area Lethic Serum|450|x} and doesn't know how to brew more. She soon leaves with any living orderlies that still obey her orders, scheming to rebuild her influence.

If {@area Doctor Belkin|43a|x} lives, he becomes obsessed with {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24|The White Worm's} secrets and refuses to leave the Isle of Mourn. If forced to leave the sanatorium, he escapes with the surgeons to the caves below—leaving no trace of his work—and seeks the White Worm's lair deep within Moonsong Lake.

The surviving patients are left in a delicate condition, their minds dulled by the serum. The characters are free to restore and rescue the living inmates of {@area Memory's Rest Sanatorium|441|x} and return to Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: The people of Wickermoor Village rejoice if any former patients return, especially Amos Dority if his cousin is saved. Families pitch in and pay the characters 25 GP for each patient they saved, and if the characters devised a cure for those that lost their memories from {@area the Lethic Serum|450|x}, Mayor Wendel Somerton rewards the characters with an heirloom {@item Amulet of Health|XDMG} that takes the form of an emerald oak leaf.

Without {@creature The White Worm|CrookedMoon24} producing more Unrefined Ichor, the number of doses of antidote that can be crafted is limited by what remains of its key components in the sanatorium. Put together, there are fewer doses of antidote than there are those whose memories were stolen by the Lethic Serum (including any orderlies that receive the treatment), leaving the difficult choice of who may be saved in the hands of those who know how to procure and produce the solution.
Optionally, you may determine that Morgan the apothecary can produce an alternative cure with the serum diagrams and alternative alchemical ingredients, producing 1 dose after 8 hours of work.

data.name: Hartsblight Forest

entries: Green is the color of life. It is the color of rot. When you see it creep into your towns, you rip it up. When you see it bloom beneath your skin, you bleed it out. But despite your struggle, it always returns. When your cities, your skin, your bones, and your virtue are gone, all that remains will be green.

A creeping rot festers in Wickermoor Hollow. A once-vibrant forest has fallen to a virulent blight that consumes trees, animals, and people alike—threatening to seed all life with rapidly spreading decay. Deep in the heart of the dying woodland, {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} nurtures this rot, delivering death laced with the promise of rebirth.
