Those willing to endure the poisonous reaches of Hartsblight Forest must unearth and purge the source of the blight to put a stop to the spreading menace before it turns all to rot.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: Hartsblight Forest was once a lush and verdant woodland at the edge of Wickermoor Hollow known as the Greenwood, home to a community of antlered, deerlike satyrs that cared for its flora and fauna. Now, it is a rotten place putrefied by {@area Hartsblight|4f4|x}, a fungal infection that brings decay to all living things.

The first to surrender to the corruption of the blight was a young satyr named Farryn of the Greenwood, who followed the call of a dead primeval god to the origin of Hartsblight. Driven by the desperation of love, loss, and the hope for rebirth, she embraced the rot and forever changed into a monstrous embodiment of decay.

Discarding the remaining shreds of who she once was, Farryn took the name of Gorthos, {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}. This newly formed abomination spread rot through the forest, turning its plants, animals, and peoples to putrefaction. Now, Gorthos turns her attention to the lands beyond Hartsblight Forest, seeking to impart the blight upon all of Wickermoor Hollow.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: Infectious fungal spores drift from the tree line of Hartsblight Forest, rapidly spreading through Wickermoor Hollow. The only way to put an end to the advancing disease is to seek out and purge the source of the Hartsblight. Characters drawn to Hartsblight Forest by the {@area Quest Hook|4fc|x} later in this chapter have the following goals:

items: Follow the trail of fungal spores to Hartsblight Forest.
Find the source of the disease.
Destroy {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}, {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with the motives and history of Gorthos, the Beast of Blight, so that encounters between her and the characters are filled with tension. Understand the features of Hartsblight Forest and the effects of the blight to properly convey the oppressive nature of the diseased forest. Finally, a review of the climactic encounter, "{@area Reign of Decay|58a|x}," will ensure an intense and cathartic conclusion.
This chapter is designed for four level 8 characters.

entries.name: The Beast of Blight
entries: {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} was once a satyr devoted to the mystic rhythms of nature. As {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}, she now spreads Hartsblight throughout Wickermoor Hollow. She believes that through death, decay, and the "Emerald Rebirth"—her distant dream where the world returns in its pure, green state—she can bring back her lost love, Gwenna. As the beast wallows in heartache in her den, decay creeps forth with the assistance of her zealous minions, every strained and sickly breath burdened by longing and the slow, relentless promise of entropy.

entries.name: Farryn of the Greenwood

entries.title: Farryn of the Greenwood and Gorthos

entries: Farryn was raised to follow the Old Ways. In the deep recesses of the Greenwood, her people—a circle of antlered satyr druids—revered the endless cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Knowing she would return to nature's fold in time, Farryn was a devout student, tending to the old and new growth of the woods with boundless joy. She lived by the natural laws, her spirit bright and strong, and joined her kin in sacred songs and worship of the wild.

The druids of the Greenwood believed that personal attachment was unnatural and would only lead tenders of the wild astray in their devotion to the endless cycle. Farryn shared this belief until she met a young human woman named Gwenna, who had traveled into the forest from Wickermoor Village. A worshiper of the Patient Lady, Gwenna held an innocent idealism that Farryn found infectious, believing that nature's harmony could bring an end to the wicked witchcraft that hung over the neighboring Wytchwood.

Although Farryn did not believe such a thing was possible, she offered Gwenna her help in exploring the Greenwood. The pair wove through the trees near the border of the Wytchwood, sharing stories, secrets, and a love that quickly blossomed. Farryn kept her new beloved hidden from her community, knowing that the druids would brand her as an oath breaker. But it mattered not; the young satyr had found a purpose more precious and beautiful than even the natural world.

It was not long until Gwenna would pay for her nave idealism. Less than a year after their first meeting, Farryn found her love on the forest floor, half eaten by a ravenous wolf monstrosity twisted by the malign power of {@area the Crooked Queen|021|x}. The druid drove off the beast, but it was too late. Gwenna had fed the creatures of the wood and would return to the earth, as decreed by the natural cycle. However, Farryn refused to accept Gwenna's fate, overwhelmed with the agony of loss. In this moment of defiance and rejection of the natural cycle, she heard the call of Gorthos.

entries.name: Gorthos, the Dead God
entries: The voice of an ancient Fey god reached Farryn, calling her deep into the forgotten heart of the Greenwood with ragged, sickly whispers and the strained bleats of dying deer. She followed, carrying Gwenna's body to a hidden cave overgrown with fungus. Within was the enormous corpse of an ancient stag. These putrid remains would not return to the earth, instead enduring decay without end.

This colossal heap of rotting flesh, fur, and bone was all that remained of Gorthos—a dead Fey god of decay from the forgotten age of the Green Queen. He told Farryn of the lost eons, when {@area Kehlenn|021|x} was pure and untwisted. A time when her realm was green with renewal. Gorthos was captive in his den, just as the Crooked Queen was captive to her misguided desire for vengeance and unnatural, crooked corruption. But an Emerald Rebirth, he knew, could restore him and the queen as they were before. Gwenna would also be restored, and she and Farryn could spend an eternity together in a vibrant world of green.

Farryn shared the dead god's dream and understood what she must do. Over many weeks, she ate his rotting flesh, taking in his knowledge, his power, his purpose, and his name. As she feasted, she rotted, changed, and grew. Each bite of Gorthos's decaying flesh was added to her own form until the stag was no more, and she had become a huge, putrid abomination.

Farryn then carried Gwenna's deeply decayed body to the Greenwood's sacred wellspring that nourished all living things in the forest. She laid Gwenna in the waters, a final offering to the god she had consumed—the god she had become. As Gwenna's body submerged, the pool spoiled, spewing forth an explosive bloom of spores that would seed all life in the wood with Hartsblight.

As the rot spread, she retreated to her putrid den and became one with the blight, filled with bitter hope that the death and decay of all things, even the Crooked Queen herself, would restart the natural cycle in an Emerald Rebirth. Then and only then might she see Gwenna again.

entries.name: Parley with the Beast
entries: {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} is bound to her den deep within Hartsblight Forest but can speak through creatures that have succumbed to the blight, her voice raspy and thin. She views the characters as potential new hosts of the Hartsblight that can leave the confines of the wood and spread the decay across Druskenvald. She shares her vision of the Emerald Rebirth with emotionless certainty, seeking the characters' acceptance of the blight without threats or aggression. However, Gorthos is prepared to kill the characters and remake them in her image should they ultimately refuse.

Throughout this chapter, there are multiple opportunities for the characters to parley with Gorthos through a dying creature—a rotting stag carcass ({@area area F1|534|x}), the slain Halden Wreath ({@area area F4|547|x}), and a blighted gloomwood ({@area area F8|567|x}). Additionally, Gorthos can project her image to any point in the forest and can approach the characters when they attempt to rest within Hartsblight Forest (see "{@area The Shadowing Beast|521|x}" later in this chapter).

entries.name: Druids of Rot
entries: The deerlike satyrs that once followed the Old Ways in the Greenwood now zealously worship {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}, serving as her chief agents in spreading her rot. These druids have been spared the slow and agonizing death and decay of the Hartsblight in exchange for the power to wield it and weave it through the woodland. They perform primeval rituals from eons past to quicken the spread of the sickness and deepen its effect, all united in the pursuit of the Emerald Rebirth.

entries.name: The Hartsblight
entries: The Hartsblight is a rotting fungal disease that decays the body of any plant or creature it infects, spread by the will of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} and her minions. It can also distort the minds of the infected, allowing {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} to deliver vivid hallucinations that blur the line between what's real and imagined.

Exposure to the blight increases a creature's Hartsblight level. There is no limit to the number of Hartsblight levels a creature can have, and all effects of the affliction are cumulative. A creature afflicted with Hartsblight suffers the following effects:

entries.name: Consuming Rot
entries: The creature subtracts its Hartsblight level from Constitution saving throws.

entries.name: Feeble Flesh
entries: Hartsblight reduces attack rolls by 1 for each level.

entries.name: Overwhelming Affliction
entries: Each time a creature reaches a Hartsblight level of 6 or higher, its current and maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} are halved (to a minimum of 1 HP).

entries.name: Spoiled Healing
entries: When the creature regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it subtracts its Hartsblight level from the total (to a minimum of 0).

entries.name: Studying the Blight
entries: Characters who assess the Hartsblight to understand it or seek a cure can make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check after spending 10 minutes examining the body or corpse of any creature or a plant infected by the blight. On a success, they learn the following:

items: An infected creature that finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} can make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, reducing its Hartsblight level by a number equal to its Constitution modifier on a successful save or half as much on a failed save (minimum of 1 for either result).
Effects that remove the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition, such as {@spell Protection from Poison|XPHB} or {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, remove 1 Hartsblight level.
{@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Heal|XPHB}, or similarly powerful magic removes all Hartsblight levels.

Even creatures who have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition or who don't breathe are vulnerable to the spread of Hartsblight, as it seeps into flesh and bone as easily as it withers plants.
Hartsblight will continue to spread until the source of the blight is destroyed.

entries.name: Tracking Hartsblight
entries: Whenever a character is affected by Hartsblight, the player should track their character's Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: Hartsblight spreads through Wickermoor Hollow, carried in virulent spores that drift on the wind.

entries.name: A Crumbling Community
entries: Members of the {@area Fold of the Patient Lady|03a|x} gather for a fellowship meal in the pavilion ({@area area V28|18c|x}) of Wickermoor Village, inviting the characters to join them and share in nature's bounty. When the characters arrive, there is concern that Sister Rain (see chapter {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}) has not yet shown up to lead the group in the pre-meal prayer.

These concerns are justified when Sister Rain (Neutral Good, human {@creature Priest|XMM}) finally appears toward the end of the gathering, her face strained with deep concern. She has just returned from a visit to a commune north of Moonsong Lake that had been established by fellow members of the Fold of the Patient Lady, announcing that their crops have begun to fail and their livestock have fallen ill.

Sister Rain attempted to assist the commune, but the affliction was beyond her ability to heal. Even worse, while she was treating an ill member of the commune, she experienced a sudden vivid hallucination of sprawling forests with brilliant emerald trees, its boughs filled with countless watching faces. By the time the vision faded, she was already a full night's travel back to Wickermoor Village.

She asks the characters to do what they can to help the commune, as she fears the threat is beyond any of the Patient Lady's faithful. She has no coin to offer but is willing to part with a precious bottle of {@item Harvest Brew|CrookedMoon24} for each character who answers her plea, which she hands over before they begin their journey. If the characters accept, she gives them directions to the commune and urges their swift departure.

entries.name: Sporefall
entries: The following night, if the characters refused Sister Rain or linger in town, a strange phenomenon comes to Wickermoor Village. A light flurry of what initially appears to be snow begins to fall, but soon the town is coated in fine, powdery spores. This spore cloud persists for 8 hours, and any creature exposed to the spores for more than 10 minutes at a time must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level.

Sickness spreads quickly to people, plants, and animals alike, and fear rises as yet another disease afflicts Wickermoor Village with the threat of famine. To prevent panic, Mayor Wendel Somerton offers the characters 300 GP each if they help put an end to the blight as he prepares to lead rituals of the Old Ways (see chapter {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}) to help combat the spreading disease.

entries.name: Patient Is the Night
entries: The commune of the Patient Lady, just south of the tree line of Hartsblight Forest, is about a four-night journey from Wickermoor Village at a Normal pace. If a spore cloud has already reached Wickermoor Village, an unmistakable carpet of spores hundreds of feet wide marks a winding path to the commune. Otherwise, the characters see the approaching cloud one night into their travels, which leaves a path they can follow.

entries.name: Commune of the Patient Lady

entries: A still and silent commune sits before an expansive forest that spreads to the northwestern border of the valley. A longhouse, built from woven branches and clay, is surrounded by humble huts and gardens. Fruit trees form a modest orchard, stretching out from one side of the dwelling in neat rows.
This small community is eerily quiet, having fully succumbed to the Hartsblight. The entire settlement is covered in a layer of spores, and decayed corpses are scattered across the commune.

entries.name: Spore Layer
entries: The commune is coated in spores of Hartsblight. Any creature that touches the spores with their bare skin or leans in close to examine something covered in spores (such as a body) must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Decayed Bodies
entries: The bodies of eighteen people can be found in and around the various dwellings. Dead chickens, ducks, goats, cows, and horses litter the livestock pen. As an action, a character who examines a body and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check can determine that the corpses are far more decomposed than would be expected given the amount of time that has passed since death.

entries.name: Blighted Crops
entries: A small orchard and several vegetable gardens bear clearly blighted crops that appear shriveled and cracked with patches of blackened rot. A creature that consumes any food from the commune gains 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Circle of the Hartsblight
entries: When the characters have explored a majority of the commune, read or paraphrase the following:

The sound of distant drums breaks the silence—a growing rhythm accompanied by the call of horns. Your attention is drawn north to the source of the strange music: Six gaunt satyrs with gnarled antlers stand in a line at the edge of the forest, their fur matted and blotted with green growth. Two centaur-like creatures stand at the lead, arms raised toward the commune. Their upper halves match the satyrs, but their lower bodies are those of decomposing stags. they chant, waving staves of withered wood.
A sickly haze rises from the ground all through the commune. Flesh and plants alike begin to erupt with decomposition, sending whirlwinds of spores into the sky.

The minions of Gorthos have emerged from the forest to perform a ritual to spread the Hartsblight. Two {@creature Keeper of the Blight|CrookedMoon24|Keepers of the Blight} and six {@creature Rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|Rotweavers} stand in a line 300 feet from the commune. The keepers wave their arms in rhythmic motions as the rotweavers pound their drums and blow their horns.

Rotting corpses and blighted plants tremble and burst apart as primal magic surges through them, advancing their decay and casting a huge cloud of spores into the air in a 200-foot-radius Sphere centered on the commune. At the start of each minute spent in the spore clouds, a creature must succeed a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level.
The ritual lasts 10 minutes. If the characters do not intervene, wind picks up in the final minute and carries the cloud of spores toward Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Dealing with the Druids
entries: If the characters move toward the druids with aggression, roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}! The blighted satyrs don't stop performing the ritual unless it is disrupted by hitting any of the minions of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} with an attack or affecting them with a spell. If the ritual is stopped, a blight keeper calls out:
"You only delay the inevitable. The Hartsblight spreads with every death. We shall all return to the green in a glorious Emerald Rebirth."
The druids fight to the death, believing that all things must die and decay to be reborn.

entries.name: Blessed by Blight
entries: Even if the ritual is interrupted, the blight in this area is empowered. Whenever a creature fails a Constitution saving throw triggered by an attack, spell, or trait of a {@creature keeper of the blight|CrookedMoon24} or {@creature rotweaver|CrookedMoon24}, it gains 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Keeper's End
entries: The first time a keeper of the blight dies, its body instantly decays into a heap of rotting flesh and fungus, sending a noxious cloud of green spores into the air. Each creature within 60 feet of the keeper must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level and have the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn as its mind is overwhelmed with a hallucination. Read the following when a character fails this save:

The world around you decays—the plants, animals, people, everything. It all dies and rots away into nothing. And then, from that nothing, a flash of emerald light erupts, and the world is reborn anew. A beautiful, natural paradise. Pristine. Untouched. Wild. Green.
Motes of Hartsblight drift from the tree line over the druids' bodies. The only path forward to seek the source of the rot is into the woods.

entries.name: Hartsblight Forest
entries: When the characters prepare to enter Hartsblight Forest, read or paraphrase the following:

The tree line stands before you, a wall of spruce, pine, and fir trees marred with long streaks of blackened rot and choking fungal growths. Motes of greenish-white spore matter drift down as the breeze shakes the sickly branches and wilted leaves, as if welcoming you to Hartsblight Forest.

Hartsblight Forest is vast and trackless. To reach the source of the blight at the Befouled Wellspring ({@area area F10|57b|x}) the characters must venture for miles toward the center of Hartsblight Forest. {@adventure The Hartsblight Forest map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: hartsblight forest} shows the sections of the forest and their points of interest.

entries.name: Navigating the Forest
entries: Hartsblight Forest is composed of three stands—distinct regions of increasingly blighted woodland, forming rings around the source of the forest's sickness.

entries.name: The Blighted Wood
entries: The first stand of the forest is diseased but has not fallen to the same level of putrefaction as the deeper woods.

entries.name: The Festering Wilds
entries: Deeper into the forest the second stand becomes more wild and the blight is more present. Every surface in this part of the woodland is covered in a slimy layer of rot.

entries.name: The Rotten Heart
entries: The third and final stand is the heart of the forest that has bloomed around the source of the Hartsblight. The trees here have been entirely consumed by rot, the low fungal canopy forms a cavern-like space overwhelmed with large green spores, and the heart of the forest looks like an alien landscape.
The characters must pass through the areas of all three stands to confront {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} and put an end to the Hartsblight.

entries.name: Fleeing the Forest
entries: If the characters wish to leave Hartsblight Forest before {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} is destroyed, they must pass through the forest's locations in the reverse order that they encountered them, finally exiting the woodland after passing through the Altar of Rot ({@area area F1|534|x}).
Once Gorthos is defeated and her control over the Hartsblight is eliminated, the characters can leave the forest without incident following a three-night trek.

entries.name: Hartsblight Forest Features
entries: The concentration of the Hartsblight and the potency of its toxic effects grow stronger the closer the characters get to the heart of the forest. Unless otherwise stated, the areas of Hartsblight Forest have the following general features:

entries.name: Choking Spores
entries: Spores of Hartsblight float through the air and seep into every surface and creature within the forest. Creatures that travel through the woods must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level every time they travel from one area to another. Tying cloth or some other barrier around a creature's face grants {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the save.

entries.name: Emerald Visions
entries: The Hartsblight has hallucinatory properties and can be used by {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} to share visions. Each time a character gains Hartsblight levels, they can receive a vision at your discretion. These hallucinations might showcase the Emerald Rebirth or provide details of {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}'s story (see "{@area The Beast of Blight|4ef|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Lurking Beast
entries: The projected image of Gorthos stalks the characters relentlessly, drawing near but always staying just out of view. When a creature fails a Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, they see the subtle movement of a huge mass between the trees. It might be a glimpse of cracked antler, rotten flesh, blackened bone, or patchy fur.

entries.name: Navigation
entries: Moving from one area to the next takes {@dice 1d4} hours of trekking through rough and fungus-choked terrain.

entries.name: Rotting Undergrowth
entries: The forest floor is overgrown with decomposing underbrush. The entire forest floor is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} and creatures can travel no faster than a Slow pace.

entries.name: Spoiled Provisions
entries: All forms of food and water not stored within an extradimensional space spoil within minutes. A creature that consumes rotten food or contaminated water within Hartsblight Forest gains 1 Hartsblight level. Creatures that forego eating and drinking risk dehydration and malnutrition.

entries.name: The Dead of Night
entries: While the characters may be resistant to sleeping in such a treacherous place, the increasingly overwhelming Hartsblight will likely require them to take several {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB|Long Rests} throughout their travels. While it is wise to rest, dangers are still present in the darkest hours of night.

Below are four optional encounters that can occur when the characters take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. When they make camp, roll on the Dead of Night table to determine which event occurs, or choose one that fits based on their choices. Once the characters experience an encounter, it can't be triggered again.

entries.caption: Dead of Night
rows: Drums in the Deep Wood
The Shadowing Beast
Shrieking Death
Paradise Lost

entries.name: Drums in the Deep Wood
entries: The familiar drone of the music of the {@creature Rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|Rotweavers} echoes through the forest as another ritual is performed. Once completed, a grotesque mass of sacrificed woodland creatures fuses with the blight to form a new horrid beast.

entries.name: Investigate
entries: Following the atonal sounds for fifteen minutes leads the characters to a group of four rotweavers conducting their rotting rites with drums and horns. If the rotweavers don't notice the characters' presence and are not interrupted for an additional ten minutes, they will produce a creature of sinew, necrotic mold, and hide that exists only to kill.

Use the {@creature Mammoth|XMM} stat block. It is a Plant, has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Necrotic damage, and creatures hit by its Gore attack must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Ignore
entries: If the characters do nothing, the blighted abomination finds them one hour after they finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} and attacks until it is destroyed.

entries.name: The Shadowing Beast
entries: During a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, a character awakens and notices a pair of reflective eyes at the center of an enormous black shadow just beyond the campsite. The voice of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} whispers to them: "You put trust in your companions, but you will lose them... Just like you will lose everything you've grown attached to..."

The shadowy image of Gorthos is projected into the forest by {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} as she lingers in her den. She speaks to the character more candidly than any previous interaction, hoping that the character will accept the gift of the blight.

entries.name: Who is Gwenna
entries: "Gwenna was life unblemished. She was warmth and innocence, untainted by the truths of this world. Now she waits for me in the green."

entries.name: Is There No Other Way
entries: "Other ways will fail. Question it if you must, but long after those you know are gone, all that will remain is rot."

If the character acts with hostility, attacks the image of Gorthos, or rouses their companions, the eyes and the shadow vanish into the night. Alternatively, if the character converses with Gorthos for one minute, the beast tells them: "There is strength in decay." The character must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level and gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Shrieking Death
entries: As the characters are making camp or otherwise settling down for a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, the terrified and agonized screams of a young man ring out, crying for help. Characters who succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check can pinpoint the location of the screams' source, a spot in the woods 250 feet from the camp. Characters who succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check realize the screams seem inhuman.

entries.name: Silent Predator
entries: The true source of the cries is a mated pair of two rotting {@creature Owlbear|XMM|Owlbears} infected and changed by the Hartsblight. As they stalk through the forest, the owlbears emit no sound other than the perfectly mimicked voice of their last victim, Halden Wreath (see {@area area F4|547|x}).

entries.name: Hunter Ambush
entries: The owlbears lure the characters away from camp. If any creature moves within 10 feet of the owlbears, they attack, surprising creatures that didn't discover the waiting ambush. The owlbears attacks deal an extra 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Necrotic damage on a hit.

entries.name: Paradise Lost
entries: As the characters settle down to rest, they hear rustling in a nearby tree. Its brittle branches curl into the shape of a smiling face as a {@creature Dryad|XMM} emerges from the pallid bark.

This dryad was once a being of the Greenwood but is now corrupted with Hartsblight, its name and purpose long since rotted away. Even though the dryad harbors a resigned contempt for {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}, it is buoyed by the grand Emerald Visions brought on by the blight. It approaches the characters out of curiosity and knows many secrets of the forest. It starts the encounter {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters.

As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can attempt to please the dryad with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check, changing its attitude to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}. Additionally, removing one or more Hartsblight levels from the dryad allows it to recognize what has happened to the forest and makes it more willing to help the characters.

entries.name: Friendly
entries: In exchange for interesting company, the dryad offers guidance that can aid the characters in finding the Befouled Wellspring (area F10), allowing them to skip the next location they travel toward within the Blighted Wood or the Festering Wilds. Additionally, the dryad might share secrets and warnings regarding potential future enemies they may face.

entries.name: Hostile
entries: The dryad does not tolerate rudeness or animosity, responding to hostility by using its Tree Stride trait to disappear into the woods, leaving behind {@dice 1d6} bright red berries that seem as though they were produced by the {@spell Goodberry|XPHB} spell but are actually mundane fruit infected with Hartsblight (see "{@area Spoiled Provisions|515|x}" earlier in this chapter). As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the berries and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB}) check determines they are tainted.

entries.name: The Blighted Wood
entries: Although far from the deeply rotten heart of the forest, this region is still afflicted by the Hartsblight. Spores drift beneath the canopy as plants and animals cling to life despite their worsening corruption. When the characters cross the tree line into the Blighted Wood, read or paraphrase the following:

Barely a glimmer of moonlight seeps through the crowded canopy above. The underbrush is dense and blackened, littered with the decaying remains of small animals. Dry, greenish-white flakes drift through the air all around you. Boughs and bark hang loosely from deteriorating trees.

Then, reality slips away as a vision overtakes you. A young human woman dances between the ancient trees of a healthy forest, laughing with innocent optimism. Another feminine voice calls out from just beside you, "Gwenna!" Just as suddenly, your senses snap back, and you are once again in the blighted woodland.

entries.name: Blighted Wood Features
entries: In addition to the features of Hartsblight Forest (see "{@area Hartsblight Forest Features|515|x}" above), areas of the Blighted Wood have the following general features unless otherwise stated:

entries.name: Canopy
entries: Hartsblight Forest is home to tangled clusters of massive birch, fir, pine, and spruce trees. The forest's canopy is 120 feet above the ground.

entries.name: Diseased Animals
entries: Sickly woodland creatures cling to life in this region of the forest but act erratically and are riddled with Hartsblight. If {@spell Speak with Animals|XPHB} is used, the minds of the creatures are befuddled, and they repeatedly extol the incoming "Emerald Rebirth" that will save them all. A creature that consumes the flesh of a forest denizen, cooked or otherwise, gains 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Scant moonlight pierces the boughs of the dense forest, shrouding the forest in {@spell Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Trinkets of the Lost
entries: The soil and underbrush of the forest floor are strewn with the personal effects of people who have been lost in the woods or dragged there for sacrifice over the centuries. Characters who succeed on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks additionally find {@dice 1d6} GP worth of weathered coins, weapons, or adventuring gear among the wood's detritus.

entries.name: Blighted Wood Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to {@adventure the Hartsblight Forest map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: hartsblight forest}. For combat encounters in the Blighted Wood, use {@adventure the Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters}.

When the characters enter Hartsblight Forest, they arrive at the Altar of Rot ({@area area F1|534|x}) after ten minutes of travel. From there, they must explore the remaining locations of the Blighted Wood before they can proceed to the next region of the forest.
To determine the order that the characters arrive at each location, roll on the Blighted Wood table below or make a determination based on their choices.

rows: Pine Barrens ({@area area F2|53c|x})
Infested Outcrop ({@area area F3|541|x})
Noxious Hollow ({@area area F4|547|x})

images.title: Map: Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters
Map: Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters (Color)

entries.name: F1: Altar of Rot
entries: {@i Blighted Wood}

Before you stands a huge, humanlike figure made from intertwined branches, shrubs, and other decaying flora. A hollow, feminine face gazes blankly ahead, draped in sheets of reeking fungus. Branches extend from its head like a mock crown. At its base lies a rotting stag carcass, resting atop a makeshift altar of stacked stones.

The effigy is a representation of who Gwenna once was—one of dozens that can be found throughout Hartsblight Forest. They are grown by the {@creature rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|rotweavers} to advance the Hartsblight and always face away from the Befouled Wellspring (area F10) to guide its spread.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character within 5 feet of the figure who examines it and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB}) check notices that spores passing through the hole in the effigy's head quicken, as though riding an {@condition invisible|XPHB} wind.

entries.name: Destroying the Effigy
entries: The effigy has AC 15, HP 30, {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage, and {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Fire damage. When it is destroyed, it releases a burst of fungal spores. Any creature within 30 feet of the figure must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level. However, its destruction ends its manipulating effect on the spores, negating the Hartsblight Forest's Choking Spores feature for 8 hours.

entries.name: Rotting Stag
entries: After the characters destroy the effigy, or before they move on from the location, a thin, monotone voice speaks from the stag carcass: "Nothing you do here can prevent the inevitable. Not even the gods can stop the green." This is the voice of Gorthos, who can speak with the characters.

entries.name: Parley with the Beast
entries: Gorthos is plain and upfront with the characters, speaking truthfully about the inevitability of decay and its necessity for the Emerald Rebirth. She remains {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters, even if they destroyed her followers or the effigy of Gwenna. When the conversation ends, the voice simply stops emanating from the carcass, and the stag continues to rot.
Who are You?

entries.name: Who—or What—Are You
entries: "I am a guide and a caretaker. I exist only to return the world to its rightful state. An Emerald Rebirth."

entries.name: Why Is the Forest Dying
entries: "It is a necessary process. Just as this rotting stag will return to the soil and give birth to new life, so will everything around us. Even you. Even me."

entries.name: Why Do You Let Us Walk in Your Woods
entries: "Your decay will come, in time. I am patient, unlike the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x}. She would have you destroyed and twisted into an abomination. I am not her. I am a guide back to the green."

entries.name: F2: Pine Barrens
entries: {@i Blighted Wood}

Thin pines stretch up into the dim canopy, their bark peeling and disheveled. A layer of dead tawny needles masks the forest floor, forming a carpet of rotten black and green. Rising up from this putrid detritus are large rib bones, cracked and stained with green. Not far is a large bear skull overgrown with blooms of yellow fungus.

These Pine Barrens were once the favored spot for local hunters and trappers that preyed on the numerous large beasts that roamed the forest. The carpet of needles covers an endless number of scattered, corroded Hunting Traps, many of which are still functional.

entries.name: Rusted Traps
entries: Creatures that move through the Pine Barrens must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw to cross without triggering a trap. Creatures aware of the traps' presence have advantage on the save. A creature that fails the save triggers a Hunting Trap. The powerful jaws deal {@damage 1d8} Piercing damage instead of the usual {@dice 1d4}.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, creatures that examine the forest floor and succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notice the rusted traps poking through the pine needles and locate a trap that is no longer functional. It is clearly decades old, and the words "Criswell and Paulson Trapping Co." are engraved in the metal.

entries.name: Hunting Beasts
entries: Eight half-decayed, feral hunting hounds roam this area—a pack that survived the death of their hunter masters years prior. Though afflicted by the Hartsblight, they remain swift, vicious, and hungry. The hounds will sniff out the characters and attack if they linger in the Pine Barrens for 10 minutes or if a character steps into a Hunting Trap.

These hounds use the {@creature Death Dog|XMM} stat block, but they each have only one head. A creature that is {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} by their Bite attack gains 1 Hartsblight level that vanishes when the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition ends.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A leather leash is tied around the trunk of one pine, its collar missing. A character who examines the leash and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds a {@item Devilbone Button|CrookedMoon24} lying on a root of the tree.

entries.name: F3: Infested Outcrop
entries: {@i Blighted Wood}

You push further into the sickly forest. Swarms of buzzing flies and crawling beetles increasingly plague your journey. Every step teems with their movement, their buzzing an ever-present drone that fills the air.

Ahead, a large rock formation juts from a ring of soft, upturned soil. Atop the rock is a small campsite, with a ring of smoke creeping along the stone and forming a barrier around the camp. The wriggling insects recoil from the smoke as if deterred by its pungent scent.

This is the final campsite of an expedition of botanists that had ventured into the forest to study the Hartsblight. The source of the emanating smoke is an {@item Eversmoking Bottle|XDMG}, partially stoppered but lightly fuming at the center of the camp, forming a small sanctuary within a 120-foot-radius Sphere. The bugs are attracted to the foul-smelling corpses of four biologists that can be found within.

entries.name: Camping Ground
entries: Four canvas Tents, Bedrolls, and Explorer's Packs are arranged neatly, crowding around the {@item Eversmoking Bottle|XDMG} near a cold campfire and empty food containers. Four turgid bodies huddle on log seating.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who searches the perimeter of the campsite and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds deep gouges and tunnels in the earth, evidence of burrowing creatures. Characters who succeed on the check by 5 or more find further evidence near the perimeter of the smoke where shallow trenches in the ground have been made by an acidic bubbling residue.

entries.name: Field Journal
entries: One of the corpses clutches a field journal in its rotten hands. Characters who spend one hour reading through the Book and succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check decipher the scribbled notes of the lead biologist and glean the following information:

items: The Hartsblight is not a naturally occurring blight, and the botanists have deduced it is Fey in origin.
It appears to have a mind of its own or is driven by a singular will.
Creatures infected with the Hartsblight can remain alive for years while rotting.
Signs point to increased blight deeper in the forest.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In addition to the {@item Eversmoking Bottle|XDMG} and the field journal, characters who search the Tents and packs for 10 minutes find a {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB}, four {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG}, and a {@item Handaxe|XPHB}. The bodies also wear matching silver bracelets, each worth 25 GP.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Burrowing in the soft earth around the outcrop are 8 giant, acid-spitting carrion beetles (use the {@creature Ankheg|XMM} stat block). It was the threat of these creatures that trapped the campers here and prevented their escape. The beetles attack if the {@item Eversmoking Bottle|XDMG} is fully stoppered, the smoke is cleared, or when the characters leave to continue their exploration.

entries.name: F4: Noxious Hollow
entries: {@i Blighted Wood}

Weaving through a maze of blighted trees and blackened brambles, you arrive at a mossy hollow in the woods that offers a welcome respite from the cluttered underbrush. This natural resting spot is shaded by a broad beech tree at its center, its branches covered in patches of greenish-white mold.

Slumped against the tree is the partially eaten corpse of a man. Shelf-like fungus grows over half of his shredded face and along what remains of his moldy chest. Carved into the tree above the corpse is a crude, jagged shape that resembles a skeletal stag.

The corpse is that of Halden Wreath, a man who went missing from Wickermoor Village some time ago. Obsessed with tales of archfey, he ventured into Hartsblight Forest seeking the fabled Tall Man (see chapter 26), who had once danced through the Greenwood before it fell to blight. He met his end to a pair of rotting owlbears (see "Shrieking Death" earlier in this chapter) in an unwitting sacrifice to {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}.

entries.name: Shrine to Gorthos
entries: The tree has been marked by druids of the blight as a sacred site to Gorthos. It strengthens the Hartsblight that infects those suffering here and bends magic itself. Using magic to remove Hartsblight from its victims does the opposite: the target of the magic instead gains 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: The Corpse
entries: As an action, a character who examines the corpse and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check determines that the man was killed by large claws and beaks. The fungal growth that covers him seems far too advanced for how long the body has been dead. Shortly after a character investigates the corpse of Halden Wreath, read or paraphrase the following:

Suddenly, the fungus-covered corpse shudders as a crack rings out from the tree it is slumped against. His body is instantly covered in vibrant mold that blooms over his arms, neck, and chest as his torso is wrenched free from his lower half with a sickening pop and rises up the tree. His arms dangle limply, and his moldy lower jaw hangs open, unmoving. Yet, you hear a familiar raspy feminine voice speak from the corpse. "Do you not see the beauty in the decay?"

entries.name: Parley with the Beast
entries: Gorthos speaks with the characters once more. She uses this opportunity to position herself as a force against the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x} in the hopes that the characters will understand their inevitable deaths and rebirth. She is uncaring toward the death of Halden and does not respond to threats.

entries.name: What Do You Want
entries: "The land is {@condition poisoned|XPHB} with vengeance and trapped in unending death. Only an Emerald Rebirth can put an end to this misery."

entries.name: What Does the 'Emerald Rebirth' Mean
entries: "It is the natural conclusion. This realm shall rise anew in emerald light, but only when all has returned to the earth. It is the only way to prevent Kehlenn's crooked rebirth."

entries.name: What Will You Do After This 'Emerald Rebirth'
entries: "Live anew, reborn and beautiful with my dear Gwenna. We shall all live and flourish in the green together, and we will know peace."

entries.name: The Blight Shows Us Visions—What Are They
entries: "The blight gives us green dreams with those it readies for rebirth. The green awaits us all, and the visions show us what has been, what is, and what's to come."
When the will of Gorthos departs, the severed torso of Halden comes free from the tree, hitting the ground with a sickening splat.

entries.name: The Festering Wilds
entries: Layers of decay and fungus are now ever-present. Every surface is encased in a slimy film of slick, soft rot. When the characters move on from the Blighted Wood and enter the Festering Wilds, read or paraphrase the following:

The gigantic trees in this section of the forest are deeply blighted, covered in impossibly huge growths of fungus. The soil stinks and squelches beneath your feet, and the underbrush is covered in fuzzy mold. The air grows hazy with motes of greenish-white spores that hang in the air.

Then, you are stricken by another hallucination. The young woman who danced in the woods now lies rotting beside you as you eat. The taste is foul, and you realize you are chewing on the slimy flesh of a colossal rotting stag. The vision melts away in green light, then shifts. You are standing beside the young woman, healthy once more, in a beautiful glade surrounded by trees of emerald green. She smiles and says, "Thank you, Farryn." You regain your senses.

entries.name: Festering Wilds Features
entries: In addition to the features of Hartsblight Forest (see "{@area Hartsblight Forest Features|515|x}" above), areas of the Festering Wilds have the following general features unless otherwise stated:

entries.name: Canopy
entries: The forest's canopy is 200 feet above the forest floor and has grown thick with fungus. A creature that tries to break through the canopy must destroy a thick fungal layer (a 5-foot-square patch of canopy has AC 12; HP 25; {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage; {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Fire damage).

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Light can't pierce the fungus-choked canopy, shrouding the forest in Darkness.

entries.name: Spore Clouds
entries: Dense clouds of floating spores fill the air, reducing visibility to a maximum of 60 feet. In addition, the area farther than 20 feet from a creature is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

entries.name: Violent Fungi
entries: Sticky layers of mold cover every surface. Attempts to burrow into the forest floor or the trunks of trees draw out {@dice 1d6} {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Violet Fungus|XMM|Violet Fungi} that attack until they are destroyed.

entries.name: Festering Wilds Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to {@adventure the Hartsblight Forest map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: hartsblight forest}. For combat encounters in the Festering Wilds, use {@adventure the Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: Blighted Wood & Festering Wilds Encounters}.

After leaving the Blighted Wood, the characters enter this second stand at the Druid Commune ({@area area F5|55a|x}). From there, they must explore the remaining locations of the Festering Wilds before they can proceed to the next stand of the forest.
To determine the order that the characters arrive at each location, roll on the Festering Wilds table below or make a determination based on their choices.

entries.caption: Festering Wilds
rows: Oozing Ravine ({@area area F6|55d|x})
Stinking Quagmire ({@area area F7|562|x})
Fungal Grove ({@area area F8|567|x})

entries.name: F5: Druid Commune
entries: {@i Festering Wilds}

Before you is an open expanse, pocked with burrow entrances at the base of each giant tree. Small windows have been punched out of the moldy trunks to form crude dwellings in some form of a community this deep within the wood.

This woodland commune is home to the druids that comprise the circle of the blight. It is the place where they rest, feed, and worship {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} when not out spreading the Hartsblight throughout the forest. Twelve {@creature Rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|Rotweavers} and one {@creature Keeper of the Blight|CrookedMoon24} are gathered at the center of the community, sitting in a drum circle and praying to Gorthos in the Sylvan tongue.

The only path deeper into Hartsblight Forest is through this community. Though it is dark, the open space between the trees provides no means for concealment save for the sporadic dwellings that encircle the common area. Characters can dart from dwelling to dwelling, avoiding the druids' attention with a successful {@dc 17} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. Succeeding on this check three times allows the characters to leave the Druid Commune undetected.

entries.name: Satyr Dwellings
entries: The druids' quarters are burrowed beneath and into the ancient, blighted trees. The bases of the trees are so overtaken with putrefaction that it is difficult to tell where root and soil ends and the diseased growth begins. Creatures must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw for every 10 minutes they spend inside one of these dwellings or gain 1 Hartsblight level. While exploring the homes, characters find:

items: Mold-covered beddings
Idols carved from antler
Instruments crafted from gourds, hide, and bones
Prayer rings that were once full circles, now sundered
Clothing made of hide, woven plant matter, and bark
A forgotten jar of {@item Keoghtom's Ointment|XDMG|Restorative Ointment} from before the Hartsblight

entries.name: F6: Oozing Ravine
entries: {@i Festering Wilds}

The strange landscape narrows, restricting the path ahead to a tightly confined ravine. Every footfall squelches wetly into an underlayer of sloppy fungal jelly. Enormous, sickly trees crowd together on either side. Above, a precarious net of fungal strands suspends large spheres of spore-laden sap.

The winding ravine is 10 feet wide and 120 feet long. Characters who succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check can deduce that disturbing the walls of the ravine or the trees that flank it could upset the hanging slime above and that the safest way to pass through is single file.

entries.name: Passing Through
entries: Characters can safely navigate the ravine without disturbing the fungus overhead by succeeding on a {@dc 17} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check. If the characters do not pass through single file or one at a time, or if they {@action Dash|XPHB} through the ravine, they make this check with Disadvantage.

entries.name: Slimy Deluge
entries: If a character fails their check moving through the narrow passage, the bulbs of sap above burst and spill down, causing six {@creature Ochre Jelly|XMM|Ochre Jellies} to fill the ravine and attack.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: When the ochre jellies are destroyed, characters can find a {@item Chunk of Oozing Fungus|CrookedMoon24} in the residue that remains.

entries.name: F7: Stinking Quagmire
entries: {@i Festering Wilds}

The spongy terrain dips down into a vast waterlogged depression. Stagnant pools of stinking green water are coated with slick algae, with patches of stable ground interspersed between deep, muddy pits. One pool amongst the morass, however, remains clean and clear, its surface showing a perfect reflection of the towering trees and outgrowths that surround the rotting wetland.
The pristine pool is approximately 25 feet on any given side, shallow, and is one of the few bastions of the forest that remains unsullied by Hartsblight.

entries.name: Cleansing Waters
entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the clear pool and succeeds on a {@dc 14} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check realizes the restorative magic of the waters can purge creatures of Hartsblight. A creature that submerges any part of their body in the water loses 1 Hartsblight level, and the crystalline water gets one shade murkier.

entries.name: Contamination
entries: For each Hartsblight level absorbed by the water, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the result is equal to or lower than the number of Hartsblight levels that the cleansing pool has absorbed, three rotting {@creature Shambling Mound|XMM|Shambling Mounds} coalesce in the befouled water and emerge from the pool, attacking the two nearest characters. Any Lightning damage listed in the shambling mound's Immunities, traits, or actions is replaced with Necrotic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The pool loses its cleansing waters property when the shambling mounds take form. The stinking water drains, revealing the source of its potency lying in the muddy bed—a {@item Ring of Resistance|XDMG} (Necrotic) that is made of bone and has the words "All That Remains" etched in Sylvan.

entries.name: F8: Fungal Grove
entries: {@i Festering Wilds}

You step into a small grove suffused with a soft, pale-green glow. Ten-foot-tall fungal stalks rise up from the rotting forest floor. Stringy tendrils hang down like vines from the canopy above. The ground rumbles as you see a huge figure slowly walking in the grove, a huge, gnarled tree in a roughly humanoid shape covered in brightly colored corpse flowers that sprout from its rotting bark. It strides between the fungal stalks, belching spores from its flowers that cling to the fungi and cause them to grow upward.

The creature is a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Gloomwood|CrookedMoon24} that tends to the fungal stalks like a blighted shepherd, serving as a guardian of the grove. The eerie emerald glow of the fungus fills the space with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} and makes it difficult to disappear into the shadows. Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks in the grove are made with Disadvantage.

The gloomwood worships {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} and holds the same beliefs as the druids who serve her. It is prepared to destroy any creature it deems a threat to the fungal stalks it tends to, shouting threats and warnings in a booming, crackling voice.

Characters who reveal themselves and are wearing clothing of the druids, which can be found at the Druid Commune (area F5), have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Charisma checks to influence the gloomwood. A character can convince the gloomwood to let them and their allies pass with two successful {@dc 20} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}, {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Performance|XPHB}, or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) checks (turning its attitude from {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}), but only if they accept its blessing—granting each character 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Doomed Gloomwood
entries: If the characters slay the gloomwood, its body stiffens and Gorthos speaks through its blighted wood. If the characters manage to convince the gloomwood to let them pass, Gorthos instantly kills it with the power of the Hartsblight that infects it, speaking to the characters all the same. Once the gloomwood is dead, read or paraphrase the following:

As the life leaves the blighted tree, veins of rot shoot across its bark, snaking out in elaborate patterns as the vibrant flowers on its bark wither and die, falling to the forest floor. The stench of its wood grows more pungent, and the familiar voice calls out from the unmoving bark. "You are so close to becoming blessed heralds of blight."

entries.name: Parley with the Beast
entries: Gorthos speaks through the stinking corpse of the gloomwood. She did not expect the characters to survive so deep in the forest, and now sees them as potential heralds of blight that can move beyond the confines of the forest to spread decay:

entries.name: What If We Refuse to Allow This
entries: "Such a choice does not exist. The blight will claim you, as it has claimed the Greenwood. Even resistance is fuel for rebirth."

items.name: Do You Even Care About Those You Hurt?
items.entry: "Care? All things must die to be reborn. If I did not care, I would not seek to bring an end to the cruelty and hate of this realm."

entries.name: Why Haven't You Stopped Us
entries: "Do you not see it? Do you not accept your role as heralds of blight, bringers of rot to usher in the Emerald Rebirth in distant lands where I could not?"

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Inside one of the wilted stinking corpse flowers that fell off the dead gloomwood is a large dormant fungal pod, which "hatches" into a {@creature Devil's Glove|CrookedMoon24} familiar after 24 hours, bonded with a creature that carries the pod.

entries.name: Rotten Heart
entries: The center of the forest is the original source of the Hartsblight. The landscapes here are so overgrown with virulent fungus and so overcome with decay that it seems otherworldly. Only {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}'s most devout followers dare to tread these grounds. When the characters move on from the Festering Wilds and enter the Rotten Heart, read or paraphrase the following:

You move into the heart of the forest. The trees that surround you are dead husks; their cores have been completely overtaken by fungus that bursts out at every opportunity, making the trees appear mutated and alien. The spores in the air are huge and shimmer with a strange emerald glow. It feels as if you've stepped into another world.

Suddenly, your surroundings melt away as a vision overtakes you. Amidst a deep wood, you see a gnarled oak with a face twisted in bitter hate. A Crooked Queen. In moments, the tree is consumed in blight, rotting away into the soil. A small sprout emerges from the forest floor, and with a flash of green light, a beautiful green woman with elven features hovers before you, wreathed in emerald leaves. A Green Queen. Then, reality returns and you're surrounded by putrid decay.

entries.name: Rotten Heart Features
entries: In addition to the features of Hartsblight Forest (see "Hartsblight Forest Features" above), areas of the Rotten Heart have the following general features unless otherwise stated:

items.name: Canopy
items.entry: The trees tower to 300 feet but are completely choked by a layer of thick, fleshy fungus that forms an impenetrable cavern-like ceiling 60 feet above the forest floor.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Eerie green light glows from spores in the air and pustule-like fungal growths that bulge from every tree, illuminating the Rotten Heart with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Spore Clouds
entries: The clouds of spores grow denser, reducing visibility to a maximum of 30 feet. In addition, farther than 5 feet from a creature is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

entries.name: Virulent Disease
entries: The sickness brought on by the Hartsblight worsens here. Whenever a creature gains a Hartsblight level in the Rotting Heart, it must succeed on {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer an additional symptom of the blight. To determine the effect, roll on the Hartsblight Symptoms table below, rerolling any effect that the creature already has. These effects are cumulative. Creatures lose all of these symptoms when their Hartsblight level is reduced by any amount.

entries.caption: Hartsblight Symptoms
rows: Pain wracks the creature and its eyes turn milky white. The creature has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition, and has it {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom checks and Wisdom saving throws.
A raging fever sweeps through the creature's body. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} made with Strength.
The creature's flesh decays. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Charisma checks and {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.

The creature's thoughts are addled. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Intelligence checks and Intelligence saving throws, and when it rolls Initiative, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or act as if affected by the {@spell Confusion|XPHB} spell.
The creature is overcome with shaking. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} made with Dexterity.

The creature bleeds uncontrollably. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Constitution checks and Constitution saving throws. In addition, whenever the creature takes damage, it takes an extra 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Necrotic damage.

entries.name: Rotten Heart Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to {@adventure the Hartsblight Forest map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: hartsblight forest}. Combat at the Befouled Wellspring ({@area area F10|57b|x}) uses {@adventure the Befouled Wellspring map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: Befoulded Wellspring}.

As opposed to the previous two stands, progression here is linear. The characters arrive at the Withering River ({@area area F9|577|x}). From there, they must proceed to the Befouled Wellspring ({@area area F10|57b|x}) before moving on to face {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} in the Den of the Blighted One ({@area area F11|584|x}).

entries.name: F9: Withering River
entries: {@i Rotten Heart}
Before you meanders a sluggish, sallow river. Dead, blackened reeds jut from its stony banks. The water is cloudy and muted, almost motionless, and the smell of peat and old decay hangs in the air.
The river spans 60 feet across and is 3 feet deep.

entries.name: Tainted Crossing
entries: The river, corrupted by Hartsblight and sharing the subconscious of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}, exacts a toll from creatures who attempt to cross without acting as a carrier of the blight. When a creature crosses the river and arrives on the other side, it takes an amount of Necrotic damage based on its Hartsblight level, as determined in the River Toll table.

entries.name: River Toll

rows: {@dice 3d8} Necrotic
{@dice 2d6} Necrotic
{@dice 1d4} Necrotic

entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the river and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}, or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check, discerning the nature of the toll on a success. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character understands that any creature can become exempt from this toll by drinking from the river, which also causes the creature to gain 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: F10: Befouled Wellspring
entries: {@i Rotten Heart}

Jagged, fungus-covered standing stones form a rough circle within the rotten trees, leaning inward over the tainted pool at its center. The putrid ooze-like water within churns unnaturally in shades of green and yellow. Strange tendrils of fungus shed from the surface of the pool before drifting into the air and breaking up into bright green spores. The pool's thick, fetid surface never stills, instead roiling faster and faster as you approach.
This is the Befouled Wellspring, the heart of the blight, the corrupted reflection of life, death, and rebirth. The clearing is 60 feet across. The mouth of the wellspring is 25 feet wide.

entries.name: Sacred Stones
entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check learns that these sacred stones are magical and are from the time before the Hartsblight began corrupting the forest. Though they feed the blight's influence, disturbing or destroying the stones will do little to weaken or end the blight.

entries.name: Thing in the Pool
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character within 30 feet of the wellspring who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check sees that beneath the churning, rotten surface of the pool is a huge mound of flesh and fungus.
The moment a character gets within 5 feet of the wellspring, read or paraphrase the following:

The stench of decay from the churning, slimy pool is overwhelming. When you approach the edge, putrid ooze spills forth in all directions as a mass of flesh and fungus lurches upward, standing in the horrific approximation of a humanoid shape. Every inch of it wriggles as sheets of decay slough off with each step it makes toward you.

This is what remains of the body of Gwenna, once dead but now corrupted by Hartsblight and granted a horrific, mindless undeath. Her body has distended, mutated, and merged with fungus over many years submerged in the befouled pool. Nothing remains of the person Gwenna once was. Her flesh has become a living expression of the Hartsblight. In this moment, it is clear that the massive wooden effigy found at the Altar of Rot ({@area area F1|534|x}) was in the image of Gwenna.
It rises to protect the wellspring, attacking the characters until destroyed. Use the {@creature Festerhulk|CrookedMoon24} stat block.

entries.name: Beginning of the End
entries: When the abomination is slain, it erupts into a huge cloud of pungent spores that instantly coalesce in the air like a swarm of flies. It surges northward, flying even deeper into the forest and leaving a slimy trail of viscous rot in its wake. This is the source of the Hartsblight rushing back to {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} in the Den of the Blighted One ({@area area F11|584|x}).

When the festerhulk turns into spores, any creatures within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or gain 2 Hartsblight levels and have the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn as its mind is overwhelmed with a hallucination. Read the following aloud:

You stand in a pristine pool with crystalline waters, sacred standing stones circling you. You hold the hideous rotting corpse of a human woman. Gwenna. You gently lower her into the water, and in an instant the pool runs foul. Rot erupts from within. All that remains is decay.
With the abomination destroyed, the wellspring lies quiet, containing only a putrid residue that clings to the edges of the pool in foul shades of green and yellow.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Hermit|05e|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Staff of Farryn of the Greenwood|CrookedMoon24} is found embedded in the rotten ground among the standing stones.

entries.name: Tracking the Beast
entries: The characters can follow the trail of slime left by the surging spores to the Den of the Blighted One, arriving after a two-hour trek.

entries.name: F11: Den of the Blighted One
entries: {@i Rotten Heart}

The oozing, snaking path of corruption through the rotten forest heart leads you to the mouth of a cave that opens at the base of a fungus-covered ridge, half-concealed by the blighted trees that frame it. A putrid stench belches from the void within.

The characters can pass through the cave mouth into a winding, esophageal tunnel that bores deep into the earth. The tunnel is 30 feet wide and slick with oozing rot and fungal blooms. After 1 minute of walking, the characters arrive at {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}'s den. Read or paraphrase the following:

You enter a large, reeking den, with strange charms and idols made from bone, flesh, and fur hanging throughout the space. Veins of necrotic, blighted roots cling to the floor and walls like ivy. Fungal nests hug the rocks in stringy congregations, oozing bile-colored pus. Patches of rotten moss are embedded into the ground, swollen with blighted matter. Spores adhere to every surface.

At the far end of the cave, the top half of a humanoid shape dangles from the fungus-covered wall. It is gaunt and skeletal, with long, stringy black hair and elongated bony arms. Its hollow eyes stare at you as it approaches and speaks with the voice of Gorthos. "You put an end to my Gwenna's suffering. You saw the power of the blight she held. It has returned to me, but I cannot leave this den. It is time for you to take my place and spread the blight beyond my forest. Accept my gift—die and be reborn, and become the heralds of the Emerald Rebirth."

The gaunt humanoid torso is all that remains of Farryn. It appears to be dangling from the cavern wall, but in truth it is just a small part of the massive bulk of Gorthos. Most of the creature's body is entirely overgrown in the fungus of the den, hiding it from view. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who examines the cave-wall and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check realizes this truth.
While appearing as just the skeletal top-half of a satyr, Gorthos makes a final plea to the characters to help her achieve the Emerald Rebirth by accepting the Hartsblight within them.

entries.name: Accept the Blight
entries: Should a character accept, it means the end of the character's life and their journey as a protagonist of this story. Gorthos extends a long, bony finger toward the character's forehead. If the character allows the claw to touch them, the Hartsblight that erupted from the corpse of Gwenna surges into the character, killing them instantly. They rot, grow, and rise again three days later as a {@creature Festerhulk|CrookedMoon24} under Gorthos' control.

entries.name: Reject the Blight
entries: If the characters reject the Hartsblight, Gorthos knows there is nothing left to be done and prepares to kill the characters to turn them into the heralds of the Emerald Rebirth by force.

The entire cave shakes as the wall of yellowed rot splits open. The fungus tears away as the dangling satyr torso lurches forward, and you see the awful truth. The gaunt shape is attached to a colossal stag-like body made from bone, blighted wood, and fungus. It stomps forward on huge cloven hooves, surging with the awful, blighted power you expunged from the wellspring. This is the Beast of Blight.

entries.name: Reign of Decay
entries: {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} seeks to kill the characters so they may rise as abominable fungal hulks that can leave the forest and spread the Hartsblight throughout Druskenvald. Use {@adventure the Den of the Blighted One map|CrookedMoon|11|Map: den of the blighted one} for this combat.

entries.name: Hartsblight Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the will of the Hartsblight stirs to cause one of the following effects; it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Blighted Spores
entries: The den fills with sickly green spores of Hartsblight. Constitution Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, each enemy of {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} in the den. Failure: The creature gains 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.name: Sticky Tendrils
entries: Sticky, fungal tendrils slither from the walls, floor, and ceiling of the cave, tugging at creatures' limbs. Until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the next round, each enemy of the Beast of Blight in the den that makes an attack roll or casts a spell with a Somatic component must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or the attack automatically misses or the spell fails (the spell slot isn't consumed).

entries.name: Weaving Rot
entries: If there are fewer than three {@creature Rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|Rotweavers} present in the den, one rotweaver appears in an unoccupied space of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}' choice.

entries.name: Phase 1: All That Remains
entries: {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} does not intend to let the characters leave her den until they are carriers of the Hartsblight. Gorthos prioritizes those that were the least receptive to her belief in the Emerald Rebirth and the mission of using decay to bring it about. She has no sense of self preservation and focuses instead on killing the characters as quickly as possible.

entries.name: Rotting Minions
entries: Three {@creature Rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|Rotweavers} arise from the fungus to defend the Beast of Blight, appearing in unoccupied spaces at the mouth of the den.

entries.name: Strength in Decay
entries: The Beast of Blight has a damage threshold equal to five times the number of rotweavers alive in the cave at any given time.

When the Beast of Blight is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, she commands the blight corrupting any remaining bones, fungi, and molds in the cave to bolster her efforts, causing them to burst into blight. All creatures of the Beast of Blight's choice in the cave must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Necrotic damage, reducing their Hit Point maximum by an amount equal to the damage taken. This event transitions the battle to the next phase.
The cave has become a smothering maelstrom of disease and primal bloodshed. Every gasping breath fills the lungs with blighted spores and hot, rancid air.

entries.name: A Storm of Spores
entries: Huge, acrid plumes of greenish-yellow spores burst from {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}'s fungal growths in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from {@creature The Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}. When a creature not aligned with Gorthos starts its turn within the Emanation, it takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Necrotic damage and must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level.

entries.title: Map: Den of the Blighted One

entries.name: Harvested Decay
entries: The first time the Beast of Blight is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, a surge of Hartsblight fills the cavern in a 120-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the Beast of Blight. Each creature within this surge must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Hartsblight level. Any {@creature rotweaver|CrookedMoon24|rotweavers} that are still alive are also destroyed. The Beast of Blight gains {@dice 1d12} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} for each rotweaver slain in this way, and for each Hartsblight level the characters gained in the surge.
When the Beast of Blight is again reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:
The Beast of Blight lets out a strained bellow as the colossal beast of flesh, bone, fungus, and rot collapses to the floor. In a thin, withered voice, Gorthos whispers, "Gwenna... Our dream..."

The creature's corpse rapidly decays before your eyes, changing from shades of green, brown, and yellow until nothing is left but a sludge, which disintegrates into motes that drift into the air and float out of the den.
With the death of Gorthos, all Hartsblight levels that the characters have accrued are removed.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 9, if they are still level 8, when they defeat Gorthos, the Beast of Blight.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Death|066|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}" in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Idol of the Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24} is found in the beast's den.

entries.name: Conclusion: The Emerald Dream
entries: The concentration of Hartsblight in Wickermoor Hollow drops precipitously. The motes that drifted off the corpse of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x} float away to a different province of Druskenvald in hopes of taking root and once more spreading toward the dream of the Emerald Rebirth. The results of such efforts won't be seen for years.

The characters can leave Hartsblight Forest, spending three nights trekking through the wood. They are not disturbed by the druids that had served Gorthos, who are overwhelmed with despair after losing their powers of rot and decay, retreating into the depths of the forest never to be seen again.

The forest remains deeply wounded from the effects of the rot and decay brought by the spread of the blight. However, the disease that affects the woods is no longer magical, and the Greenwood begins to slowly heal.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: Sister Rain is horrified to learn what happened to the commune of the Patient Lady but is pleased to hear of the end of the blight's spread. She recruits a group of missionaries to venture back into Hartsblight Forest in hopes of helping it heal.

{@area The Followers of the Old Ways|039|x} are pleased to learn of the destruction of {@area Gorthos|4f1|x}, who was a fabled enemy of the Green Queen in the stories told among the faithful. A great hunt is held in the woods around Wickermoor Village to seek a stag to be served at a feast in celebration.

data.name: Maidenmist Cemetery

entries: My friends... I am but one light in the darkness. One soul against the crushing weight of the hate and hunger of death. It is happening. It is inevitable. I will break, and so will the chains around the shrieking dead. My friends... Forgive me... I have failed...

The gates of Maidenmist Cemetery have burst open, and the raging dead rise from their graves to escape. {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}, the necropolis's caretaker, stands alone against a rising tide of undeath, slowly corrupted by the incessant whispers of the malicious, ravening spirits he has sworn to entomb and imprison. Unless aided by the characters, the jailer will break, and a wave of shrieking spirits will crash upon Wickermoor Hollow and devour every living soul within.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: Maidenmist Cemetery sprawls across the fogbound, rolling hills to the southeast of Wickermoor Village, riddled with headstones, crypts, mausoleums, and every other kind of grave marker. It serves as the final resting place for all mortal beings in Wickermoor Hollow and has done so for millennia. None know who first built the cemetery, for it has always been there. It is said that the wrought iron fence that surrounds it inches forward night by night, forever welcoming the endlessly increasing deceased.

For years, a ghostly orc known as {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x} has served as the sole gravedigger and sexton of the cemetery. However, he is not just a caretaker for the dead that he buries and for whom he performs the final rites. He also serves as a warden, for the cemetery's true purpose is a prison for thousands of screaming spirits that seek only to corrupt and consume the souls of both the living and the dead.
