The cemetery's secret is that it was built upon a tear into the Shroud, which normally serves as an impenetrable barrier around Druskenvald, but here it serves as a gateway for the twisted spirits to cross over into the realm freely. These souls are filled with inhuman wrath for being deprived of a true afterlife; left unchecked, they would spill across the valley and the entire domain beyond, feasting upon the living.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: The haunted hills of Maidenmist Cemetery have never been safe for the living, but the warding lights of the necropolis have gone out, and their caretaker slowly succumbs to the corruption of the Shroud. Now, the cemetery is a prison overrun with rioting dead. Only the relighting of the balefire beacons and the sealing of the tear into the Shroud can stop the coming tide of death. Characters who are drawn to Maidenmist Cemetery by the {@area Quest Hook|5b0|x} later in this chapter have several goals:

items: Find {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x}, the Gravedigger.
Light the five extinguished balefire beacons.
Discover the source of the dead's corruption within the sepulcher.
Destroy {@creature the Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} and seal the tear to the Shroud.

entries: Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with Yorgrim, the key NPC, to convincingly convey his grim duty and descent into corruption. Refresh yourself on the stories of the other Fallen (see chapter {@adventure The Crooked Moon|CrookedMoon|1}) to provide the characters with inspiration in performing their rites. Review the locations of Maidenmist Cemetery so you are prepared to improvise encounters as the characters explore.
This chapter is designed for four level 9 characters.

entries.name: The Gravedigger
entries: {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x}, an orcish spirit bound to an eternity of penance, is the dour sexton that oversees Maidenmist Cemetery, hunched beneath the crushing weight of his duty and the heavy stone chained to his back. Haunted by the failures of his past and the loss of his friends to their respective sins, he goes about his duties with grim determination, never relenting despite the constant cracking of his soul and the chains that bind the spirits he keeps imprisoned.

entries.name: The Penitent Pilgrim
entries: Before coming to Druskenvald, Yorgrim was a seer for his people, the orcs of the Shadestone Clan. He communed with the spirits of the deceased, performing their burial rites and guiding them to the afterlife. However, he was deceived by his chieftain and unwittingly performed a necromantic ritual that slaughtered his entire community and annihilated their souls with unspeakable and forbidden power.

entries.title: Yorgrim the Gravedigger and Yorgrim the Seer

entries: Yorgrim took his vengeance, but it was a hollow victory. His people were dead, and their souls would never find peace. As a self-imposed penance, the seer etched the name of every fallen orc onto a heavy stone that he chained to himself, committing to carrying the weight forever as he sought to wander the land and bring peace to souls that were not yet beyond help.

For years, Yorgrim trudged across the land, a dour pilgrim performing burial rites for countless souls until his body finally gave out beneath the crushing weight of his penance. However, his spirit did not yield, and he arrived in Druskenvald not reborn but instead fated to forever exist as a ghost, still chained to the heavy gravestone even in death.

In this new realm, with so many restless dead in need of peace, Yorgrim wandered Druskenvald, performing rites alone until he finally made connections with five other souls as powerful and burdened as his. Despite his gloomy disposition, Yorgrim developed an affection for and eventual friendship with {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x}, {@area Sir Marius Renathyr|027|x}, {@area Mister Crossroads|353|x}, {@area Matron Lethica|426|x}, and {@area Farryn of the Greenwood|4f0|x}, regularly visiting each throughout his wayward travels.

entries.name: The Shroud Warden
entries: Shortly after meeting his new friends and softening his stony heart, he discovered the mysterious Maidenmist Cemetery in Wickermoor Hollow. Deep within the sepulcher at the center of the necropolis was a small tear into the primordial mists of death called the Shroud (see chapter {@book Druskenvald|CrookedMoon|1} in {@book The Crooked Moon Part One|CrookedMoon}), and the shrieks and whispers of the tortured souls within concerned {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x} deeply. He feared an apocalyptic reckoning should the shrouded abominations freely pass into Druskenvald.

Feeling as if he had discovered his true purpose, he bound himself to the cemetery and took up the mantle of its sexton and gravedigger, performing the burial rites for the thousands of dead he found there. His duty was to provide this service for every new death in Wickermoor Hollow. This prevented the spirits of the Shroud from slipping through to possess and reanimate the corpses that lay within the earth of the necropolis.

However, as the years went on, the tear to the Shroud grew larger, and Yorgrim beseeched his friends for aid. All agreed, and each of the six unlikely companions offered a fragment of their soul to kindle great braziers of spectral balefire, the light of which repelled the Shroud and the abominable spirits within.

After parting ways, Yorgrim would never see his friends again; the lighting of the beacons bound him to the cemetery as a jailer and warden of the shrieking spirits and occasionally restless dead within. In his duty, he took up a lantern tethered to the anima of his soul that serves as his primary weapon and tool to keep the unruly spirits chained.

As each of his former friends fell one by one to the sin of {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}, the balefire beacons dimmed greatly, and Yorgrim's nightly duties became far more challenging. When the {@adventure Ghostlight Express|CrookedMoon|3} crashed into Wickermoor Hollow, bringing the ghastly fog of the Shroud with it, the tear in the sepulcher grew immensely. And following the deaths of each of the Fallen, their respective balefire beacons have gone completely dark. Now, Yorgrim expends every measure of his being to keep the riotous and raging dead from spilling forth, his own soul weakening with every passing night.

entries.name: Parley with the Gravedigger
entries: {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x} is dour, grim, and stoic, but he is not cruel. He views the characters as the only hope to relight the balefire beacons and investigate the source of the Shroud. He is not talkative and speaks with few words but doesn't withhold important information that the characters need to know.
These are some responses to common questions the characters may ask of this spectral sextant:

entries.name: Who Are You
entries: "I am called Yorgrim. This is my cemetery. I serve the dead here."

entries.name: What Is this Place
entries: "The graves of Maidenmist bear the dead of the hollow. Centuries of souls rest here. It was here before me. It will be here after me."

entries.name: Are You Dead
entries: "My life ended long ago, but my duty did not. It persists until I atone for my sins and failures. This is my burden to bear."

entries.name: Who Is the Dog
entries: "This is Isolde. She is a grim, a spirit bound in duty to the dead. We are of a kind. She is my sole companion."

entries.name: What Is the Shroud
entries: "The Shroud is an element. Like the air you breathe and the earth you stand upon. It is death incarnate. It should not be here. Not even in an afterlife."

entries.name: What Are the Shrouded
entries: "Souls once living but devoured and corrupted by the Shroud. They have lost everything they once were in life. Abominations."

entries.name: You Were Friends
entries: "The monsters you killed were my friends. Before they succumbed to corruption, they had strong wills and good hearts, like you. They fell to their burdens, like you might yet. None are immune to the weight of failure."

entries.name: Why Would We Perform Rites for Villains
entries: "We will not perform the rites for the evil you faced. We do not mourn {@creature The Crimson Abbot|CrookedMoon24}, {@creature The Grinning Sinner|CrookedMoon24}, or the rest. I mourn who they were when there was light in their souls. It is for them we perform the rites. It is the only way."

entries.name: Isolde, the Grim
entries: After isolating himself, {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x} found companionship in Isolde (ih-ZOAL-duh), a type of guardian spirit known as a grim. These spectral watchers guard cemeteries, graveyards, and other burial sites and can take the form of any animal. Isolde (Neutral Good {@creature Ghost|XMM}) manifests as a black hound with bright white eyes. She is deeply loyal to Yorgrim, and carries in her mouth a {@item Hooded Lantern|XPHB} lit with a spark of the gravedigger's soul.

While Isolde is similarly bound to Maidenmist Cemetery like her master, she is able to exit its cold iron gates and walk beyond its borders. In recent years, she has served as the primary messenger between Yorgrim and {@area Mori Shade|184|x}, the undertaker of Wickermoor Village. With a supernatural intuition that only a dog can possess, she can sense that Yorgrim is suffering from the gibbering of the Shroud and is close to breaking.

entries.name: The Shrouded
entries: The shrouded are malicious, ravenous spirits entirely stripped of their anima—the soul-stuff that retains an individual spirit's essence and identity. Having lost whoever they might have been in life, the shrouded exist as devouring forces of the primordial element of death itself, filled only with the hunger to corrupt and consume souls that retain their anima, whether they be living or dead. They only feel rage and hate for those who don't share their fate, forever drifting through the Shroud and seeking new prey to corrupt into shrouded themselves.

In Maidenmist Cemetery, numerous shrouded have spilled forth from the tear in the depths of the great sepulcher, and some have even slithered out between the cracks of the ancient tomb. They drift through the ghastly rolling fogbanks or possess the corpses once interred in the earth but now shamble about the necropolis.

entries.name: Quest Hook
entries: Throughout their time in Wickermoor Hollow, the characters may have heard tales of Maidenmist Cemetery and perhaps even attempted to visit if their curiosity was piqued by the mysterious, haunted place. Until now, they would have found the gates closed and heavily chained, only spying the distant flicker of {@area Yorgrim's|5a1|x} lantern as he dug a grave or tended to the grounds. Now, the rising tide of the shrouded has smashed the gates open and undeath threatens to spill into Wickermoor Village and the hollow beyond.

entries.name: Downtime
entries: The remaining chapters of this book are likely to occur in rapid succession, so if the characters have unfinished business or are in need of a reprieve, you can offer them a moment to complete downtime activities. This also serves as the ideal opportunity to tie up subplots and side quests before the swift approach of the story's climax. Nights or even weeks can pass before Yorgrim begins to fall to the pressures introduced by the shrouded.

entries.name: Dusk of the Dead
entries: Late into the Dusk Hour, screams ring out through Wickermoor Village. Eight {@creature Ghast|XMM|Ghasts} wordlessly shriek as they slaughter any villagers they can find and feast on the slain. Alarm bells toll from the clocktower, and if the characters do not dispatch the Undead, the ghasts are brought down by a rallied militia of armed townsfolk ({@creature Guard|XMM|Guards}) led by Constable Doris Squire (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Knight|XMM}), suffering heavy losses.

After the ghasts are defeated, as an action, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 10} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check can deduce that the risen corpses had been dead for varying lengths of time, with the oldest ghast having been dead for centuries and the freshest one only several weeks deceased.

Mori Shade (see chapter {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}) arrives shortly after the battle and recognizes the most recently deceased corpse as Gregor Bolton, a once-burly workman who died from a fall while repairing the roof of Mayor Somerton's manor. She mentions that she had delivered his body to Maidenmist Cemetery shortly before the characters arrived at Wickermoor Village.

She is deeply concerned by the arrival of Undead creatures in Wickermoor Village, suspecting that something is wrong in Maidenmist Cemetery. She beseeches the characters to investigate to prevent more death and destruction from the walking dead. Use the details below to guide the conversation with Mori:

items: The shambling corpses' aggressiveness and shrieking suggests they aren't normal Undead.
From {@area Yorgrim|5a1|x}, she knows the Shroud can turn spirits and corpses into ravening monsters.
She has not heard from Yorgrim or seen Isolde since her delivery of Gregor Bolton's body to the cemetery.
A pile of corpses from recent deadly events around town has accumulated near the funeral home.
She went to Maidenmist Cemetery a week prior to look for Yorgrim, finding the gates chained and the cemetery covered in a dense fog.
There was no sign of the blazing fires or Yorgrim and Isolde's flickering lantern light, and her calls to them went unanswered.

entries: Mori implores the characters to see if they can find a way into Maidenmist Cemetery and discover what's become of Yorgrim. She then works with the townsfolk to collect the corpses from the battle and the funeral home, piling them on the outskirts of town to burn them, ensuring that they do not rise in undeath. If the characters interrupt the burning, the ghasts rise once more during the Dusk Hour of the following night.

If the characters fail to act, another group of townsfolk volunteers to make the journey to the cemetery. They never return, and can be found shambling among the Endless Gravestones ({@area area Y3|5de|x}) as {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies}. Every night of inaction, the village sees more attacks, the number of Undead in the horde doubling with each passing night.

entries.name: Maidenmist Cemetery
entries: Maidenmist Cemetery sprawls across many miles of hilly land in southeast Wickermoor Hollow. It has existed for centuries, its original builders lost to time. Countless dead rest here through every manner of burial and interment, and each of the thousands of grave markers that cover the land is never more than a few feet away from the next.

entries.name: Through Cold Iron Gates
entries: It takes approximately half a night's travel southeast at a Normal pace to reach the edge of Maidenmist Cemetery from Wickermoor Village, crossing the Silverbell River by way of an old cobblestone bridge. With each passing mile, the landscape becomes increasingly foggy, and the air grows colder. When the characters arrive at the cemetery, read or paraphrase the following:

The night is strangely cold and quiet as you arrive at Maidenmist Cemetery. A tall iron fence stretches out on either side of you, with thick, tightly spaced pickets that look like prison bars. The gate, flanked by metal sculptures of hooded reapers, hangs askew, bent as if it had been smashed open from the inside. The landscape before you, dotted with thousands of tombstones, rises in elevation before disappearing into the dense fog that shrouds the hills, wisps of blue-green mist billowing amidst the gray. A faint wail sounds from somewhere in the rolling fog.
A 15-foot-tall iron fence encircles the entirety of Maidenmist Cemetery, its base heavily reinforced with stone. A Tiny creature can pass through the fence's narrow pickets.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the bent gate and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds a 50-foot {@item Chain|XPHB} in the damp earth, along with several broken links, as if it snapped from a single violent thrust against the inside of the gate.

A cobblestone path leads into the cemetery up the hill, but it disappears into the fog. The blue-green mist is reminiscent of the Shroud, which the characters experienced during their trip aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}.

entries.name: Maidenmist Cemetery Features
entries: Unless otherwise noted, Maidenmist Cemetery has the following features:

entries.name: Ghastly Mist
entries: Eerie, billowing mist rolls across the landscape. The entire cemetery is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB} out to 60 feet, and {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB} beyond that distance.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The light of the Crooked Moon is caught and refracted in the mist, bathing the cemetery in {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Shrouded Spirits
entries: Corrupted spirits lurk in the mist, searching for souls to devour. Every hour that the characters travel through the mist, three {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (one of each variant) attack until they are destroyed.

entries.name: Wails of the Damned
entries: The mist of the cemetery is interwoven with the Shroud, and the shrieking souls within wail incessantly. Constitution saving throws made to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

entries.name: Corrupting Shroud
entries: If a creature that isn't a shrouded dies in the cemetery, it is corrupted by the Shroud and rises 10 minutes later, {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all creatures that aren't Undead. A Humanoid rises as an Undead, as determined on the Restless Dead table below. An Undead creature rises as a {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (random variant).

entries.caption: Restless Dead
rows: {@creature Skeleton|XMM}
{@creature Will-o'-Wisp|XMM}
{@creature Zombie|XMM}
{@creature Mummy|XMM}
{@creature Shadow|XMM}
{@creature Wight|XMM}
{@creature Ghoul|XMM}
{@creature Ghost|XMM}
{@creature Ghast|XMM}
{@creature Vampire Spawn|XMM}
{@creature Specter|XMM}
{@creature Wraith|XMM}

entries.name: The Phantom Gravedigger
entries: While {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} clings to his identity and duty, the weight of his penance and the insurmountable struggle against the tide of undeath has taken a toll on the gravedigger. His spirit is weak, tired, and fated to become The Chained Reaper. Before this transformation takes place in the Tomb of the Shrouded ({@area area Y15|633|x}), his shade can barely interact with the physical world, with most of his remaining power focused in the spectral lantern he always carries.

Therefore, when Yorgrim (found in {@area area Y2|5d9|x}) joins the characters in Maidenmist Cemetery, he doesn't use a stat block, has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage, and can't be affected by spells or other magical effects. His size is Medium, and he has a {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} of 30 feet. He can move through other creatures and can share a space with them.

entries.name: Balefire Lantern
entries: {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} carries a spectral azure lantern that is as incorporeal as he is, which sheds {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 30-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 30 feet. Once all six balefire beacons are lit, the lantern dims, shedding {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 5-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 15 feet.
The lantern has the following features:

entries.name: Azure Protection
entries: Creatures in the lantern's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} are immune to the Shrouded Spirits and Corrupting Shroud features (see "{@area Maidenmist Cemetery Features|5b6|x}" earlier in this chapter) of the cemetery's mist.

items.name: Balefire Warding
items.entry: All {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} cannot enter the lantern's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}. Shrouded in the lantern's light have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}.

entries.name: Gravedigger Actions
entries: While {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} is generally unable to interact with the physical world, when the characters are in danger, he summons up what little strength he has left to help.

While carrying the balefire lantern, on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), Yorgrim causes one of the following effects; he can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Balefire Burst
entries: Yorgrim's lantern erupts with balefire. Each creature of Yorgrim's choice within the lantern's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) Fire damage and 4 ({@dice 1d8}) Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Chained Phantom
items.entry: Yorgrim hurls a spectral chain to bind a foe. One creature Yorgrim can see within the lantern's light must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically.

entries.name: Garish Light
entries: Yorgrim unleashes a blinding flare from his lantern. Each creature of Yorgrim's choice within the lantern's {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

entries.name: Grave Resilience
entries: Yorgrim's lantern imparts vitality. Each creature of Yorgrim's choice within the lantern's light gains 13 ({@dice 2d12}) {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Balefire Beacons
entries: Six beacons of balefire, each with its own hue, are meant to roar in braziers around the cemetery to ward it from the encroaching Shroud. Five have gone dark and must be reignited to banish the eldritch fog and the vicious spirits within from all outdoor locations of Maidenmist Cemetery. This is the only way to open the doors to the Great Sepulcher ({@area area Y2|5d9|x}) so that the characters and Yorgrim can investigate the growing tear in the Shroud deep beneath the cemetery.

The balefire beacons have gone out following the deaths of the Fallen, the powerful beings whose souls were used to spark the flames. To reignite these beacons, the characters must travel across the cemetery to assist Yorgrim in performing each of the Fallen's final rites at their flame's respective brazier. The beacons, their locations, and the Fallen whose souls they were sparked from are as follows:

entries.name: Crimson Beacon
entries: Flame of Sir Marius Renathyr (see chapter {@adventure The Crimson Monastery|CrookedMoon|7}), found in the Highborn Crypts ({@area area Y4|5e1|x}).

entries.name: Violet Beacon
entries: Flame of Lethica Nightborne (see chapter {@adventure Memory's Rest|CrookedMoon|10}), found in the Cremation Gardens ({@area area Y5|5ea|x}).

entries.name: Amber Beacon
entries: Flame of Ol' Jericho Sticks (see chapter {@adventure Fields of the Crow|CrookedMoon|6}), found in the Potter's Field ({@area area Y6|5f3|x}).

entries.name: Magenta Beacon
entries: Flame of Captain Briggsy Kratch (see chapter {@adventure The Drowned Crossroads|CrookedMoon|8}), found in the Mausoleum Lanes ({@area area Y7|5fc|x}).

entries.name: Emerald Beacon
entries: Flame of Farryn of the Greenwood (see chapter {@adventure Hartsblight Forest|CrookedMoon|11}), found in the Burial Mounds ({@area area Y8|605|x}).

entries.name: Azure Beacon
entries: Flame of Yorgrim, found in the Shadestone Sanctuary ({@area area Y9|60f|x}).

The Azure Beacon is the only one that remains ablaze. When each of the remaining five beacons is lit, its corresponding sconce above the doors of the Great Sepulcher ({@area area Y2|5d9|x}) and within the Balefire Chamber ({@area area Y11|623|x}) lights with the same-colored flame. When all six beacons are lit, the sepulcher's doors unseal.

entries.name: Final Rites
entries: To perform the final rites of the Fallen, a 1-minute ritual led by {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} must be conducted at a balefire brazier. During the ritual, the characters must slay the attacking monsters and succeed on six ability checks. The specific details to complete the ritual are as follows:

entries.name: Spark the Flame
entries: Special kindling connected to the Fallen, kept entombed at the respective cemetery location, must be placed in the brazier and ignited, beginning the ritual. Roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}! If 1 minute passes without the beacon becoming fully lit, the flame goes out, and a character can offer a fragment of their soul to restore the kindling, gaining 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. The characters can then attempt the ritual again.

entries.name: Sacrifice a Soul
entries: The ignition of the flame draws the attention of {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} cemetery monsters corrupted by the Shroud, committed to preventing the beacon from being lit. These monsters must be slain during the ritual as an offering to the balefire (see "The Beacon is Lit" below).

entries.name: Hold Back the Shroud
entries: The ravenous Shroud is drawn to the ritual, kept at bay with immense effort from Yorgrim. It billows around the fringes of the light cast by Yorgrim's lantern (see "{@area Balefire Lantern|5be|x}" earlier in this chapter), waiting for the light to be snuffed out. Everything outside of the lantern's light is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB}. Additionally, any character who leaves the light and steps into the Shroud is attacked by three {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (one of each variant).

entries.name: Honor the Fallen
entries: Once the balefire flame is lit, it burns small and must be stoked. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, a character can make a contribution to the ceremony that honors who the Fallen were before they fell. The character makes a {@dc 15} ability check. Each of the Fallen has a list of suggested "resolution proficiencies" that have the best chance of contributing to the ritual. Other checks can work at your discretion, but the DC for such checks rises to 18 unless you feel the justification is especially fitting.

entries.name: Stoke the Fire
entries: Each successful ability check is one step toward finishing a Fallen's final rites (see "The Beacon is Lit" below). With each failure, tormented souls from the Shroud take on mocking shapes of the Fallen and unleash hateful words to torment the gravedigger and the characters. Each creature that can hear this verbal assault must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or take 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Psychic damage and gain the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. A creature can choose to take an extra 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Psychic damage to avoid the Stunned condition.

entries.name: The Beacon Is Lit
entries: After the destruction of the guardian monsters and six successful ability checks, the ritual concludes and the balefire beacon is fully lit, banishing the Shroud from the cemetery location. All shrouded in the beacon's location are destroyed, and the area loses the effects of the Shrouded Spirits, Wails of the Damned, and Corrupting Shroud features (see "{@area Maidenmist Cemetery Features|5b6|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Brilliant Success
entries: How well the characters perform the final rites affects the encounter in the Balefire Chamber ({@area area Y11|623|x}) within the sepulcher. Each ability check during a ritual that succeeds by 5 or more is considered a Brilliant Success. The number of Brilliant Successes achieved during the ritual determines the balefire beacon's intensity, as shown in the Beacon Intensity table below (important in {@area area Y11|623|x}).

entries.caption: Beacon Intensity
rows: 2 or fewer
Glowing Beacon
Blazing Beacon
Roaring Beacon

entries.name: Maidenmist Cemetery Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to {@adventure the map of Maidenmist Cemetary|CrookedMoon|12|Maidenmist Cemetary}.

entries.name: Y1: Corpse Road

entries: A long road wide enough that two carriages can pass side by side leads toward a huge sepulcher that sits atop the hill at the center of the cemetery. At the base of the great stone structure, you see small lights flickering a pale blue. The sight of the hill is swallowed by the gloom as the fog rolls in, becoming incredibly dense all around you.

This 20-foot-wide cobblestone road stretches three miles from the cemetery gates to the Great Sepulcher ({@area area Y2|5d9|x}), and it once served as the main pathway for hearses and carriages delivering corpses to be buried. The mist is at its most dense around the gates, with the billowing plumes of the Shroud seeking to be free of the confines of the cemetery. Traveling this road without the protection of balefire is dangerous, and new threats emerge after each mile traveled.

entries.name: First Mile
entries: The shrieking, whispering, and gibbering of the tormented spirits of the Shroud threaten to corrupt the characters' souls and psyche. Any non-Undead in the mist must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw, taking 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Psychic damage and 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Second Mile
entries: The characters draw the attention of malign spirits. Six {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (two of each variant) attack until they are destroyed. This resets the time of the cemetery's Shrouded Spirits feature (see "{@area Maidenmist Cemetery Features|5b6|x}" earlier in the chapter).

entries.name: Third Mile
entries: The oppressiveness of the Shroud becomes overwhelming. Any non-Undead in the mist must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level.

entries.name: Y2: Great Sepulcher

entries: You step out of the mist into a flickering blue glow as you arrive at the base of a great sepulcher, seemingly ancient with long thin cracks and dense moss covering its surface. The cobblestone road circles around the structure and splits off at several points that lead further into the cemetery.

Before the huge double doors are two spectral figures holding lanterns that radiate with ghastly blue light. One is a bearded orcish spirit, hunched low by a tombstone chained to his back. The other is a shadowy hound with bright white lights for eyes. Both shine their lanterns upon the narrow gap between the doors to burn away the snaking tendrils of ghastly gray and blue-green mist that writhe between the seams in hopes of escape.

Mounted into the stone above the doors are six iron sconces, five of which are unlit. In the sixth sconce on the far right flickers an azure flame that casts the same light as the two lanterns held by the spirits before you.

The two spirits are {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} the gravedigger and Isolde the grim (Neutral Good {@creature Ghost|XMM}), who are straining to keep the Shroud from escaping the sepulcher. Yorgrim looks especially hollow and tired, failing to notice the characters' arrival until they announce themselves or Isolde alerts him.

When the characters approach Yorgrim, he is surprised that mortals have made it to the sepulcher alive, but he's relieved that they might be able to set things right in the cemetery and push back the Shroud. Use the details below to guide the conversation with Yorgrim:

items: The tear in the Shroud within the sepulcher is growing, as shown by the shrouded trying to escape.
The balefire beacons that ward against the Shroud have gone out one by one in recent weeks.
Only one beacon remains lit, and its azure color matches his lantern. Both flames are tethered to his soul.
His five former friends, similarly tied to the now-unlit beacons, have all been slain.
The burial rites for the Fallen must be performed at each of the beacons to relight them.
Undead creatures and other monsters corrupted by the Shroud guard the beacons' unlit braziers.
Yorgrim is weakened due to battling the spirits but will aid the characters in this task and protect them from the mist.
Isolde stays to keep her light on the sepulcher doors. She can only last sixteen hours on her own before her spirit's essence is spent and she fades away.
Once all six balefire beacons are lit, the doors to the sepulcher can be opened to investigate the rift.

entries.name: Ghost of a Chance
entries: Yorgrim joins the characters in their exploration of Maidenmist Cemetery to protect them from the Shroud (see "{@area The Phantom Gravedigger|5bd|x}" earlier in this chapter), share what he knows about the Fallen (see chapter {@i The Crooked Moon}), and assist in performing the burial rites for each of his slain friends so that their respective balefire beacons can be lit.

This is a tremendous strain on his spirit. After each challenge his fortitude lessens, his spirit appears more hollow, and the maddening voices of the shrouded affect him more and more, leading toward his inevitable transformation into {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} in the Tomb of the Shrouded ({@area area Y15|633|x}). Once all six balefire beacons are lit, Yorgrim's balefire lantern dims, shedding {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 5-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 15 feet.

entries.name: Loyal Hound
entries: While Yorgrim and the characters explore Maidenmist Cemetery, Isolde is left alone to defend the doors of the sepulcher against the Shroud. She dutifully devotes herself to keep her balefire lantern lit, slowly draining her spectral essence. After 16 hours, Isolde's spirit is spent and she fades away, allowing the ghastly fog of the Shroud to seep out of the door and coalesce around the sepulcher.

Every 15 minutes after Isolde is gone, a {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (random variant) escapes its prison and lurks in the gloom, waiting to attack the characters when they return. This effect stops once all six balefire beacons are lit, but the shrouded remain until they are destroyed.

entries.name: Cemetery Paths
entries: Six paved paths lead from the sepulcher to the locations containing balefire beacons, and a seventh leads to King's Rest ({@area area Y10|615|x}). Each one is 3 miles long.

entries.name: Y3: Endless Gravestones
entries: Between the major locations of Maidenmist Cemetery are vast stretches of hilly terrain covered in numerous tombstones that mark the gravesites of Wickermoor Hollow's dead throughout the centuries.

entries.name: Shortcut
entries: These grave-laden hills can be traversed as a 1-mile shortcut between adjacent outdoor locations of Maidenmist Cemetery (see {@adventure map of Maidenmist Cemetary|CrookedMoon|12|Maidenmist Cemetary}) instead of returning along the path back to the Great Sepulcher ({@area area Y2|5d9|x}) before moving to the next location.

entries.name: Ravenous Dead
entries: The corruption of the Shroud has turned many once-restful corpses into hordes of shambling Undead creatures that seek only to devour the living. Whenever the characters travel across the Endless Gravestones, they are attacked by a group of these ravening dead before arriving at the next location. Roll on the Ravening Hordes table to determine which horrors rise to attack the characters.

entries.caption: Ravening Hordes
rows: Four {@creature Wight|XMM|Wights} and four {@creature Warhorse Skeleton|XMM|Warhorse Skeletons}
One {@creature Vampire Spawn|XMM} and six {@creature Specter|XMM|Specters}
Six {@creature Minotaur Skeleton|XMM|Minotaur Skeletons}
Two {@creature Ghast|XMM|Ghasts} and four {@creature Ghoul|XMM|Ghouls}
One {@creature Wraith|XMM} and three {@creature Will-o'-Wisp|XMM|Will-o'-Wisps}
Three {@creature Mummy|XMM|Mummies} and three {@creature Shadow|XMM|Shadows}
Three {@creature Ogre Zombie|XMM|Ogre Zombies} and eight {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies}
One {@creature Ghost|XMM} and twelve {@creature Skeleton|XMM|Skeletons}

entries.name: Y4: Highborn Crypts

entries: The paved pathway splits into various offshoots that lead to small courtyards, around which stand exquisitely crafted crypts topped with leering gargoyles. These structures, built of polished dark stone, are grand and gaudy, with the family names of the dead chiseled above each crypt's door. The air is filled with the sound of flapping wings and chittering as bats take off into the night sky in gyrating swarms.

Wealthy and noble families of Wickermoor Hollow are entombed within these imposing crypts. They are arranged around small courtyards and circled with wrought iron fences. {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} leads the characters to a courtyard that contains a large metal brazier filled with dull red coals—the site where the final rites must be performed for {@area Father Renathyr, The Crimson Abbot|027|x} (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter) to light the Crimson Beacon. For battles in this location, use {@adventure the highborn crypts map|CrookedMoon|12|Highborn Crypts}.

entries.name: Blood Tithe
entries: The doors to the crypts are magically sealed and deeply tied to the noble blood of those entombed within. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines a door and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check deduces that to open the door, fresh blood must be shed into a basin built into the crypt. A creature can shed its own blood, taking 6 ({@dice 1d12}) Necrotic damage and unsealing the crypt's door.

entries.name: Bat-Filled Crypts
entries: The crypts here are large structures, each housing a staircase that leads to an underground chamber with several stone sarcophagi containing the corpses of the once rich and powerful. Bat colonies that don't wish to be disturbed roost in these dark spaces. The first time a crypt's door opens, the bats spill out and into the night sky, biting and shrieking. Each creature within 10 feet of the door must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@dice 4d4}) Piercing damage from the bats.

entries.name: Knight's Tale
entries: While preparing to perform the final rites of Sir Marius Renathyr, the characters may recall what they learned in their exploration of the Crimson Monastery (see chapter {@adventure The Crimson Monastery|CrookedMoon|7}). Additionally, Yorgrim can share the following details of his old friend:

items: Marius was a valiant knight that served a god of the morning and his king Viktor Denathria, who was like a brother to him.
He was a relentless destroyer of evil and protector of the innocent, riding to quests atop his trusted steed named Dawn.
The righteous wrath that raged within him could only be soothed by his true love, the elven priestess {@area Lethica Nightborne|426|x}.

entries.name: Crimson Kindling
entries: The kindling to light the Crimson Beacon, a dried red rose, is kept in an underground chamber in one of the crypts, but Yorgrim's fragmented memory cannot recall which. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who observes the crypts and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check determines the correct crypt by noting the imagery of suns and roses etched in the stone.

entries.name: Crimson Rites
entries: When performing the ritual to light the Crimson Beacon, below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Marius's final rites:

items: {@skill Acrobatics|XPHB} or {@skill Athletics|XPHB}: Replicate great physical feats of heroism from his knightly quests.
{@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}: Recall the chivalric tenets of his king, his oath, and his god of the morning.
Painter's Supplies or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}: Appeal to the personal connections he had with his love.

entries.name: Creatures of the Night
entries: When the ritual to light the Crimson Beacon begins, five {@creature Night Creature|CrookedMoon24|Night Creatures} emerge from nearby crypts and attack until they are destroyed. For each failed check to locate the kindling, a {@creature Ghoul|XMM} joins the battle.

entries.name: Grotesque Gargoyles
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of each round during the ritual to light the Crimson Beacon, the hideous gargoyles perched atop the crypts pulse with a terrifying aura. Each creature that isn't a Fiend or an Undead in a 60-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the brazier must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. When Frightened in this way, the creature must immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} away from the brazier by the safest route possible.

entries.name: Y5: Cremation Gardens

entries: Roiling dark clouds overhead begin a downpour of rain upon the gardens you walk through, the winding pathway flanked by large clay urns that hold the ashes of the dead. The sound of burbling fountains at the center of each circle of the pathway joins in mournful harmony with the pattering of rainfall, punctuated by the low, monotonous tolling of a bell. Flowers of purple and white grow from the bushes and other vegetation that these memorial walkways cut through.

These melancholically beautiful gardens are where the ashes of those cremated in Wickermoor Hollow are kept amidst the brick-paved pathways intended for mourners to stroll down or ride through in carriages. {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} leads the characters to a circle where a brazier beside a fountain is filled with strangely purple coals. The final rites must be performed here for {@area Lethica Nightborne|426|x} (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter) to light the Violet Beacon. For battles in this location, use {@adventure the cremation gardens map|CrookedMoon|12|Cremation Gardens}.

entries.name: Wishing Fountains
entries: Numerous coins rest below the surface of the water of every fountain—6,000 GP worth of coins in total—remnants of lucky offerings from centuries of mourners. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the fountains and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check determines that there is a boon for tossing in an offering and a punishment for stealing from the fountain.

Each character who tosses 1 GP worth of coins into a fountain gains the benefits of the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell for {@dice 1d4} hours. Each time a creature takes a coin from a fountain, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be cursed for {@dice 1d4} hours. While cursed in this way, the creature has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}.

entries.name: Mourning Urns
entries: The urns that line the garden's pathways contain the ashes of the dead and the sorrow of those they left behind. The lids are fastened tightly but can be removed with a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and a successful {@dc 13} Strength check. When opened, the urn emits the sound of inconsolable mourning wails. Any creatures within 15 feet of the urn that can hear the wails must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or drop to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Night's Tale
entries: While preparing to perform the final rites of Lethica Nightborne, the characters may recall what they learned in their exploration of Memory's Rest Sanatorium (see chapter {@adventure Memory's Rest|CrookedMoon|10}). Additionally, Yorgrim can share the following details of his old friend:

items: Lethica was a devout priestess of the Nightmother, a goddess of night, healing, and motherhood who takes the form of a barn owl.
The gravely ill traveled from far and wide on pilgrimages to have their ailments cured by her and her acolytes with magic and healing brews.
She forever wore a mask and hid her face from all until she met Sir Marius Renathyr and experienced true love, finally revealing herself to him.

entries.name: Violet Kindling
entries: The kindling to light the Violet Beacon, a barn owl feather, is kept in an urn within the garden, but Yorgrim's fragmented memory cannot recall which. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who observes the urns and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check can find the correct urn by finding the imagery of barn owls and new moons. Opening this urn does not cause mourning wails (see "Mourning Urns" above).

entries.name: Violet Rites
entries: When performing the ritual to light the Violet Beacon, below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Lethica's final rites:

items: {@item Brewer's Supplies|XPHB} or {@skill Medicine|XPHB}: Showcase her favored healing techniques, tonics, and salves.
{@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}: Appeal to the personal connection she had with her love.
{@skill Performance|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}: Sing the hymns and recite the tenets of the Nightmother.

entries.name: Black Coach
entries: When the ritual to light the Violet Beacon begins, a {@creature Phantom Hearse|CrookedMoon24} rattles down the pathway from deeper into the garden, attacking until it is destroyed.

entries.name: Death Knell
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of each round during the ritual to light the Violet Beacon, the tolling of a phantom bell booms out over the garden. Each creature that isn't Undead in a 60-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the brazier must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw, taking 13 ({@dice 2d12}) Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Y6: Potter's Field

entries: The path turns from a paved walkway to a dirt road that eventually ends at a sprawling expanse of hills topped with countless simple wooden posts, each marking a nameless grave. The cawing and croaking of carrion birds fills the air as the fog rolls along this potter's field. Within the gloom, many amber-hued lights flicker in the distance.

This rolling potter's field is where the poor and forgotten of Wickermoor Hollow are buried, their final resting place only marked by wordless wooden posts. For battles in this location, use {@adventure the map of Potter's Field|CrookedMoon|12|potter's field}.

entries.name: Finding the Brazier
entries: {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s fraying memory cannot recall the location of the Amber Beacon amidst the endless expanse of nameless gravesites. The characters must find the orange coals in the gloom, but trickster spirits known as kackles flit about the hills and carry lanterns that glow with the same color in hopes of luring victims to their death.

To travel through the potter's field, the characters can observe the amber lights in the darkness and make a group {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check. On a success, they arrive at a brazier sitting amidst a scattering of nameless gravesites that's filled with dim orange coals—the site where the final rites must be performed for {@area Ol' Jericho Sticks|238|x} (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter) to light the Amber Beacon.

On a failure, the characters are deceived and are led to a deep mass grave that appears suddenly out of the gloom. Each character deceived in this way must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature falls into the open grave, has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition, and has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition from dozens of skeletal hands that emerge from the earth. A creature that enters the grave willingly must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. A {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the condition on itself on a success. While {@condition Restrained|XPHB} in this way, a creature takes 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns.

entries.name: Shallow Graves
entries: Most of the graves marked by the wooden posts are shallow and swarmed with sickly crows, ravens, and vultures that peck at the rotting remains that protrude from the earth. Approaching a grave disturbs the carrion birds, which scatter into the night sky, shedding their pestilence on those below. Each creature in a 15-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the grave must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 hour.
After the carrion birds have fled, the grave can be dug up in 10 minutes using a Shovel or other digging tools, or in 1 hour using bare hands.

entries.name: Scarecrow's Ballad
entries: While preparing to perform the final rites of Ol' Jericho Sicks, the characters may recall what they learned in their exploration of Foxwillow and the Fields of the Crow (see chapter {@adventure Fields of the Crow|CrookedMoon|6}). Additionally, Yorgrim can share the following details of his old friend:

items: Jericho was a kindly scarecrow who, at his heart, was a tunesmith, favoring his banjo, whistling, and singing in his warbling timbre.
He loved to travel from town to town and tell stories and fables to the villagers, especially the children who hung on his every word.
He was a skilled handyman and craftsman, lending his expertise to build or fix whatever people needed and offering to help tend to the fields.

entries.name: Amber Kindling
entries: The kindling to light the Amber Beacon, a bundle of straw, is buried in a shallow grave in the potter's field, but {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} does not remember which. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who walks among the graves and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notices the correct grave, which is flocked exclusively with crows.

entries.name: Amber Rites
entries: When performing the ritual to light the Amber Beacon, below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Jericho's final rites:

items: Musical Instrument or {@skill Performance|XPHB}: Play or sing a folksy song about his travels and good deeds.
{@item Disguise Kit|XPHB} or {@skill History|XPHB}: Tell one of his tall tales with a flourish or act out his folktales in costume.
{@item Carpenter's Tools|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB}: Showcase his handy skillset or knowledge of all things farming.

entries.name: Trickster Spirits
entries: When the ritual begins, two {@creature Kackle|CrookedMoon24|Kackles} emerge from the gloom and attack until they are destroyed. For each failed check to locate the kindling, a {@creature Specter|XMM} joins the battle.

entries.name: Dancing Lanterns
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of each round during the ritual, colorful lanterns flit about the fog in hypnotic patterns. Each creature that isn't Undead and that can see the lights must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition. While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, the creature is compelled to move into the fog. The creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Y7: Mausoleum Lanes

entries: The landscape around you becomes waterlogged and boggy, with tall, gnarled trees rising up from the fen, draped in hanging moss. The stone path cuts through the swampy terrain and splits into long lanes flanked on either side by tightly packed mausoleums. The modestly sized vaults are overgrown with creeping vines and ivy, while murky water pools in the cracks between the square stone tiles of the pathway before you.

The numerous mausoleums that line the crisscrossing network of paved pathways form a veritable city of the dead in the swampy terrain, where it is too wet to bury bodies beneath the earth. Yorgrim leads the characters to a brazier with eerie pink coals that sits at the end of a sunken lane near a mossy tree. This is the site where the final rites must be performed for Captain Briggsy Kratch (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter) to light the Magenta Beacon. For battles in this location, use {@adventure map of the masoleum lanes|CrookedMoon|12|mausoleum lanes}.

entries.name: Acrid Muck
entries: The boggy terrain threatens to swallow the tiles that form the paths between the vaults. For every 10 minutes of travel down the mausoleum lanes, each character must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or slip into the muck and have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. A {@condition Restrained|XPHB} character takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Acid damage at the start of each of its turns. It can take an action to repeat the saving throw, freeing itself on a success.

entries.name: Hexed Vaults
entries: The mausoleums that house the resting dead are jinxed with powerful magic to ward off would-be graverobbers. The heavy stone doors are tightly sealed and can be opened with a successful {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check, but any creature that attempts to open the vault must first make a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw as the protective hex is activated. On a failed save, the creature takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Force damage, is pushed 10 feet away from the door, and gains the effects of the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell for {@dice 1d4} hours. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

entries.name: Pirate's Shanty
entries: While preparing to perform the final rites of Captain Briggsy Kratch, the characters may recall what they learned in their exploration of the Drowned Crossroads (see chapter 15). Additionally, Yorgrim can share the following details of his old friend:

items: Briggsy was a pirate of fearsome renown but with a heart of gold, sailing the seas into danger and adventure with his loyal crew.
He was skilled at swordplay, earning the moniker "The Kutlass," but was also infamous for his clever plans and cunning tricks.
Luck always seemed to be on his side, and he excelled at games of chance, eventually mastering the art of fate-bending sorcery.

entries.name: Magenta Kindling
entries: The kindling to light the Magenta Beacon, a bottle of rum, is kept in a sealed mausoleum vault, but Yorgrim is foggy as to which it is. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who observes the mausoleums and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill History|XPHB}) check deduces the right vault by noting nautical motifs and sorcerous glyphs.

entries.name: Magenta Rites
entries: When performing the ritual to light the Magenta Beacon, below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Briggsy's final rites:

items: {@skill History|XPHB} or Navigator's Tools: Recall the daring nautical and piratical exploits of him and his crew.
{@skill Acrobatics|XPHB} or {@skill Deception|XPHB}: Show off his fancy footwork or his famous cunning ruses.
{@skill Arcana|XPHB} or Gaming Set: Highlight his skills in sorcery or his lucky breaks in gambling.

entries.name: Swamp Thing
entries: When the ritual begins, a {@creature Dream Eater|CrookedMoon24} swoops down from the branches of the moss-shrouded trees—its wings casting a hazy, psychedelic glow across the mausoleums—and attacks until it is destroyed. For each failed check to locate the kindling, two {@creature Mud Mephit|XMM|Mud Mephits} join the battle.

entries.name: Jinxed Flame
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of each round during the ritual, the old hexes that linger over the mausoleum lanes react to the stoking pink flame and suffuses it with unpredictable magic. Each character in a 60-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the brazier must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or be afflicted with a random jinx as determined by the Mausoleum Jinxes table below.

entries.caption: Mausoleum Jinxes
rows: Snake Eyes. On the character's next turn, they can only do one of the following: move or take an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. If the character takes an {@action Attack|XPHB} or {@action Magic|XPHB} action, they take 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Psychic damage.

The Nightmare. The character has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of their next turn, and they must immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move as far as they can away from the brazier, up to their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

Whiskey Bottle. The character drops anything they're holding. Until the end of their next turn, whenever they pick up an object, they must suceed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or immediately drop it.
Cheap Shot. Until the end of the character's next turn, their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved, and attack rolls against them have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.
Withered Arm. Until the end of the character's next turn, they have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} that rely on Strength or Dexterity.
Bad Luck. Until the end of the character's next turn, whenever they make an attack roll or a saving throw, they must subtract {@dice 1d6} from the total.

Dead Man. If the next attack roll made against the character before {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round hits, the attack is automatically a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}. If that attack roll misses, it hits instead.

entries.name: Y8: Burial Mounds

entries: The pathway turns to grass and widens into a small woodland clustered on an especially hilly portion of the cemetery. You realize that the hills are too round, tall, and tightly packed to be naturally occurring and must instead be burial mounds. You walk deeper into the grove of trees and see strange apples growing from hand-like branches. Jagged faces are embedded in the trunks, as if the trees themselves are watching and beckoning you deeper into the wood.

These ancient burial mounds are where the oldest and most wild peoples of Wickermoor Hollow were buried long ago. For battles in this location, use the map of the {@adventure burial grounds|CrookedMoon|12|burial mounds}.

entries.name: Finding the Brazier
entries: The trees that have grown up from the mounds of soil rich with decaying dead have twisted into strange and sentient watchers that form an ever-shifting woodland. This, combined with a weakened memory, has caused {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} to lose track of the brazier that holds the Emerald Beacon. The characters must navigate the wooded mounds to find it without getting lost.

To find the brazier, the characters make a group {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check. On a success, they arrive at a brazier atop a mound filled with eerie green coals—the site where the final rites must be performed for Farryn of the Greenwood (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter) to light the Emerald Beacon.

On a failure, the characters get lost in the woods, wandering for 1 hour before stumbling upon a ring of colorful toadstools growing up from the decay of death. Any creatures that walk into the ring of toadstools must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or take 9 ({@dice 2d8}) Poison damage and gain the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for {@dice 1d4} hours as the mushrooms burst with toxic spores.

entries.name: Forbidden Fruit
entries: Despite the gloomy trees that make up the woodland, the apples that grow from their gnarled branches seem strangely supple and colorful. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a creature can examine the apples and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB}) check, determining that they are magical with potential beneficial or harmful effects on a success.

When a creature picks an apple, the twisted tree responds to the theft of its fruit with violence. The jagged face in its trunk shifts to a wrathful expression, and its gnarled branches lash out. Each creature in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the tree must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 6 ({@dice 1d12}) Bludgeoning damage and 4 ({@dice 1d8}) Necrotic damage and have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, a creature can eat an apple to gain a magical effect as determined by the Forbidden Fruit table below.

entries.caption: Forbidden Fruit
rows: Drop to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}
Gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level
Gain the effects of the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell for 1 hour
Take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Poison damage
Gain the effects of the {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} spell
Regain 14 ({@dice 4d4 + 4}) {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}
Gain the effects of the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell for 1 hour
Gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}

entries.name: Mounds of the Old Ones
entries: The mounds of the wood have small circular openings leading to the burial chambers within, packed with several feet of dirt. As an action, a character who scours a mound and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check find the opening, which can be dug through in 1 minute with a Shovel or digging tools, or in 10 minutes by hand.

entries.name: Druid's Lore
entries: While preparing to perform the final rites of Farryn of the Greenwood, the characters may recall what they learned in their exploration of Hartsblight Forest (see chapter 18). Additionally, Yorgrim can share the following details of his old friend:

items: Farryn was a member of a druid circle of antlered satyrs that followed the Old Ways and adhered to the tenets of the Green Queen.
She had a deep affinity for all creatures of the forest, from beasts to birds to Fey beings, and was committed to the flourishing of plant life.
The one thing she loved more than the wilds was an optimistic human woman named Gwenna, who worshiped the Patient Lady.

entries.name: Emerald Kindling
entries: The kindling to light the Emerald Beacon, an oak branch, is buried within a burial mound, but Yorgrim cannot recall which. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who walks through the mounds and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB}) check identifies the correct mound, from which a tree marked with the face of the Green Queen grows.

entries.name: Emerald Rites
entries: When performing the ritual, below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Farryn's final rites:

items: {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}: Extol the tenets of her druid circle, the Old Ways, or the Green Queen.
{@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or Herbalism Kit: Showcase her affinity for the forest's flora and fauna.
{@skill Persuasion|XPHB} or Woodcarver's Tools: Appeal to the flowering love and passion she had for Gwenna.

entries.name: Twisted Treant
entries: When the ritual begins, a nearby tree uproots with oaken legs, and a {@creature Gloomwood|CrookedMoon24} attacks until it is destroyed. For each failed check to locate the kindling, two Violet Fungi join the battle.

entries.name: Corpse Roots
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) of each round during the ritual, the roots intertwined with the dead of the burial mounds grow restless and erupt around the ritual. Each creature in a 60-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the brazier must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 12}) until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Y9: Shadestone Sanctuary

entries: A strange sense of calm and peace washes over you as you approach a gathering of tall, chiseled stones that stand before a small ziggurat made of stacked stone blocks. A brazier at the top of the structure holds a blazing blue flame that casts an azure light over the area.

This small sanctuary was erected by {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} when he first arrived at Maidenmist Cemetery. The standing stones and ziggurat bear the markings of his orcish Shadestone Clan.

entries.name: Azure Beacon
entries: The beacon of azure balefire, sparked from Yorgrim's soul, still burns here. However, the flame has shrunk as Yorgrim's spectral essence has been depleted over time. The sanctuary does not have Maidenmist Cemetery's Wails of the Damned, Shrouded Spirits, and Corrupting Shroud features (see "{@area Maidenmist Cemetery Features|5b6|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Clan Stones
entries: The tall, carved stones standing throughout the sanctuary are etched with countless names written in Orc. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the stones and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check determines these are the names of orcs. If the characters ask Yorgrim about the names, he tells them that they are the names of his clan members who have died. He might share the story of his time before coming to Druskenvald (see "{@area The Penitent Pilgrim|5a2|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Chamber of Rest
entries: At the top of the ziggurat's steps is an open chamber that contains ten stone slabs. Yorgrim recommends that the characters rest here if they are tired or wounded. A sense of peace washes over any character who steps within. Short Rests taken in this chamber take 10 minutes and Long Rests take 1 hour.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Strength|05c|x} was pulled during the {@area "Fated Tarot Reading"|049|x} in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Shovel of Yorgrim|CrookedMoon24} rests on one of the stone slabs within the Chamber of Rest.

entries.name: Y10: King's Rest

entries: In the distance, the sound of battle rages from the roiling fog that hangs over an enormous palatial barrow. A great stone statue of a heavily armored, kingly figure stands tall on the mound, its sword piercing through the gloom. Through the green and gray wisps of mist, you see numerous undead soldiers battling against hordes of twisted shrouded spirits before the huge stone doors of the barrow.

This is the most ancient of all the sites in the cemetery, even older than the Great Sepulcher and the chambers beneath it. The circumstances of its construction are lost to time, but {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} knows that it is the resting place of a long-dead and incredibly powerful monarch. The ruler's name has long been forgotten, and he is now only known as {@creature The Barrow King|CrookedMoon24} (see "Moonfall" chapter).

entries.name: War of the Dead
entries: Before the stone doors of the enormous barrow are fifty {@creature Wight|XMM|Wights} forever locked in a clash with fifty {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (random variants). The Shroud seeks to overtake King's Rest so it may corrupt the Barrow King and dominate him to its will, and the army of wights relentlessly protect their monarch, aided by the ancient wards placed on the tomb. Yorgrim will gravely caution against approaching, as it would be certain death for the characters.

entries.name: Protective Runes
entries: Two huge stone doors to the barrow are covered in ancient runes that protect it. The substance of the barrow is immutable, the space within can't be entered with teleportation magic and is lined with a {@spell Wall of Force|XPHB}, and the doors are sealed with {@spell Arcane Lock|XPHB}.

Additionally, four prominent runes etched on the doors are four different glyphs created with the {@spell Symbol|XPHB} spell (Death, Fear, Pain, and Stunning), triggered when any non-Undead creature touches the door.

entries.name: King's Arms
entries: In the unlikely event that the characters enter the burial chamber of the Barrow King alive, a huge, impenetrable stone sarcophagus is topped with a set of {@item Armor of Invulnerability|XDMG} and a {@item Luck Blade|XDMG}.

entries.name: Sepulcher of the Shroud
entries: Once all six balefire beacons are lit, the door to the Great Sepulcher ({@area area Y2|5d9|x}) can be opened, and the characters can proceed into the heart of the necropolis. When the characters approach the sepulcher after they've lit all the beacons, read or paraphrase the following:

As you return to the sepulcher, you see the flickering multi-colored lights of balefire dancing across its great entrance. Crimson, violet, amber, magenta, emerald, and azure flames burn in the sconces affixed to the stone, and not a sliver of the Shroud can be seen escaping from the crack between the doors.

The tremendous strain on {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s spirit has weakened him greatly, and his ghostly form is visibly more faint and hollow. His fading essence has caused his lantern to dim, which now only sheds {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 5-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 15 feet (see "{@area Balefire Lantern|5be|x}" and "{@area Gravedigger Actions|5c0|x}" earlier in this chapter).

As his mind continues to unravel, he is clearly more affected by the gibbering of the shrouded, and he becomes less aware of the characters, directly engaging them in conversation less and less as they proceed. Despite this, he is determined to discover why the surge of the Shroud is increasing, and he won't turn back.

If Isolde has not been destroyed, Yorgrim commands her to stay behind and guard the door to the sepulcher and ensure that no Undead follow the characters inside. In truth, Yorgrim does not believe he will return from the depths and wants to ensure Isolde can help guide the next caretaker of the cemetery.

entries.name: Sepulcher Features
entries: Unless otherwise noted, the sepulcher's interior has the following features in addition to Maidenmist Cemetery's Corrupting Shroud feature (see "{@area Maidenmist Cemetery Features|5b6|x}" earlier in this chapter):

entries.name: Eldritch Gloom
entries: The Shroud itself spills forth into the sepulcher, making all interior locations {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The chambers inside the sepulcher and beneath the earth never see the light of the Crooked Moon and are shrouded in Darkness.

entries.name: Passageways
entries: Stone passageways between chambers, stairwells, and catacombs are 10 feet wide with 10-foot-high ceilings.

entries.name: Shrieks of the Damned
entries: The screams of the tormented souls within the Shroud echo through the chamber even louder. Whenever a creature makes a Constitution saving throw to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}, it must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the roll.

entries.name: Sepulcher Locations
entries: Death reigns in the chambers within the Sepulcher of the Shroud, always threatening to escape.

entries.name: Y11: Balefire Chamber

entries: This stone chamber is bathed in the flickering, multi-colored hues of the balefire emanating from the sconces embedded into the walls at even intervals. The light rises upward to the ceiling towering sixty feet overhead. In contrast, the far end of the room is shrouded in a gray and blue-green mist, billowing up from a ruined passage flanked by crumbled walls with shattered sconces. In the fog, the otherworldly gibbers of twisted spirits call out from the malformed shapes within.

This entrance chamber within the sepulcher is lined with sconces of balefire to prevent the Shroud from escaping into Wickermoor Hollow. The recent snuffing out of the balefire beacons allowed the Shroud to gain power and collapse a portion of the walls and passage to the undercroft that once shed warding light. The chamber is filled with {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Roaring Shrouded
entries: Throughout the roiling mist, ten {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (random variants) spill up from the undercroft and attack. However, a number of them are obliterated as they enter the light cast by the balefires in the sconces. The intensity of the flame in the sconces and the number of shrouded obliterated is determined by how successful the characters were in performing the final rites rituals to light the balefire beacons (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter):

items: For each Roaring Beacon, two shrouded are destroyed.
For each Blazing Beacon, one shrouded is destroyed.

entries.name: Rubble
entries: The far end of the chamber is collapsed with rubble from the crumbled sepulcher walls. To clear the pathway, the characters can take 10 minutes and make a group {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check, removing the blockage to the undercroft on a success. On a failure, it takes 1 hour to clear the rubble.

entries.name: Y12: Undercroft Catacombs

entries: You walk down the steps into the labyrinthine catacombs beneath the sepulcher. Rows of skulls line the earthen walls, and a thin layer of mist pools along the ground, streaked with eerie blue-green mist. Each step is uneven, and you feel the floor tremble unsteadily as you navigate the twisting tunnels.

These catacombs run like a maze through the sepulcher's undercroft and are the only passage to the stairs that leads to the tear in the Shroud. It is easy to get lost here, and the journey is treacherous, as cracks grow in the earthen floor, threatening to crumble away into the depths below.

entries.name: Catacomb Maze
entries: The characters must use their wits and tread lightly to navigate the catacombs. For every 10 minutes of travel, the characters must make a group {@dc 15} Intelligence check. On a success, the characters make it closer to their destination. After three successful checks, they arrive at the Stygian Descent ({@area area Y14|62f|x}).

After each failure, the characters arrive at a dead end where the floor beneath them is especially fragile and cracked. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or break through a 5-foot breach in the floor and plummet 60 feet into the Necropolis Depths ({@area area Y13|62a|x}).

entries.name: Y13: Necropolis Depths

entries: The stench of death and damp earth fills this massive, naturally occurring cavern, but it is clear that its size has been expanded even further by huge, burrowing claws. Several wide tunnels burrowed into the walls of the chamber have collapsed, each one lined with corpses in varying stages of decay, all coated in a layer of eerie, pallid slime. Several pockets of ooze glow with the ghastly blue-green and gray of the Shroud.

This is the lair of a spirit-devouring {@creature Necrolisk|CrookedMoon24}, which burrowed into the cavern to trap and consume the shrouded spilling forth from the tear to the Shroud. The unfortunate shrouded that occasionally squirm into this space through cracks in the stone wall of the Stygian Descent ({@area area Y14|62f|x}) become a succulent meal for the monster. The draconic creature lurks in one of its burrows toward the top of the cavern, and it ambushes any creatures that enter its lair.

entries.name: Necrolisk Slime
entries: The burrows dug into the walls of the cavern are lined with twelve blobs of foul, shimmering slime created by the saliva of the necrolisk, each containing a corpse or the dissolved remnants of a shrouded. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who examines the slime and succeeds on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check determines that it has the properties to restrain and break down shrouded, and it can potentially be harvested and used against the twisted spirits.

A character who spends 1 minute collecting a blob of slime and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check gains one use of Necrolisk Slime. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can throw the slime up to 30 feet at a shrouded, which must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition Restrained|XPHB} for 1 minute (escape {@dc 12}). While {@condition Restrained|XPHB} in this way, the shrouded takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Force damage at the start of each of its turns.

entries.name: Cave Formations
entries: The cavern floor is covered in rough and strangely shaped rock formations, making it {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} for Large or smaller creatures.

entries.name: Cracked Wall
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who observes the walls of the cavern and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notices wisps of the Shroud entering the cavern from cracks along a weakened wall. A character can smash through this wall with a successful {@dc 13} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check, creating a 5-foot-wide opening that leads to the landing of the Stygian Descent ({@area area Y14|62f|x}).

entries.name: Y14: Stygian Descent

entries: You arrive at the top of a stone spiral staircase that plunges deep into the earth. Its walls are etched with thousands of gaunt, skeletal faces wailing in agony. Huge plumes of shrieking mist billow up from the depths below. Sconces hold flickering balefire that glows with a color you have seen far too often: the ghastly blue-green of the Shroud. Yorgrim lets out a deep sigh filled with concern.
"Impossible... The balefire itself... Corrupted by the Shroud... We must hurry..."

The balefire that once warded this staircase has turned from azure to the ghastly hues of the Shroud, filling the area with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} that eliminates the effects of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s lantern (see "{@area Balefire Lantern|5be|x}" earlier in this chapter). These sconces can't be extinguished until the tear to the Shroud is sealed.

entries.name: The Descent
entries: Yorgrim and the characters must make the final descent down the stairs and through the ghastly mist of the Shroud. The voices within scream out to Yorgrim in Common and Orc, blaming him for their deaths and condemning him to their fate. When the characters have descended into the mist, they must each succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level.

entries.name: Tomb Door
entries: Once the characters finish descending the steps, a long hallway carved with the faces of wailing souls leads to large stone doors engraved with the shape of a hooded woman holding a lantern. Spectral mist spills from between the cracks of the doors, slithering along the sides of the hallway. Only Yorgrim can open the door. Before he does, he asks the characters, "Are you prepared to face what's within?" When the characters tell him they are ready, he opens the door to the Tomb of the Shrouded ({@area area Y15|633|x}).

entries.name: Y15: Tomb of the Shrouded

entries: Ghastly blue-green light fills this cavernous tomb, cast from braziers of corrupted balefire that sit upon two stone platforms—one raised up from the chamber floor, and one hanging above, suspended by immense, iron chains.
