Billowing plumes of eldritch mist roil throughout the room, spilling forth from a huge gyrating tear in reality that hovers near the tomb's ceiling. The Shroud itself spills forth, heralded by the shrieking of tormented souls.

The door slams shut behind you, and Yorgrim stares up at the tear into the Shroud, his spectral face filled with despair. "No... It was the size of a headstone only one month ago... I must close this tear once and for all... It must be me..."

This chamber has imprisoned the tear into the Shroud for centuries, but the crash of the {@i Ghostlight Express} into Wickermoor Hollow and the deaths of the Fallen have allowed the Shroud to corrupt even the balefire that had once kept it at bay. It is here where the Shroud is at its strongest, allowing it to finally defeat its jailer. Stone coffins sit on all three levels of the chamber.

entries.name: Platforms
entries: A three-pronged platform rises from the main floor of the tomb, accessible by three separate sets of stairs. A second three-pronged platform hangs 20 feet above the first, held aloft by enormous chains, accessible by three sets of stairs on the first platform.

entries.name: Shrouded Tear
entries: 20 feet above the second platform and 10 feet below the tomb's ceiling is a 20-foot wide oblong-shaped tear into the Shroud, which rapidly spills forth blue-green and gray mist, causing the whole chamber to be {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

entries.name: Corrupted Balefire
entries: Eerie blue-green light of the Shroud emanates from eight braziers throughout the tomb, filling the space with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}. This corruptive light is so powerful that it renders Yorgrim powerless, eliminating the features of his lantern and preventing any actions (see "{@area Gravedigger Actions|5c0|x}" and "{@area Balefire Lantern|5be|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: The Harrowing
entries: After many years of strain, toil, and penance, the resilient {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} finally breaks, and the Shroud claims him. However, he makes one act of defiance in his despair, as he ascends to the second platform beneath the shrouded tear. When he proceeds to the center of the second platform, read or paraphrase the following:

The faded spectral form of Yorgrim, now nearly translucent, holds his lantern toward the yawning, shrieking portal above him that spills forth with oscillating mist. In one last act of defiance, he shines his azure light into the dark fog and bellows, "Be gone, abominations! Return to the gloom! These souls are not for you to feast upon!"

Despite his determination, the gravedigger is too hollow and too weak. The azure lantern flickers and dims, and Yorgrim's will breaks. His face falls and he lets out an exhausted whisper. "The voices spoke true. I have failed."

In an instant, a shrieking tendril of the Shroud bursts forth from the tear and crashes into Yorgrim's spirit. It billows around him until the final glimmer of azure is enveloped in mist, a plume that grows to an enormous size amidst the cacophony of shrieking spirits and rattling chains.

With a burst of blue-green flame, the fog is expunged, and before you floats a colossal avatar of death. Yorgrim, still burdened by his gravestone, heaves a scythe of corrupted balefire and glares at you through skeletal eye sockets. Yorgrim calls out, a thousand voices in one: "He's broken, and now we will feed!"

The last of the Fallen falls, and Yorgrim has been transformed into {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}, now little more than a manifestation of death itself and the hunger of the Shroud. If the characters do not slay him, he will destroy the sepulcher and cold iron gates of the cemetery, unleashing a tide of ravenous dead upon Wickermoor Hollow and beyond. Use the map of the {@adventure Tomb of the Shrouded|CrookedMoon|12|tomb of the shrouded} for this combat.

entries.name: Shroud Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the will of the Shroud causes one of the following effects; it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Abominable Spirits
entries: Three {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (one of each variant) appear in an unoccupied space within the tomb (GM's choice). They act immediately and on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on subsequent rounds. The shrouded vanish when they die, when this effect happens again, or when the Shroud tear is sealed.

entries.name: Oppressive Gloom
entries: Dense blue-green mist spills forth from the tear and fills the room, making the tomb Heavily Obscured until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

entries.name: Tide of Death
entries: Waves of shrieking fog burst forth from the malevolent souls. Strength Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, each enemy of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} within a 5-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the reaper and any Shrouded. Failure: The target is pushed up to 15 feet straight away from the source.

entries.name: Phase 1: Cold Iron
entries: The countless chains that rattle from {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} slither out like tentacles, seeking to make his foes experience the burden and imprisonment he's suffered. Three {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} (one of each variant) appear in unoccupied spaces within the tomb and attack with the Chained Reaper.

entries.name: The Jailer
entries: Once per turn, whenever the Chained Reaper is hit by a melee or ranged attack roll, a chain shoots out toward the attacker. The attacker must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 13}) until the end of the attacker's next turn.

entries.name: Corrupted Braziers
entries: Corrupted balefire roars in eight braziers in the tomb, radiating with the soul-sapping power of the Shroud. A creature that passes through the fire must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. A creature makes this save only once during a turn.

entries.name: Azure Defiance
entries: When the Chained Reaper is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, faint wisps of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s azure light flit through his form as the hold of the Shroud on his soul lessens, causing the malevolent eldritch mist to lash out. The voices within the Shroud let out sickening shrieks in unison. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or gain the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of their next turn. This transitions the battle to Phase 2.

Cold, corrupted balefire rages all around you as the scythe of the Chained Reaper explodes into an inferno and the lantern rages into a fiery beacon. Yorgrim's voice booms out with the chorus of wailing souls. "You will break... They all break..."

entries.name: Corrupted Beacons
entries: The braziers' corrupted balefire rages brighter. The saving throw DC of the braziers increases to 15, and a creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of a brazier must make the save.

entries.name: Fallen Effigies
entries: Six stone coffins rest upon the tomb's platforms, five of which contain simple adult-sized effigies of the other Fallen. The sixth is empty. As {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s azure hue returns to {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} (see "Azure Defiance" above), these effigies begin to glow with their respective balefire colors. Characters who succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check realize the effigies can serve as kindling and be used to cleanse the corrupted balefire braziers.

As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can pick up one of the effigies and place it into the brazier while standing within 5 feet of it, cleansing the brazier and removing the effects of "Corrupted Beacons" from it. The calming and kind voice of Yorgrim's friend calls out to him as the effigy burns, dealing 10 Psychic damage to the Chained Reaper.

Additionally, the flame turns the color of the Fallen effigy that was used to purify it (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter), shedding warding light in a 20-foot radius around the brazier. If the Chained Reaper or any shrouded are fully within the light of this cleansed balefire, they have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}.

entries.name: Devouring Balefire
entries: The Shroud and its corruptive balefire seeks to devour the souls of all who oppose it. Constitution saving throw: {@dc 15}, a creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the Chained Reaper. Failure: 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Necrotic damage.

entries.name: A Light in the Darkness
entries: When {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

The colossal reaper before you gyrates violently, not able to maintain its form. Its chains break, its tombstone crumbles, its scythe snaps, and the ghastly gray and blue-green mist bursts from within in an explosion of azure light. Thousands of shrieking voices scream out and are silenced until one remains—Yorgrim's—emanating from the huge, ornate lantern before you, now flickering with azure flame. "Perform my rites... Seal the tear..."

The Chained Reaper is destroyed, but the tear in the Shroud is still open and must be sealed to put an end to the invasion of the shrieking dead once and for all. Any character who considers {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}'s words, observes the lantern left behind from the reaper's scythe, and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check can deduce that Yorgrim is the final Fallen whose final rites must be performed.

entries.name: Azure Rites
entries: Despite the destruction of the Chained Reaper, the battle for the fate of Maidenmist Cemetery is not over, {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} order is maintained, and the Shroud still acts against the characters (see "{@area Shroud Influence|63a|x}" earlier in this chapter). Yorgrim's final rites must be performed by fulfilling the "Honor the Fallen" step of the 1-minute ritual (see "{@area Balefire Beacons|5c4|x}" earlier in this chapter). Below are the suggested resolution proficiencies the characters can utilize to perform Yorgrim's final rites:

items: {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@item Mason's Tools|XPHB}: Showcase his abilities in tending to the dead, performing burial rites, or communing with the spirit world.
{@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}: Recall his dutiful commitment to the Shadestone Clan and the performance of his ritualistic duties.
{@skill Performance|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}: Perform a funeral dirge and extol the bond he had with his people, his friends, or his hound Isolde.

entries: After six successful checks, read or paraphrase the following:

The azure balefire rages within the lantern, and you hear Yorgrim's faint, distant voice. "Thank you." A moment later, the lantern erupts into a blaze of soothing balefire, filling the tomb with light that becomes so bright it blinds you. Hissing shrieks of tormented and twisted souls ring out for a moment before sizzling into nothing. When your vision returns, the tear into the Shroud is gone.

The tear has been sealed forever, and the Shroud now remains just beyond the borders of Druskenvald. The balefire flames within the sepulcher's depths have returned to their soothing azure hue. The dead of Maidenmist Cemetery finally rest once more. Any remaining shrouded are destroyed.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 10, if they are still level 9, when they seal the tear into the Shroud.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area Judgement|074|x} was pulled during the {@area "Fated Tarot Reading"|049|x} in chapter {@adventure Running the Adventure|CrookedMoon|2}, the {@item Lantern of the Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} remains on the stone floor of the tomb.

entries.name: Conclusion: Don't Fear the Reaper
entries: Peace returns to Maidenmist Cemetery, and the six balefire beacons remain lit as a final reminder of the six wayward souls who once bore good intentions but fell to the wickedness that lingers and lurks within every mortal heart.

If Isolde was not destroyed by the Shroud, she mourns the loss of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24} but continues her eternal duty bound to Maidenmist Cemetery. She awaits the next soul brave enough to take up the mantle of the cemetery's sexton. As the characters leave the sepulcher, she approaches them and gives them thankful licks, attempting to guide them to the Shadestone Sanctuary ({@area area Y9|60f|x}) for a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} before leaving the cemetery.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: The nightly assaults of the shambling dead cease, and uneasy quiet returns to Wickermoor Village. When Mori Shade discovers the news about the loss of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}, she grieves in her own stoic way but goes about seeking a new caretaker for Maidenmist Cemetery. She considers taking up the role herself if she cannot find a suitable volunteer or apprentice.

{@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} approaches the characters with a look of relief and tells them that she had seen a vision of a massive swarm of spirits tearing through Wickermoor Village, and she incorrectly guesses that this was a future that was stopped with the defeat of {@creature The Chained Reaper|CrookedMoon24}.

With all of the Fallen destroyed, Golub Graygullet prepares to make her move if her disguise as Theodora Mayville has not yet been exposed. The pigeons of Theodora Mayville roost all over the village now, having grown extremely aggressive against the songbirds drawn to the newly erected chapel of {@area the Brightsingers|03b|x}. Dozens of songbirds are found dead every night, and Weston Murdoch tries to put an end to the avian war.

data.name: The Roving Rookery

entries: Mother always said that my lilac eyes were bad luck. That I was born bewitched and would be led to wickedness. But Miss Mayville says they're blessed and a sign that greatness is in my future. She loves my eyes. She hired me because of my eyes, you know.

Evil nests in Wickermoor Village. Folk go about their daily routines, and the pigeon hag watches and waits for the return of the Crooked Queen. She hides in plain sight amongst them, lea{@s }rning everything they know and guiding what they believe. Golub Graygullet, disguised as Postmaster Theodora Mayville, subtly controls the flow of information and manipulates the minds of the people so that they fall in place when the time is right to free Kehlenn. Until then, she bides her time and pulls the strings, every moment filled with haughty contempt.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: A master plan is in the works, hatched by Golub Graygullet, who arrived in town seventy years ago with her dovecote that can secretly walk about the valley on pigeon legs. After the characters arrived in Druskenvald, she knew the time for sacrifice had arrived. Pulling the strings of the people of Wickermoor Village like a puppet master, she has helped guide the townsfolk's interactions with the characters every step of the way through news carried by the pigeons she commands.

Believing herself to be the true mastermind behind the Crooked Queen's return, she sought the destruction of the Fallen and even betrayed her two sisters, understanding their deaths to be critical sacrifices to return her mistress to power. However, Golub herself has been deceived. Kehlenn promised the pigeon hag that she would serve at her left hand as a grandmother hag of legendary power, but this was a lie.

The fabled prophecy and sacrificial ritual require one final conjuring from Golub before she herself is slain in sacrifice. Soon, she will be reborn with her sisters as a horrific abomination in the bowels of {@area the Crooked House|6f7|x}. The minds of the townsfolk, so subtly influenced for years, must be made perfectly malleable for the revelry of the coming {@area Lord of Fools|681|x} and celebration at the feet of the Wicker Man atop {@adventure Rowan's Rise|CrookedMoon|16}.

One final bewitching enchantment is brewing to cause a mass hysteria whipped up by a sudden murder in town. It is through the violent urges of the agitated mob that Golub plans on finally disposing of the characters, whom she views as pawns that have outgrown their usefulness.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: A shocking murder blamed on the characters whips the people of Wickermoor Village into a frenzied mob but was, in truth, caused by a bewitching enchantment cast by the pigeon hag, Golub Graygullet. Once the town descends into mass hysteria, she escapes in her Walking Dovecote, sending mind-broken monsters to wreak even more havoc. Before the village burns and its townsfolk tear each other apart, the Walking Dovecote must be found, and Golub must be killed. Characters spurred to seek out the dovecote by the {@area Quest Hooks|65a|x} later in this chapter have these goals:

items: Escape unjust imprisonment by the people of Wickermoor Village.
Uncover the true identity of Golub Graygullet.
Track down the Walking Dovecote and destroy Golub Graygullet.

entries: This chapter is designed for four level 10 characters.

entries.name: The Pigeon Hag
entries: Golub Graygullet whispers to the numerous pigeons that flock about her, spreading them throughout Wickermoor Hollow and beyond to deliver and receive letters. Her whispers and enchanting spells also manipulate people of all variety to her cause, and she even possesses the power to make mighty monsters her minions.

entries.name: Golub Graygullet
entries: {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24}) is the leader of the Vermintoll Coven, as well as the eldest and most powerful of the three hags. Her short and stout body resembles the pigeons she adores, with taloned fingers, a beak-like nose, a puffed-up neck, and mauve skin.

Just as it was her sisters' roles to corrupt the soul and body of sacrifices to the Crooked Queen, Golub corrupts her victims' minds through the control of information and magical enchantments she weaves. A malignantly proud creature, Golub views every mortal as merely a pawn, tool, or puppet to help advance her own aims, viewing her tactics of seeking, manipulating, and distributing information as far more tasteful than the more uncouth methods favored by her sisters.

Golub is obsessed with not merely acquiring information, which she primarily gathers through the eyes and ears of her pigeon spies, but in controlling its flow. Every written communication in Wickermoor Village passes through her hands, and she alone decides what is passed on, withheld, or altered. She listens, watches, and whispers from her perch in the Walking Dovecote, choosing whether to deliver truths or lies that aid in her grand designs, even among the Vermintoll Coven and cult of the Crooked Queen.

Preferring the comforts of town and leveraging the close proximity to the victims of her mental corruption, Golub lives among the people of Wickermoor Village disguised as {@area Theodora Mayville, the postmaster|180|x}. To ensure a more reliable and long-term disguise, she wears the skin of the person she impersonates, needing to change bodies every decade or so to avoid drawing suspicion. The one thing she cannot change between personas is the vibrant lilac eyes cast by her bewitching enchantment. When Golub uses a victim's skin, the disguise is flawless and can't be perceived as false, even through magical means, which detect her as a Humanoid. Golub also has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) checks while in this disguise.

entries.name: Peeping Albert
entries: {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}) is Golub's pigeon familiar, a pudgy bird that eerily resembles a person, with a wrinkled bald head, human-like ears, and hands instead of talons. He serves as Golub's most precious child and her chief spy. Albert gains a sick satisfaction from peeping on the townsfolk of Wickermoor Village and listening in on their conversations, eagerly awaiting the praise he'll receive when he reports back to his mother.

Sharing Golub's distaste for the weasel hag and centipede hag, Albert has a puffed-up superiority complex and looks down on his counterparts Filthy Jasper and Slippery Oswald. When the vile pigeon familiar is not spying on the villagers, he is always seeking new young women with lilac eyes so that Golub can prepare her next disguise.

entries.name: Geneva Fairchild
entries: {@creature Geneva Fairchild|CrookedMoon24} (Lawful Good, human {@creature Commoner|XMM}) had a difficult upbringing in a superstitious household that believed her lilac eyes were an ill omen. Despite the strained relationship with her parents, Geneva grew into a compassionate and hardworking young woman in large part due to the tutelage of her mentor Theodora Mayville.

Theodora, who had lilac eyes herself, instilled in Geneva a pride for her unique feature that some in Wickermoor Village saw as a sign of malign witchcraft. The young apprentice to the postmaster learned everything she could about mail, freight, and even river shipping, eventually becoming an invaluable assistant in the post office's day to day business.

However, Geneva's true role in assisting Theodora is serving as the unwitting next form of Golub Graygullet. The pigeon hag had not been planning on making the change to a new disguise for several years, but the characters' arrival in Wickermoor Hollow has hastened her timeline. If the characters do not expose Theodora before the last of the Fallen has been destroyed, young Geneva is killed, her skin worn by Golub as a younger and more unassuming disguise.

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: Whether or not the characters discover Theodora Mayville's true identity throughout the adventure, Golub Graygullet makes her move, turning the townsfolk against them and attempting to escape in her Walking Dovecote. The primary quest hook, "A Murder Most Fowl" below, occurs sometime after the defeat of {@area the Chained Reaper|638|x}. If the characters uncover the true identity of Theodora Mayville before the Chained Reaper is defeated, see "{@area Postmaster Exposed|65e|x}" later in this chapter.

entries.name: A Murder Most Fowl
entries: While the characters are in Wickermoor Village, they are approached by Geneva Fairchild, who is in a blubbering panic. She tells them that she found Theodora Mayville murdered in the post office and is scared to go to the constable's station because of Constable Squire's callous nature and previous distrust for Geneva's lilac eyes. She fears that because she was the last person seen with Theodora, she will be blamed for the murder, so she asks the characters to help her investigate the scene.

In truth, Geneva Fairchild is dead, and her skin is being worn by Golub Graygullet the {@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24} (as detailed in "{@area Golub Graygullet|657|x}" previously). The false Geneva takes the characters to the {@area post office|180|x}, which has been locked ({@dc 15}). A large "Closed" sign hanging over the door. Within, the stench of death is heavy in the air, and the corpse of Theodora Mayville is sprawled out on the floor, both of her eye sockets empty. As an action, a character who examines the corpse and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check determines that, while the corpse maintains a normal form, it has no bones or internal organs. In truth, this "second skin" is all that remains of Golub's former disguise.

entries.name: The Master Stroke
entries: This is a deception to turn the townsfolk against the characters. Before seeking them out, Golub sent a letter to the constable's station from Theodora Mayville, accusing the characters of threatening her and Geneva with violence and claiming that the pair feared for their lives. A posse of townsfolk led by Constable Squire and Deputy Butterman make their way to the post office while the characters investigate.

Geneva lingers by the door of the post office, never moving deeper into the room. When the characters discover that Theodora's corpse has no bones or organs, if they accuse Geneva of foul play, or if enough time has passed for the posse to get close, read or paraphrase the following:
Suddenly, Geneva lets out a bloodcurdling shriek.

"They killed her! They ripped out her eyes! They're coming for me! Please help!" She then looks at you with a sinister smirk before her body contorts with a sickening pop. A burst of pigeon feathers erupts around her, and she collapses to the floor, her empty eye sockets staring blankly.

A cacophonous creaking draws your attention to the window that looks out the north side of the post office. Down the road, the town's dovecote lurches back and forth, then suddenly rises into the air, held up by enormous, grotesque pigeon legs that protrude from its underside. Gray, feathery wings erupt from its shingled roof as the legs begin to strut away from Wickermoor Village, hopping through the air as its wings flap rapidly.
From the direction of the Founder's Round, you hear the agitated shouting of at least a dozen angry voices.

Golub casts {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} to teleport to the Pigeon Roost ({@area area R2|674|x}) of her Walking Dovecote, commanding it to use its {@action Dash|XPHB} action to flee from Wickermoor Village (see "{@area Walking Dovecote Features|66c|x}"), heading northward through the moors. It is unlikely that the characters can catch up to the dovecote at this time, but if they do, see "Walking Dovecote" later in this chapter.

The corpse of Geneva Fairchild remains on the floor of the post office, her eyes removed. Characters who examine the remains can determine that there are no bones or organs in the same manner as Theodora Mayville's body.

The posse of townsfolk consists of twelve {@creature Tough|XMM|Toughs}, led by Constable Doris Squire (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Knight|XMM}) and Deputy Howie Butterman (Neutral Evil, human {@creature Spy|XMM}). They have been bewitched to be {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, and fail to notice the escaping dovecote. If the characters confront the mob, Constable Squire produces the letter from Postmaster Mayville containing the accusations of threats.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who observes the crowd and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check can discern that they have been {@condition Charmed|XPHB} with magic. The characters may be able to talk their way out of the situation, but if any of the posse see the corpses of Theodora Mayville or Geneva Fairchild, they attack and attempt to apprehend the characters to face trial for murder.

entries.name: Postmaster Exposed
entries: If the characters confront Postmaster Theodora Mayville—who is actually the {@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24} Golub Graygullet in disguise—before she kills Geneva, she attempts to dissuade the characters from their accusation and alleviate suspicion. In truth, Theodora is dead and her skin is being worn for a flawless shapeshifted form (as detailed in "{@area Golub Graygullet|657|x}" previously).

If the characters persist in their accusations of villainy or attack Theodora, Golub is forced to act. She lets out a sinister cackle and casts {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} to teleport to the Pigeon Roost ({@area area R2|674|x}) of her dovecote, which she commands to rise on its pigeon feet and flee Wickermoor Village. The corpse of Theodora Mayville is left behind, its eye sockets empty.

A character who inspects the body and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check discovers that while the corpse keeps its form, it has no bones or internal organs. It is up to the characters to decide how they deal with the corpse and the postmaster's disappearance.

In her employer's absence and following the shocking disappearance of the dovecote, Geneva Fairchild attempts to take over as the town's new postmaster, swapping to mail delivery by rider on horseback. This persists while the characters continue their adventures and defeat the Fallen. On their travels, they might see the transformed dovecote walking far off in the distance, but never drawing near until the time is right.

Once the Chained Reaper is destroyed, Golub makes her move and bewitches the town with a charm. Geneva accuses the characters of plotting to assassinate Mayor Somerton and whips the town into a violent mob.

entries.name: The Mob Rules
entries: The people of Wickermoor Village have been bewitched by Golub Graygullet and now believe the characters to be murderers and assassins, following the events of either of the two main Quest Hooks of this chapter (see "{@area A Murder Most Fowl|65b|x}" and "{@area Postmaster Exposed|65e|x}" above).

entries.name: Mass Hysteria
entries: Wickermoor Village's townsfolk have had mixed opinions about the characters since they arrived, with many unsure what to make of the newcomers who seemingly brought so much bad luck and death to the valley. However, spurred on by the accusations of murder and the enchantments of Golub Graygullet, they are now united in blaming the characters for their ills.

Until Golub Graygullet is destroyed, all of Wickermoor Village's inhabitants are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters. The streets are patrolled by groups of people at all hours of the night seeking the "murderers" that brought misfortune to their home. Each angry mob that wanders throughout the town consists of twelve {@creature Tough|XMM|Toughs} led by three {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Veterans}, which attack the characters on sight and cannot be reasoned with. They will initially attempt to knock the characters {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} for imprisonment to stand trial, but if any villagers are slain by the characters, they fight to the death.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who observes the villagers and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check deduces that the mob is bewitched by an enchantment. The charm is powerful, but the use of {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} or {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} is enough to suppress the effects of the enchantment for one hour. Once the hour has passed, the villager loses their sense once more and is whipped up into a frenzy against the characters.

entries.name: The Stealthy Approach
entries: Although the village is crawling with angry townsfolk at all times, the characters can attempt to sneak through town. For every 10 minutes spent in Wickermoor Village, the characters must succeed on a group {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check or be detected by a wandering mob (see "{@area Mass Hysteria|660|x}" above). The DC lowers to 10 if they hide within a building or similar structure to allow these mobs to pass, though nearly every door and window has been locked.

If the characters are staying at the Green Queen Inn, any possessions left in their rooms are removed and kept in the inn's storage room. The door to the room is locked but can be picked with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}.

entries.name: The Birds
entries: Although the dovecote has walked off from Wickermoor Village, numerous pigeons roost on the roofs of every building in town. Golub can speak through them, regularly taunting the characters as they stealthily navigate town. Characters who attempt to climb on the roofs of any building or spend more than one hour outside in the open are attacked by four {@creature Squabswarm|CrookedMoon24|Squabswarms}.

{@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}) remains in town as long as the characters are there, attempting to spy on them and commanding the mundane pigeons in service of their mistress. He can be spotted with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check and flees if attacked.

entries.name: Powder Keg
entries: The charm on the people of Wickermoor Village continues to increase in its potency as long as Golub Graygullet lives. While the town is united in its vitriol against the characters, it won't be long until they turn on each other as accusations fly regarding the aiding and harboring of the characters.

If the charm persists for one week after first afflicting the townsfolk, tensions boil over and violence breaks out. Four townsfolk, including one named NPC (see {@area Wickermoor Village|159|x}) are killed in the conflict. Three homes and one named location are burned beyond repair. For every subsequent week that passes, the number of people killed and buildings destroyed doubles.

entries.name: Hunting the Hag
entries: Golub Graygullet's Walking Dovecote strides across Wickermoor Hollow, occasionally settling down and moving on once more. The hag weaves her spells and bides her time until the characters are destroyed and Wickermoor Village is overwhelmed with mass hysteria.

entries.name: The Rookery Roves
entries: After making its escape, the Walking Dovecote settles down in a new location so that Golub can devote her focus to her ritualistic work corrupting the townsfolk's minds. The range of the hag's spellcasting is not limitless, so the dovecote never strays too far from Wickermoor Village. It is always a three-night journey away from town traveling at a Normal pace, favoring areas not far from human settlements so that Golub always has access to new minds to corrupt.

To determine where the dovecote has settled, roll on the Rookery Roost table below. It stays in that location for three nights before moving on once more, its next destination determined by the Rookery Roost table, rerolling the result of its previous location.

entries.caption: Rookery Roost
rows: Rolling Prairie
Murky Swamp
Barren Foothills
Stormy Lakeshore

entries.name: Wild Pigeon Chase
entries: Characters can watch the skies for pigeons to track down the elusive Walking Dovecote. The birds follow distinct routes across Wickermoor Hollow, forming patterns that can be followed directly to Golub Graygullet. Characters keeping their eyes skyward and actively looking for Golub's pigeons can roll {@dice 1d6} every hour, spotting one on a 6. Characters who observe the pigeon can discern the location of the dovecote with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check.

If the characters hope to catch Golub unawares, they must avoid the watchful eyes of {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}). Every night of travel, the characters must succeed on a group {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check or be spotted by the pigeon familiar. Characters who keep their eyes to the sky and succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notice Peeping Albert flying 250 feet away. He will attempt to flee and warn Golub, and if he is not killed, the Walking Dovecote moves onto its next destination early (see "{@area The Rookery Roves|665|x}" above), uprooting itself and moving on that very night. The characters can see the dovecote walking in the far distance and must track it to its new location once more.

While Golub weaves her sinister spells and continues to twist the minds of the townsfolk of Wickermoor Village, she also dominates the minds of monsters and communities near the Walking Dovecote's present location and sends them into the wilds to harry the characters' travel. Every night that the characters travel while seeking Golub Graygullet, there is a 50 percent chance that the hag's minions find them and attack. The creatures that can attack are determined by the dovecote's location.

entries.name: Rolling Prairie
entries: The Walking Dovecote rests in the rolling grasslands past Foxwillow and close to the border of Wickermoor Hollow. If the characters are attacked while the dovecote is here, roll on the Prairie Creatures table below to determine what attacks.

entries.caption: Prairie Creatures
rows: Three {@creature Fire Elemental|XMM|Fire Elementals}
Four {@creature Ettin|XMM|Ettins}
Ten {@creature Dire Wolf|XMM|Dire Wolves}
Two {@creature Shield Guardian|XMM|Shield Guardians}
Five {@creature Nightmare|XMM|Nightmares}
Six {@creature Bandit Captain|XMM|Bandit Captains}

entries.name: Murky Swamp
entries: The Walking Dovecote lurks just within the Drowned Crossroads, sitting right on the murky water far from prying eyes. If the characters are attacked while the dovecote is here, roll on the Swamp Creatures table below to determine what attacks.

entries.caption: Swamp Creatures
rows: Two {@creature Mage|XMM|Mages}
Three {@creature Troll|XMM|Trolls}
Two {@creature Giant Crocodile|XMM|Giant Crocodiles}
{@creature Clay Golem|XMM}
{@creature Hydra|XMM}
Three {@creature Water Elemental|XMM|Water Elementals}

entries.name: Barren Foothills
entries: The Walking Dovecote looms high in the chilled air of the foothills at the base of the Howlers, not far from Dawn's Gate. If the characters are attacked while the dovecote is here, roll on the Foothill Creatures table below to determine what attacks.

entries.caption: Foothill Creatures
rows: {@creature Stone Golem|XMM}
Six {@creature Ogre|XMM|Ogres}
Ten {@creature Giant Vulture|XMM|Giant Vultures}
Three {@creature Earth Elemental|XMM|Earth Elementals}
Two {@creature Wyvern|XMM|Wyverns}
Five {@creature Knight|XMM|Knights}

entries.name: Stormy Lakeshore
entries: The Walking Dovecote sits on the rainy northern shore of Moonsong Lake, a short distance from the tree line of Hartsblight Forest. If the characters are attacked while the dovecote is here, roll on the Lakeshore Creatures table below to determine what attacks.

entries.caption: Lakeshore Creatures
rows: Three {@creature Air Elemental|XMM|Air Elementals}
Two {@creature Oni|XMM}
Ten {@creature Giant Spider|XMM|Giant Spiders}
Two {@creature Flesh Golem|XMM|Flesh Golems}
Three {@creature Chuul|XMM}
{@creature Assassin|XMM}

entries.name: Walking Dovecote
entries: When the characters complete the journey to the Walking Dovecote before it moves on and without being detected by {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}), they find the structure on the ground of whatever setting it has settled in.

You've finally arrived at the dovecote of Golub Graygullet, its shingled walls and thatched roof marked by the droppings of the numerous pigeons that flutter around the tall, circular structure. Despite having been on the run, it now sits motionless.

The circular building has a thatched roof, and its external walls are clad in wooden shingles. It spans 40 feet across and 40 feet tall, but it rises to 50 feet in height once it stands on its birdlike legs.
If the characters attack Golub within the dovecote, it animates and begins running and flying during the battle (see the "Animated Building" feature below).

entries.name: Walking Dovecote Features
entries: The Walking Dovecote has the following features:

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The dovecote is illuminated by {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} from grimy lanterns.

items.name: Animated Building
items.entry: The dovecote is an animated building that responds to Golub's commands (no action required by her). When she wakes it, it stands up on giant pigeon legs that lift the lowest floor 10 feet off the ground, and it unfurls stubby pigeon wings from its roof. It has a {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} of 50 feet and a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB}  of 100 feet, but it must land at the end of its turn. It moves during Golub's turn as she directs it. Golub can give the dovecote simple commands it follows without her being present to oversee it. The dovecote settles when commanded or if it has no other instructions from Golub. A creature underneath it when it lands or settles must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 27 ({@dice 5d10}) Bludgeoning damage and have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. The cramped crawlspace under the dovecote is sized for Small creatures. If Golub dies, the dovecote settles down where it is and permanently de-animates.

items.name: Violent Lurches
items.entry: If the characters are inside the dovecote while it animates, such as if they attack Golub here, on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) any creature other than {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24|Golub}, {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24}, or any {@creature Squabswarm|CrookedMoon24|Squabswarms} (see "Creatures" below) must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: R1: Parcel Storage

entries: You enter what once was a storage room for the post office of Wickermoor Village. Countless letters scatter the ground amidst a jumble of crates and parcels that have been jostled about by the lurching steps of the dovecote. Open windows shed moonlight across the room.

The ground floor of the dovecote serves primarily as storage for extraneous supplies from the post office—letters and packages that lingered unclaimed long enough to be forgotten—and supplies for the carrier pigeons.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: The floor is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} due to the haphazard supply piles and the occasional slippery patch of pigeon droppings.

entries.name: Floor Access
entries: A single ladder leads to the second floor.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Golub's familiar, {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Vermin Familiar (Pigeon)|CrookedMoon24}), likes to nest among the abandoned parcels and letters. He lurks here and attacks the characters when they intrude in his home, terrified of what his mistress will do if he allows interlopers to disturb her after failing to spot their approach. He calls forth three {@creature Squabswarm|CrookedMoon24|Squabswarms} to assist him.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The room contains sacks of seed, spools of thin leather cord, straw, wire mesh, and a set of Carpenter's Tools for upkeeping the rookery. The Mysterious Packages table offers some examples of what the packages and crates contain.

entries.caption: Mysterious Packages
rows: A set of Fine Clothes and a gold pocket watch worth 150 GP
4 cannisters that each contain the following seasonings: salt (5 CP each); ginger (1 GP each); cinnamon (2 GP each); pepper (2 GP each); cloves (3 GP each); saffron (15 GP each)
A bag of trinkets: three raven feathers bound by silver thread, a cracked hand mirror etched with the initials E.A.P., and a glass bottle containing a miniature sailing ship
A crate of 12 bottles of fiery spirits (20 GP each). Two of the bottles are {@condition poisoned|XPHB}, each one acting as a {@item Potion of Poison|XDMG}
A set of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB}, an {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, a {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB}, and two {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing}
An assortment of small taxidermy animals: a giant rat, a weasel, a skunk, and a black cat
A large box of moldy straw, containing three {@creature Swarms of Spider|XMM|Swarms of Spiders}
A {@item Toy Riverboat|CrookedMoon24}

entries.name: R2: Pigeon Roost

entries: The floor is scattered with straw, birdseed, and pigeon droppings. The low, constant cooing of pigeons fills the space with an unsettling lullaby. Numerous cubbyholes where the birds roost are built into the walls of this tall chamber, reaching all the way up to a circular wooden walkway that rests on the rafters. A tall ladder against the wall is locked into a track that allows it to swivel around the circular room and provide access to each roost cubby.

This level serves as the rookery for the carrier pigeons, with roosts and cages lining the perimeter of the space. Constant squeaking can be heard over the rustling of feathers from the cages containing small rodents, which are kept as treats for the birds.

entries.name: Rafter Roost
entries: Tucked up in the rafters is a wooden platform covered in old straw and cloth. This is Golub's roost, where she rests, performs her bewitching magic, and bides much of her time. Four large windows look out from the roost, which allows Golub to spot intruders. However, she prefers to focus on her witchcraft and leave the sentry duties to Peeping Albert.

entries.name: Stashed Secrets
entries: Numerous cubbies on this level have been cleared of their roosting materials and instead are stuffed with the letters, journals, and other documents that Golub secreted away in her quest to acquire information on every inhabitant in Wickermoor Village.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This is where {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24}) spent her time while not performing the postmaster duties of Theodora Mayville. Now, it is her personal sanctum, and the sanctuary for her {@spell Word of Recall|XPHB} spell. The pigeons in the roosts, out on the roof, and flying near the dovecote comprise three {@creature Squabswarm|CrookedMoon24|Squabswarms} that amass and rush to Golub's defense if she's threatened. If {@creature Peeping Albert|CrookedMoon24} is still alive when combat begins, he joins the fight as well. Battle here prompts the cottage to stand up and run or fly (see "{@area Dovecote Cottage Features|66c|x}" above).
When combat begins, read or paraphrase the following:

A shrill and haughty cackle reverberates through the dovecote as numerous pigeons take wing, turning the inside of the dovecote into a storm of feathers. A sudden lurch causes the entire structure to shake as the building is lifted into the air on enormous pigeon feet. The wrinkled, bloated face of Golub Graygullet leers at you with utter contempt as she takes to the air and cries, "Your minds are such fragile little things! They will be broken! They will be mine!"

Golub fights viciously in her home, delighting in paralyzing foes with {@spell Hold Person|XPHB} and then tossing them out of the windows, possibly while the dovecote soars through the air high above the ground.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Tucked away in Golub's roost are a gold birdcage worth 500 GP, a chest of gold nuggets from Skitterdeep Mine worth 1,000 GP, a diary detailing the locations of homes or businesses for most of the inhabitants of Wickermoor Hollow, a crystal ball worth 1,000 GP (suitable for casting {@spell Scrying|XPHB}), and a vial with one dose of {@item Midnight Tears|XDMG} poison. Stashed in the cubbies are a great collection of secrets about many of the citizens of Wickermoor Village, ranging from minor embarrassments to damning sins—including the various cults and factions to which they belong (see {@adventure the Crooked Moon|CrookedMoon|1} and {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}).

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Sun|072|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}," the character who pulled this card increases one of their ability scores by 2 after defeating Golub Graygullet. The score can't exceed 24.

entries.name: Conclusion: Home to Roost
entries: When Golub is slain, the dovecote immediately settles down wherever it is, the pigeon legs and wings withdraw into its frame, and it becomes a mundane building never to move again. If Peeping Albert is alive when his mistress is slain, he joins her in death.

With Golub defeated, her influence on the people of Wickermoor Hollow immediately fades, leaving folks in stunned confusion and with little memory of any wrongdoings. The villagers try to piece together what has happened but feel befuddled by the nights spent in their bewitched fervor. This has left their minds ripe to be manipulated once more—next time by the Lord of Fools himself.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: Many of the mundane pigeons that had once been controlled by Golub return to Wickermoor Village, roosting on the roofs around town, allowing an enterprising new postmaster to attempt to reestablish mail delivery. If Geneva still lives, she is up to the task.

Phillip and Adela Druskenvald, who had avoided the worst of the mob violence due to the townsfolks' fear of the Crooked House, which persisted even under Golub's charm, offer to help fund the repairs to anything damaged during the mass hysteria.

The townsfolk realize that the beloved Festival of Fools is about to come to town, perfect timing in light of the recent misery and wrath. Preparations start to be made, costumes are pulled from dusty chests, and decorating begins; the people of Wickermoor Village eagerly await the mirth and revelry.

data.name: Fool's Day

entries: I scream! You scream! We all scream in the fires of The Horned King's return! They always say that anyone who would be king for a day is a fool for a lifetime, but what's so bad about being a fool?! Everyone should be a fool for a day at least once in their miserable lives!

What joy there is when a clown comes to town! Though Wickermoor Hollow is draped in shadow and fear, the lights of the Fool's Day Festival pierce the gloom. Of all the celebrations in Wickermoor Village, none is more cherished—rife with costumed revelers, dancing bears, grand feasts, and lamplight dances.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: Ignore the sinister fact that people vanish each festival night. Fix your gaze on the brilliant, many-colored lanterns and the ever-grinning Chuckles the Clown! Those cries in the night? Simply howls of delight, nothing more. The Fallen are defeated! The Fool's Day Festival will be happy. It must be happy. The parade is coming, and you will be so, {@i soooo} happy.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: The Fool's Day Festival consumes Wickermoor Village, led by Chuckles, Lord of Fools. This wicked clown has a perverse death wish and seeks to goad the characters into slaying him as his own ritual sacrifice. While he brings joy to the townsfolk, Chuckles delights in mocking the characters, belittling their previous exploits, and even attacking villagers they care about, so long as it brings them one step closer to killing him. The characters' goals are:

items: Play carnival games to earn tickets.
Rescue the forced revelers through tickets or combat or by severing their enchantments.
Free Phillip and Adela Druskenvald from their forced revelry.
Destroy Chuckles, the Lord of Fools.

entries: Before running this chapter, you should review Wickermoor Hollow's townsfolk (see "{@area Forced Revelers|685|x}" below) to decide the most compelling NPCs to include in this chapter. Read through the festival events (see "{@area Festival of Fools Locations|68d|x}" below) so you can smoothly run games for the characters. Finally, study the climactic battle, "Parade of Fools," to fill the encounter with menace and hilarity.
This chapter is designed for four level 10 characters.

entries.name: The Lord of Fools
entries: Chuckles, Lord of Fools, is an evil spirit in clownish guise. He dances and cavorts as the malevolent jester of The Horned King, tormenting mortals for his master's vile amusement. Chuckles's true form is a grotesque balloon with a leering clown's face, draped in multicolored ribbons, usually resting atop a maypole. This totem projects a puppet-like jester illusion that calls itself Chuckles, luring victims into a false sense of security.

entries.name: Tears of a Clown
entries: Once, long ago, a troupe of performers roamed the lands of Druskenvald. Each had their role: Bjorn the Horned Bear, Apia the Queen Bee, Chateau the Dancing Manor, Libro the Singing Tome, Cloche the Chiming Bell, and Cicogna the Stilted Stork. Leading them all was Chuckles the Great Fool.

Though Chuckles played the merry fool on stage, his heart was heavy, for his troupe, though beloved, was starving and impoverished. Clowning brought little coin. His tears caught the attention of the woman with a crooked smile, who whispered of a wonderful king who could erase his troubles if he would become his jester.
Desperate, Chuckles followed the Crooked Queen into the Wytchwood and communed with The Horned King, whose power grew each year. Chuckles, driven by despair, would do anything for his troupe.
"Anything?" asked The Horned King.
"Anything," said Chuckles, foolishly.
"Forever?" asked The Horned King.
"Forever," said Chuckles, sealing his doom.

Chuckles is now nothing more than a spirit dancing futilely at the right hand of The Horned King, yearning for death's sweet release. If Chuckles frees his king, he too is set free. For ages, he has danced, waiting for the Fallen to be sacrificed. Now, he has arranged to be the final sacrifice for The Horned King, just as Adela Druskenvald will be for the Crooked Queen.

This masterstroke will prepare The Horned King's spirit for incarnation through Phillip Druskenvald (see {@area The Crooked Moon|01f|x}), releasing Chuckles from his cursed servitude and letting him dance into the night one last time.

entries.name: Parley with the Fool
entries: The Lord of Fools views life as a cruel, endless joke, trapped in a wretched role as The Horned King's jester. He craves not just the characters' participation in his games but their hatred. Their wrath and other deadly sins are the true feast for The Horned King.
These are some responses to common questions the characters may ask of this wicked clown:

items.name: Who Are You?
items.entry: "Sweet sweeties, I'm Chuckles the Great Fool! There isn't a person alive who doesn't love my japes 'n jokes. So if you don't... then you must already be dead!"

items.name: How Do You Know Us?
items.entry: "Why wouldn't we know who you are? You're known far and wide as the heroes who are finally cleaning up Wickymoor Hollow!" (Chuckles is an agent of The Horned King and has been using {@spell Scrying|XPHB} to observe the characters.)

items.name: Why Are You Happy to See Us?
items.entry: "I'm a kooky-crazy clown, sillies! And it's festy-val time! Can't I enjoy my own party?" (The characters are his only hope of escaping his torturous existence as The Horned King's jester!)

entries: {@b What is this Festival?} "Fool's Day is a way to escape the sad-sad-suffering of this sad-sad-world. Don't you want people to be happy? Besides, this year's festy-val is speci-all." (Fool's Day is an age-old tradition, but this one is special.)

items.name: Special, Huh?
items.entry: "Because of you, my hip-hip-heroes! You're the guests of honor! The cream of the crop! The slayers of the fabulous Fallen! We've never had killers like you in our midst!" (This is the unvarnished truth. Even if it's omitting the bit about the ritual.)

entries.name: Revelers of the Festival
entries: Something is wrong in Wickermoor Village. When the characters arrive back in town from their last adventure, the Fool's Day Festival will begin soon or is already in progress, as determined by you (see "{@area A Puckish Dream|689|x}" below). The Lord of Fools plans to ruthlessly antagonize the characters, turning their former friends from Wickermoor Village into their enemies.

entries.name: Forced Revelers
entries: This chapter works best if the characters have become close with some NPCs in Wickermoor Village.
These NPCs have become bewitched by the Lord of Fools, forced to don garish costumes and party endlessly. The forced revelers:

items: Have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition
Are {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} and are delighted to be a part of the festival in their mesmerized state
Don't become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} or attack unless attacked or forced to make a saving throw

entries: Characters are able to free a charmed reveler by:

items: Cashing in tickets at the Prize Counter ({@area area C3|6a6|x})
Reducing a reveler to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}
Any effect that ends the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition
Bringing them to the Silent Church ({@area area C5|6ac|x})

entries: Select twelve NPCs from the Forced Revelers table or use NPCs that the characters have formed bonds with. These are the forced revelers.

entries.name: Seeking out the Revelers
entries: Hundreds of festivalgoers swarm Wickermoor Village, but only a few wear costumes like those of Chuckles's old troupe, as described in "Tears of a Clown," earlier in this chapter. If the characters search for these figures instead of playing Chuckles's ridiculous games, they can ask around the festival for clues. After spending 1 hour searching, any participating characters make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. Compare the check's total to the "Carnival Cavalcade" table. The characters learn everything up to their total.
When the characters follow these clues, they find all the forced revelers of that type in that area.

entries.caption: Forced Revelers
rows: Bear
{@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Great Beast)
Choose two: Randall Graham, Solomon Roderick, Siv Harga, Hilda Brom
Flag

entries.caption: Carnival Cavalcade
rows: Less than 5
The Festival of Fools is a yearly festival that brings uncharacteristic revelry and delirium to the people of Wickermoor Village.

Chuckles the Clown was the famous leader of a traveling troupe of clowns long ago. He was a dance master who carried a large flag and led six other clowns with their own unique costumes. Revelers with flags were watching the puppet show ({@area area C2g|6a4|x}).
The second-most famous clown in Chuckles's troupe was Bjorn the Horned Bear (BYORN). You saw someone in that costume near the test of strength ({@area area C2e|6a0|x}).
Who could forget Apia the Queen Bee (AY-pee-uh), who dressed like a leggy beehive. There was definitely someone like that in the shooting gallery ({@area area C2a|697|x}).
A niche star of the act was Chateau the Dancing Manor (sha-TOE), a bizarre house on legs. Someone like that was lurking around the drinking contest ({@area area C2f|691|x}).
Cloche the Chiming Bell (KLOESH) was never a popular member of the act, but there was someone dressed like that near the memory game ({@area area C2|699|x}b).

Perhaps the strangest member of the troupe was Libro the Singing Tome (LEE-bro), who pranced around on a pony while singing old rhymes. There was a book-and-pony act in the town square ({@area area C2c|69b|x}).

Easily the most hated member of the troupe was Cicogna the Stilted Stork (chee-KOHN-yuh)—far too creepy for anyone's liking. There were some storks lurking about the rhythm game ({@area area C2d|69e|x}).

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: The festival arrives in Wickermoor Village after the sixth Fallen is defeated and the Vermintoll Coven is destroyed. The events of this adventure take place once the characters arrive back in town. While the characters may not need prompting to return to the village, you can use the following hook to guide them there.

entries.name: I Know What You Did
entries: At the end of their last adventure, a {@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Bell) in full costume finds the characters wherever they are.

She jingles, "Ring-a-ding-ding, you're all so mighty! I have a message, don't be flighty!" She hands them a wax-sealed scroll, lets out a horrible wail as she collapses, and dies. Removing her costume reveals a familiar face from the Green Queen Inn. If the characters use magic to restore her to life, she recalls nothing of the costume, only that a circus had come to town. The message reads:

entries.name: A Puckish Dream
entries: You can determine when the festival arrives in Wickermoor Hollow. To get right into the action, the festival is in full swing by the time the characters return to town after their last adventure, and most of the villagers are already in revelers' costumes that disguise their identities. No one is behaving like themselves.

If you wish to allow the characters some downtime in the village before the festival arrives, they can fall into wild, feverish dreams the night before the festival begins. They see the land of Druskenvald bathed in the light of day, but the sun is the face of a horrific clown. It laughs until blood spurts from its nose and then crashes down onto Wickermoor Hollow, setting the valley ablaze. They awake with a jolt, hearing the festival outside. When they investigate, they are unable to return to the place where they slept (see "{@area Festival of Fools Features|68d|x}" below).

entries.name: Festival of Fools
entries: Wickermoor Village has succumbed to the invasion of the Festival of Fools! Not only is it decorated with countless streamers and ribbons stretching from roof to roof, but the town itself has transformed! The streets are impossibly massive and filled with revelers, and the Founder's Round has gone square! Stalls for food, games, and prizes have been set up throughout. And none are free from the joy this festival brings.

entries.name: Festival of Fools Features
entries: Unless otherwise stated, the Festival of Fools has the following general features:

items.name: Disappearing Act
items.entry: Homes and buildings are missing from where they would normally be. In their place, stalls, stages, and booths have been set up for a festival. When the festival ends, they are once again in their original locations.

items.name: Finger Food Flood
items.entry: All buildings are filled to their ceilings with scotch eggs and hand pies, blocking and preventing entry.

items.name: Hard to Navigate
items.entry: Roads and walkways leading away from the festival are treated as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} (see {@area area C4|6ab|x}). Characters attempting to leave for the first time arrive at the Silent Church ({@area area C5|6ac|x}). Any further attempts to leave the village require a success on a {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check to reach the village limits (see {@area area C4|6ab|x}). On a failure, they find themselves traveling back into the square.

entries.name: Party Hard
entries: All who partake in the festival, willingly or not, are bound by magic and compelled to revel until the Twilight Hour, which won't come until Chuckles wills it (or dies). Festivalgoers push beyond their natural limitations, even to their own detriment. Creatures within Wickermoor Village during the festival have the following benefits:

{@b Life is a Party.} Creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} to resist any spell or effect that would influence them to stop partying. Likewise, creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} to push, shove, or drag creatures back into the festival should they try to leave it before it ends.

items.name: No Wicked Rest
items.entry: Creatures inside the Festival of Fools can't sleep (and magic can't put them to sleep) and can't be affected by the {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} condition until the end of the festival. All creatures in Wickermoor Village instantly gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level when the festival ends.

items.name: Tapped Out
items.entry: Corpses appear as exhausted, drunk, or otherwise passed-out people. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a creature can examine the body and succeed on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check to see through the illusion.

entries.name: C1: Absurd Streets

entries: The town is illuminated like never before. The air is thick with the scents of food and sounds of carnival music. A shrill, manic laughter cuts through the noise and bustle.

As you step into the streets of the village, something feels wrong. The roads seem longer, the buildings more numerous, stretched and twisted as if the town itself has swelled to two or three times its normal size. Familiar streets now appear endlessly duplicated, forming a maze of dreamlike corridors. The townsfolk are replaced by costumed festivalgoers, their numbers growing as you press deeper into the celebrations.

The streets of Wickermoor Village have changed! They are 30 feet wide and twist and turn so there's never more than a 60-foot-long sightline. Throngs of revelers in costume dance and cartwheel, coming closer and closer to the characters. They start pushing, shoving, and urging the characters to meet the "Great Fool" at the center of town. The entire area feels like a claustrophobic fever dream.

entries.name: Follow, Follow
entries: If the characters don't follow the revelers urging them to head to the center of town, their cajoling becomes violent. First, a {@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Great Beast) attacks, bellowing, "Follow! Follow! To the square!" He ceases his attack as soon as the characters obey (or flee). Each round the characters stay in this area, another reveler joins the brawl on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20, as indicated on the Brawl Rounds table.

entries.caption: Brawl Rounds
rows: Round 2
{@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Drone)
Round 3
{@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Hero)
Round 4
{@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Drum)
Round 5
{@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Witch)
Round 6
{@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Bell)
Round 7 and Onward
{@creature Herald of Fools|CrookedMoon24}

entries: Any characters reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by the revelers are knocked {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}—Chuckles needs them alive and participating, after all, even if they're a bit bruised.

entries.name: C2: Festival Square

entries: This part of town is nearly unrecognizable, swallowed by outrageous festival banners and blazing bonfires. Ribbons of green, red, and gold stretch between rooftops, and the streets overflow with costumed revelers.

Stalls host games of skill and chance, and children dart from booth to booth, clutching tickets to exchange for prizes. At the far end of the festival, atop a maypole, a great clown-faced balloon leers over the festivities while dozens dance around the base, winding colorful streamers.
Balancing precariously atop the balloon, performing gaudy flips and dances, is a child-sized wooden marionette in the shape of a jester.

This central square contains the bulk of the festival's activities, from food stalls to games to performances. Characters who examine the area and succeed on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check know that while this used to be the town center, some buildings are outright missing to make room for all the festival pavilions.

entries.name: Meeting Chuckles
entries: The first time the characters arrive here, Chuckles enthusiastically greets them, wanting to welcome them personally to the festival itself. When they first enter this area, read or paraphrase the following:
When the jester puppet catches you watching, he backflips into a net and lands before you with a honk of his red nose.
"Bravissimo, me!" he squeaks, striking an exaggerated pose. "The Great Fool, Chuckles the Clown!" He reaches for your hands and shakes them wildly.

"Welcome! Welcome! And welcome my hip-hip-hoorah-heroes! How goodie-good it is to finally meet you! We've heard a great deal about you, here among the revelry! I'm sure you're flush with questions about my ultimate party."
Chuckles actively engages with the characters but answers any direct questions with misdirection or ignorance (see "{@area Parley with Chuckles|683|x}" earlier in this chapter).
After Chuckles describes why the characters are his honored guests or when the conversation reaches a lull, read or paraphrase the following:
"As I said, I've made this year's Fool's Day super-special for our guests of honor. Your friends? They're all dressed up for a game of hide-and-seek unlike any you've seen.

"Play the games, win tickets—I'll cash their lives in as prizes! Maybe you'll even hunt for them yourselves!" Chuckles's wide grin warps into a sinister sneer. "But if you stop playing, or stop making merry, I'll think you aren't enjoying my festival. And then your costumed friends will lead the parade themselves."
The clown honks his nose, then leaps into the air, bursting into a flurry of ribbons that drift away on the wind.
With his challenge made, Chuckles uses his Ribbon Step {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to disappear into the crowd. From here, the characters choose where to go within the fair.

entries.name: Festival Games
entries: The following games are found within the festival square:

items: A beehive-themed darts game ({@area area C2a|697|x})
A bell-themed cup-and-ball game ({@area area C2b|699|x})
A book-themed riddling game ({@area area C2c|69b|x})
A stork-themed drumming game ({@area area C2d|69e|x})
A bear-themed test of strength ({@area area C2e|6a0|x})
A dollhouse-themed drinking game ({@area area C2f|691|x})
A merry puppet show ({@area area C2g|6a4|x})

entries: These games are operated by revelers not local to Wickermoor Village, doubtless minions of the Great Fool. If defeated, no body can be found within the costume.

entries.name: C2a: Apiary Aim

entries: A festival worker dressed like a beekeeper in a wicker mask stands next to half a dozen dart boards in cabinets. The stall is painted green, and colorful ribbons adorn its sides. The stall worker waves you over to play. A sign says three darts for a copper piece, but before you can pay, the worker holds out three darts to you.

This is a game of accuracy operated by a {@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Drone). Characters playing this game throw three Darts at a target, earning more points based on how high their ranged attack roll against it is, consulting the table below.
After the third Dart toss, they receive a ticket for every five points they earned, with a minimum of one ticket.
Should the hive reveler be killed, no one seems to notice the fighting or pay any attention to the "snoring" reveler on the ground, and a new reveler shows up to take their place running the game.

rows: 14 and lower
Miss (0 points)
Outer Ring (3 points)
Inner Ring (5 points)
25 and higher
Bullseye (10 points)

entries.name: C2b: Bell and Ball

entries: A festival worker wearing a suit decorated with dozens of tiny bells jingles around a circular table that is, itself, covered in large bells.

This is a game of memory operated by a {@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Bell). Anyone playing this game must keep track of which ball is under which bell as the festival worker begins sliding it alongside other bells, attempting to confuse the characters. Those playing who succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Perception|XPHB}) check keep track of the ball and win two tickets!

entries.name: C2c: Riddles and Rhymes

entries: A horse and rider stand before prop bookshelves and books, addressing the audience before him, expecting an answer. A book is propped on the horse, which has blinders on, and the rider is dressed as a knight. When the rider catches your eye, he beckons you over, inviting you to participate.

This is a game of cleverness operated by a {@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Hero). Characters must bet one ticket, after which they are asked a riddle by the operator. If they answer the riddle correctly, they win three tickets. The players can answer the riddle if they puzzle it out, or the character can figure out the solution with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB}) check. Failing to answer the riddle correctly loses them their bet.
Characters can request a harder riddle if they bet two tickets. The DC rises to 18, and answering it awards seven tickets.

entries.name: Asking The Right Questions
entries: As an alternative to two set DCs for riddles, you could also prepare your own set of riddles and assign both ability check DCs and ticket rewards for each one.

entries.caption: Riddles
rows: I wear a cap to keep me dry. When eaten, I'm a real fun guy! What am I?
Mushroom
I have an ear, yet I cannot hear. I stalk for days, so beware my maze. What am I?
Corn
I run hot and I run cold. I'm bright when new, and I'm dark when old. What am I?
Blood
I cube and mince when I'm with a friend. When I'm alone, I meet my end. What am I?
Die / Dice
I wear a hood but have no head. Through bovine eyes, a glare is shed. What am I?
Lantern
I sag with sadness, I beam with glee. I let them choose who they want to be. What am I?
Mask

entries.name: C2d: Rhythm Hero

entries: The reveler running this game appears as a spindly, upright bird, reminiscent of a stork, wearing a set of traveler's clothes and a large drum around its neck. On the counters in front of it are drums and drumsticks matching its own, and to each festivalgoer, it drums a small sequence, waiting for them to play it back.

This game is one of musical ability and skill operated by a {@creature Reveler of Song|CrookedMoon24} (Drum). Participants must repeat a musical pattern back to the operator. Characters participating must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) check or a {@dc 15} Charisma check using a Musical Instrument to repeat a pattern successfully.
Those who succeed on three checks before failing three win five tickets.

entries.name: C2e: Strongarm

entries: This game setup is simple. Across from the table sits a reveler in a large, horned bear costume, adorned with macabre offerings. He sits, elbow on the table, ready to begin arm wrestling with any challengers.

This is a simple game of strength operated by a {@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Great Beast). Characters who participate in this game must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to win an arm-wrestling contest against the operator and earn one ticket.

For those looking for a greater challenge, the bear reveler offers a wrestling match. Characters who accept make a {@dc 25} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a success, they win the match and earn ten tickets.

entries.name: C2f: Wretched Drink

entries: A prop dollhouse standing on carved chicken legs is perched on a table. From its door it produces cup after cup of dour and unpleasant looking drinks, whose consumers make sounds of revile, regret, and disgust.

This is a vile game of fortitude operated by a {@creature Reveler of Stories|CrookedMoon24} (Witch). Anyone who participates in this game is given a mysterious drink to consume, designed to taste horrible. Upon drinking it, they must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw in order not to cough, utter disgust, or otherwise exclaim its unpleasantness; characters who succeed are awarded two tickets. If a saving throw exceeds the DC by 5 or more, they remain utterly stone faced despite the awful taste and are awarded three tickets instead.
Anyone who consumes three or more drinks has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for one hour.

entries.name: C2g: Puppet Theater

entries: This stall is a tall and slim box, decorated in all kinds of fantastical paintings and cloth. From below a large opening and in front of a colorful backdrop, half a dozen hands rise, covered in varying puppetry.
As you watch, it's clear that you are the heroes of this story. One by one, puppets dressed to look like you butcher puppets representing the Fallen, and huge spurts of red ribbons fly everywhere.

This gaudy puppet theater is operated by a {@creature Herald of Fools|CrookedMoon24}. Anyone who sits to watch one of the puppet shows sees that it is portraying the defeat of one of the Fallen at the hands of the characters. Though exaggerated, the details are curiously specific, as if whoever staged the play had been there watching.

The macabre puppet master encourages audience participation in exchange for a reward! Roll on the "Fates of the Fallen" table below to determine which show is performed. Characters can choose to participate in the puppet show from the audience, making the associated ability check. This check is {@dc 20}, but it can be lowered to {@dc 15} if the characters share something personal as defined in the table. On a success, the character wins three tickets.

entries.caption: Fates of the Fallen
rows: Harvest Terror
{@skill Arcana|XPHB}
Share a secret
Crimson Abbot
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Share a guilt
Grinning Sinner
{@skill Deception|XPHB}
Share a desire
Weeping Widow
{@skill Insight|XPHB}
Share a sad memory
Beast of Blight
{@skill Nature|XPHB}
Share a favorite animal
Chained Reaper
{@skill History|XPHB}
Share a ghost story

entries.name: C3: Prize Counter

entries: A stall with paintings of treasure troves, grinning suns, and crowns stands tall, with shelves displaying prizes that festivalgoers claim with tickets. Chuckles mans the booth, giggling as he hands out carved crows, stuffed dragons, and jester outfits. He claps his hands and coos as you approach. "The chippy-chippy-champions, here to save their friends!"
Festivalgoers can exchange their tickets here for toys, trinkets, and tokens on the Prize Counter table.

entries.caption: Prize Counter
rows: Plush of an angry crow
Wooden toy sword painted to be bloody
A pair of crocodile skin shoes
Porcelain doll dressed head to toe in black lace and cloth

Sealed jar of glue. The glue takes 10 minutes to dry after being applied, after which time breaking glued items apart requires a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and a successful {@dc 10} Strength check.
Shovel and pail sized for a child
A single card from a {@item Deck of Illusions|XDMG}
{@item Potion of Healing|XDMG} (greater)
{@item Bag of Tricks|XDMG} (rust) that only produces goats
{@item Revelry Suit|CrookedMoon24}
A random {@filter Paranormal Potion|items|source=crookedmoon24|type=potion}
A random {@filter Cursed Curio|items|source=crookedmoon24|property=cursed curio}
A {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Resurrection|XPHB}
Varies
Free a reveler (see "Exchange Rate" below)

entries: There's only one of each magic item available. But the real point of the booth is for the characters to exchange their tickets for the lives of their twelve friends from Wickermoor Village who have been brainwashed and stuffed into revelers' outfits (see "{@area Forced Revelers|685|x}" earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Exchange Rate
entries: Chuckles frees the first reveler for a measly one ticket. But the second costs two tickets, then the third costs three, and so on. This mounting cost is part of Chuckles's plan to spur the characters to hate and murder him.

entries.name: Obeying the Clown's Orders
entries: Once all twelve of the NPCs who have been trapped in suits have been rescued, Chuckles begins the parade as planned (see "{@area Parade of Fools|6af|x}" later in this chapter).

entries.name: Rebelling Against the Clown
entries: If the characters attack Chuckles before they've rescued all twelve villagers, Chuckles smugly asks, "Are you really sure you want your friends to play in the parade? You must really hate me a lot. Is that tooty-too-true?"

If someone makes it clear that they hate Chuckles, he cackles in glee and teleports to his proper place for the parade, which begins immediately (see "{@area Parade of Fools|6af|x}" later in this chapter).

entries.name: C4: The Roads Out
entries: The roads of Wickermoor Village are twisted and curved by the nightmarish magic of this carnival.
