The first time a character tries to escape the village, they somehow find themselves at the Silent Church ({@area area C5|6ac|x}). On future attempts, they are misdirected back to the Festival Square ({@area area C2|691|x}) unless they succeed on a {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check. On a success, they flee Wickermoor Village, leaving it in Chuckles's wretched clutches until they return.

If they fail this check three times, they're redirected back to the Prize Counter ({@area area C3|6a6|x}) instead, where Chuckles asks them if they're tired of playing. "Has happy-happy-hunting for your friends made you hate me and my games? Should I take us straight to the pippy-parade?" he asks. If they answer yes, see "Parade of Fools" below.

entries.name: C5: Silent Church
entries: Only one place in Wickermoor Hollow is safe from Chuckles's sinister manipulations: the abandoned church. Read or paraphrase the following when the characters enter:
The distant sounds of the festival vanish as you step inside the abandoned church. The party's light does not breach its darkened windows.

Before the humble altar stands a towering statue of a knight, carved from marble and nearly eight feet tall. His stony face is twisted into a scornful grimace. Suddenly, a voice whispers in your mind, echoing through the silence:
"The jester of The Horned King holds no power here, so long as my stone stands. Interlopers, speak truth—who are you, and what purpose brings you?"

This is the Man in Marble, a mythical protector carved in a long-lost, brighter age. Unbeknownst to Weston Murdoch, the church keeper, the Man in Marble channels holy power and has awakened to defend Wickermoor Village. It uses the {@creature Stone Golem|XMM} stat block, except it speaks Common and has an Intelligence score of 14.

The Man in Marble explains that the evil in the village is too strong for him to leave the church, but he protects any villagers that are delivered to him. Bringing forced revelers (see "{@area Forced Revelers|685|x}" earlier in the chapter) to the church suppresses the evil magic that compels them to make merry so long as they remain inside.

entries.name: Resting
entries: This church is a safe place for the characters to rest. They can even take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} here. When they emerge, it's as if no time has passed; everyone is tirelessly partying just as before.

entries.name: Parade of Fools
entries: This climactic event begins once all twelve forced revelers (see "{@area Forced Revelers|685|x}" earlier in this chapter) have been freed or once someone tells Chuckles to his face that they hate him. Use the Ring of Fools map for this battle. Read or paraphrase the following:

The ground trembles as countless partiers stomp to the chaotic rhythm of a devilish calliope playing on an unseen organ. The partiers abandon their revelry, melding into a throng that snakes through the streets. A torrent of dancers, tumblers, and acrobats surges toward you, led by a color guard hoisting effigies on high poles: a scarecrow, a knight, a pirate, a priestess, a satyr, and a gravedigger.
As the parade sweeps through town, two revelers wielding vicious halberds break away, cartwheeling toward you in a whirl of deadly steel!

Roll Initiative! This fight against two masked {@creature Herald of Fools|CrookedMoon24|Heralds of Fools} likely begins in the Festival Square or by the Prize Counter (areas {@area C2|691|x} and {@area C3|6a6|x}).

After these two revelers are defeated, their porcelain harlequin masks shatter, revealing Phillip and Adela beneath. They stand, despite their mortal wounds, and cheerily thank the characters for saving them. A successful {@dc 8} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check reveals that these two are without a doubt Phillip and Adela, but the way they act like nothing is amiss is unsettling; it's as if the wounds and blood are nothing more than stage makeup, and it is clear that the Druskenvalds are in a state of delirium.
Before the characters investigate further, Chuckles cartwheels in. Read or paraphrase the following:

"Whoops!" Chuckles chuckles. "Can't have you seeing these two lovelies before their cue. Exit super-duper-stage-right, please! His Majesty has a bigger role for you!" With a touch, Phillip and Adela burst into streamers, vanishing. "Follow, follow!" he says, pointing toward the maypole.
Chuckles dances toward the center of the festival. Once the characters return to the Festival Square ({@area area C2|691|x}), read or paraphrase the following:

The parade has halted in the center of the festival grounds, and countless revelers form an ominous circle around the square. The stalls are gone. Only the maypole remains, its leering clown face perched above.

Chuckles sits atop the grotesque balloon, but it's not his squeaky voice you hear. Instead, the maypole booms in a deep, growling baritone: "And now, our grand finale. We trust you've come to hate us, since we tailored our pranks and pratfalls just for you! Isn't that right, everyone?" The crowd cheers.
"Yes! Three cheers for the heroes whose murders have primed The Horned King's grand entrance! All that's left is to kill you... or me. Either way, what an entrance."

At least three revelers dance around the maypole. When this fight begins, check how many of the captured villagers (see "{@area Forced Revelers|685|x}" earlier in this chapter) were not saved. They are present here and are magically compelled to dance around the maypole with their masks removed, screaming for help. These minions, whether compelled captives or not, use the {@creature Herald of Fools|CrookedMoon24} stat block, except they have 30 HP and lack the Multiattack action.
Any townsfolk here as forced revelers only break away from the maypole and attack if the characters harm them first. Otherwise, they continue dancing until Chuckles is defeated.

entries.name: Festival Influence
entries: The frantic energy of the revelry peaks as the battle is joined and takes on a life of its own. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the revelry causes one of the following effects; it can't choose the same effect two rounds in a row:

items.name: Join the Dance
items.entry: If there are fewer than three heralds of fools in the battle, one herald of fools (using the adjustments noted above) dances out of the crowd and joins the fight. It acts on the same {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count as the other heralds, or if there are none, on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20.

items.name: Ribbon Bind
items.entry: Ribbons, streamers, or pennants animate and bind victims. Strength Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, up to two creatures in the town square. Failure: The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. The effect ends early if the revelry uses this option again.

items.name: Snack Pelting
items.entry: Carnival foods fling from the crowd and pelt a creature in the square. The creature has a −2 penalty on attack rolls and saving throws to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the next round.

entries.name: Phase 1: Fool for a Day
entries: The bloated clown balloon with its ribbon tentacles is the true body of {@creature The Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24}; the puppet jester form the characters have interacted with so far is a projection of his power and personality. As the battle begins, Chuckles is content to let the characters think the jester image is him and fights with his Joy Buzzer action as much as possible. A character who interacts with the image by attacking, touching, or casting spells on it makes a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, they rationalize the impossible interaction, perceiving an attack to miss, a spell to be resisted, or even to think it was successful. On a successful save, the character realizes the jester is an insubstantial image.

A character who perceives the image for what it is, or one who takes the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the area and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, discerns the balloon is the true villain.
When Chuckles is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, the battle enters phase 2.

The huge balloon painted with the garish face of a clown swells and lifts into the air, ripping its pole from the ground. The mouth moves and speaks with Chuckles's voice as it grotesquely floats and bounces across the festival grounds. "All right, chums, let's do this! It's time for you all to be fools for a day!"

entries.name: Maniacal Bounding
entries: Chuckles grows increasingly agitated and aggressive. At the start of each of his turns, he can jump up to his {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} to an unoccupied space without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} action.

entries.name: No Fun to Die
entries: When Chuckles reaches 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

The head of the jester pops off as if he's been beheaded, letting out a wild, howling wail as the illusion fades, and a headless marionette clatters to the ground. The head of the maypole balloon swells to an enormous size, as if it's being overfilled with air, until it eventually pops off the pole and whizzes high into the sky. It grows smaller and smaller as it soars higher and higher until it explodes in an enormous firework, accompanied by deep, ominous laughter. The outline of a leering clown face formed from glowing motes is visible for just a moment.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 11, if they are still level 10, when they defeat Chuckles.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Magician|04e|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}," the {@item Marotte of the Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24} is found in the wooden hands of the lifeless marionette.

entries.name: Conclusion: Show's Over!
entries: Confetti rains down over Wickermoor Village as the town's streets revert to their normal size and arrangement. Nobody notices the change as Chuckles's enchantments gradually fade away. The townsfolk have a pleasant memory of seeing the festival pack up their wagons and roll out of town, with Chuckles the Great Fool waving goodbye and his whole troupe singing a merry song as they went on their way.
The revelers, the decorations, and all other things that were part of the festivities go up in smoke and glitter. Chuckles is gone forever, finally freed from his obligation to The Horned King.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: The characters and the NPCs rescued during the festival are the only ones who remember the wicked bacchanale. They collapse into well-deserved rest (they suffer 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level). Upon waking, the NPCs gather with the characters to piece together the horrors of the recent nights.

Unbeknownst to the characters, Phillip and Adela have been captured by the Crooked Man and are in the Crooked House, which has reawakened through Kehlenn's ancient power and the rebirth of the Vermintoll Coven.

With the Lord of Fools sacrificed, the Followers of the Old Ways know Adela's time has come. Those loyal to the Crooked Queen vanish from town, moving to the moors north of Wickermoor Village to construct the Wicker Man for the final sacrifice.

data.name: The Crooked Nightmare

entries: Oh Phillip, I had such a terrible dream! I saw this shining, beautiful world we've built turned to ash and smoke. I've had so many nightmares lately. It's this awful house. I just know it!

Nightmares stir anew in the Crooked House. Though slain one by one, the Vermintoll Coven has returned, reborn with the malignant power of Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen. Despite their hatred for one another, the three vile hags have been fused together as one horrific abomination. They now twist the potent dreams of the clairvoyant Adela Druskenvald to fulfill her foretold fate. The house cannot be cleansed and must be destroyed along with the coven to bring the terrors to an end.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: With the destruction of the Fallen and the sacrifice of the Lord of Fools, the next step of the prophesized ritual to turn The Horned King to flesh and free the Crooked Queen from her prison is the sacrifice of Adela Druskenvald. However, her inevitable burning in the Wicker Man atop Rowan's Rise can only occur once her body, mind, and soul have been prepared.

These preparations were the wicked purpose of the Vermintoll Coven before they were slaughtered. However, their malefic spirits lingered, and Kehlenn returned them to abominable life to utilize their twisted magic one last time. Now, they have pulled Adela Druskenvald's prophetic dreams into the Crooked House, weaving them with Kehlenn's primeval power deep in the earth below to turn the entire home into a waking nightmare that has shattered reality itself.

After watching the characters throughout their trials and tribulations in Wickermoor Hollow, the Crooked Man waits for them inside his old home in hopes of adding more sacrifices to the pyre. He knows he will be given a new body just like his Horned King. The night has come for him to incarnate as the Wicker Man, and he only need delay the would-be heroes a little longer.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: The Crooked House has reawakened with the rebirth of the Vermintoll Coven in their new amalgamative form. The {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24} has trapped the Druskenvalds—once again—and the Jenkins within the house. Characters who enter the nightmare have these goals:

items: Approach Druskenvald Manor and ensure the safety of Dani Jenkin.
Enter the Crooked House, confront the Crooked Man, and witness it shatter into the Crooked Nightmare.
Venture through the horrific dreamscapes, rescuing Walter Jenkin, Gilly Jenkin, and Phillip Druskenvald along the way.
Confront the hags of the Vermintoll Coven in the attic of the Crooked House and destroy the Coven Abomination.

entries: Before running this chapter, refresh yourself on the major NPCs, all of which the characters have previously encountered: the Druskenvalds, the Jenkin family, the Vermintoll Coven, and the Crooked Man. Read through the locations and dreamscapes of the Crooked Nightmare to better improvise each encounter.
This chapter is designed for four level 11 characters.

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: After the characters deal with the chaos of the Festival of Fools, they may choose to check in on Phillip and Adela at Druskenvald Manor. Otherwise, follow the Quest Hook below.

entries.name: Prodigal Son
entries: The characters are approached by Old Rusty while they're in Wickermoor Village, hoping to catch them on the edge of town or on the Founder's Round. Read or paraphrase the following:

The groundskeeper Old Rusty stands before you as if he's been waiting for you. His eyes are wide with terror, but there is a hint of lucidity. He speaks in a voice that seems more present and controlled than normal for him.

"I saw him. The man who chopped down my father and mother. He took them. The goat and the lamb. The lord and the lady. The house on the hill dreams. The vermin scurry once more. They are brewing the end of things."

Old Rusty is not fully lucid, but it is clear he is telling the truth. If the characters have not figured out that he is Francis, the son of Joseph and Gail Patrini, a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check allows them to connect the dots.

If the name Patrini is mentioned around him, Old Rusty nods vigorously. The characters then feel a warmth within and hear a distant harpsichord as they fulfill the final request of Joseph Patrini, gaining the effects of the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell for {@dice 1d4} hours (see "{@area H3: Parlor|1dc|x}").

entries.name: Return of the Crooked House
entries: When the characters ascend the hill and enter through the gates of the Druskenvald Estate, read or paraphrase the following:
The state of Druskenvald Manor has changed. The last time you saw it, the supernatural trappings and weird angles of the house had been banished. Now, it is crooked once more.
Screams emanate from the building. Garish red lights shine from windows but then wink out into darkness. The walls leak a slick purple substance.
Striding boldly toward the porch is Dani Jenkin. But before she can move up the undulating steps, her dog, Shuck, leaps out of some writhing bushes and knocks her to the ground.

If the characters try to gauge the dog's behavior or assess the situation, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Insight|XPHB}) check realizes the animal isn't trying to hurt Dani. In fact, it's trying to stop her from entering the house, for the dog is the reincarnated spirit of Sally Lockwood, who knows that the evil spirits and creatures within will overwhelm the young girl.

entries.name: Talking with Dani
entries: Shuck holds Dani back until the characters arrive. Then, the dog lets Dani go, pushing her with its nose toward the characters.

Use the bullet points here to guide a conversation between the characters and Dani. Shuck can also make whatever gestures he can to communicate with the characters. If they cast a spell that lets them talk to animals, use the conversation at the end of this chapter when Sally's spirit is released to guide conversations with Sally via Shuck (see "{@area Conclusion: Dreaming No More|703|x}" later in this chapter).

items: Dani's parents went into the manor house when they heard Phillip and Adela screaming. Right after they went in, the house changed.

Many voices from inside the house are calling for Dani to come into the house to be with her parents. She asks, "Can't you hear the voices?" The characters can't hear the voices unless they succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, in which case the voices are terrifying and unfamiliar.

She can sense the hags are inside and knows they must die, as there is no other hope for the lost souls within. If the characters won't let Dani go in, she begs them to go in and find out what is happening with her parents and the Druskenvalds.
Dani can sense Adela's fear and the nightmares she's having within. She knows that her parents and Phillip are lost in the dream.
She tells the characters that if they can free everyone inside, she can guide them out of Adela's nightmares. She doesn't know how, but she knows she can do it.

entries: When the conversation ends, Dani does whatever the characters instruct her to do, assuming they go into the house to deal with the hags.

entries.name: Into the Nightmare
entries: The characters leave Dani and Shuck behind and enter the horrifying Crooked House to put an end to its evil once and for all.

entries.name: Crooked Nightmare Features
entries: Unless otherwise stated, the areas of the Crooked Nightmare have the following general features:

{@b Infinite Dreams}. The dreamscapes within the Crooked Nightmare defy reality, regardless of the location they seem to take place in. If a creature attempts to leave a location, it finds itself moving back into the location, no matter how far or in what direction it travels.

items.name: Crooked Doors
items.entry: Crooked doors appear throughout the nightmare generally in impossible places. These doors invitingly open to a swirling reddish glow, which a character can step into and disappear, waiting in limbo. Once all characters have stepped through, they arrive at the next area together.

items.name: No Escape
items.entry: The Crooked Nightmare is a demiplane. Spells cast for the purpose of leaving it fail, as do effects that banish a creature to another plane of existence.

items.name: Vermin
items.entry: The Crooked Nightmare is infested with the vermin favored by the Vermintoll Coven. Whenever a character fails a Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, rather than spotting or finding nothing, they discover a weasel, centipede, or pigeon.

items.name: Prophecy
items.entry: Spells that contact creatures or beings on other planes of existence instead return a feverish prophecy from Adela Druskenvald.

entries.name: Crooked Nightmare Locations
entries: The following locations are different dreamscapes within the nightmare, following the encounter flowchart.

entries.name: N1: Crooked Pit
entries: When the characters enter the Crooked House, read or paraphrase the following:

The door closes behind you as you enter the foyer and find it pristine and comfortable, much to your surprise. Then, the false beauty shatters with a loud thud as the Crooked Man drops in from overhead, a noose around his neck. The moment he smacks against the tiled floor, the entire Crooked House shatters apart in a nightmare dreamscape.

A sudden cacophony fills the air as the broken pieces of the house swirl around you. Fragments of wall, floor, and ceiling, as well as furnishings, decorations, and everything else that once filled the ruined manor fly through the space within the house's outer walls.

A chorus of wicked cackling echoes from above, and you see the floorboards of the attic seemingly hundreds of feet away through the debris. The Crooked Man joins in the laughter, and the floor crumbles away. You begin to plummet into darkness.

The {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24} attacks while he and the characters plummet through a seemingly endless pit into the depths below the Crooked House. He cackles and gleefully extols the power of the Crooked Queen that thrives below the house he called home. This fight has the following features:

items.name: Free Fall
items.entry: While falling, the characters and the Crooked Man remain on the same horizontal plane relative to the walls, regardless of their movement. Characters can move on this plane up to their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. Any attempts at flight, gliding, levitation, slow falling, or teleportation fail.

items.name: Slick Walls
items.entry: The earthen walls of the bottomless pit ooze a viscous substance that resembles rotten blood. Any attempts to climb, grab onto, or attach to the walls fail, as do any attempts to slow the falling.

items.name: Crooked Debris
items.entry: Debris from the Crooked House falls amidst the battle. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), one of the pieces of debris flies toward a random character, who must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or suffer the effect rolled on the Crooked Debris table.

entries.caption: Crooked Debris
rows: Clawfoot Bathtub
The target takes 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Bludgeoning damage from the impact.
Bergamot Tree

The roots of the tree wrap around the target. The target takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Bludgeoning damage and has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 17}), and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends.
Family Portrait

The painting sucks the target into it. The target is {@condition Stunned|XPHB}, on another plane of existence, and can't be targeted by attacks, spells, or other magical effects until the end of its next turn.
Stuffed Moose Head
The target takes 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Piercing damage from the antlers.
Grandfather Clock
The clock chimes cacophonously. The target takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Thunder damage and has the {@condition Deafened|XPHB} condition for 1 minute.
Chandelier
The target takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Fire damage and starts burning.

entries: When the Crooked Man is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

The rope tied around the neck of the Crooked Man finally runs out of slack. He jolts with a sickening snap, and you plummet past him, continuing to fall. As his form gets smaller, he lets out a sickening laugh. He calls out above you, his voice echoing in the pit.
"Enjoy the nightmare, friends! If you'll excuse me, I've got to retrieve our little dreamer from the attic and prepare her to be the star of the show in the final act!"

The Crooked Man vanishes as the characters and debris continue to fall. He teleports to the attic, where Adela is sleeping. He aims to take her to the Wicker Man which has finished its construction atop Rowan's Rise in the moors north of Wickermoor Village. Meanwhile, the characters harmlessly land in the middle of a dark woodland.

entries.name: N2: Dark Wood

entries: You land onto the damp floor of a foreboding forest, and despite having fallen what felt like forever, you feel no pain. Feeling the breeze of an autumn night and surrounded by trees of beech, ash, and hickory, you look up and see a full moon with no grinning witch face. You then hear the terrified whimpering of a little girl who calls out seemingly from all directions. "Please help me! I'm lost!"

The child's voice rings out around the characters. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who tries to follow the voice and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB}) check can determine the direction where the voice is loudest.

entries.name: Handprints
entries: Following the sound leads to a tree that is covered in white, child-sized handprints from its roots to a height of three feet up its trunk. Every fifteen feet is a similar tree, forming a path that leads deeper into the woods. Following the trail of trees for 10 minutes leads to a clearing, with the child's voice crying and begging along the way.

You arrive at a small clearing illuminated by the light of the full moon and see a little girl in a white dress. Despite never having seen her before, the girl is hauntingly familiar. Her brown hair falls to her shoulders in curls, and she stares at you with large gray-blue eyes filled with tears while clutching a stuffed toy of a strange creature. "Frederick says he's going to gobble you up..."

The little girl (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM}) is fearful of what her imaginary friend Frederick has been telling her. She explains that Frederick, her doll, is a toy version of a one-eyed beast that looks like a mix between a turkey and dinosaur.

She becomes increasingly nervous if the characters approach, telling them that Frederick is very hungry and wants to devour their flesh. She whispers that Frederick will devour her flesh if she lets go of him. She is scared and doesn't know what to do. Use the Dark Wood map for combat in this area.

entries.name: Little Adela
entries: The mole on the girl's right cheek seems familiar. A character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check deduces this must be Adela Druskenvald as a child.

entries.name: Frederick
entries: When a character moves within 5 feet of Adela's stuffed creature, it instantly transforms into a {@creature Gobblegeist|CrookedMoon24} and attacks the characters. When the gobblegeist is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it reverts to a stuffed toy.

After Frederick is defeated, little Adela apologizes for her imaginary friend and blames the "Bad Bug Lady." At this mention, the cackling voice of Stonoga Blackstinger fills the clearing. Little Adela's eyes go wide, and in an instant, she is dragged screaming by an {@condition Invisible|XPHB} force into the woods.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: When the characters follow the direction little Adela is dragged, they find a strange, crooked door standing on the forest floor, covered in child-sized white handprints. Any attempt to leave the area around the door triggers the Crooked Nightmare's Infinite Dreams feature. The door opens, beckoning to the characters; it lead{@s }s to area N3.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: When little Adela is whisked away, she drops her stuffed Frederick. The toy acts as a {@creature Corn Dolly|CrookedMoon24} familiar.

entries.name: N3: Crooked Oven

entries: Oppressive heat blasts you as you step into an enormous room-sized oven, reminiscent of an oversized version of the one in the kitchen of the Crooked House. Flames roar up in the back of the space, roasting a huge reptilian turkey beast on a spit fastened to the brick walls.

Chained to a second iron spit in the chamber is Gilly Jenkin, her face flushed red as she screams in pain while being slowly cooked alive. To the side of the chamber, turning a large crank that spins the spits, is Stonoga Blackstinger in an obscene mockery of a chef's outfit.

This vision of Stonoga Blackstinger ({@creature Centipede Hag|CrookedMoon24}) cackles with glee, saying there is an art to preparing a body for sacrifice and that Phillip's precious wife will get a more thorough roasting than the turkey they just killed. The hag disappears if she takes any damage.

entries.name: Saving Gilly
entries: Gilly Jenkin is secured to the spit by three heavy, locked chains. Even if the characters don't attack Stonoga, roll Initiative! All three chains must be removed within 10 rounds or Gilly succumbs to fatal burns.

The chains have AC 17, HP 1, a damage threshold of 40, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, Poison, Psychic, and Slashing damage. While trapped by the chains, Gilly can't be targeted by spells or other magical effects.
A chain can be unlocked, broken, slipped, or otherwise escaped with any of the following {@dc 20} ability checks made as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to break a chain
Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} to pick a lock
Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check to find a weak link in a chain that can be easily pried or broken
Other appropriate checks at your discretion

entries: Each round on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} counts 20 and 10 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the oven's inferno sends forth a burst of fire that randomly targets a character or Gilly. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Fire damage. If Gilly is targeted, the number of rounds she can survive decreases by 1. These bursts continue until all characters have left the area or died.

When all three chains are removed, Gilly falls free from the spit. If she is alive, she is terrified and in pain. She reacts as if hearing a voice that the characters can't. She calls out to her daughter Dani, who pulls her out of the dream in a swirl of blue mist.

entries.name: Roast Gobblegeist
entries: The roasting beast on the spit is the monstrous form of the creature that little Adela had called Frederick. Dealing 10 Slashing damage to the roast slices off a portion of delectable meat. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can eat a piece of meat and regain 9 ({@dice 2d8}) {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. Only the first three portions of meat carved off have healing properties.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: After Gilly Jenkin escapes or dies, a crooked door appears in the flames of the oven, leading to area N4. Creatures that pass through the door must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level from the heat. A creature with {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Fire damage automatically succeeds on the save.

entries.name: N4: Smoking Crater

entries: You step out into a cool summer night, a gleaming half-moon above with no trace of crookedness. In the distance. across a small bay, you see the twinkling lights of a sprawling metropolis, its skyline rising high in the night sky. Just up ahead is a massive crater in the countryside, still smoking from whatever formed it. On the ridge of the crater, a strange, colorful glow illuminates a human silhouette that stands and stares at what's within before jumping in and disappearing from view.

When the characters approach the crater, they see a huge, smoking meteorite within, pulsing with every color imaginable—and even impossible ones. A teenage girl slowly approaches the falling star, calling up to the characters without turning to them. "Don't you hear the whispers?! They're calling us home!" Use the Smoking Creater map for combat in this area.

entries.name: Teenage Adela
entries: The voice clearly belongs to Adela Druskenvald (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Commoner|XMM}), though a decade older than her form in the forest. When she arrives at the pulsing meteorite, she stares at it with awe and beckons the characters to join her so they can all travel beyond the stars together. A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check makes it clear that she is enchanted by the fallen star. She is currently {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by the Whispers from Beyond.

entries.name: Whispers from Beyond
entries: When a creature steps over the ridge and into the sloping crater, they hear gibbering, incomprehensible whispers and must make a {@dc 17} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition, and while {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, it must use as much of its movement as possible each round to move toward the meteorite. On a success, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours. A {@condition Charmed|XPHB} creature can repeat the saving throw whenever it takes damage, or at the start of its turns while it can't see the meteorite, ending the effect on a success.

Characters who speak {@language Deep Speech|XPHB} can puzzle out that the whispers are inviting them on a trip through the stars to realms beyond comprehension, but such a voyage requires leaving their bodies behind. Only their minds can make the trip.

entries.name: Space Invaders
entries: The first time a character moves within 5 feet of the meteorite, it cracks and an {@creature Invader Out of Space|CrookedMoon24} rises from within, attacking the characters until it's destroyed. Any Disrupting Touch attacks that hit creatures {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by Whispers From Beyond are {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB|Critical Hits}. Creatures killed from damage in this way are turned to dust except for their brain or equivalent organ responsible for thought.

entries.name: Fallen Star
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the cracked meteorite pulses with its strange, alien colors. Creatures within 60 feet of the fallen star that can see the colors must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or roll on the Fallen Star table to determine the alien experience and its effect. Aberrations succeed on the save automatically.

entries.caption: Fallen Star
rows: The target's mind temporarily travels beyond the stars; it has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.
Incomprehensible whispers gibber in the target's mind. On the target's next turn, it can only take an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, or it can move.
The target sees glimpses of alien landscapes and has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.
The target's psyche begins to fragment in the face of cosmic infinity. Until the end of its next turn, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and attack rolls.
Shrieking otherworldly voices rip through the target's mind. It takes 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Psychic damage.
The indescribable colors linger in the target's eyes. It has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.

entries: When the invader is destroyed, teenage Adela comes to her senses and rubs her eyes as she tries to shake off her stupor, saying that she followed a weird pigeon to get here. At this mention, the shrill screech of Golub Graygullet fills the air, and Adela rockets upward into the night sky, shrieking as she disappears into a twinkling star.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: Once Adela disappears, a crooked door rises from the crack in the fallen star. The characters must climb up the 7-foot-tall meteorite to reach the door, which leads to area N5. A creature that passes through it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Intelligence saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Psychic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: When the door emerges from the meteorite, a glowing chunk of stone chips off and lands at the characters' feet. The fragment is an {@item Ioun Stone|XDMG} (reserve).

entries.name: N5: Crooked Bookshelf

entries: You step out onto an enormous bookshelf as you realize that you've seemingly been shrunk down to a tiny size. You recognize the huge room beyond the opening in the shelf as the library of the Crooked House. Suddenly, the huge, leering face of a monstrous cat blocks the view, its colossal paws clutching the wooden plank you stand upon. The transformed creature you know as Wisp grins at you with razor-sharp teeth.

On the shelf with you is a massive glass decanter. Walter Jenkin is trapped within, terrified. He pounds on the glass and screams voicelessly while standing in waist-deep liquor. Shrieking, bitter voices fill the air, spewing vitriolic hate toward Walter. The chorus is joined by Golub Graygullet, who perches atop the glass stopper of the decanter dressed in an absurd parody of a schoolteacher's outfit. She cackles as she calls out in a mocking tone.

"Poor Walter was such a 'good man.' The most loyal human I've had the displeasure of knowing! But all it takes is a few well-placed lies to make someone forget themselves and become a prisoner of their own making! Can you remind him of his loyalty?!"

The vision of {@creature Golub Graygullet|CrookedMoon24} ({@creature Pigeon Hag|CrookedMoon24}) leers at the characters and crows about the perfected process of preparing a mind for sacrifice, aided by deceitful words and stupefying substances. She gloats that Adela never learned how to control the powerful mind that she didn't deserve, and it has led to her doom. The hag disappears if she takes any damage. Even if the characters don't attack Golub, roll Initiative!

entries.name: Decanter
entries: The glass decanter has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage and can't be moved. Its stopper can't be removed by any means from outside, but it can easily be pressed up from within if Walter chooses to escape. However, the mental torture that he is suffering makes him unaware of this solution and unable to do anything but impotently bang on the glass in agonized desperation.

entries.name: Wisp
entries: Even if the characters previously killed the malicious ketgrinn during the events of {@adventure the Crooked House|CrookedMoon|5}, this nightmare version of Wisp has stolen Walter's voice once more. Now colossal, Wisp grins and speaks with not just the voice of Walter, but also Gilly, Dani, Mayor Somerton, and other townsfolk as you see fit. He spews vicious words to keep the man paralyzed in self-loathing.

Wisp looks into the bookshelf with only his head and paws visible, attacking the characters as he wraps Walter in despair. He uses the {@creature Sphinx of Lore|XMM} stat block with the following changes: his alignment is Chaotic Evil, his size is Gargantuan, his creature type is Fey, and his Claw attacks deal Psychic damage. Wisp vanishes with a yowl if reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Saving Walter
entries: The liquor level continually rises in the great decanter imprisoning Walter. He is terrified and clutches his head in agony. On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 0 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties) on the 10th round, Walter drowns in the liquor.

Only Walter can save himself, but he can't do it alone. He can be snapped out of his nightmare-induced powerlessness by appealing to the most defining aspect of his personality: his sense of loyalty. This can be accomplished through encouragement or by him seeing those he cares about in grave danger. He starts with loyalty 0, and he gains loyalty when any of the following occur:

items.name: Rally (Gain 1 Loyalty)
items.entry: An attack made against Wisp scores a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}.

items.name: Resolve (Gain 1 Loyalty)
items.entry: An attack against a character scores a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, or a character fails a saving throw Wisp forced.

items.name: Victory (Gain 3 Loyalty)
items.entry: Wisp is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

items.name: Encourage (Gain 1 Loyalty)
items.entry: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character succeeds on a {@dc 20} ability check using one of these approaches, or any other that you deem appropriate:

items: Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) to distract Wisp from unleashing more mental torture.
Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB} or {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}) to inspire him to block out the verbal abuse or to pull himself together.
Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB}) to use logic to help Walter realize that the nightmare is full of lies.

entries: When his loyalty reaches 6, Walter snaps himself out of his tortured inaction. He pushes the glass stopper out of the decanter and climbs out, horrifically shaken and scarred but alive. He reacts as if hearing a voice only he can hear and calls out to his daughter Dani, who pulls him from the nightmare in a burst of blue mist.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: After Walter Jenkin escapes or dies, a crooked door appears in an image of Wisp's enormous grin of sharp teeth. To pass through, characters must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Slashing damage. This door leads to area N6.

entries.name: N6: Wedding Feast

entries: You step into the darkness of a moonless night, the faint silhouette of a new moon hanging in the sky above. The scent of springtime flowers drifts through the air along with jubilant music and cheerful voices. Before you lies a wedding feast in the middle of a meadow, filled with a throng of dancing guests dressed in all manner of strange costume, each one bearing an animal mask.

Past the long tables laden with lavish food and drink and the grassy dance ring is a raised dais with the bride and groom. Adela Druskenvald sits in a cumbersome dress and crown of roses in brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow, only her face visible through the flowers. Beside her, tethered to the raised platform, stands the groom, a simple black goat with a leather collar, complete with a dangling bell.

Twenty wedding guests (human {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners}) immediately invite the characters to join them in the dance to celebrate the beautiful union in which the bride and groom have pledged their souls to each other. Characters who agree and dance along with the guests are welcome to move about freely. Characters who refuse must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, the character must join the throng in their dance. Use the Wedding Feast map for combat in this area.

entries.name: Bride Adela
entries: Now a fully grown adult, Adela Druskenvald (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Noble|XMM}) is smiling unnaturally with wide, maddened eyes. She laughs gleefully and calls to the characters, exclaiming, "What a joy it is to give your soul to another!" She invites them to the dais to help her celebrate the wedding by offering her and the goat well wishes and a kiss on the hand and hoof.

entries.name: Black Goat
entries: Adela's immeasurable joy is a direct contrast to the anxious fear radiating from the {@creature Goat|XMM} beside her. It struggles against the rope that tethers it to the dais, trying to get away frantically as its bell jingles. Each character must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}) check. The check has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} if the character is {@condition Charmed|XPHB}. On a success, a character notes that the animal is reacting to something moving through the crowd of wedding guests, as if a predator is stalking near. On a failure, the character is surprised by the imminent attack.

entries.name: Last Dance
entries: When the characters get within five feet of the dais, a {@creature Drakkenhob|CrookedMoon24} emerges from the throng and devours the black goat before attacking the characters. All the guests step aside and form a ring around the battle, watching on with joy and cheering with every blow and death.

entries.name: Wedding Song
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the wedding guests add their music to the song of battle that affects the very soul. All characters must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or suffer the effect of a random instrument from the Wedding Song table.

entries.caption: Wedding Song
rows: Drum. The target takes 13 ({@dice 2d12}) Thunder damage.
Hurdy Gurdy. The target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.
Flute. The target can't make melee or ranged weapon attacks until the end of its next turn.
Fiddle. The target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on saving throws until the end of its next turn.
Jaw Harp. The target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.
Bells. The target can't cast spells until the end of its next turn.

entries: When the drakkenhob is destroyed, Adela's smile fades, and she takes in the garish display before her. She asks where Phillip is and then realizes that she's in the Crooked House. At this mention, the sneering hiss of Vessla Browntooth rips apart the wedding guests in a bloody massacre, and the form of Adela immediately ignites into flame, burning up with her flower gown in an instant while screaming in agony.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: Once Adela disappears, a crooked door, which leads to area N7, rises from the feast table that is now covered in the gore of the slaughtered wedding guests. Passing through the putrid carnage, characters who enter the door must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 hour.

entries.name: N7: Crooked Throne

entries: You step into a frigid, ancient basement you don't recognize, where the ruined, crumbling stone floors and walls are all remarkably crooked and caked with ice. Swarms of wailing souls surge throughout the space like a raging snowstorm. Through the blizzard of spirits, you see Phillip Druskenvald sitting on a throne made of gnarled roots that intertwine all over his body, binding him to his seat. A crooked crown of woven brambles rests atop his head, sending streams of trickling blood down his face. In his right hand, he clasps a burning torch, and in his left, an apple.

Amidst the frigid moans of the damned are the vicious sneers of Vessla Browntooth, who prods and pokes Phillip with a flaming golden sword while dressed like a grotesque mockery of an angel. "You wished to have my home, and now you have it! It's yours, oh great King of All! The lamb... the bride of the King... the clairvoyant is finally ready for the ritual to be ushered in!"

This vision of Vessla Browntooth ({@creature Weasel Hag|CrookedMoon24}) snarls at the characters as they enter the frozen basement, spurning her sisters and claiming they know nothing about properly preparing a soul for sacrifice. The hag disappears if she takes any damage, leaving the sword to clatter to the ground.

entries.name: Saving Phillip
entries: While Phillip Druskenvald (Neutral, human noncombatant {@creature Noble|XMM}) is nearly catatonic and bloodied while encased in choking roots, he is not in true imminent danger. His flesh is needed to usher in The Horned King. Even if the characters don't attack Vessla, roll Initiative! The quicker the characters can free Phillip, the less they will be worn down ahead of the climactic battle in the next area.
As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can remove a root from Phillip by succeeding on one of the following {@dc 20} ability checks:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to rip a root apart
Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check to slip the root free
Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check to find the right knots in the roots to easily undo one
Other appropriate checks at your discretion

entries.caption: King of All
rows: The Illuminating Torch burns the characters when they get too close.
Fire
The Poisonous Apple spreads its venom to the characters on a touch.
Poison
The Thorned Crown pierces the characters' skin when they reach into the roots.
Piercing

entries: On a failed check, a character slips and takes 14 ({@dice 4d6}) damage of a type depending on the implement that injures the character, determined by rolling on the King of All table. The torch, apple, and crown cannot be removed from Phillip by any means until he is freed.

After six successful checks, Phillip is freed and his crown, apple, and torch fall to the ground. He regains his senses and immediately asks for Adela with growing panic, exclaiming that she had just been there. He protests against a voice only he can hear before disappearing into blue mist, pulled from the nightmare by Dani Jenkin.

entries.name: Frozen Throne
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the icy basement gets more frigid. Creatures other than Phillip Druskenvald must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Cold damage and gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. A creature with {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Cold damage automatically succeeds on the save.

entries.name: Souls of the Damned
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 10 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the storm of souls targets a random character and attempts to possess them. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or be possessed by the spirits for 1 minute. A possessed character is compelled to attack their allies with their most powerful spells or abilities. The character can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the possession on a success. A character who succeeds on the save is immune to this effect.

entries.name: Crooked Door
entries: Once Phillip disappears, a crooked door rises from the icy gnarled roots, leading to the final section: Toil and Trouble.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The sword dropped by Vessla Browntooth is a {@item Flame Tongue|XDMG} (Longsword).

entries.name: Toil and Trouble
entries: This crooked door is the last the characters step through, leading them to the heart of the nightmare.

You step into the attic of the Crooked House, but it has warped into an even more horrific version of itself. It's considerably larger and cluttered with the putrid remnants of all manner of vile ritual. The room's walls are covered in thousands of vermin that undulate in a single mass. At the center of the chamber is a huge bubbling cauldron with clawed feet standing over a fire that licks the iron. A moment later, you hear the cackling voices of all three hags of the Vermintoll Coven.

In an instant, the brew in the cauldron bubbles up and spills over, slithering into a new form as an enormous, squirming monstrosity is birthed from the goo—an amalgamation of Vessla Browntooth, Stonoga Blackstinger, and Golub Graygullet with body parts resembling those of weasels, centipedes, and pigeons. The three-headed abomination sneers at you, and the cauldron begins to walk.
There's no time for the characters to make any preparations once they arrive in the crooked attic. Roll Initiative! Use the Crooked Attic map for combat in this area.

entries.name: Phase 1: Sing Ye Vermin
entries: The revolting remnant of the Vermintoll hags, {@creature The Vermintoll Abomination|CrookedMoon24} attacks. All three heads extol the greatness of the Crooked Queen and taunt the characters for their inability to save the doomed Adela Druskenvald. The hags' favored vermin swarm throughout the room, writhing and crawling over the floor and walls. The hags' precious familiars are reborn over and over from these pests and arise as three {@creature Vermin Infestation|CrookedMoon24|Vermin Infestations}.

entries.name: Squirming Walls
entries: Any creature other than the Vermintoll Abomination and vermin infestations that is within 5 feet of the walls has its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} halved by the teeming vermin while the creature remains that close.

entries.name: Verminsong
entries: As the Vermintoll Abomination fights, the three heads of Vessla, Stonoga, and Golub sing together in a vile incantation that fuels their magic. The lyrics are as follows:
{@i Answer us, ye messengers who scrape beneath the soil.}
{@i Where mortal dreams are choked by roots, and shrivel, shrink, and spoil.}
{@i Come out now, your mothers yield, our softened hands with kindness.}
{@i Shake off your blind and wretched sleep and wriggle forth from darkness.}
{@i Sing, ye vermin, sing! What pleasures have you seen?}
{@i Scream, ye vermin, scream! Release what you have gleaned!}
{@i And in the soup, your steaming death shall lend a nice aroma!}

entries.name: Phase 2: Scream Ye Vermin
entries: When the Vermintoll Abomination is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, the amalgamation shrieks, driving the teeming vermin into a frenzy. They spread across all the surfaces of the attic, causing the following effects.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: The floor, walls, and ceiling are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} for any creature other than the Vermintoll Abomination and vermin infestations.

entries.name: Endless Bites
entries: When a creature other than the Vermintoll Abomination or a vermin infestation starts its turn, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or take 9 ({@dice 2d8}) Piercing damage and have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of its turn.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 12, if they are still level 11, when they destroy the Vermintoll Abomination.

entries.name: Conclusion: Dreaming No More
entries: After the characters have defeated the Vermintoll abomination, read or paraphrase the following:

With the last blow struck, the house trembles not in anger but in fear. Reality shatters as the nightmare around you breaks. Loud cracking noises erupt all around you, and the floor gives way under your feet. You roll and tumble, falling from floor to floor as the Crooked House collapses.

You land, finally, amid a heap of wood, plaster, and dust under a cloudless night sky. Dani Jenkin and Shuck stare down at you. Spirits and ghostly forms of countless varieties swirl around the collapsed house like wasps around a destroyed hive. Some fly into and out of Dani, who stands calmly within the ghost-fueled maelstrom.
The girl speaks in a distant, resigned tone: "They don't know where to go. They've been trapped here so long. They'll find peace now."

The Crooked House has been destroyed, and the spirits are finally free. Amidst the cacophony of swarming souls, the spirit of Joseph Patrini appears before the characters briefly to give them a thankful nod before flying off to join the spirit throng once more.

If the characters saved either Walter, Gilly, or both, they will be with Dani and Shuck amidst the ruins of the Crooked House. However, they say that Phillip Druskenvald immediately bolted and took off in search of Adela as soon as he was pulled from the nightmare.
As the characters regain their footing, the Jenkins share a family hug, but there is more to share. Use the information below to guide a conversation:

items: The spirit of Sally Lockwood is released from Shuck, who becomes a normal dog. Sally shares the story of her family's demise (see {@area the Crooked House|1ae|x}) and how she's tried but failed to keep the horror from repeating itself.

Dani knows that the spirits are restless because they can feel a terrible power growing out on the moorlands. That's where Phillip and Adela Druskenvald are right now. She can feel their presence there.

If the characters saved both her parents, the joy and relief in Dani's soul cannot be contained. The characters gain the benefits of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. If they saved only one parent, this is a Short Rest.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Empress|052|x} was pulled during the "{@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}", the {@item Cauldron of the Vermintoll Coven|CrookedMoon24} is found among the rubble of the Crooked House.

entries.name: Back In Wickermoor Village
entries: Wickermoor Village is in chaos. The scheming cultists among the Followers of the Old Ways have made their move and initiated the ritual to sacrifice Adela Druskenvald and countless more innocents atop Rowan's Rise, the highest hill in the moors north of Wickermoor Village.

Once the construction of the Wicker Man was complete, cult members from across the valley donned uncanny animal masks and descended upon Wickermoor Village, kidnapping victims from the streets and their homes and dragging them out into the moors. Which NPCs have turned evil and joined the cultists and which are at risk of being sacrificed are up to you to escalate the dramatic tension of forthcoming events (see {@adventure Wicker's Vigil|CrookedMoon|16}).

data.name: Wicker's Vigil

entries: Run, run, don't shrink and cower, and join us at the witching hour. We'll skip and sing in thrashing light, to smother the shrieks of endless night. Dance beneath the Crooked Moon! Round rising rapture, hand in hand! From pale decay and empty gloom, we'll comfort you. May our light embrace you too, and pierce the edge of midnight soon. Through wicker's blaze and ashen plume, the Crooked Moon!

The song of the Old Ways fills the air, carried high by enraptured voices and intertwined with embers that hiss and crack as they die. Their breath slows, drawn to a halt, until all that remains of the sacrificed is ash. Atop the highest hill in the gloomy moorland stands a titan made of wicker, casting its crooked shadow over a throng of devotees that sing praises to the Crooked Queen.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: A {@area prophecy|02c|x} has been whispered among the {@area Followers of the Old Ways|039|x} since {@area Kehlenn|021|x} first stirred within her prison in the Crooked Tree. Following the {@area deaths of the Fallen|027|x}, the {@area bloody revelries|67e|x} brought forth by the Lord of Fools, and the preparations for sacrifice conducted by the {@area Vermintoll Coven|024|x}, the final piece of the prophecy is put into place with the capture of {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x}.

Adela's sacrifice is all that remains to free the Crooked Queen and unleash her twisted, vengeful power upon {@area Phillip Druskenvald|01f|x} and the domain he dared to steal. No fewer than thirteen souls must be consumed by flames within an enormous wicker effigy shaped into the form of the humanity that Kehlenn loathes so much. Among those doomed to burn is the beloved bride of her eons-old foe.

With the ritual set in motion and the ancient prophecy poised to come to fruition, the Followers of the Old Ways have erected a Wicker Man atop the highest hill in the moors north of Wickermoor Village. This sacred site, known as Rowan's Rise, is where {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man} makes his final play, drawing forth his ancient power.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: Leaving the collapsed remains of the Crooked House behind, the characters follow the massive swarm of spirits—their ethereal cries now mingled with gleeful screams of dying victims—out into the moors toward {@area Rowan's Rise|721|x}. Characters have these goals:

items: Journey across the moors, saving innocent townsfolk from the monsters of the Crooked Queen.
Disrupt the ritualistic magic at the standing stones atop Rowan's Rise.
Destroy the animated Wicker Man and annihilate {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man}.

entries: Before running this chapter, review the {@area NPCs of Wickermoor Village|199|x} and decide who will be cultists and who will be captives based on the characters' connections for the most dramatic climax. Read through the encounters across the moors so you can better improvise the innocents' reactions to the horrors around them. Finally, familiarize yourself with the climactic battle, {@area Shadow of The Wicker Man|72a|x}, so that you can deliver a satisfying ending to The Crooked Man's story arc.
{@i This chapter is designed for four level 12 characters.}

entries.name: Across the Moors
entries: The characters see the swarming mass of spirits from the Crooked House rushing across the darkened landscape toward the highest hill in the moors—Rowan's Rise. This sacred place draws the freed souls to it before they fly off in all directions and fade in an attempt to find rest. Now is the time to save the still-living souls.

entries.name: The Legend of Rowan
entries: Many years ago, a young woman named Rowan became enchanted by the moon that forever gazes upon Druskenvald, its gentle light a soft invitation from the heavens. She followed its beckoning glow from her bedroom in Wickermoor Village and disappeared into the moors. When she did not return home, a search party scoured the highlands all night before finding the last trace anyone would ever find of her. Her precious silver locket lay abandoned at the center of a ring of ancient standing stones, the portrait of her beloved sister within replaced by the image of an antlered hare.

The story told for generations was that Rowan soared into the night sky, flying higher and higher until she could sit upon the Crooked Moon, watching over the people of Wickermoor Hollow forever more. From then on, that great crowned hill was known as Rowan's Rise.

Beneath the tale lies the truth... that Rowan became the first human sacrifice to Kehlenn when she first reawakened her power. And so, it is at this sacred site that the Followers of the Old Ways perform the final rites to release the Crooked Queen so that she can reclaim her usurped domain.

entries.name: Sacrifices
entries: Each encounter in this section places innocent villagers in peril. Every villager that dies loses their soul to the ongoing sacrificial ritual and feeds {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24} atop the hill. This is made obvious to the characters when, after each death of an innocent, a mote of blue-green light rises from the corpse and is whisked toward The Wicker Man. Keep track of how many villagers perish in the encounters, up to a maximum number noted in each encounter. The total determines how much stronger The Wicker Man becomes in the final confrontation.

Should the characters fare poorly while moving across the moors or falter in protecting the innocents, they may find themselves overwhelmed. If they retreat, dozens of townsfolk will be sacrificed, and The Wicker Man will achieve its full power, turning its wrath toward Wickermoor Village and the valley beyond until all has turned to ash.

entries.name: What's at Stake
entries: Before parting ways with the Jenkin family at the ruins of the Crooked House, Dani tells the characters that she senses that both Phillip and Adela Druskenvald are on the moors. Adela is trapped in a prison of wicker surrounded by terrified innocents and animals. She can sense Phillip desperately searching the moors but does not know where he is.

entries.name: Crooked Chaos
entries: When the characters arrive at the moors, read or paraphrase the following:
The moors outside of Wickermoor Village are treacherous even in the best of times. But now, a violent storm batters the highlands, and rain floods the sodden grounds.

Townsfolk scatter in a frenzy, some fleeing toward the village, others vanishing into the depths of the moors. The ground is strewn with bodies, cut down by gleeful hands, their blood mingling with the mud.

On a distant hill, a towering bonfire roars, its light dancing wildly in the storm. Above, the clouds churn, forming a grinning face with hollow eyes. The voice of The Crooked Man bellows from the sky, dripping with twisted merriment.

"Welcome, dear friends, to the exaltation!" the disembodied voice lilts. "The hollow rejoices, and all have come to witness my blazing incarnation. Like lambs to the slaughter, each little sacrifice adds to the pyre of our beloved queen's power. Do you think you can save them all? Remember, there are no heroes here."
The face of The Crooked Man is replaced by roiling storm clouds, leaving the scattered people to scream in even greater terror.
{@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man} has incited mass panic and calls forth the minions of the Crooked Queen to descend upon the numerous potential sacrifices.

If the characters attempt to get clarity regarding the situation by asking one of the people in their vicinity, choose an NPC who they've dealt with in the past and whom they trust. Use the event details here to decide what the NPC saw to guide that conversation.

items: Some of the villagers in animal masks started attacking others, knocking them {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}, and dragging them out into the moorland.
Strange monsters swarmed out from the moorlands into the village. These creatures seemed to be helping the violent villagers in their kidnapping efforts.
The mayor immediately disappeared, and the constable was the first person snatched, causing a lack of planning in the defense of the village.
In addition to the monsters from the moors, some strangers from Foxwillow, Dawn's Gate, and Murkwater Bend arrived and joined the kidnapping effort. Some of them brought captives of their own.
The captives and the kidnappers appeared to have gone deep into the moor, and now there is a raging fire atop Rowan's Rise.

entries.name: Encounters on the Moors
entries: The servants of the Crooked Queen place obstacles in front of the characters as they rush across the moors and ascend Rowan's Rise. Use the Moors Encounters map (see below) for combat in this area.

entries.name: Encounter 1: Death From Above
entries: When the characters strike out toward Rowan's Rise, read or paraphrase the following:
The distant blaze continues to rage far across the moors, its fires not dampened by the downpour. Billowing smoke joins with the roiling clouds to form a dense gloom above you.
With a loud and guttural shriek, six gaunt and bent vulture-like creatures swoop down upon you, extending sharp, grasping talons toward potential victims that may soon be new carrion to feast upon.
The first of the Crooked Queen's minions assails the characters once they have begun the treacherous trek across the moors.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Six {@creature Boneflayer|CrookedMoon24|Boneflayers} swoop down into the characters' path. Two of them grab onto an innocent civilian nearby, and the other four attack the characters.

entries.name: Sacrifices
entries: On the boneflayers' turns, the two grappling a villager carry their prey 50 feet into the air and drop them, likely to their death unless the characters have some method to intervene, such as the {@spell Feather Fall|XPHB} spell. The boneflayers then take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action to swoop down and grapple another for their next turn.

A maximum of five villagers can perish in this encounter. If the characters skip the boneflayers' assault entirely, add five to the total number of innocent villagers killed (see {@area Sacrifices|71b|x} above).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If at most one villager dies from the monster attacks, a fleeing villager in the area gives the characters their thanks and provides them with two {@item Potion of Greater Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing (Greater)}.

entries.name: Encounter 2: Death From Below
entries: As the characters move closer to Rowan's Rise, read or paraphrase the following:
The thunderstorm and rain have ceased, but the ground is a waterlogged mess. Some townsfolk have become stuck in the mire, beginning to panic as they desperately try to escape.
The mud begins to shift and churn as three enormous and twisted serpent-like creatures burst out of the quagmire. Massive, crooked jaws unhinge hungrily as the serpents lurch toward the innocents.
The marshy ground in this area is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature Wellwyrm|CrookedMoon24|Wellwyrms} emerge to devour the helpless, offer up more souls to the Crooked Queen, and slay any who stand in their way. The wellwyrms use their {@variantrule Burrow Speed|XPHB}  to ignore the {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Sacrifices
entries: If the characters haven't freed any villagers since the wellwyrms' last turn, a wellwyrm devours one of the trapped people on its turn. Freeing a villager causes the wellwyrms to turn their attention on the characters during that round. As an action, a character frees a trapped villager and sends them running to safety by succeeding on a {@dc 15} ability check. Methods of rescue and required ability checks are listed below:

items.name: Brawn
items.entry: Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) to bodily haul a villager free. The villager must be in reach, or the character must use Rope, a 10-foot Pole, or a similar tool.

items.name: Cunning
items.entry: Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) to talk a villager through how to get unstuck and point out solid footholds.

items.name: Leadership
items.entry: Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB} or {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) to encourage the villager with reassurance or to motivate them with a terrible picture of the fate that awaits if they don't escape.

entries: If all the wellwyrms are defeated, three more emerge from the quagmire until a total of six villagers have been saved or slain, in any combination.
A maximum of six villagers can be killed here. If the characters bypass this encounter completely, add six to the total number of innocent villagers killed (see {@area Sacrifices|71b|x} above).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters save four or more innocents from the wellwyrms, one of the survivors is a wandering priestess of the Brightsinger. She offers to cast {@spell Cure Wounds|XPHB} three times and speaks a benediction that grants each character {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Encounter 3: Death From Within
entries: After the characters leave the wyrm-infested quagmire behind, read or paraphrase the following:

The ground hardens beneath your feet as you break free from the muck. Ahead, four people from Foxwillow stumble past, their desperate flight toward the village cut short. They collapse, writhing in agony, their bodies convulsing as if possessed by the land itself.

Their skin and muscles swell, rippling unnaturally, until gnarled roots and twisted branches burst forth through their flesh, sprouting like cursed saplings. These masses of plants coil and grow into grotesque approximations of the humans from whom they spawned. These new beings, now puppets of the rooted ground, reach for rusted sickles and pitchforks scattered nearby, their wooden limbs ready to harvest.

This gruesome process then happens to the characters, who must each make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a character takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Necrotic damage as a similar creature grows and rips free from their body, appearing in the nearest unoccupied space.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The four grotesque creatures are {@creature Woodwarped|CrookedMoon24}, and they turn their attention to the villagers that spawned them, intent on slaying their progenitors. Any that spawned from the characters who failed the save move to attack the characters.

entries.name: Sacrifices
entries: On the woodwarpeds' turns, the four that spawned from the villagers surround one of the hapless townsfolk and attack. Any of the four woodwarped that were attacked or took damage instead turn their attention to whatever creature harmed them for that turn.
A maximum of four villagers can be lost here. If the characters leave the villagers to their fates, add four to the total number of innocent villagers killed (see {@area Sacrifices|71b|x} above).

entries.name: Rowan's Rise
entries: With the threats of the moors behind them, the characters now stand at the base of Rowan's Rise, a towering hill topped with a jagged stone circle. Looming beyond the circle is a colossal Wicker Man. Use the Rowans Rise map (see below) for combat in this area.

entries.name: Encounter 4: Cult of the Crooked Queen
entries: When the characters move past the battle with the woodwarped and reach Rowan's Rise, read or paraphrase the following:

You arrive at the base of Rowan's Rise, its looming hilltop thrumming with revelry. Atop the hill is a ring of ancient standing stones, a bonfire blazing within. Throughout the stones, dozens of people clad in animal masks are singing, dancing, and writhing, their laughter rising with the crackle of the flames. Their hands, torches, and sickles are raised skyward in hypnotic and jubilant rapture.

Unrestrained anthems of praise fill the air in melodies that are equal parts joyous and disturbing. Beyond the ring of stones stands a colossal wicker effigy, its woven limbs bathed in the thrashing light of the conflagration.
Amidst the ecstatic throng, six terrified townsfolk are chained to the stones, dressed in ritualistic garments. Their cries are swallowed by the roaring flame and deafening chorus of celebration.

The six chained townsfolk are being prepared for sacrifice and will be consumed by fire if the characters do not quickly find a way to disrupt the stones and free them. Dancing around the circle of stones are twenty-four Chaotic Evil human {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}. They greet the characters hospitably, beckoning them to join in the chorus to complete the happy ritual for the Crooked Queen. If the characters attempt to free the captives or fight the cultists, the cultists become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and attack.
If the characters ask to learn the song, they are taught its words:
{@i Fire rising, wrest our breath away!}
{@i Fill the skies with the songs we've borrowed!}
{@i Flesh and senses born of clay!}
{@i Fill the field where your bounty lays!}

This is the climactic showdown with the cult ahead of {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24} battle, and familiar NPCs from Wickermoor Village are among the cultists and captives. Select which NPCs to include from the options below based on the experiences the characters have had throughout the adventure.

Optionally, instead of using the cultist alignment and stat block for the NPCs below, you may replace them with the alignments and stat blocks for the NPCs as listed in {@area Wickermoor Village|159|x}.

rows: Beatrice Wells
Alda Farnum
Eleanor Heyling
Baltus Tolliver
Doris Squire
Gaston Doray
Finneas Trout
Hilda Brom
Jean Myriel
Holly Aster
Marianna Grey
Howie Butterman
Sister Rain
Jeremiah Stover
Siv Harga
Randall Graham
Solomon Roderick
Thomasin Ardor
Weston Murdoch
Wendel Somerton

entries: Once all the characters enter the stone circle, have three rounds of conversation with the cultists, or when a fight breaks out, read or paraphrase the following:

The bonfire roars hotter as flames suddenly erupt around you, and all within the circle are trapped inside a ring of fire that rages around the stone circle. The stones gleam with burning runes and glyphs, their energy feeding the blaze. The chained captives scream in panic as the wall of flames threatens to consume them.
If the cultists are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, they attack the characters. Otherwise, they continue their jubilant singing.

entries.name: Ring of Fire
entries: This malign ritual completely encircles the standing stones in a ring of fire. The ring is a {@spell Wall of Force|XPHB} that deals 22 ({@dice 5d8}) Fire damage to a creature that touches it. Unlike a normal wall, creatures can pass through it from the outside to the inside, though they still take Fire damage.

The ring of fire can be brought down by deactivating or destroying four of the nine standing stones. A stone has AC 17, HP 30, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Fire, Poison, and Psychic damage. A stone can be deactivated with a successful {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} ({@dc 15}), or by taking a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and succeeding on an ability check using one of the following methods (or another at your discretion):

items: {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) to forcefully or precisely expose a weakened area on the stone.
{@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) to alter a rune and prevent it from drawing on the Crooked Queen's power.
{@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) to find and break a natural flaw in the stone.
{@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) to undo the magic flow at the point of weakness.

entries: Each time a character damages one of the stones or fails an ability check made with the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to disable a stone, the character is targeted by a burst of flame as described in "Sacrifices" below.

entries.name: Sacrifices
entries: The captives are chained to the stones, but the chains are melded into the rock and have no lock or latch to open. The chains have AC 17, HP 20, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage.

While the ring of fire exists, on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 0 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the center bonfire flares and belches a gout of flame at one of the captives, killing them. A character can intercept the flames and save the captive by taking a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} to within 5 feet of the prisoner. The character becomes the target of the flames and must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 5d8}) Fire damage on a failure or half as much damage on a success.
A maximum of six villagers can be lost to this fire. If the characters bypass this encounter in some way, add six to the total number of innocent villagers killed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters extinguish the ring of fire and only two or fewer innocent lives are lost, residual energies from the ritual infuse a rune-marked fragment of a standing stone, turning it into an {@item Elemental Gem, Yellow Diamond|XDMG|Elemental Gem (Yellow Diamond)}.
When the glyphs on the stones have been deactivated and the innocents have been saved, read or paraphrase the following:

Before you looms the wicker titan, casting its shadow across the moors as the Crooked Moon leers bright and large overhead. Within its woven construction, more than a dozen people squirm and cry out, crammed in along with bleating farm animals and hundreds of pounds of crops. Within the chest of the enormous human effigy, you see the tiny shape of Adela Druskenvald peering out at the valley below, her face filled with sorrow but without a hint of fear.

entries.name: Shadow of The Wicker Man
entries: After dealing with the standing stones, the characters have run the gauntlet of the Crooked Queen's interference. They are now ready to deal with {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24}.
