Add up the total number of innocent souls that the characters failed to save in each of the encounters (see {@area Sacrifices|71b|x} above) and compare it to the Soul Motes table below, noting how many Soul Motes The Wicker Man gains, in addition to the 3 it starts with. Once you have determined that number, continue to {@area Phase 1: The Final Sacrifice|72c|x} below.

The Wicker Man that looks over Rowan's Rise ignites, and {@area Adela Druskenvald|020|x} is sacrificed alongside more innocents. {@creature Crooked Man|CrookedMoon24|The Crooked Man} possesses the blazing titan and tries to put an end to the characters in the name of the Crooked Queen. They must destroy The Wicker Man to annihilate the spirit of The Crooked Man once and for all. Use {@adventure the Wicker's Vigil map|CrookedMoon|16|Wicker's Vigil} for combat in this area.

entries.name: Old Ways Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the ancient power behind the cult manifests one of the following effects; it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items.name: Bolstering Jubilation
items.entry: Any surviving {@creature Old Ways Chosen|CrookedMoon24} on the hilltop gain 10 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

items.name: Endless Song
items.entry: Echoes of the cult's hymns haunt the faithless. Wisdom Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, each non-cultist on the hilltop. Failure: The target must subtract {@dice 1d4} from attack rolls until {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on the following round.

items.name: Wrathful Blaze
items.entry: The bonfires flare balefully. Dexterity Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, one burning creature on the hilltop. Failure: The creature takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Fire damage.

entries.name: Phase 1: The Final Sacrifice
entries: When the characters leave the standing stones and proceed even higher to The Wicker Man, read or paraphrase the following:
The Wicker Man erupts into an inferno as more masked cultists dance, caper, chant, and sing in delight around it.

From within the hollow confines of the effigy, agonized screams bellow. Sacrifices of crops, livestock, and people burn together. Adela Druskenvald stares through a gap in the woven wicker at the land below as a single tear rolls down her cheek. She is sorrowful yet serene as her flesh melts away. Her spirit is absorbed into the blazing heart of the conflagration.

A wild, cackling voice echoes from the head of the blazing titan as The Wicker Man lurches forward, its massive limbs moving with cacophonous creaking. It turns toward you, its flaming eyes filled with equal parts joy and hate. The voice of The Crooked Man booms, "Now all is ready for my queen. Bow before me and let your souls join the feast of her return!"

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24} is attended by three {@creature Old Ways Chosen|CrookedMoon24}. The cultists sing jubilantly, some through ecstatic tears. Sparks of ruddy light rise from them and pour into The Wicker Man, stoking its hunger for souls. The Wicker Man attacks, intent on slaughtering the characters and devouring their souls.

entries.name: Doomed Sacrifices
entries: The sacrificial victims inside the burning Wicker Man can't be targeted or affected by magic from outside The Wicker Man. The soul of a creature that dies within The Wicker Man is trapped within the Crooked Tree (see {@area The Crooked Tree|73c|x}) and can't be returned to life by any means until its soul is freed.

entries.name: Blazing Ardor
entries: The Wicker Man has a damage threshold equal to 10 times the number of Old Ways chosen currently alive.

entries.name: Bonfires
entries: Scattered bonfires burn throughout the ritual circles marking the hilltop. The Wicker Man delights in pushing foes into the flames with its attacks. A creature pushed into a bonfire takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Fire damage and begins burning.

entries.name: Phase 2: Dying Embers

entries: The agonized and ecstatic shrieks of rapture are snuffed out as the final cultist of the Old Ways drops to the scorched earth, each one of their souls being ripped from their bodies and consumed in the growing conflagration of the blazing wicker titan. The bellowing voice of The Crooked Man booms out around you.
"Their souls burn with the rest! Soon shall yours! Soon shall Wickermoor Village! Soon shall all the hollow! Fear not, there is purity and salvation in the ash!"

When the last {@creature Old Ways chosen|CrookedMoon24} dies, {@creature The Wicker Man|CrookedMoon24} absorbs their souls like sparks from a fire and gains 1 Soul Mote for each cultist. If any of the cultists are at 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} but alive—such as if a character chose to knock one out instead of killing it—The Wicker Man turns all its attention to killing any such cultists itself.
When the characters defeat The Wicker Man, read or paraphrase the following:

As the final blow against the wicker giant is struck, the entire construct collapses in on itself, a crumbling mass of flames and wicker ash. The surviving cultists shriek in agony as the pouring motes of flame surround and consume them, leaving behind only ash.
From the smoldering remains, a twisted figure emerges. The Crooked Man, no longer a man but a charred and shriveled specter, wails with fury, sorrow, and disbelief.
"Lies! I served my queen with my very soul, and yet, she has forsaken me. I've naught to show... but... pain..." His final words choke from his lips as he collapses, consumed by his own despair.

Quiet finally comes to Rowan's Rise as the sky opens up once more, and a gentle rain falls upon Wickermoor Hollow. Any nearby innocents or spared cultists of the Old Ways slowly limp off into the night in hopes of escape. The glowing embers in the ruins of The Wicker Man are put out by the rain, and the remains turn to a pile of smoking ash. {@area Phillip Druskenvald|01f|x}, who had been deceived, turned around, and led deeper into the moors away from Rowan's Rise, finally arrives.

An agonized wail fills the air as Phillip Druskenvald sprints toward the remains of The Wicker Man, out of breath and covered in wounds and minor burns. He begins rummaging through the ash and smoking wreckage, tossing aside bone fragments and charred wicker while screaming, "Adela!" over and over again.
Finally, he lifts charred skeletal remains wearing the blackened remnants of Adela's planchette necklace.
"No... My Love. We had so much more time..." The words come out as a broken whisper. "We were supposed to..."
The words leave him, and all he can do is sob as he collapses into the pile of ash, clutching all that remains of his beloved.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 13, if they are still level 12, when they destroy The Wicker Man.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Tower|06c|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the {@item Visage of the Old Ways|CrookedMoon24} is found covering the face of a slain Old Ways chosen.

entries.name: Conclusion: Ashes to Ashes
entries: {@area Phillip's|01f|x} loss is the final blow. He has broken and is doomed. He will do anything to bring {@area Adela|020|x} back, and the {@area Crooked Queen|021|x} will manipulate that desperation to sink her claws into him. He leaves the characters to give his slain wife a proper burial—privately—now entirely indifferent to what's become of {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}.

entries.name: Back in Wickermoor Village
entries: Wickermoor Village is a veritable ghost town. A large percentage of its inhabitants were either sacrificed innocents or slain as cultists. The changes to the village depend on who survived this chapter. Roles that were filled by various slain townsfolk are either taken up by family or apprentices, or they go unserved for the rest of the adventure.
With the Druskenvald Estate destroyed, Phillip takes up a room in the Green Queen Inn as he grieves and plans his next steps.

data.name: The Crooked Tree

entries: I once knew the kiss of the sun, the song of the mourning dove, the caress of leaf and branch. I ruled a world of green, and my subjects were of the forest, from the smallest hare to the greatest elk. Now, the cycle is shattered, and all that remains is sin. Even my own soul is sin. All that's left to be done is disintegration. All that remains is annihilation.

The Wytchwood bows to the {@area Crooked Queen|740|x}. At its heart stands a Crooked Tree, a barren oak that thirsts for revenge. The deposed queen need only wait a little longer. Her patience wears thin, and her old wounds still fester. It is in this dark wood that desperate bargains and sacrifices will be made, and only fate can tell the true cost.

Now, {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x}, once the most powerful being in all the land, moves toward his sealed fate and certain doom. The final reckoning of Druskenvald is at hand, and the land itself holds its breath.

entries.name: Chapter Background
entries: The end is coming to Druskenvald. With the sacrifices of {@area the Fallen|025|x} and the {@creature The Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24|Lord of Fools}, {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} is primed for his hellish birth, his influence now spreading beyond the tree line of the Wytchwood. At the gnarled forest's heart, the {@area Crooked Queen|740|x} calls {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} to her barrow so she may exact her vengeance and bring about the annihilation she has craved for millennia.

The blazing ritual and massacre atop Rowan's Rise have caused great turmoil within {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4}. With so many lost, townsfolk are looking for salvation. This is especially true of Phillip Druskenvald, who lost the love of his life to {@area the burning Wicker Man|709|x} and is now desperate to return her to life. He does not yet know that {@area Adela's soul is bound to Kehlenn as the final sacrifice|02c|x} needed for her escape from her tomb and prison.

In his grief, Phillip has sequestered himself away in the Green Queen Inn. Now out of options, he desperately hopes to use the primeval magic of the Old Ways to bring his beloved back to him. This is doomed to fail, and the lord of the land will be utterly powerless. In his lowest moment, Phillip will finally hear Kehlenn's call and will answer.

entries.name: Chapter Summary
entries: The time for the final confrontation with {@area Kehlenn|740|x} has come. Her vengeful designs have all worked toward this moment to ensnare {@area Phillip|743|x} within the {@area Crooked Tree|789|x} and transform him into {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}. Unless the characters stop the ritual, her consort will ascend to godhood, the Crooked Queen will be free, and all of Druskenvald will be annihilated and experience a horrid, crooked rebirth. Characters who enter the Wytchwood following the {@area Quest Hooks|744|x} later in the chapter have several goals:

items: Search the forest for Phillip Druskenvald.
Defeat The Horned King, and prevent the Crooked Queen from returning.
Perform a sacrificial ritual to sever Kehlenn's bonds with Druskenvald forever.

entries: {@i This chapter is designed for four level 13 characters.}

entries.name: A Clash of Kings and Queens
entries: Only three pivotal figures remain in this final climax: {@area Kehlenn|740|x}, {@area The Horned King|742|x}, and {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x}. Each represents a key fury in the characters' journey through Wickermoor Hollow, their fates intertwined in the struggle for Druskenvald's soul.

entries.name: Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen
entries: In ages past, Kehlenn once ruled the domain now known as Druskenvald as an archfey goddess called the Green Queen. Her world of rebirth allowed for no sapient life, and reborn souls existed only in the wild flora and fauna. This new life was always brutal, short, and filled with terror, but wholly natural as she saw it.

This untouched world of green changed forever when {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} arrived. How he found her and where he received the power to depose her, she never learned, but it was not long before she was reduced to a pile of bones in a barrow and a weakened fey spirit bound to a single tree.

As Phillip remade the domain in his image, Kehlenn remained. As Phillip forgot the violent conflict that usurped her, Kehlenn remembered. And with each passing year, her slow recovery from the crushing defeat brought greater awareness of the hubris of the man who named her domain after himself.

She powerlessly witnessed the vile desecration of her once-green world with the introduction of sapient life using her stolen power. The resulting hatred consumed her entire being, and over the millennia, she was twisted into the Crooked Queen, a moniker she now bears with spiteful pride.

The moment she has waited eons for has finally arrived. The sacrifices required to bring an end to Phillip Druskenvald and reclaim the power he stole from her have come to fruition, one after the other, just as she had planned for so long. All that remains is for Phillip to kneel, and she will remake him just like he remade her precious domain.

entries.name: All Will Be Crooked
entries: Kehlenn's freedom is nothing short of apocalyptic. She seeks not only to reclaim Druskenvald but to reshape it in her twisted image. Her eons of solitude and imprisonment have spoiled her once-green nature and transformed her into vengeance incarnate.

While she once sought to restore the natural cycle of life, death, and rebirth, she now only seeks the total annihilation of Druskenvald. Her ultimate goal is the corruption and disintegration of every sapient being, returning them to nature as she now defines it. She plans to rebirth them into crooked mockeries of what they once were—to live a terrifying, painful, and short life before perishing and being reborn to experience their horrible existence over and over again for eternity.

Now that the final stages of the Crooked Queen's plan are in motion, there is no need for subterfuge, and Kehlenn has no interest in hiding her intentions. She will be honest with the characters, offering up her tale to persuade them to see her side of the story and turn them against Phillip in his final agonizing moments as a parting knife in the back.

entries.name: The Horned King
entries: {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} is Kehlenn's cruel and powerful creation, made from sin itself. Through temptation and desire, he seeks to corrupt souls and bring about her vengeance. He is a monstrous shade of Phillip Druskenvald himself, woven from fragments of his very soul. This terrible entity intends to replace the lord of the land and sit at the right hand of his Crooked Queen.

The Horned King remains bound within the {@area Wytchwood|753|x}, his incorporeal form unable to cross its borders. Yet with the sacrifice of the {@creature The Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24|Lord of Fools}, his influence has begun to creep into the lands beyond. He bides his time, stalking the forest and whispering temptations throughout Wickermoor Hollow, slowly ensnaring its inhabitants.

The Horned King is subtle in his methods. His greatest pleasure lies in softly seducing the most disciplined and pious souls—those who believe themselves above vice—into giving in to their hidden desires. His whispers are a constant pressure, a slow unraveling of restraint. The more they resist, the deeper his influence burrows, until even the most virtuous souls find themselves standing before their own corruptive acts.

At the command of his Crooked Queen, The Horned King seeks to achieve physical form through the possession and metamorphosis of Phillip Druskenvald. After consuming Phillip's soul and becoming corporeal, he plans to leave Wickermoor Hollow and siphon the energies of all of Druskenvald. If not stopped, he will use this immense power to finally free his queen from her prison to remake the domain in her crooked image.

entries.name: Phillip Druskenvald
entries: Phillip Druskenvald is a broken man at his lowest point. He is consumed by guilt, desperation, and the agonizing pain of loss following the {@area death of Adela|72c|x}. Despite having fallen for Kehlenn's trap and acting as the architect of his own downfall, he is still filled with the misguided belief that he can somehow control or undo what he has set in motion.

This mindset is what has led him to seek the power of the {@area Old Ways|039|x}. His forward-thinking obsession with progress and the future has brought him nothing but destruction, so his last hope lies with the primeval powers that existed before he brought civilization to the domain. However, his attempts to harness this power to resurrect Adela in the Green Queen Inn have failed, shattering him further.

This humbled husk of a man is whom Kehlenn calls out to once the ritual fails, her whispers laced with the promises to return Adela's soul and her life. With no further options before him, Phillip set off into the Wytchwood to seek the Crooked Queen in the desperate hope he can finally make things right. Like a sacrificial lamb, he is oblivious to his imminent slaughter and the ritualistic power his death will provide.

entries.name: Quest Hooks
entries: Following the events of {@adventure Wicker's Vigil|CrookedMoon|16}, the characters can take their time surveying the extent of the damage done to {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4} and its community. However, knowing that {@area Phillip|743|x} vanished after discovering Adela's charred remains within The Wicker Man—hearing from villagers that he has locked himself away within the {@area Green Queen Inn|747|x}—may prompt them to seek him out.

entries.name: The Last Hope
entries: Wickermoor Village has been thrown into chaos in the aftermath of the massacre on the moors. The revelation that many townsfolk were behind the dreadful events has left the village divided and in disarray. Unrest simmers and power structures unravel. Some cling to old superstitions, while others look for new leadership, each with their own interpretation of what has happened and what must be done to make things right.

If {@area Mayor Somerton|161|x} survived the events on Rowan's Rise and did not fall in league with the nefarious cultists of the Old Ways, the panicked townsfolk blame him for everything that has happened and swiftly turn on him, imprisoning or even killing him. If {@area Constable Doris Squire|15e|x} still lives, she is powerless to bring order to the chaos, disheartened by the evident betrayal of {@area Deputy Howie Butterman|15e|x}.

The characters may find themselves drawn into this turmoil, as various people vie for their favor or assistance. But nothing is more pressing than discovering the fate of {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x}. Some want him captured and punished for bringing suffering and death to Wickermoor Hollow. Others want him rescued, viewing him as the only possible authority figure that can prevent Wickermoor Village from falling to anarchy. Both sides implore the characters to investigate.
After a brief inquiry, some townsfolk claim to have seen Phillip Druskenvald stumbling into the {@area Green Queen Inn|747|x}—his face pale and his eyes haunted.

entries.name: Chaos Reigns
entries: If the characters choose to delay or ignore the rising threat of the {@area Crooked Queen|740|x}, time becomes their greatest enemy. The longer they wait, the stronger {@area The Horned King's|742|x} influence grows. One by one, villagers begin to fall to their vices. Pure bedlam and pandemonium are but a few short nights away as even the most disciplined, chastened, and restrained people give in to their basest desires.

The townsfolk that the characters confront discover the evil impulses that had once lain dormant in the corrupted villagers' hearts. They also learn that the common thread among them was that all of them heard the seductive whispers of a three-eyed beast that stalks the dark woods. Those who confess and admit their transgressions, deeply shamed, plead with the characters to discover what is happening and put an end to it.

entries.name: The Green Queen Inn
entries: Regardless of whether {@area Alda Farnum's|15a|x} allegiance to the nefarious sect of the Followers of the Old Ways was revealed, she did not survive the events atop Rowan's Rise and is nowhere to be found following the burning of the Wicker Man. With no family, heirs, or apparent last will and testament, the future of the Green Queen Inn remains uncertain.

The nearly empty tavern on the first floor is unnervingly silent. At the bar sit {@area Jean Myriel |178|x} and {@area Siv Harga|176|x}, mourning {@area Holly Aster|174|x}. This could also be another NPC familiar to the characters, at your discretion. Either way, those in the tavern are aware that {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} suddenly arrived at the Green Queen Inn after returning from the moors, looking haggard. He then sequestered himself in one of the suites upstairs. Nobody has seen or heard anything since.

The door to the suite is locked and can be opened with a {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}. Alternatively, a spare key for the suite can be found on the first floor of the inn behind the bar with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: The Master Suite

entries: The air in this master suite stinks of charred flesh. The bed and furnishings have been pushed against the walls. At the center of the room, a large runic circle of glyphs has been etched into the floorboards, ringed with candles that have long since burned down. Inside the ritual circle rests charred human remains.
The master suite is the largest and grandest room at the Green Queen Inn.

entries.name: Adela's Remains
entries: The burned bones are the physical remains of Adela Druskenvald. Among the bones is Adela's scorched planchette necklace. All attempts to resurrect Adela fail.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: This room, now tarnished by the failed ritual, bears the remnants of innkeeper Alda Farnum's former life:

items: A desk, cluttered with writing implements and personal letters, which holds a set of {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}
A well-worn ledger tracking favors and debts owed by various residents and travelers
A simple, elegant jewelry box with a pair of silver earrings shaped like hares, worth 15 GP, and 3 silver and copper rings, each worth 5 GP

A dresser filled with finely stitched yet worn dresses and neatly folded clothes—in one drawer, a locked strongbox ({@dc 20}) contains 242 GP and a will stating that Alda's inn and belongings are to be left to {@area Marianna Grey|15c|x} in the event of her death

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Lovers|058|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, Adela's necklace among the charred remains is the {@item Planchette of Adela Druskenvald|CrookedMoon24}.

entries.name: Grimoire of the Old Ways
entries: An open book lies next to the ritual circle, its pages yellowed and brittle from use. The ritual laid out on the wooden planks is reflected within the revealed pages. A loose parchment, crumpled and stained with tears, rests beside the book.
It is obvious that Phillip was attempting some form of resurrection ritual, and the book in your hands confirms this. The ritual before you matches the illustrations in the book to every detail.

The loose parchment tells a different story. It shows a crude but unmistakable drawing of a twisted, gnarled tree. Beneath it, a simple mound of earth. Words are scratched into the parchment: {@i "The Crooked Queen holds her soul. She waits in the Wytchwood."}

entries.name: Ritual Tome
entries: Bound in cracked, aged leather, this tome bears embossed sigils. In the margins, scrawled notes read:

items: {@b {@i Blood—always fresh. Old blood spoils the circle}.}
{@b {@i Hold steady. One wrong breath and the sigils crack}.}
{@b {@i Failed again here. Must find something stronger. Something that can bring life}.}

entries.name: Phillip's Failed Hope
entries: With his powers diminished in Wickermoor Hollow, Phillip has turned to a rite of the Old Ways kept in the book found in Alda Farnum's quarters. While the innkeeper was alive, she had been too forthcoming with Phillip to get on his good side and hinted at a powerful tome. After Adela's death, this tome became his last hope.

Even with his shattered psyche, Phillip correctly deduced the location of the ancient book and performed the terrible rite within. The endeavor failed and opened the door to Phillip's mind, welcoming Kehlenn in. Following the botched resurrection, the Crooked Queen sent a vision that implied the possession of Adela's soul and the willingness to return her if he would only find her in the Wytchwood. Phillip immediately left the inn to find Kehlenn's resting place beneath the Crooked Tree.

entries.name: The Wytchwood
entries: The Wytchwood is an ancient forest of pines and firs that has been truly wild for eons, with only beasts of the wood as its inhabitants. There have been few visitors that have dared to walk among the primeval trees since the forgotten times when the forest was young. Only a small collection of trophies buried beneath the Crooked Tree serve as evidence of those doomed souls' existence. For the unwary, the Wytchwood is a place of endless misdirection and a tomb for all those who become lost within.

entries.name: Features of the Wytchwood
entries: There are no clear paths in this untouched wilderness—only beasts tread here. Unless otherwise stated, the Wytchwood has the following features:

entries.name: Canopy
entries: The forest's canopy is 60 feet above the ground.

entries.name: Fitful Rest
entries: Creatures that finish a Long Rest take 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Psychic damage after regaining {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} for the rest. They also find their belongings moved about and arranged on the ground in strange patterns, with no evidence of how or when it happened.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The light of the Crooked Moon passes through the sparse tree cover and sends shadows dancing about the forest floor. The entire forest is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

entries.name: A Quiet Place
entries: Dense needles on low-hanging branches dampen sounds that fail to echo through the wood. Sounds can't be heard beyond 120 feet from their source, even if shouted or magically produced (such as with the {@spell Knock|XPHB} spell).

entries.name: Entering the Wytchwood Early
entries: If the characters want to explore the Wytchwood before the events of this chapter, {@area Kehlenn|740|x} wraps the wood in an impenetrable glamour. Until {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} heeds the Crooked Queen's call in the wake of the Wicker Man's burning, the Wytchwood has the following features:

entries.name: Twisting Paths
entries: No matter how long a visitor explores or what methods they employ to find or mark their way, travelers in the wood find themselves trekking back toward the edge of the forest where they entered.

entries.name: Hunted
entries: Travelers in the Wytchwood are at the mercy of Kehlenn's creatures. Every night that characters explore the wood during the Witching Hour, roll {@dice 1d12}. On a roll of 2 or higher, a {@creature Hypnovulfen|CrookedMoon24} attacks the characters before the hour is up.

entries.name: Into The Dark Woods
entries: The Wytchwood is a two-night trek from Wickermoor Village across the moors to the north. In his grief-stricken journey, Phillip has left an unmasked trail, not caring who might follow. The characters venture into the forest with one goal: to find the Crooked Tree, where Phillip has gone to confront the Crooked Queen.
When the characters enter the Wytchwood, read or paraphrase the following:
The moment you step into the wood, darkness and quiet surround you. The pine and fir trees before you bend subtly at odd angles in an endless expanse that feels truly ancient.

entries.name: Tracking Phillip
entries: The characters can follow the messy trail left by Phillip with relative ease. Upon first entering the Wytchwood and after each encounter until the characters arrive at the {@area Crooked Tree|78f|x}, a character can make a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check to find muddy footprints, crushed pine needles, and snapped branches, which lead to the next encounter after an hour of travel. A character has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check after an encounter if any of the characters successfully found Phillip's Clue (see {@area Wytchwood Encounters|76b|x} later in this chapter). Characters will always experience the encounters in order, and they always are at least one hour of travel through the wood apart.

If the check fails, the characters lose the trail and wander for one hour until they are attacked by monstrous denizens of the forest. Roll on the Hungry Woods table to determine what creatures attack.

entries.caption: Hungry Woods
rows: One {@creature Hypnovulfen|CrookedMoon24}
One {@creature Wellwyrm|CrookedMoon24}
Two {@creature Ketgrinn|CrookedMoon24}
One {@creature Dream Eater|CrookedMoon24}
Three {@creature Boneflayer|CrookedMoon24}
One {@creature Gobblegeist|CrookedMoon24}

entries: After the characters defeat the attacking creatures, they may repeat the check to continue tracking Phillip. On a success, they proceed to the next encounter after an hour of travel. On a failure, they wander for another hour and are attacked by the monsters of the Wytchwood once more.

entries.name: On Cloven Hoof
entries: {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} stalks the Wytchwood, an incorporeal spirit unable to take physical form until his unholy union with {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x}. His arrival is signaled by the snapping of branches under an enormous bulk, the rumbling of earth from heavy footfalls, and the hot, putrid breath of a huge panting beast.

His form is that of a massive black goat with three ruby-red eyes. While stalking the characters, he never fully reveals himself, always keeping just beyond sight. The characters might catch glimpses of a bloody eye, some shaggy black hair, or a jagged gray horn between the trees.

entries.name: Within Temptation
entries: While the characters are traveling between encounters (see {@area Wytchwood Encounters|76b|x} later in this chapter), The Horned King will make his presence known and call out in a low, rumbling, and seductive voice. His goal is to pry into the characters' hearts to determine what they truly desire, erode confidence in their mission, plant seeds of doubt in their allies, and elicit curiosity for what he can truly offer them. To properly persuade the characters, have The Horned King visit them two or more times before {@area Encounter 4|77b|x}.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can gauge the intentions behind The Horned King's words with a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check. They sense that, while his words are carefully measured, he is earnest about learning their true desires and offering them what they want, but for a clearly ulterior purpose.

The Horned King never answers the characters' questions outright and continues to steer the conversation to the things they crave most, especially vices. Those who demand gifts or bargains are denied until he makes his final offer (see {@area Live Deliciously|781|x} later in this chapter).

entries.name: Impotent Wrath
entries: Any attempts to engage The Horned King in combat are futile, but he won't vanish simply because of an attempted ranged attack or spell. Any character who attempts to initiate combat with The Horned King before the final confrontation (see {@area Born King|79f|x} later in this chapter) must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition Frightened|XPHB} for one minute. While {@condition Frightened|XPHB} in this way, the character must drop whatever they're holding, use their action to {@action Dash|XPHB}, and use their movement to run away from The Horned King after being filled with the dread of what lurks in the hearts of mortals.

entries.name: Conferring with The Horned King
entries: The Horned King thrives on sin and desire, with the power to turn mortals toward corruption (see {@area The Horned King|742|x} earlier in this chapter). He initiates conversations with questions that play into the characters' wants, fears, and struggles in hopes to tempt them. Some example responses include:

items: "Why do you carry such a heavy burden alone? There are easier paths."
"Do you wish to suffer forever? The pain can end with a spoken word."
"Do you truly believe you have all the answers? There are many secrets yet to discover."
"Why do you rush toward your fate? There is peace in letting time pass you by."
"Why do you struggle against the inevitable? Lay down your weary head and rest."
"Would you like to live deliciously? Life need not be filled with tragedy and loss."

entries: If asked questions by the characters, his answers are cryptic and always drive toward temptation. Use the following to guide responses if the characters speak with The Horned King:

entries.name: Who are you
entries: I am he who stalks the deepest woods and darkest hearts. I am in the heart of every mortal. I am the very thing you desire most. I am The Horned King, consort of she who watches from the Crooked Tree.

entries.name: What do you want from us
entries: I ask for nothing besides friendship and loyalty. And in exchange, I offer you the means to live deliciously. You come to my woods burdened, and I offer to alleviate that which weighs down your soul.

entries.name: Why should we trust you
entries: Trust? You need not trust me to see the truth in my words. You need only walk the path I tender.

entries.name: What do you know of the Crooked Queen
entries: She is the first, and she shall be the last. There is nothing but the forest. There is nothing but my queen.

entries.name: What of Phillip
entries: He is an honored guest in these woods and has been given safe passage.

entries.name: What happens if we refuse you
entries: It is your choice, but not one to be made lightly. Refuse, and nothing will protect you from what is to come. Accept, and you may find comfort and succor.

entries.name: Wytchwood Encounters
entries: The Wytchwood is not just a physical space but also a manifestation of the {@area Crooked Queen's|740|x} will. Instead of a traditional map, an encounter flowchart is provided below. For combat encounters in the Wytchwood, use {@area the Wytchwood Encounters map|76b|x}.

entries.name: Encounter 1: A Familiar Presence

entries: The sound of running water fills the quiet forest air as a twisted creek snakes through the wood before you, filled with dark water that seems to run too quickly and babbles with the sound of snapping bones.

The creek is 40 feet wide and 5 feet deep. Crossing is especially treacherous in this malicious forest, but there are several ways to cross, including across a fallen log, over a series of rocks in the creek, and even wading through the water.

A character who chooses to cross via any of these mundane methods must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check or fall into the water and be swept downstream, become lost in the woods, and draw the attention of a hungry creature (see {@area Tracking Phillip|760|x} earlier in this chapter). Characters swept away by the creek can be followed by succeeding on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check.

Once all characters have successfully crossed the creek or defeated the creatures triggered by rolling on the {@adventure Hungry Woods table|CrookedMoon|17|Hungry Woods}, read or paraphrase the following:

A snapping branch and the rustle of leaves on the other side of the creek draw your attention to a creature on the forest floor just ahead. It looks like a large black hare with gnarled antlers, feathered wings, and sharp fangs. Two wide yellow eyes stare at you as the creature waits, unmoving.

This {@creature Crooked Hare|CrookedMoon24} is Kehlenn's familiar, bound to the confines of the Wytchwood. The Crooked Queen sees through its eyes, and the creature speaks with her voice. The crooked hare does not approach or attack at first. It simply watches and waits, never once blinking.

If the characters attempt to approach or attack, the creature lets out a shrill scream, and Kehlenn's raspy and crackling voice fills the air. "You will be devoured by the beast that stalks these woods!"

It then leaps forward, attempting to fly amongst the characters before exploding into a 15-foot-radius Sphere of putrid gore. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 33 ({@dice 6d10}) Necrotic damage and is affected by the {@spell Bane|XPHB} spell for 8 hours. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

entries.name: Phillip's Clue
entries: A character who investigates the gore left by the crooked hare and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds Phillip's silver pocket watch, its chain broken several links up.

entries.name: Encounter 2: Beware the Beast

entries: As you press deeper into the Wytchwood, the dense forest closes in around you, and a prickling sensation runs across your skin. You are overwhelmed by the sensation of someone or something watching you, and you suddenly hear the rustling of leaves as a person stumbles out of the underbrush before you. And you recognize them.

This person is an illusion created by a particularly big, bad {@creature Hypnovulfen|CrookedMoon24} that hopes to devour the characters. Choose a surviving NPC that the characters have developed a strong connection with or even someone from a character's backstory for maximum emotional weight. The illusion doesn't move past a large patch of underbrush and begs the characters for help.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character who closely examines the scene can make a {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to discern that the person is not real or spot the fur of the hypnovulfen in the bushes behind the illusory person. When a character gets within 5 feet of the illusion, the hypnovulfen attacks, surprising the characters if the illusion was not seen through. The hypnovulfen has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against a character who hasn't yet taken an action in the combat.

entries.name: Phillip's Clue
entries: A character who investigates the underbrush that the hypnovulfen was lurking in and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds a bent and cracked {@item Hooded Lantern|XPHB} expended of {@item Oil|XPHB}, clearly discarded in haste by Phillip on his trip through the woods.

entries.name: Encounter 3: Death of Hope

entries: A rickety wooden hovel stands alone among the gnarled trees, its frame slanted against the weight of time. A single door creaks faintly in its tilted frame. Slatted windows offer no view of what lies within. Hanging from the grasping branches around the hut are hundreds of strange symbols made from crooked sticks and bones bound together.
This solitary structure is a manifestation of the Crooked Queen, where she hid away the last of her compassion and hope. The hovel is 20 feet by 30 feet, with a 15-foot ceiling.

entries.name: Crooked Idols
entries: The hanging idols are woven from sticks, bone, leather, twine, and strips of old cloth. Hundreds of these creations hang from branches in all directions. Characters who succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notice that these ritualistic markers are eerily familiar, depicting moments from the characters' past, distorted but unmistakable. These moments are either from their time in Wickermoor Hollow or from their life before their ride aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express}.

These crooked idols have a bewitching hex placed on them. Any character who damages or disturbs the charms must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or be cursed until they finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. While cursed in this way, {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} are made with Disadvantage. A {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spell or similar magic ends the effect.

entries.name: Into the Hovel
entries: When the characters enter the hovel, read or paraphrase the following:

A heavy layer of dust covers the ruined remnants of what once was a simple home. A rotting bed sits in the corner, not far from a bent table and broken chair. Ancient chipped paint covers every wall, forming strange scenes in simple articulation.

Closer inspection of the markings on the walls reveals that there are six separate scenes that wrap around the interior. A successful {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check pieces together what each depicts in the following order:

items: A beautiful green queen stands in a lush forest, surrounded by bowing animals and fairy folk.
A tall, thin man wreathed in fog holds a cane in one hand and a blazing torch in the other.
The green queen and the thin man clash in battle amidst the inferno of a burning forest.
A bustling city of tall buildings rises high over a pile of ash and bone.
The green queen lies entombed beneath the earth, her skeletal remains entwined with gnarled roots.
Standing beside a huge black goat, a barren, crooked tree reaches toward a crescent moon with a leering face.

entries: If the characters investigate the hovel and take in the scenes depicted in the art, they gain the benefits of a Short Rest. A character who searches the room and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds an old set of Painter's Supplies underneath the bed.

entries.name: Ashes to Ashes
entries: After the characters finish studying the artwork, read or paraphrase the following:

Suddenly, the cracks in the hovel glow bright as light fills the room, and you realize it's actual sunlight. A beam of light focuses on the art of the burning forest, and a rush of blistering wind and intense heat sets the hovel ablaze! Flames lick up the walls, the floorboards bend and pop from the heat, and acrid smoke fills the air. The door of the hovel slams closed. You are trapped!

The characters must find a way to escape before they succumb to fire and smoke. The interior of the hovel is Heavily Obscured by the smoke, and all creatures within must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Fire damage from the heat, repeating this saving throw every 1 minute spent inside. All parts of the wooden hovel have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Fire, Poison, and Psychic damage. The door is locked ({@dc 20}). Characters can break down the door as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action with a successful {@dc 25} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. The door has AC 15 and HP 20. The sealed windows have AC 15 and HP 10.

When all characters are free from the hovel, the fire immediately snuffs out. The flames vanish without a trace, and the building remains intact save for any damage dealt to the structure while escaping.

entries.name: Phillip's Clue
entries: A character who investigates around the base of the hovel and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds an empty silver hip flask that smells faintly of liquor with the letters "P.D." engraved on one side.

entries.name: Encounter 4: Her Limbs Are Thrawn

entries: The forest becomes so dense that only certain paths are navigable, slowing down your pace to a crawl. Finally, the overgrown thicket opens up to a grove ringed with unnervingly evenly spaced trees. At the base of one of these trees kneels a young woman with dark hair in a white sleeping gown, digging away in the dirt amidst the roots. She looks down with determination and desperation.

The young woman is trying to find a locket that was lost to her long ago. Though the characters may not know it, this facsimile is the image of Rowan, the first human sacrificed to Kehlenn and the namesake of Rowan's Rise.

entries.name: No Real Rowan
entries: The false Rowan has been created by a {@creature Maidenwood|CrookedMoon24} using its bewitching power and gnarled branch lure to form a near-perfect facsimile of the maiden. She will speak to the characters, claiming she is trying to find her missing locket and asking if they have any tools to help her dig deeper. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who scrutinizes the young woman and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check realizes that her fluid movements are too deliberate and she is not what she appears to be.

If a character comes within 5 feet of the false Rowan, or the Maidenwood believes the characters have seen through the deception, it attacks. When the Maidenwood is destroyed, the figure of Rowan remains whole and lifelike unless damaged during combat. Examining the figure reveals its true nature, formed from crooked branches.

entries.name: Maidenwood Grove
entries: When the first Maidenwood is destroyed and the characters collect themselves, read or paraphrase the following:

Suddenly, you hear the familiar voice of the maiden call out. "I need my locket. It is the only thing that can protect me from the Crooked Queen, and I fear her so. Her limbs are thrawn. Her soul is sin. She wants to open my throat to feed the tree. Please."

Then dozens more of the same voice cry out, and you see the same young woman at the base of every tree in this grove. The path behind you has sealed shut, and the only opening in the interlocking branches and roots is directly before you on the other side of the grove.

These identical facsimiles are able to speak with an understanding of the story of Kehlenn and Rowan (see {@area Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen|021|x} and {@area The Legend of Rowan|70d|x}) and will be frank with the characters despite their disingenuous plea for help finding the locket. The characters can converse with the Rowans, and as a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character who succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check can discern that the details of the stories are true, though the intention is to lure the characters to the base of the roots for an ambush.

The characters must walk to the other side of the grove to find passage back to the rest of the Wytchwood. Any character who moves within 5 feet of a false Rowan is attacked by the maidenwood projecting the lure, but the trees are far enough apart to pass between them without getting too close. However, as the characters proceed, the pleading of the maidens becomes more aggressive and intense, begging the characters to help find her locket.

When a character reaches the center of the grove, they must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by the Wytchwood for 1 minute. While {@condition Charmed|XPHB} in this way, a character is compelled to move toward the nearest false Rowan to help find her locket. The moment that the characters leave the grove, all sounds of the identical Rowans' pleading dissipate, and the pathway closes behind them with the creaking of moving branches.

entries.name: Phillip's Clue
entries: A character who examines the first maidenwood and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check finds scraps of torn, bloody cloth hanging from one of the branches, clearly from a black pinstriped suit.

entries.name: Encounter 5: Live Deliciously

entries: The forest grows darker as dense clouds swallow the Crooked Moon above. Through the trees, you see the familiar form of the black goat of the woods stalking your every move. Branches snap and the earth trembles with each fall of his huge hooves as the beast steps from the thicket until he is directly before you.

You feel the enormous goat's hot, putrid breath on your skin, which crawls as he stares through your very soul with his third ruby-red eye. His low, seductive voice calls forth once more. "You have come so far, but for what? Tell me, what is it you truly seek? What does your heart desire? It shall be yours, and so much more."

While still an incorporeal spirit, {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} is the most visible he's been since the characters entered the Wytchwood. It is here he makes his final offer before they face the {@area Crooked Queen|740|x}.

entries.name: Heart's Desire
entries: The Horned King tailors his offering for each character, promising them whatever they wish for. This is his final gambit to make the characters fall, ensuring that the Crooked Queen can give him form and reclaim the dominion that was stolen from her.

Characters who accept this offer may ask for anything their heart desires, effectively asking The Horned King to cast a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell for them. He will oblige but will do nothing that interferes with his or the Crooked Queen's machinations. Characters who accept gain these additional benefits:

items: They may choose a {@adventure Dark Bargain|CrookedMoon|24} for themselves. Moreover, they can choose which features of the bargain they wish to accept.
They gain a level.

entries: Only you can know what the characters in this story would desire most, and it is up to you to offer the most delicious option. Refer to what the characters have revealed about themselves throughout the adventure and craft an offer that appeals to their most amoral appetites. These offers should be nearly impossible to resist—something that might align with their goals, their fears, or their proclivity to sin.
To the characters who accept his offers, read or paraphrase the following:
"You have chosen wisely. Now, let us see this to its end."
To the characters who resist him, read or paraphrase the following:
"You would deny yourself that which you crave? Foolish. This path is all that remains to you. There is only me. There is only my way. There is only forest. There is only surrender."

entries.name: The Price
entries: Any character who accepts The Horned King's offer is cursed. While cursed in this way, the character deals half as much damage to The Horned King and his minions. Additionally, if the character targets The Horned King, the Crooked Queen (including the Crooked Tree), or their minions with an attack or spell, they must first succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or be forced to choose a different target or waste the action. Only a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell or Divine Intervention can lift this curse.

Once The Horned King has finished making his final offers and the characters have either accepted or rejected him, he steps back into the shadows, his three eyes burning with hellish malevolence. Now, nothing stands in the way of the characters' arrival at the seat of the Crooked Queen, and they can proceed to the finale without having to make a Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check (see {@area Tracking Phillip|760|x} earlier in this chapter).

entries.name: Phillip's Clue
entries: Once The Horned King leaves the characters, the glinting of silver on the forest floor draws their attention to Phillip's cane, its goat skull topper tarnished with mud.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The Devil|06a|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the discarded cane is the {@item Cane of Phillip Druskenvald|CrookedMoon24} .

entries.name: Six Horns His Crown
entries: There, bathed in moonlight, stands the Crooked Tree—gnarled and impossibly tall, its twisted branches reaching for the sky. Beneath it, a mound of earth—the Crooked Queen's barrow—awaits at the heart of the Wytchwood. The silvery light of the Crooked Moon washes across the clearing, highlighting an entrance into the burial mound that had opened to welcome {@area Phillip|743|x} so he might finally come face to face with {@area Kehlenn|740|x}.

entries.name: Wytchwood Heart Features
entries: The heart of the Wytchwood has the following features:

entries.name: Forest Wall
entries: Characters can enter the clearing freely. Attempts to escape are blocked by the trees, which twist and writhe to form an impenetrable wall of branches and roots that have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Vivid moonlight illuminates the clearing with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Warded
entries: The forest heart is blanketed by clouding magic that prevents Divination spells from creating sensors or targeting creatures within the heart, stop teleportation into or out of the area, and blocks planar travel within the heart. A {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} spell can end the protection only if cast with a level 9 spell slot.

entries.name: Before the Crooked Tree

entries: A crooked tree, twisted beyond comprehension, grows from a steep mound of earth, its roots snaking over large stones. A clearing in the forest stretches out all around it, a flat glade of short, green-gray grass. Moonlight casts an ominous glow throughout the clearing. The Crooked Moon has never felt closer as it looms above, enormous and grinning. A large goat skull rests at the base of the tree, a wooden symbol carved to look like a crescent moon tied between its horns. A wide opening in the barrow yawns beneath the trunk of the gnarled tree, radiating with warm light.

The clearing is 130 feet across. The mound itself is steep, rising to 15 feet. The tree's trunk is thick and stretches 40 feet into the sky. The branches are bare and twist in on themselves in unnaturally gnarled shapes. The tree and the goat skull have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage while Kehlenn inhabits the tree. The entrance to the barrow is narrow, just large enough for a Medium creature to squeeze through, forcing characters to crouch or crawl.

entries.name: Into the Barrow

entries: You crawl into the barrow and find a chamber aglow with warm light. The walls, floor, and ceiling are made of packed earth and knotted roots. It feels truly ancient here.
The soft light is cast by a large skeletal figure against the far wall, intertwined with roots and covered in green moss. Thin, sinewy roots dangle from the dirt above.
Bound to the floor in a crooked kneeling position is Phillip Druskenvald, his body battered, broken, and firmly restrained by thick roots that writhe and crush him slowly.

This is the burial chamber of {@area Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen|740|x}. The remains of her former archfey body are filled with power, but her true essence and consciousness inhabit the entirety of the Crooked Tree.

entries.name: Ceiling
entries: The ceiling is low, barely 6 feet tall at its highest point, and threaded with tangled roots. The tendrils bristle and twitch when Kehlenn speaks. The roots have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage.

entries.name: Kehlenn's Bones
entries: The bones shed faint light with the colors of a campfire. They have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to all damage and can't be removed from the roots. Creatures within the barrow can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, and after every hour a creature remains in the cave, it gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} emanates from the bones bound in roots, shifting and dancing with the images of slain fey spirits that once thrived in Kehlenn's primeval green world.

entries.name: Treasure and Trinkets
entries: Held within the roots along the walls are the grisly trophies that Kehlenn has amassed during her long death. Any objects lost by or stolen from the characters over the course of the adventure are here, in addition to the following:

items: A small oval portrait of a young woman (Rowan's beloved sister)
A {@item Hypnovulfen Figure|CrookedMoon24}
A wooden toy deer, its edges worn smooth from handling
A glass jar of human teeth
A tarnished silver posy ring worth 10 GP
An empty bird's nest made of human hair

entries.name: Druskenvald Kneels
entries: This is the final confrontation between {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} and the {@area Crooked Queen|740|x}. Phillip cannot be saved—his fate is already sealed.

entries.name: Kehlenn's Voice
entries: The Crooked Queen's voice emanates not from the skeleton lying before Phillip, but from the roots that intertwine with the earthen walls of the barrow itself. Her voice is raspy and crackling; her words are bitter and cruel.

"He sought to unmake me. To steal what is mine. To shatter the cycle. To replace towering trees with towering buildings in garish cities and scum that scurry about their unnatural lives. He took everything from me and forgot that I existed! He truly thought this world had always been his. As if he did not steal it.
"But now, everything he ever was, everything he ever loved, belongs to me. And all shall be disintegrated, annihilated, and remade in my image once more!"

Kehlenn converses with the characters and even shares her story (see {@area The Crooked Moon|021|x}) if asked. However, nothing will dissuade her from her goal of annihilating Druskenvald and remaking it in an abominable, crooked mockery. If the characters see her side of the story and agree to help her, Druskenvald is doomed and the adventure is over (see {@area Crooked Defeat|7a7|x} later in the chapter).

entries.name: Phillip's Final Moments
entries: The roots continue to crush Phillip, who winces in pain but does not attempt to prevent his fate. He is completely defeated. Brought to his lowest, he has a distant, hollow stare and responds to any attempts to talk to him with muttering:

items: "All our high and shining towers... Now ash and bones..."
"You promised... You said you'd give me back my beloved..."
"The awful price you paid..."
"How could I have forgotten?"
"The future I imagined... This wasn't what I wanted..."
"We were supposed to have all the time we needed..."
"What would be enough to spare my soul?"
"What have I done?"

entries: Phillip (Lawful Neutral, human {@creature Noble|XMM}) has 6 remaining {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} out of a maximum of 16.

Characters can interact with Phillip. Any attempts to remove him from the roots fail and cause him intense pain. The roots tighten, and he takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Bludgeoning damage that can't be reduced or prevented in any way. If reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, Phillip's transformation begins (see "Phillip's Transformation below).
As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can succeed on a {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check to realize Phillip is beyond saving, and trying to free him only hastens his death.

entries.name: Phillip's Transformation
entries: Let this moment play out for as long as you wish, or until Phillip reaches 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. When Kehlenn believes Phillip's suffering is at its peak, she acts. Read or paraphrase the following:
The chamber fills with the cracking of roots as they slither over every inch of Phillip Druskenvald's body, which bends and snaps as the man attempts to speak his last words. "Please. Adela."

Immediately, a hole in the ceiling opens, and his body is ripped from the earthen floor and pulled up into the crooked tree above. The room rumbles as roots spill in from all around you. You hear the howling of wind from beyond the barrow. The agonized screams of Phillip Druskenvald echo for just a moment before turning into the horrific guttural bleating of a colossal abominable goat.

Each creature within 10 feet of Phillip when he is ripped into the ceiling must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) Force damage and have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. The interior of the barrow is now a tangled mesh of roots and is considered {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Born King
entries: When the characters leave the barrow to face {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24}, read or paraphrase the following:

Hellishly hot wind whips past you, caused by the beating of enormous bat-like wings that sprout from the shoulders of a gargantuan fiendish monstrosity that stands before you. Far larger than the creature you faced in the woods, The Horned King, now made flesh and blood, has six twisted horns, a long slithering tongue, a split lion's tail, and the jagged maw of a dragon from hell.

Its three eyes stare you down with all the sin and hate of this world. As it bellows apocalyptically, the triumphant and mocking voice of the Crooked Queen echoes from the trunk of the tree at the center of the clearing, which shifts and twists until the form of a gnarled fey queen appears in the bark.
"You will be the next to fall, just as he has—the first sacrifices at the altar of my consort. You will be the kindling for the flames of the great crooked rebirth!"

{@b The Horned King} manifests in his final form, a once-immaterial Fiend of corruption now made flesh. This is the climactic battle with the fate of Druskenvald—and the characters themselves—hanging in the balance. The Crooked Queen commands her consort and uses her influence to destroy the characters so she can be freed to remake Druskenvald. The trunk of the Crooked Tree shifts and curves, taking on the guise of the Crooked Queen herself, who watches on in anticipation.

The tree line has framed the outer ring of a massive magical circle with wide tracts of withered grass that form lines, shapes, and runic sigils on the earth. Embers float upward from these ley lines of power toward the Crooked Moon above. Use {@area The Crooked Tree map|73c|x} for this battle.

Regardless of promises made or the allegiance of the characters, The Horned King attacks as soon as more than half of them emerge from the barrow. The king is entirely patient if the characters linger in the barrow, waiting for them to present themselves so he can annihilate them for the glory of his queen. Roll Initiative!

entries.name: Kehlenn's Influence
entries: On {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 (losing {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} ties), the Crooked Queen causes one of the following effects; she can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

entries.name: Crooked Effigies
entries: Three {@creature Crooked Effigy|CrookedMoon24|Crooked Effigies} grow from the branches of the Crooked Tree and drop into unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of the burial mound. The effigies act immediately and on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 on subsequent rounds. The effigies vanish when the Crooked Queen uses this option again, or when they or The Horned King are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Grasping Roots
entries: Strength Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, up to three creatures within the clearing. Failure: The target has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 13}) until the Crooked Queen uses this option again.

entries.name: Moonlight Dirge
entries: Constitution Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, each creature in the moonlight other than The Horned King. Failure: 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Radiant damage, and the target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn. Success: Half damage only.

entries.name: Phase 1: The Beast Is Rising
entries: {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} engages the characters, towering 30 feet high and trembling with power. At full strength, The Horned King's attacks are aggressive and relentless.
When The Horned King is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}, the battle progresses to the next phase.

entries.name: Phase 2: Wrath of the Crooked Queen

entries: The intense light of the Crooked Moon shines as though it were just above you, watching the battle with wicked glee. The shape of Kehlenn upon the Crooked Tree writhes as the tree itself bends toward the colossal beast.
"Now, born king, leave it all burning, bleeding, breaking! You are the ritual of my freedom, my ascension, my revenge!"
The Horned King lets out a terrible roar and surges with fiendish power as the circle of primeval magic crackles with sacrificial energy.

{@area Kehlenn's|740|x} magic intensifies. When a creature other than {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} or a {@creature Crooked Effigy|CrookedMoon24} starts its turn, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or choose one of the following options:

entries.name: Crooked Thoughts
entries: The creature loses {@status Concentration|XPHB}. If it isn't concentrating, it takes 10 Psychic damage.

entries.name: Daze
entries: The creature can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Crooked Defeat
entries: If all the characters are slain or otherwise fall, read or paraphrase the following:

You have fallen, just like the rest of them. This sacrificial slaughter has ensured the end of all things. The Horned King rears up on its hind legs, filled with ascendant triumph, and lets out a bellow that sounds like the mixture of goat, lion, and dragon. The cacophonous sound cracks the Crooked Tree, and from the split trunk, a beautiful and horrifying fey queen emerges, her limbs and teeth as crooked as her soul. She rises into the sky, her arms toward the Crooked Moon above as she ushers in the annihilation of Druskenvald.

entries.name: Fleeting Victory
entries: When The Horned King is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, read or paraphrase the following:

With the final blow, The Horned King begins to unravel as the colossal beast lets out vile bleating death throes. Its flesh begins to shrink and contort, and for a moment, its head shifts to a dreadful mockery of Phillip Druskenvald's before the rippling fiendish body erupts into a putrid explosion of blood, viscera, and bone. A moment later, all that remains of The Horned King is the simple goat skull that had once rested against the barrow.

The face of Kehlenn sneers with rage as she lets out a wordless shriek, her physical shape disappearing from the bark of the Crooked Tree. However, the tree itself begins to creak and bend back and forth, its limbs twisting in wrathful vengeance. This is not yet over.

entries.name: Fated Tarot Reading
entries: If {@area The World|076|x} was pulled during the {@area Fated Tarot Reading|049|x}, the character this card was pulled for is granted the ability to cast the {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell one time after the defeat of The Horned King.

entries.name: End of the Crooked Queen
entries: Upon {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24|The Horned King's} destruction, {@area Kehlenn's|740|x} voice shrieks and rages against the defeat as the Crooked Tree sways back and forth with wrathful creaking.

Kehlenn is intertwined with the Crooked Tree. She can no longer exert her influence and is now vulnerable. The ritual within the clearing still crackles with energy. The characters must disrupt the ritual to sever Kehlenn's last connection to the land. The bloody goat skull from the remains of The Horned King whispers to the characters with the voice of {@area Phillip Druskenvald|743|x} in one last attempt to set things right.

"She is still here. The circle remains. But there is hope. My beloved is here. I can hear her now. She has shown me the path. My power still exists beyond the borders of Wickermoor Hollow, but there must be sacrifice to harness it.

"You must make the sacrifices while touching the skull. Each one of you. If the sacrifices are great enough, Adela will claim my power and dethrone Kehlenn, sever her ties to my land, and bind her within the Crooked Moon.
"Please... Let's set this right..."

To complete the ritual and trap the Crooked Queen within the moon, a character can touch the goat skull and offer a sacrifice. This can be anything of great personal value to the character: a cherished item, a piece (or person) of their past, or even a part of themselves (reducing an ability score by 2, giving up a class feature, etc.). Whatever is offered is lost forever.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, a character can touch the goat skull, offer a sacrifice, and roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 10 or higher, the sacrifice is accepted. However, Kehlenn in her Crooked Tree rages against her potential banishment. On a 9 or lower, Kehlenn receives a number of Ritual Points equal to the amount the roll failed by (10 minus the total rolled). Kehlenn can use these points to reduce future rolls before a character rolls the {@dice d20} for their sacrifice, potentially turning success into failure. On a failure, a character can try again on subsequent turns with a new sacrifice.

entries.name: Last Act
entries: A character whose sacrifice isn't accepted can choose to give their all to assure the queen's demise—the character can sacrifice their own life. A character who takes this option dies and can't be restored to life. The sacrifice is accepted, and the Crooked Queen is powerless to stop it.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: If the characters fail in making their sacrifices 6 times, or if any of the characters ignore the pleading of Phillip's spirit and don't offer a sacrifice, the ritual completes in the Crooked Queen's favor, and The Horned King reforms (see {@area Crooked Defeat|7a7|x} earlier in this chapter). If each character's sacrifice is accepted before that, the ritual collapses, and Kehlenn is untethered from Druskenvald and bound forever within the Crooked Moon.

entries.name: Underneath the Crooked Moon
entries: When the final sacrifice is accepted, read or paraphrase the following:

As the final sacrifice is accepted by the goat skull, its empty eye sockets fill with a glowing orange light that spreads along the cracks in the bone, up its horns, and to the wooden moon through the twine that holds it aloft. Then, a breeze whips through the clearing. Riding the wind is a single small ember, the very same one that floated away after the burning of the Wicker Man. The glowing ember, guided by the will of Adela Druskenvald, drifts down and lands at the base of the Crooked Tree.

In an instant, it bursts into flame. Shrieks of rage, pain, and hate fill the night sky for just a moment before silencing as the entire tree is fully engulfed from root to bough. You look up to the face of the Crooked Moon above, and where once had been a leering grin is now a scowl twisted with malice.

The radiating energy of the sacrificial ritual fades as the tree burns, and the eternal night of Druskenvald quiets. For a brief moment, the shimmering blue-green specters of Phillip and Adela appear before you, embracing sorrowfully, before fading into nothing.
Those that still live find themselves watching the ancient trunk and branches collapse in flames, as safe as if they were sitting around a campfire sharing a story.

The primeval bonds that tied {@area Kehlenn, the Crooked Queen|740|x}, to the land of Druskenvald have been severed. She is trapped within the Crooked Moon, fated to forever look down impotently on the people she so bitterly hates.

entries.name: Level Up
entries: The characters reach level 14, if they are still level 13, when they complete the ritual and defeat the Crooked Queen. If you plan on continuing the adventure to level 20 (see {@adventure Moonfall|CrookedMoon|19}), they remain at level 13 and instead increase one ability score of their choice by 2. This increase can't raise a score above 24.

entries.name: Conclusion: Flickering Life
entries: With the threat of {@area The Horned King|742|x} and {@area Crooked Queen|740|x} eliminated, the characters can find their way out of the {@area Wytchwood|753|x} and return to {@adventure Wickermoor Village|CrookedMoon|4} if they choose. The manipulation of sin that was driving the townsfolk to chaos and mass hysteria has ended, and the survivors of the recent horrors just want to rebuild their lives in peace.

The people of Wickermoor Hollow, and indeed the peoples of Druskenvald, may never know how close they came to annihilation. With Kehlenn bound within the cold, distant light of the Crooked Moon, her power and vengeance no longer threaten this realm.
But Druskenvald will never be the same.
To conclude the story of the characters and learn about the fate of this land between life and death, proceed to the {@adventure Epilogue|CrookedMoon|18}.

entries.name: Fateweaving Climax
entries: The Climax Narrative Touchpoint for all thirteen Threads of Fate occurs following the destruction of The Horned King and the defeat of the Crooked Queen. Depending on the number of characters who survive this final battle, it could be difficult to weave all of these climactic character moments together in a way that feels satisfying. It is recommended to select an order for the characters receiving their narrative Climax that allows for time to breathe in between each one so that every character gets their appropriate spotlight.

Some moments are a natural fit for happening immediately after the burning of the Crooked Tree, while others fit better later as the characters "catch their breath" physically, emotionally, and spiritually after their harrowing experience. These Climaxes should all be initiated while the characters are still within the Wytchwood, but not all of them must be at Kehlenn's barrow, so you can initiate these impactful moments at various points throughout the trek out of the woods. For characters who wish to use teleportation magic to immediately leave the Wytchwood, you may determine that these spells fail despite the banishment of the Crooked Queen, caused by the surging energies called forth by the final sacrifice to burn the Crooked Tree.

Finally, while the immediate effects of the respective Climaxes and the resulting Catharses may be fitting to happen immediately following each Climax, you are encouraged to allow some time to pass for the characters to fully process each of the climactic moments of their narrative journeys. The Catharsis of each character's Thread of Fate can be fully implemented during the conclusion of the campaign as presented in the {@adventure Epilogue|CrookedMoon|18}.

data.name: Epilogue

entries: Ya know, I never liked happy endings. There's a lie to 'em. A lovely lie, sure, but everyone knows it ain't the truth-even the narrator. Now, a story with a bittersweet ending is one worth listenin' to. How can you truly appreciate the few, brief moments of sweetness in life without first tastin' a whole bunch of bitter?

Phillip Druskenvald is dead. Kehlenn has suffered her final defeat. The journey of these two souls, intertwined by fate since time immemorial, has finally come to an end. As they moved toward their inevitable destiny, they left an immeasurable amount of death, destruction, and despair in their wake. It is up to the survivors to pick up the pieces.

In the aftermath of the bloody and burning fall of {@creature The Horned King|CrookedMoon24} and the Crooked Queen, the story of {@i The Crooked Moon} comes to an end. What awaits the characters following this epilogue is up to you and your players.

Tables interested in epic fantasy may continue the adventure into the higher tiers of play, and you can even guide the characters all the way to level 20 in Wickermoor Hollow with the tools presented in the {@area Moonfall|7cc|x} chapter. However, concluding the adventure following the events at the Crooked Tree provides for the most thematic experience that stays true to the spirit of folk horror. This epilogue is written with this in mind.

entries.name: What's Become of Wickermoor?
entries: After the defeat of The Horned King and the Crooked Queen, the characters leave the Wytchwood to find Wickermoor Hollow forever changed by their time in the valley. Although its people have grown accustomed to difficult lives filled with hardship and horror, the events in the recent weeks have deeply shaken even the hollow's hardiest folk.

Of all the places in the valley, Wickermoor Village has suffered the most since the characters first arrived from beyond the Shroud. Following the chaos unleashed by the minions of the Crooked Queen, some people search for a scapegoat to blame and exact vengeance upon, while others hope to leverage the instability to gain power. Most of the townsfolk, however, simply want to get their old lives back and return to some form of normalcy.

How the specific NPCs have been affected is largely dependent on the connections and choices that the characters made and how you chose to incorporate them throughout the adventure, especially during the burning of the Wicker Man atop Rowan's Rise.

As the characters spend time in Wickermoor Village to wrap up their unfinished business, make sure to tie up plot lines and provide closure with the surviving NPCs that became important to the characters. The people of the various ideologies and groups of the village respond to the recent horrors in the following ways.

entries.name: Followers of the Old Ways
entries: With the cult of the Crooked Queen exposed and almost entirely wiped out, the followers of the Old Ways who revered the Green Queen and never fell to wickedness become more entrenched in their superstitions and beliefs, blaming the corruption of their kin on the influence of new and profane ideals brought to the valley over the years. They become more distrustful of nonbelievers and anyone outside of their community, even going so far as to drive off members of the other groups. Wickermoor Hollow and its settlements retreat into the comfort of the old ideals.

entries.name: Fold of the Patient Lady
entries: Many adherents of the Patient Lady see the apocalyptic inevitability of magic and strange supernatural power and conclude that they must escape this doom, trusting that the wilds will provide for them. They chase off their own members who have magical abilities, leave the settlements of Wickermoor Hollow, and relocate to the natural world they view as a paradise, even if they do not have the survival skills to withstand the harsh conditions that await them.

entries.name: The Brightsingers
entries: Unlike the Fold of the Patient Lady, the Brightsingers do not lose hope in their community, seeing the recent disasters as proof that the bizarre superstitions and grim rituals of the valley are heretical acts that nearly brought about the doom of Druskenvald. Energized with a zealous desire to convert the folk who hold outdated beliefs to their newer religion filled with light, love, and truth, they call more missionaries to the valley and begin to aggressively spread their faith.

entries.name: The Newcomers
entries: The death of Phillip Druskenvald represents the crumbling of everything he stood for. All his vision, forward thinking, progress, and enlightenment could not save him from the hate of the old things. The newcomers in the valley see that there is little left for them, and what little hope they had was foolishness. Most of these folk will leave Wickermoor Hollow behind and seek civilizations that share their ideals, perhaps even seeking passage aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express} to discover new horizons beyond Druskenvald.

entries.name: Foxwillow
entries: While the once cheery and hardworking folk of Foxwillow had shared deep fellowship, the time spent trapped within the Fields of the Crow took a toll. The secrets unearthed and bared to all planted seeds of doubt, distrust, and shame amidst the efforts to rebuild.
