entries.caption: Potion Quirks
rows: Cracked Bottles. Spend twice the normal heightened brewing cost. You can pause work on the potion to acquire more materials.
Unusual Viscosity. This potion takes an action to use instead of a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
Strange Feeling Inside. The drinker must expend 1 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Point Die} as part of the {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to use this potion, or it has no effect.

Dormant Magic. This potion only provides a benefit for a drinker who can cast spells, and the drinker must expend a spell slot as part of the {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to use this potion or it has no effect.
Bitter Brew. The potion tastes so awful that the drinker must succeed a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or spit out and waste the potion.
Concentrated Draught. By strange innovation or pure luck, you've created a potion that can be used one additional time.

data.name: Appendix C: Chaotic Curses
entries: This section presents 156 Chaotic Curses, which can be optionally used to add a bit of unexpected chaos and humor to your game. Normally, curses are lasting or permanent negative conditions that require magic or significant effort to end. Chaotic Curses deviate from such curses in several ways:

entries.name: Fleeting
entries: These curses are designed to last a brief amount of real-world time (15-30 minutes or less) and should fade before they become tedious.

entries.name: Roleplay-Focused
entries: They add whimsy, surprise, or mayhem to the game without heavily impacting mechanics or combat.

entries.name: Unpredictable
entries: These effects alter the characters' beliefs, appearance, and actions in humorous or unexpected ways.

Chaotic Curses are entirely optional and should be used with discretion. Groups that prefer less active roleplay or serious folk horror atmosphere should avoid these curses. For those that favor sillier games, even while confronting the many horrors described in this book, these curses add levity and entertainment.

entries.name: Using Chaotic Curses
entries: To distribute Chaotic Curses, use one of the following methods:

entries.name: Tarot Deck
entries: Shuffle a tarot deck and draw a card. Each card is associated with a curse (see the table below), and the card's position—upright or reversed—determines which curse takes effect. The card can then be removed from the deck permanently or reshuffled into the deck each time.

entries.name: Rolling Dice
entries: Alternatively, you can roll a {@dice d100} and check the corresponding curse on the table below.

entries.name: Starting and Ending Curses
entries: Chaotic Curses are best left up to the GM's discretion, so they occur at unexpected times rather than during intense or pivotal moments. However, you can use mechanical triggers to determine when a curse begins and ends. Here are some ideas that might trigger Chaotic Curses:

items: Rolling a natural 1 on a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}
Whenever combat ends
Finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}
Touching a cursed object
Entering a specific location

entries: Ending curses can also be handled in a variety of ways:

items: Expending {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}
{@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} or similar magic
Healing magic above a certain threshold
Finishing a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}
GM pity

entries.name: Tarot Interpretations
entries: The tarot deck is simply used for randomization. There is no intended connection between the card's traditional meaning and its curse effect.

rows: The Fool (Upright). You become a clown and are foolish and silly.

The Magician (Reverse). Everyone around you appears to have had their eyes replaced by small round black buttons.

The High Priestess (Reverse). Every time you drink something, you feel as if you are drowning.
The Empress (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of wrath.
The Empress (Reverse). Everything you touch begins to rot.
The Emperor (Upright). You see false visions of a past where you did horrible things. They are so realistic and convincing that you begin to doubt your own reality.

Strength (Upright). You believe yourself to be the ferryman of the dead, and all souls must be judged by you.

Wheel of Fortune (Upright). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of greed.

Death (Reverse). You become the epitome of the deadly sin of gluttony.
Temperance (Upright). Your eyes disappear from your face and appear in the palms of your hands.
Temperance (Reverse). You can only move by crawling around on all fours, and the crawling is always creepy and unsettling.

Four of Swords (Upright). Your feet and hands swap places.

Page of Coins (Upright). You believe you are betrothed to a creature of the deep, and you must prepare to leave the surface world behind.

King of Coins (Upright). You are haunted by the ghost of a very depressing clown.

data.name: Appendix D: Music
entries: Alongside this book are three music albums by The Blasting Company that serve as companion pieces to the adventure of {@i The Crooked Moon}, all available on most streaming platforms. However, they can be used to set the tone for any Folk Horror adventure you wish to run. Below is suggested guidance for how to use all three albums to maximize the atmosphere of your dreadful folktales.

entries.name: The Crooked Moon Soundtrack
entries: The first album acts as a soundtrack for this book's adventure campaign. In most cases, these songs aren't literally occurring in the "canon" of the world (non-diegetic music) and can be utilized for conveying the tone of each character or encounter. Alternatively, if you wish to run a more musical campaign, you can find creative ways to incorporate each song into the context of the adventure (diegetic music). The list below overviews the characters and scenarios that have inspired each song.
{@b Crooked Moon}. A cultist of the Old Ways tells of the folklore and superstitions of Wickermoor Hollow.

entries.name: When It's Time
entries: The Vagrant welcomes wayward souls aboard the {@i Ghostlight Express} for their final journey.

entries.name: Impossible
entries: Phillip and Adela Druskenvald share a tender moment and celebrate what they've built.

entries.name: The Echoes
entries: The spirit of Joseph Patrini laments the grisly fate of the inhabitants of the Crooked House.

entries.name: Coal Eyed Birds
entries: Ol' Jericho Sticks is manipulated by his inner demon Virgil to join together as Raum.

entries.name: Under Your Shadow
entries: Father Renathyr leads worship of the devil goddess Viraxys, still wounded by lost love.

entries.name: By the Lagoon
entries: Mister Crossroads makes a deal with a sinner and takes them to the Dead Man's Hand.

entries.name: Lullaby of the Sea
entries: Matron Lethica sings a lullaby to Hugo, still consumed by the grief of her lost love.

entries.name: Dead Trees
entries: Gorthos dwells on who she once was, whom she once loved, and what she has become.

entries.name: Cold Iron
entries: Yorgrim tends to his penitent duties as the twisted souls of the Shroud corrupt him.

entries.name: No Fun to Die
entries: Chuckles wakes up to lead a parade of revelry and usher in rebirth in Wickermoor Hollow.

entries.name: Sing Ye Vermin
entries: The Vermintoll Coven meets to brew a magic concoction and commune with their vermin.

entries.name: Light of My Life
entries: Adela reflects on her life and love before meeting a fiery fate in the Wicker Man.

entries.name: Born King
entries: Kehlenn takes her revenge against Phillip and transforms him into the Horned King.

entries.name: Nightwind
entries: The Vagrant returns at the end of the journey to take the survivors to their next destination.

data.name: Appendix E: Dark Bargains
entries: Dark Bargains weave Druskenvald's essence into the characters who dare to strike them. These ancient agreements bind the land, its magical energies, its creatures.. and you. The effects bring boon and bane alike. It may be best for some sinister characters to offer their bargains plainly, letting the lurking curses reveal themselves only when the time is right. Beware your entry into these iniquitous accords.

entries.name: Shake on It
entries: Any bargain offered by an utterly unknowable, unfathomable power such as those that position themselves within the realm of Druskenvald must be carefully considered by you, your character, and the GM. These gifts are not to be offered lightly and should not be accepted lightly; their mere presence should herald significant roleplaying opportunities now and in the future.

entries.name: Entering a Dark Bargain
entries: In nearly all cases, the power that is proposing a Dark Bargain is uninterested in negotiating the duration or eventual cost of this gift. However, there may be extenuating circumstances. There could be roleplaying scenarios or simply the current events in the adventure's narrative that could cause the power to briefly—briefly!—consider negotiating. The GM has the final say on whether a given bargainer has the inclination to haggle. Generally, characters need the Dark Bargain far more than the powers need to grant it.

In any event, Dark Bargains reflect the entity imparting them, as well as the circumstances and any prices asked in exchange. You and the GM should tailor the cosmetic details of the bargain to the character's situation.
There are multiple ways a character might be tempted with power in Druskenvald.

entries.name: Character Creation
entries: With the GM's permission, you can choose a Dark Bargain when you make your character. Work with the GM to determine the circumstances of your character entering into the bargain, who offered it, and what terms your character had to fulfill—or is still expected to fulfill—to make good on the deal.

entries.name: During Play
entries: Dark Bargains can also come about during play in a campaign. There might be times where inscrutable powers have their own designs and see an opportunity for a character to further those ends in exchange for gifts. Others might be willing to negotiate a bargain as an alternative price to death or worse.

In these cases, the GM might alter terms of the bargains, such as increasing, lessening, or even waiving the prices of the bargains entirely—though perhaps only for a short time, or as long as some other condition is met.

entries.name: Unique Bargains
entries: Each Dark Bargain is unique, and a character can enter into a given bargain only once. A character could be bound to multiple Dark Bargains at one time, but each one only once.

entries.name: Removing Dark Bargains
entries: Dark Bargains are binding once sealed. There are tales and legends of those who have outwitted a bargainer or found a way to break a bargain's hold on them, but the truth of such stories is left to the GM to decide.

Every member of our team has poured their heart and soul into this project to meet the high standard we set for ourselves, and we hope you've found its contents both useful and inspiring as you craft your own folk horror stories for years to come. As we look toward new horizons, I hope you've enjoyed your time in Druskenvald. Once again, thank you for making our wild, kinetic dreams a reality.
